I grasp thee radiance in the radiance, thee resplendent in the resplendence for every sacrifice, for the gods, for every prayer.

column1: na kṣodhuko bhavati nāsya rudraḥ paśūn abhi manyate vajro vai yajñaḥ kṣut khalu vai manuṣyasya bhrātṛvyas |
column2: he is not hungry and Rudra does not plot evil against his cattle. The sacrificer is a bolt, the enemy of man is hunger;

column1: yad anāśvān upavasati vajreṇaiva sākṣāt kṣudham bhrātṛvyaṃ hanti |
column2: in that he fasts without eating, he straightway smites with the bolt the enemy, hunger.

column1: yo vai śraddhām anārabhya yajñena yajate nāsyeṣṭāya śrad dadhate |
column2: He who offers sacrifice without faith, they place not faith in his sacrifice.

column1: apaḥ pra ṇayati śraddhā vā āpaḥ śraddhām evārabhya yajñena yajata ubhaye 'sya devamanuṣyā iṣṭāya śrad dadhate tad āhur ati vā etā vartraṃ nedanty ati vācaṃ mano vāvaitā nāti nedantīti manasā pra ṇayatīyaṃ vai manaḥ |
column2: verily with faith he offers sacrifice, and both gods and men place faith in his sacrifice. They say, 'They foam over the barrier, they foam over speech, but over mind they do not foam.' He brings them forward with mind; mind is this (earth) [1]; verily with this (earth) he brings them forward.

column1: anayaivaināḥ pra ṇayaty askannahavir bhavati ya evaṃ veda yajñāyudhāni sam bharati yajño vai yajñāyudhāni yajñam eva tat sam {F bharati}{W bharati}{GOLS bharati} yad ekamekaṃ sambharet pitṛdevatyāni syur yat saha sarvāṇi mānuṣāṇi dvedve sam bharati yājyānuvākyayor eva rūpaṃ karoty atho mithunam eva yo vai daśa yajñāyudhāni veda mukhato 'sya yajñaḥ kalpate sphyaḥ |
column2: verily he collects the sacrifice. If he were to collect them one by one, they would have the Pitrs as their divinity; if all together, (they would have) men as their divinity. He collects them in pairs, and so he makes the form of the Yajya and the Anuvakya, and thus there is a pair. If a man knows the ten weapons of the sacrifice, his sacrifice is in order at the beginning.

column1: ca kapālāni cāgnihotrahavaṇī śūrpaṃ ca kṛṣṇājinaṃ ca śamyā colūkhalaṃ ca musalaṃ ca dṛṣac copalā caitāni vai daśa yajñāyudhāni ya evaṃ veda mukhato 'sya yajñaḥ kalpate yo vai devebhyaḥ pratiprocya yajñena yajate juṣante 'sya devā havyam havir nirupyamāṇam abhi mantrayetāgniṃ hotāram iha taṃ huva iti |
column2: The wooden sword [2], the potsherds, the offering-spoon, the basket, the black antelope skin, the pin, the mortar and pestle, the lower and upper millstones, these are the ten weapons of the sacrifice; the sacrifice of him who knows thus is in order at the beginning. If a man sacrifices after announcing the sacrifice to the gods, they delight in his sacrifice. He should as the oblation is being offered recite (the words), 'Agni, the priest, him I summon hither' [3].

column1: devebhya eva pratiprocya yajñena yajate juṣante 'sya devā havyam eṣa vai yajñasya graho gṛhītvaiva yajñena yajate tad uditvā vācaṃ yachati yajñasya dhṛtyai |
column2: Thus he announces the sacrifice to the gods and sacrifices, and the gods delight in his sacrifice. This is the taking of the sacrifice and so after taking the sacrifice he sacrifices. After speaking he remains silent, to support the sacrifice.

column1: atho manasā vai prajāpatir yajñam atanuta manasaiva tad yajñaṃ tanute rakṣasām ananvavacārāya yo vai yajñaṃ yoga āgate yunakti yuṅkte yuñjāneṣu kas tvā yunakti sa tvā yunaktv ity āha prajāpatir vai kaḥ prajāpatinaivainaṃ yunakti yuṅkte yuñjāneṣu |
column2: Now Prajapati performed the sacrifice with mind; verily he performs the sacrifice with mind to prevent the Raksases following. He who yokes the sacrifice when the yoking (time) arrives yokes it indeed among the yokers. 'Who (ka) yoketh thee? Let him yoke thee', he says. Ka is Prajapati--verily by Prajapati he yokes it;

column1: prajāpatir yajñān asṛjatāgnihotraṃ cāgniṣṭomaṃ ca paurṇamāsīṃ cokthyaṃ cāmāvāsyāṃ cātirātraṃ ca tān ud amimīta yāvad agnihotram āsīt tāvān agniṣṭomo yāvatī paurṇamāsī tāvān ukthyo yāvaty amāvāsyā tāvān atirātras |
column2: Prajapati created the sacrifices, the Agnihotra, the Agnistoma, the full moon sacrifice, the Ukthya, the new moon sacrifice and the Atiratra. These he meted out; the Agnistoma was the size of the Agnihotra, the Ukthya that of the full moon sacrifice, the Atiratra that of the new moon sacrifice.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān agnihotraṃ juhoti yāvad agniṣṭomenopāpnoti tāvad upāpnoti ya evaṃ vidvān paurṇamāsīṃ yajate yāvad ukthyenopāpnoti |
column2: He who knowing thus offers the Agnihotra obtains as much as by offering the Agnistoma; he who knowing thus offers the full moon sacrifice obtains as much as by offering the Ukthya [1];

column1: tāvad upāpnoti ya evaṃ vidvān amāvāsyāṃ yajate yāvad atirātreṇopāpnoti tāvad upāpnoti parameṣṭhino vā eṣa yajño 'gra āsīt tena sa paramāṃ kāṣṭhām agachat tena prajāpatiṃ niravāsāyayat tena prajāpatiḥ paramāṃ kāṣṭhām agachat tenendraṃ niravāsāyayat tenendraḥ paramāṃ kāṣṭhām agachat tenāgnīṣomau niravāsāyayat tenāgnīṣomau paramāṃ kāṣṭhām agachatām |
column2: he who knowing thus offers the new moon sacrifice obtains as much as by offering the Atiratra. This sacrifice was in the beginning Paramesthin's, and by means of it he reached the supreme goal. He furnished Prajapati with it, and by means of it Prajapati reached the supreme goal. He furnished Indra with it, and by means of it Indra reached the supreme goal.

column1: evaṃ vidvān darśapūrṇamāsau yajate paramām eva kāṣṭhāṃ gachati yo vai prajātena yajñena yajate pra prajayā paśubhir mithunair jāyate dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaro dvādaśa dvaṃdvāni darśapūrṇamāsayos tāni sampādyānīty āhus |
column2: He who [2] knowing thus offers the new and full moon sacrifices reaches the supreme goal. He who sacrifices with an abundant offering is multiplied with offspring, with cattle, with pairings. 'The year has twelve months, there are twelve pairs of new and full moon sacrifices;

column1: ava ca hanti dṛṣadau ca samāhanti |
column2: these are to be produced', they say.

column1: adhi ca vapate kapālāni copa dadhāti puroḍāśaṃ ca | adhiśrayaty ājyaṃ ca stambayajuś ca haraty abhi ca gṛhṇāti vediṃ ca pari gṛhṇāti patnīṃ ca saṃ nahyati prokṣaṇīś cāsādayaty ājyaṃ ca |
column2: He lets the calf go free and puts the pot on the fire: he puts down (the rice), and beats the millstones together; he scatters (the grains) and collects the potsherds; the cake [3] he puts on the fire and the melted butter; he throws the clump of grass, and gathers it in;

column1: etāni vai dvādaśa dvaṃdvāni darśapūrṇamāsayos tāni ya evaṃ sampādya yajate prajātenaiva yajñena yajate pra prajayā paśubhir mithunair jāyate |
column2: These are the twelve pairs in the new and full moon sacrifices. He, who thus sacrifices with these, sacrifices with an abundant offering and is multiplied with offspring, with cattle, with pairings.

column1: dhruvo 'si dhruvo 'haṃ sajāteṣu bhūyāsam ity āha dhruvān evainān kurute |
column2: 'Thou I art secure; may I be secure among my equals', he says; verily he makes them secure.' 'Thou art dread;

column1: ugro 'sy ugro 'haṃ sajāteṣu bhūyāsam ity āhāprativādina evainān kurute |
column2: may I be dread among my equals'; verily he makes them harmonious.

column1: abhibhūr asy abhibhūr ahaṃ sajāteṣu bhūyāsam ity āha ya evainam pratyutpipīte tam upāsyate yunajmi tvā brahmaṇā daivyenety āhaiṣa vā agner yogas tena |
column2: 'Thou art overcoming; may I be overcoming among my equals,' he says; verily he overthrows him who rises against him. 'I yoke thee with the divine Brahman', he says; this is the yoking of the fire;

column1: evainaṃ yunakti yajñasya vai samṛddhena devāḥ suvargaṃ lokam āyan yajñasya vyṛddhenāsurān parā bhāvayan yan me agne asya yajñasya riṣyād ity āha yajñasyaiva tat samṛddhena yajamānaḥ suvargaṃ lokam eti yajñasya vyṛddhena bhrātṛvyān parā bhāvayati |
column2: verily [1] with it he yokes it. With the prosperous part of the sacrifice the gods went to the world of heaven, with the unsuccessful part they overcame the Asuras. 'Whatever, O Agni, in this sacrifice of mine may be spoiled', he says; verily with the prosperous part of the sacrifice the sacrificer goes to the world of heaven, with the unsuccessful part he overcomes the foes.

column1: agnihotram etābhir vyāhṛtībhir upa sādayed yajñamukhaṃ vā agnihotram brahmaitā vyāhṛtayo yajñamukha eva brahma |
column2: The Agnihotra is the beginning of the sacrifice, these Vyahrtis are the Brahman; verily at the beginning of the sacrifice he makes the Brahman [2].

column1: kurute saṃvatsare paryāgata etābhir evopa sādayed brahmaṇaivobhayataḥ saṃvatsaram pari gṛhṇāti darśapūrṇamāsau cāturmāsyāny ālabhamāna etābhir vyāhṛtībhir havīṃṣy ā sādayed yajñamukhaṃ vai darśapūrṇamāsau cāturmāsyāni brahmaitā vyāhṛtayo yajñamukha eva brahma kurute saṃvatsare paryāgata etābhir evā sādayed brahmaṇaivobhayataḥ saṃvatsaram pari gṛhṇāti yad vai yajñasya sāmnā kriyate rāṣṭram |
column2: He who is undertaking the new and full moon and the four monthly offerings should set in place the oblations with these Vyahrtis. The new and full moon and the four monthly sacrifices are the beginning of the sacrifice, these Vyahrtis are the Brahman; verily at the beginning of the sacrifice he makes the Brahman. When the year is completed, he should thus with them (Vyahrtis) set down (the oblations), and so with the Brahman he surrounds the year on both sides. To the kingly class falls the blessing of the part of the sacrifice which is performed with the Saman [3];

column1: yajñasyāśīr gachati yad ṛcā viśaṃ yajñasyāśīr gachaty atha brāhmaṇo 'nāśīrkeṇa yajñena yajate sāmidhenīr anuvakṣyann etā vyāhṛtīḥ purastād dadhyād brahmaiva pratipadaṃ kurute tathā brāhmaṇaḥ sāśīrkeṇa yajñena yajate yaṃ kāmayeta yajamānam bhrātṛvyam asya yajñasyāśīr gached iti tasyaitā vyāhṛtīḥ puro'nuvākyāyāṃ dadhyād bhrātṛvyadevatyā vai puro'nuvākyā bhrātṛvyam evāsya yajñasya |
column2: to the people (falls) the blessing of what (is performed) with the Rc; now the Brahman sacrifices with an offering without a blessing; when he is about to recite the kindling- verses he should first insert the Vyahrtis; verily he makes the Brahman the commencement, and thus the Brahman sacrifices with an offering which has a blessing. If he desire of a sacrificer, 'May the blessing of his sacrifice fall to his foe', he should insert for him those Vyahrtis in the Puronuvakya (verse);

column1: āśīr gachati yān kāmayeta yajamānānt samāvaty enān yajñasyāśīr ghached iti teṣām etā vyāhṛtīḥ puro'nuvākyāyā ardharca ekāṃ dadhyād yājyāyai purastād ekāṃ yājyāyā ardharca ekāṃ tathainānt samāvatī yajñasyāśīr gachati yathā vai parjanyaḥ suvṛṣṭaṃ varṣaty evaṃ yajño yajamānasya varṣati sthalayodakam parigṛhṇanty āśiṣā yajñaṃ yajamānaḥ pari gṛhṇāti mano 'si prājāpatyam |
column2: verily the blessing of his sacrifice falls to his foe [4]. If he desire of sacrificers, 'May the blessing of the sacrifice fall to them equally', he should place for them one of the Vyahrtis at the half-verse of the Puronuvakya, one before the Yajya, and one at the half-verse of the Yajya, and thus the blessing of the sacrifice falls to them equally. Even as Parjanya rains down good rain, so the sacrifice rains for the sacrificer; they surround the water with a mound, the sacrificer surrounds the sacrifice with a blessing.

column1: manasā mā bhūtenā viśety āha mano vai prājāpatyam prajāpatyo yajño mana eva yajñam ātman dhatte vāg asy aindrī sapatnakṣayaṇī vācā mendriyeṇā viśety āhaindrī vai vāg vācam evāndrīm ātman dhatte |
column2: 'Thou art mind derived from Prajapati [5], with mind and true existence do thou enter me', he says; mind is derived from Prajapati, the sacrifice is derived from Prajapati; verily he confers upon himself mind and the sacrifice. 'Thou art speech, derived from Indra, destroying the foe;

column1: yo vai saptadaśam prajāpatiṃ yajñam anvāyattaṃ veda prati yajñena tiṣṭhati na yajñād bhraṃśate |
column2: He who knows the seventeenfold Prajapati as connected with the sacrifice rests secure through the sacrifice, and falls not away from the sacrifice.

column1: ā śrāvayeti caturakṣaram astu śrauṣaḍ iti caturakṣaraṃ yajeti dvyakṣaraṃ ye yajāmaha iti pañcākṣaraṃ dvyakṣaro vaṣaṭkāras |
column2: 'Do thou proclaim' has four syllables; 'Be it proclaimed' has four syllables; 'Utter' has two syllables; 'We that do utter' has five syllables; the Vasat has two syllables;

column1: eṣa vai saptadaśaḥ prajāpatir yajñam anvāyattas |
column2: this is the seventeenfold Prajapati as connected with the sacrifice;

column1: ya evaṃ veda prati yajñena tiṣṭhat na yajñād bhraṃśate yo vai yajñasya prāyaṇam pratiṣṭhām | udayanaṃ veda pratiṣṭhitenāriṣṭena yajñena saṃsthāṃ gachati |
column2: he who knows thus rests secure through the sacrifice and does not fall away from the sacrifice. He who knows the beginning, the support, the end of the sacrifice [1] reaches the end with a secure and uninjured sacrifice.

column1: ā śrāvayāstu śrauṣaḍ yaja ye yajāmahe vaṣaṭkāra etad vai yajñasya prāyaṇam eṣā pratiṣṭhaitad udayanam |
column2: 'Be it proclaimed'; 'Utter'; 'We that do utter'; the Vasat call, these are the beginning, the support, the end of the sacrifice;

column1: ya evaṃ veda pratiṣṭhitenāriṣṭena yajñena saṃsthāṃ gachati yo vai sūnṛtāyai dohaṃ veda duha evainām |
column2: he who knows thus reaches the end with a secure and uninjured sacrifice. He who knows the milking of the generous one milks her indeed.

column1: yajño vai sūnṛtā |
column2: The generous one is the sacrifice;

column1: śrauṣaḍ ity {upāvāsrāg < upāvāsrāj} yajety ud anaiṣīt | ye yajāmaha ity upāsadat |
column2: (with the words) 'Do thou proclaim', he calls her; with 'Be it proclaimed' [2], he lets (the calf) go up to her;

column1: vaṣaṭkāreṇa dadghi |
column2: with 'Utter', he raises (the pail);

column1: eṣa vai sūnṛtāyai dohas |
column2: This is the milking of the generous one;

column1: ya evaṃ veda duha evainām |
column2: he who knows thus milks her indeed.

column1: devā vai sattram āsata teṣāṃ diśo 'dasyan ta etām ārdrām paṅktim apaśyann ā śrāvayeti purovātam ajanayann astu śrauṣād ity abhraṃ sam aplāvayan yajeti vidyutam |
column2: The gods performed a sacrificial session; the quarters were dried up; they discerned this moist set of five; (with the words) 'Do thou proclaim', they produced the east wind; with 'Be it proclaimed', they caused the clouds to mass together;

column1: ajanayan ye yajāmaha iti prāvarṣayan abhy astanayan vaṣaṭkāreṇa tato vai tebhyo diśaḥ prāpyāyanta ya evaṃ veda prāsmai diśaḥ pyāyante prajāpatiṃ tvo veda prajāpatis tvaṃ veda yam prajāpatir veda sa puṇyo bhavati |
column2: with 'Utter' they begat [3] the lightning; with 'We that do sacrifice' they made rain to fall, and with the Vasat call they caused the thunder to roll. Then for them the quarters were made to swell; for him who knows thus the quarters are made to swell. One knows Prajapati, Prajapati knows one;

column1: eṣa vai chandasyaḥ prajāpatir ā śrāvayāstu śrauṣaḍ yaja ye yajāmahe vaṣaṭkāras |
column2: This is the Prajapati of the texts, 'Do thou proclaim', 'Be it proclaimed', 'Utter', 'We that do utter', the Vasat call;

column1: ya evaṃ veda puṇyo bhavati vasantam |
column2: he who knows thus becomes pure.

column1: ṛtūnām prīṇāmīty āha |
column2: 'Of the seasons spring [4] I delight', he says;

column1: ṛtūn eva prīṇāti te 'smai prītā yathāpūrvaṃ kalpante kalpante 'smā ṛtavo ya evaṃ veda |
column2: verily he delights the seasons; they delighted place themselves in order for him; the seasons are in order for him who knows thus.

column1: agnīṣomayor ahaṃ devayajyayā cakṣuṣmān bhūyāsam ity āha |
column2: 'By sacrifice to the gods, Agni and Soma, may I be possessed of sight', he says;

column2: the sacrifice is possessed of sight through Agni and Soma; verily by means of them he confers sight upon himself.

column1: agner ahaṃ devayajyayānnādo bhūyāsam ity āha |

column1: agnir vai devānām annādas tenaiva |
column2: Agni is among the gods the eater of food;

column1: annādyam ātman dhatte dabdhir asy adabdho bhūyāsam amuṃ dabheyam ity āha |
column2: verily by means of him [5] he confers the eating of food upon himself. 'Thou art a deceiver; may I be undeceived; may I deceive N.

column1: etayā vai dabhyā devā asurān adabhnuvan tayaiva bhrātṛvyaṃ dabhnoti |
column2: N.', he says; by that deceit the gods deceived the Asuras; verily by this he deceives his foe.

column1: agnīṣomayor ahaṃ devayajyayā vṛtrahā bhūyāsam ity āha |
column2: 'By sacrifice to the gods, Agni and Soma, may I be a slayer of foes', he says;

column2: by means of Agni and Soma Indra slew Vrtra; verily by means of them he lays low his foe.

column1: indrāgniyor ahaṃ devayajyayendriyāvy annādo bhūyāsam ity āha |
column2: 'By sacrifice to the gods, Indra and Agni, may I be powerful and an eater of food', he says;

column1: indriyāvy evānnādo bhavati |
column2: verily he becomes powerful and an eater of food.

column1: indrasya | ahaṃ devayajyayendriyāvī bhūyāsam ity āha |
column2: 'By sacrifice to the god Indra, may I be powerful', he says;

column1: indriyāvy eva bhavati mahendrasyāhaṃ devayajyayā jemānam mahimānaṃ gameyam ity āha jemānam eva mahimānaṃ gachati |
column2: verily he becomes powerful. 'By sacrifice to the god Mahendra, may I attain superiority and greatness', he says; verily he attains superiority and greatness.

column1: agneḥ sviṣṭakṛto 'haṃ devayajyayāyuṣmān yajñena pratiṣṭhāṃ gameyam ity āha |

column1: āyur evātman dhatte prati yajñena tiṣṭhati |
column2: verily he confers long life upon himself and attains security through the sacrifice.

column1: indraṃ vo viśvatas pari havāmahe janebhyaḥ |
column2: Indra for you we invoke On all sides from other men;

column1: asmākam astu kevalaḥ |
column2: Be he ours only.

column1: indraṃ naro nemadhitā havante yat pāryā yunajate dhiyas tāḥ |
column2: Indra men call in reverence That he may cause their prayers to be accomplished;

column1: śūro nṛṣātā śavasaś cakāna ā gomati vraje bhajā tvaṃ naḥ |
column2: Hero, men overpowering, delighting in strength, Do thou confer upon us a stall full of kine.

column1: indriyāṇi śatakrato yā te janeṣu pañcasu |
column2: O Çatakratu, the strength of thine That is in the five folks, That do I choose of thee.

column1: indra tāni ta ā vṛṇe | anu te dāyi maha indriyāya satrā te viśvam anu vṛtrahatye | anu | kṣatram anu saho yajatrendra devebhir anu te nṛṣahye |
column2: To thee hath been assigned for mighty power, For ever, in the slaying of Vrtra, All lordship, and all strength, O thou that art worthy of sacrifice In the overcoming of man, by the gods, O Indra [1].

column1: ā yasmint sapta vāsavās tiṣṭhanti svāruho yathā | ṛṣir ha dīrghaśruttama indrasya gharmo atithiḥ |
column2: In whom the seven Vasavas rest As it were firm rooted, The Rsi of farthest hearing, The glowing pot is the guest of Indra.

column1: āmāsu pakvam airaya ā sūryaṃ rohayo divi |
column2: In the raw thou didst produce the cooked, And madest the sun to mount in the sky;

column1: gharmaṃ na sāman tapatā suvṛktibhir juṣṭaṃ girvaṇase giraḥ |
column2: Like the glowing pot heat ye the Saman With good prayers, delightful to the lover of song.

column1: indram id gāthino bṛhad indram arkebhir arkiṇaḥ | indraṃ vāṇīr anūṣata |
column2: Indra the singers aloud, Indra with praises the praisers, Indra the songs have praised.

column1: gāyanti tvā gāyatriṇaḥ | arcanty arkam arkiṇaḥ |
column2: The singers sing thee [2]; The praisers hymn thy praise;

column1: brahmāṇas tvā śatakratav ud vaṃśam iva yemire |
column2: The Brahmans raise thee, 0 Çatakratu, like a pole.

column1: aṃhomuce pra bharemā manīṣām oṣiṣṭhadāvne sumatiṃ gṛṇānāḥ |
column2: Let us offer our praise to him who delivereth from trouble, Swiftest to give, celebrating his loving kindness;

column1: idam indra prati havyaṃ gṛbhāya satyāḥ santu yajamānasya kāmāḥ |
column2: Indra, accept this oblation; May the desires of the sacrificer be fulfilled.

column1: viveṣa yan mā dhiṣaṇā jajāna stavai purā pāryād indram ahnaḥ |
column2: That to which Dhisana impelled me have I produced; shall praise Indra before the decisive day;

column1: aṃhaso yatra pīparad yathā no nāveva yāntam ubhaye havante |
column2: Him that goeth as with a ship Both parties invoke that there he may rescue us.

column1: pra samrājam prathamam adhvarāṇām | aṃhomucaṃ vṛṣabhaṃ yajñiyānām |

column2: thee that sittest on the earth, that sittest on the atmosphere, that sittest on the vault, I take acceptable to Indra; this is thy birthplace; to Indra thee! column1: teṣāṃ viśipriyāṇām iṣam ūrjaṃ sam agrabhīm eṣa te yonir indrāya tvā | apāṃ rasam udvayasaṃ sūryaraśmiṃ samābhṛtam |
column2: This is thy birthplace; to Indra thee! The sap of the waters, the vigorous, The ray of the sun that has been gathered, The sap of the sap of the waters, That of you I take which is the best;

column1: apāṃ rasasya yo rasas taṃ vo gṛhṇāmy uttamam eṣa te yonir indrāya tvā |
column2: This is thy birthplace; to Indra thee!

column1: ayā viṣṭhā janayan karvarāṇi sa hi ghṛṇir urur varāya gātuḥ | sa praty ud aid dharuṇo madhvo agraṃ svāyāṃ yat tanuvāṃ tanūm airayata |
column2: By this shape producing mighty deeds, He is dread, a broad way for gain, He hath come to the top, bearing sweetness, What time he moved a body in his own body.

column1: upayāmagṛhīto 'si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭaṃ gṛhṇāmy eṣa te yoniḥ prajāpataye tvā |
column2: Thou art taken with a support; agreeable to Prajapati I take thee this is thy birthplace; to Prajapati thee!

column1: anv aha māsā anv id vanāny anv oṣadhīr anu parvatāsaḥ | anv indraṃ rodasī vāvaśāne anv āpo ājihata jāyamānam |
column2: The months, the woods, The plants, the mountains, The earth and sky in longing, The waters, followed Indra on his birth.

column1: anu te dāyi maha indriyāya satrā te viśvam anu vṛtrahatye | anu kṣatram anu saho yajatrendra devebhir anu te nṛṣahye | indrāṇīm āsu nāriṣu supatnīm aham aśravam | na hy asyā aparaṃ cana jarasā | marate patiḥ |
column2: To thee hath been assigned for mighty power, For ever, in the slaying of Vrtra, All lordship, and all strength, O thou that art worthy of sacrifice In the overcoming of man by the gods, O Indra, Indrani beyond other women have heard to be favoured with a spouse, For never at any time [1] Shall her husband die of old age.

column1: nāham indrāṇi rāraṇa sakhyur vṛṣākaper ṛte | yasyedam apyaṃ haviḥ priyaṃ deveṣu gachati |
column2: I have not joyed, O Indrani, Without my friend Vrsakapi, Whose oblation rich in water Goeth dear to the gods.

column1: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat | yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetām nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ |
column2: He who first born in his wisdom god, surpassed the gods in insight, From whose breath the sky and earth recoiled, In the greatness of his manhood, he, O ye men, is Indra.

column1: ā te maha indroty ugra samanyavo yat samaranta senāḥ |
column2: Hitherward be thy might with aid, O dread Indra, What time the armies meet in combat, And the arrow flieth from the arms of the strong men;

column1: patāti divyun naryasya bāhuvor mā te |
column2: Let not thine [2] anger spread on every side.

column1: mā no mardhīr ā bharā daddhi tan naḥ pra dāśuṣe dātave bhūri yat te |
column2: Destroy us not; bring and give to us That plenteous bounty which thou hast to give to the pious man, For this new gift, this song we have sung to thee;

column1: navye deṣṇe śaste asmin ta ukthe pra bravāma vayam indra stuvantaḥ |
column2: Let us speak forth in praise of Indra. Bring it to us, let none intercept it;

column1: ā tū bhara mākir etat pari ṣṭhād vidmā hi tvā vasupatiṃ vasūnām |
column2: For we know thee as wealth lord of riches;

column1: indra yat te māhinaṃ dattram asty asmabhyaṃ tad dharyaśva |
column2: That mighty gift of thine, O Indra, Vouchsafe it us, O lord of the bay steeds [3].

column1: pradātāraṃ havāmaha indram ā haviṣā vayam |
column2: With our oblation we summon 1ndra, the giver;

column1: ubhā hi hastā vasunā pṛṇasvā pra yacha dakṣiṇād ota savyāt |
column2: Fill both thy hands with bounty; Give to us from the left and the right.

column1: pradātā vajrī vṛṣabhas turāṣāṭ chuṣmī rājā vṛtrahā somapāvā | asmin yajñe barhiṣy ā niṣadyāthā bhava yajamānāya śaṃ yoḥ |
column2: The giver, the bolt-bearer, the bull, the overpowering, The impetuous, the king, slayer of Vrtra, drinker of the Soma, Seated at this sacrifice on the strew, Be thou health and wealth to the sacrificer.

column1: indraḥ sutrāmā svavāṃ avobhiḥ sumṛḍīko bhavatu viśvavedāḥ |
column2: Indra, the protector, the granter of aid with his aids; All knowing, be kindly to us;

column1: bādhatāṃ dveṣo abhayaṃ kṛṇotu suvīryasya | patayaḥ syāma |
column2: Let him restrain the enemy, let him make security, May we be lords of strength [4].

column1: tasya vayaṃ sumatau yajñiyasyāpi bhadre saumanase syāma |
column2: May we enjoy the favour of him the worshipful, And also his loving kindness;

column1: sa sutrāmā svavāṃ indro asme ārāc cid dveṣaḥ sanutar yuyotu | revatīr naḥ sadhamāda indre santu tuvivājāḥ |
column2: May the protector Indra, the granter of aid, For ever fend far from us the enemy. Rich banquets be ours with Indra, With mighty strength, Wherewith fed we may be glad.

column1: pro ṣv asmai puroratham indrāya śūṣam arcata |
column2: To Indra, here sing strength To place his chariot in the front;

column1: abhīke cid u lokakṛt saṃge samatsu vṛtrahā | asmākam bodhi coditā nabhantām anyakeṣām |
column2: Even in conflict in battle he maketh wide room; Slayer of foes in the contests Be thou our comforter; Let the feeble bowstrings Of the others break on their bows.

column1: jyākā adhi dhanvasu |
column2: the sacrificial fee is a cow.

column1: anumatyai puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapati dhenur dakṣiṇā ye pratyañcaḥ śamyāyā avaśīyante taṃ nairṛtam ekakapālaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ vāsaḥ kṛṣṇatūṣaṃ dakṣiṇā vīhi svāhāhutiṃ juṣāṇas |
column2: The (grains) which are thrown down to the west of the support he (offers) on one potsherd to Nirrti; the sacrificial fee is a black garment with a black fringe. Go away, hail! rejoicing in the oblation.

column1: eṣa te nirṛte bhāgo bhūte haviṣmaty asi muñcemam aṃhasaḥ svāhā namo ya idaṃ cakāra |
column2: This is thy share, O Nirrti; thou who hast prospered, thou art rich in oblation; Free him from evil. Hail! Honour to him who hath done this.

column1: ādityaṃ caruṃ nir vapati varo dakṣiṇā |
column2: He offers an oblation to Aditya; the sacrificial fee is a choice (ox).

column1: āgnāvaiṣṇavam ekādaśakapālaṃ vāmano vahī dakṣiṇā | agnīṣomīyam | ekādaśakapālaṃ hiraṇyaṃ dakṣiṇā |
column2: (He offers) to Agni and Visnu on eleven potsherds; the sacrificial fee is a dwarf beast of burden. (He offers) to Agni and Soma [1] on eleven potsherds;

column1: aindram ekādaśakapālam ṛṣabho vahī dakṣiṇā | āgneyam aṣṭākapālam aindraṃ dadhy ṛṣabho vahī dakṣiṇā |
column2: (He offers) to Indra on eleven potsherds; the sacrificial fee is a bull as a beast of burden. (He offers) to Agni on eight potsherds, and curds to Indra;

column1: aindrāgnaṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ vaiśvadevaṃ carum prathamajo vatso dakṣiṇā saumyaṃ śyāmākaṃ caruṃ vāso dakṣiṇā sarasvate carum mithunau gāvau dakṣiṇā |
column2: the sacrificial fee is a bull as a beast of burden. (He offers) to Indra and Agni on twelve potsherds, and an oblation (caru) to the All-gods; the sacrificial fee is a first-born calf. (He offers) an oblation of millet to Soma;

column1: āgneyam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapati saumyaṃ caruṃ sāvitraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ sārasvataṃ carum pauṣṇaṃ carum mārutaṃ saptakapālaṃ vaiśvadevīm āmikṣāṃ dyāvāpṛthivyam ekakapālam |
column2: He offers to Agni on eight potsherds, an oblation to Soma, to Savitr on twelve potsherds, an oblation to Sarasvati, an oblation to Pusan, to the Maruts on seven potsherds, clotted curds to the All-gods, and on eleven potsherds to sky and earth.

column1: aindrāgnam ekādaśakapālam mārutīm āmikṣāṃ vāruṇīm āmikṣāṃ kāyam ekakapālam praghāsyān havāmahe maruto yajñavāhasaḥ karambheṇa sajoṣasaḥ |
column2: He offers on eleven potsherds to Indra and Agni, clotted curds to the Maruts, clotted curds to Varuna, and on one potsherd to Ka. The voracious we invoke, The Maruts who bear the sacrifice, Rejoicing in the mush.

column1: mo ṣū ṇa indra pṛtsu devāstu sma te śuṣminn avayā |
column2: Be not against us in battles, O god Indra Let there be expiation to satisfy thee, O impetuous one;

column1: mahī hy asya mīḍhuṣo yavyā |
column2: For great is the barley heap of this bountiful one;

column1: haviṣmato maruto vandate gīḥ | yad grāme yad araṇye yat sabhāyāṃ yad indriye | yac chūdre yad arya enaś cakṛmā vayam | yad ekasyādhi dharmaṇi tasyāvayajanam asi svāhā |
column2: Rich in oblation are the Maruts whom our song praises.' The wrong we have done in village or wild, In the assembly, in our members, The wrong to Çudra or Aryan, The wrong contrary to the law of either, Of that thou art the expiation; hail!

column1: akran karma karmakṛtaḥ saha vācā mayobhuvā |
column2: The doers of the deed have performed the deed, With wondrous speech;

column1: devebhyaḥ karma kṛtvāstam preta sudānavaḥ |
column2: Having done the deed to the gods go ye To your home, ye bounteous ones.

column1: agnaye 'nīkavate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālam nir vapati sākaṃ sūryeṇodyatā marudbhyaḥ sāṃtapanebhyo madhyandine carum marudbhyo gṛhamedhibhyaḥ sarvāsāṃ dugdhe sāyaṃ carum pūrṇā darvi parā pata supūrṇā punar ā pata |
column2: To Agni Anikavant he offers a cake on eight potsherds as the sun rises, an oblation to the Maruts as the heaters at midday, and to the Maruts as lords of the house he milks at evening an oblation of all (the cows). O ladle, fly away filled, And well filled do thou fly back;

column1: vasneva vi krīṇāvahā iṣam ūrjaṃ śatakrato |
column2: Like wares, O Çatakratu, Let us barter food and strength.

column1: dehi me dadāmi te ni me dhehi ni te dadhe |
column2: Give thou to me; I shall give to thee;

column1: nihāram in ni me harā nihāram | ni harāmi te |
column2: I shall bestow upon thee; Accept my offering; shall accept thy offering [1].

column1: marudbhyaḥ krīḍibhyaḥ puroḍāśaṃ saptakapālaṃ nir vapati sākaṃ sūryeṇodyatāgneyam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapati saumyaṃ caruṃ sāvitraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ sārasvataṃ carum pauṣṇaṃ carum aindrāgnam ekādaśakapālam aindraṃ caruṃ vaiśvakarmaṇam ekakapālam |
column2: To the Maruts, the playful, he offers a cake on seven potsherds at the rising of the sun; he ofibrs to Agni on eight potsherds, an oblation to Soma, to Savitr on twelve potsherds, to Sarasvati an oblation, to Pusan an oblation, to Indra and Agni on eleven potsherds, to Indra an oblation, to Viçvakarman on eleven potsherds.

column1: somāya pitṛmate puroḍāśaṃ ṣaṭkapālaṃ nirvapati pitṛbhyo barhiṣadbhyo dhānāḥ pitṛbhyo 'gniṣvāttebhyo 'bhivānyāyai dugdhe mantham etat te tata ye ca tvām anv etat te pitāmaha prapitāmaha ye ca tvām anv atra pitaro yathābhāgam mandadhvam |
column2: He offers to Soma with the Pitrs a cake on six potsherds, to the Pitrs who sit on the straw fried grains, for the Pitrs prepared by Agni he milks a beverage from a cow which has to be won over (to another calf). This for thee, O father, and for thy line; This for thee, O grandfather, great-grandfather, and for thy line Do ye Pitrs rejoice in your portions.

column1: susaṃdṛśaṃ tvā vayam maghavan mandiṣīmahi | pra nūnam pūrṇavandhura stuto yāsi vaśāṃ anu |
column2: May we gladden thee, bountiful one, fair to see; Forth now with full chariot seat Being praised, dost thou fare according to our will;

column1: yojā nv indra te harī |
column2: Yoke, O Indra, thy two bay steeds [1].

column1: akṣann amīmadanta hy ava priyā adhūṣata | astoṣata svabhānavo viprā naviṣṭayā matī yojā nv indra te harī |
column2: They have eaten, they have rejoiced, The dear ones have dispelled (evil), The radiant sages have been praised with newest hymn; Yoke, O Indra, thy two bay steeds.

column1: akṣan pitaro 'mīmadanta pitaro 'tītṛpanta pitaro 'mīmṛjanta pitaraḥ pareta pitaraḥ somyā gambhīraiḥ pathibhiḥ pūrvyaiḥ |
column2: The Pitrs have eaten, the Pitrs have rejoiced, the Pitrs have been glad, the Pitrs have purified themselves. Go away, O ye Pitrs, Soma loving, With your majestic ancient paths;

column1: athā pit ṝnt suvidatrāṃ apīta yamena ye sadhamādam madanti |
column2: Then reach ye the kindly Pitrs Who carouse in company with Yama.

column1: mano nv ā huvāmahe nārāśaṃsena stomena pitṝṇāṃ ca manmabhiḥ |
column2: Mind let us summon hither With the praise of Naraçansa And the reverence of the Pitrs.

column1: na etu manaḥ punaḥ kratve dakṣāya jīvase | jyok ca sūryaṃ dṛśe | punar naḥ pitaro mano dadātu daivyo janaḥ |
column2: Let mind return to us [2] For vigour, for insight, for life, And that long we may see the sun.' May the Pitrs restore mind to us, May the host of the gods;

column1: jīvaṃ vrātaṃ sacemahi |
column2: May we belong to the band of the living.

column1: yad antarikṣam pṛthivīm uta dyāṃ yan mātaram pitaraṃ vā jihiṃsima | agnir mā tasmād enaso gārhapatyaḥ pra muñcatu duritā yāni cakṛma karotu mām anenasam |
column2: Whatever hurt we have done to atmosphere, to earth, to sky, To mother or to father, May Agni of the house free me from this sin; May he make me blameless In respect of all the ill we have wrought.

column1: pratipūruṣam ekakapālān nir vapaty ekam atiriktam |
column2: For each he offers on one potsherd, and one over.

column1: yāvanto gṛhyāḥ smas tebhyaḥ kam akaram paśūnāṃ śarmāsi śarma yajamānasya śarma me yacha |
column2: As many as we are of the house, to them have I made prosperity. Thou art the protection of cattle, the protection of the sacrifice; give me protection.

column1: eka eva rudro na dvitīyāya tasthe |
column2: Rudra alone yieldeth to no second.

column1: ākhus te rudra paśus taṃ juṣasva |
column2: The mole is thy beast, O Rudra; rejoice in it.

column1: eṣa te rudra bhāgaḥ saha svasrāmbikayā taṃ juṣasva bheṣajaṃ gave 'śvāya puruṣāya bheṣajam atho asmabhyam bheṣajaṃ subheṣajam |
column2: This is thy portion, O Rudra, with thy sister Ambika; rejoice in it. (Give) medicine for ox, for horse, for man, And medicine for us, medicine That it be rich in healing, Good [1] for ram and sheep.

column1: yathāsati sugam meṣāya meṣyai avāmba rudram adimahy ava devaṃ tryambakam |
column2: We have appeased, O lady, Rudra, The god Tryambaka;

column1: yathā naḥ śreyasaḥ karad yathā no vasyasaḥ karad yathā naḥ paśumataḥ karad yathā no vyavasāyayāt |
column2: That he may make us prosperous, That he may increase our wealth, That he may make us rich in cattle, That he may embolden us.

column1: tryambakaṃ yajāmahe sugandhim puṣṭivardhanam |
column2: To Tryambaka we make offering, The fragrant, increaser of prosperity;

column1: urvārukam iva bandhanān mṛtyor mukṣīya māmṛtāt |
column2: Like a cucumber from its stem, From death may I be loosened, not from immortality.

column1: eṣa te rudra bhāgas taṃ juṣasva tenāvasena paro mūjavato 'tīhi |
column2: This is thy portion, O Rudra; rejoice in it; with it for food, do thou go away beyond the Mujavants.

column1: avatatadhanvā pinākahastaḥ kṛttivāsāḥ |
column2: With unstrung bow, thy club in thy hand, clad in skins.

column1: aindrāgnaṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ vaiśvadevaṃ carum indrāya śunāsīrāya puroḍāśaṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ vāyavyam payaḥ suryam ekakapālaṃ dvādaśagavaṃ sīraṃ dakṣiṇā |
column2: (He I offers) to Indra and Agni on twelve potsherds, an oblation to the All-gods, a cake on twelve potsherds to Indra Çunasira, milk to Vayu, to Sarya on one potsherd; the sacrificial fee is a plough for twelve oxen.

column1: āgneyam aṣṭākapālaṃ nirvapati raudraṃ gāvīdhukaṃ carum aindraṃ dadhi vāruṇaṃ yavamayaṃ caruṃ vahinī dhenur dakṣiṇā ye devāḥ puraḥsado 'gninetrā dakṣiṇasado yamanetrāḥ paścātsadaḥ savitṛnetrā uttarasado varuṇanetrā upariṣado bṛhaspatinetrā rakṣohaṇas te naḥ pāntu te no 'vantu tebhyaḥ |
column2: To Agni he offers on eight potsherds, to Rudra an oblation of Gavidhuka, to Indra curds, to Varuna an oblation made of barley; the sacrificial fee is a cow for draught purposes. The gods that sit in the east, led by Agni; that sit in the south, led by Yama; that sit in the west, led by Savitr;

column1: namas tebhyaḥ svāhā samūḍhaṃ rakṣaḥ saṃdagdhaṃ rakṣa idam ahaṃ rakṣo 'bhi saṃ dahāmi |
column2: to them homage; to them hail! [1] The Raksases are collected, the Raksases are burnt up; here do I burn up the Raksases.

column1: agnaye rakṣoghne svāhā yamāya savitre varuṇāya bṛhaspataye duvasvate rakṣo ghne svāhā praṣṭivāhī ratho dakṣiṇā devasya tvā savituḥ prasave 'śvinor bāhubhyām pūṣṇo hastābhyāṃ rakṣaso vadhaṃ juhomi hataṃ rakṣo 'vadhiṣma rakṣas |
column2: To Agni, slayer of Raksases, hail! To Yama, Savitr, Varuna, Brhaspati, the worshipful, the slayer of Raksases, hail! The sacrificial fee is a chariot with three horses. On the instigation of the god Savity, with the arms of the Açvins, with the hands of Pusan, I offer (for) the death of the Raksases; the Raksases are slain;

column1: yad vaste tad dakṣiṇā |
column2: The sacrificial fee is what he wears.

column1: dhātre puroḍāśaṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vapati | anumatyai carum | rākāyai carum |
column2: He offers a cake on twelve potsherds to Dhatr, to Anumati an oblation, to Raka an oblation, to Sinivali an oblation, to Kuhu an oblation;

column1: sinīvālyai carum |
column2: the sacrificial fee is a pair of cattle.

column1: āgnāvaiṣṇavam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapati | aindrāvaiṣṇavam ekādaśakapālam | vaiṣṇavaṃ tṛkapālam |
column2: To Agni and Visnu he offers on eleven potsherds, to Indra and Visnu on eleven potsherds, to Visnu on three potsherds;

column1: vāmano vahī dakṣiṇā |
column2: the sacrificial fee is a dwarf beast of burden.

column1: agnīṣomīyam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapati | indrāsomīyam ekādaśakapālam |
column2: To Agni and Soma he offers on eleven potsherds, to Indra and Soma on eleven potsherds, to Soma an oblation;

column1: saumyaṃ carum babhrur dakṣiṇā somāpauṣṇaṃ caruṃ nir vapati | aindrāpauṣṇaṃ carum pauṣṇaṃ carum |
column2: To Soma and Pusan he offers an oblation, to Indra and Pusan an oblation, to Pusan an oblation; the sacrificial fee is a dark (animal).

column1: śyāmo dakṣiṇā vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vapati hiraṇyaṃ dakṣiṇā vāruṇaṃ yavamayaṃ carum aśvo dakṣiṇā |
column2: To (Agni) Vaiçvanara he offers on twelve potsherds; the sacrificial fee is gold. To Varuna (he offers) an oblation made of barley; the sacrificial fee is a horse.

column1: bārhaspatyaṃ caruṃ nir vapati brahmaṇo gṛhe śitipṛṣṭho dakṣiṇā |
column2: To Brhaspati he offers an oblation in the house of the Brahman (priest); the sacrificial fee is a white-backed (animal).

column1: aindram ekādaśakapālaṃ rājanyasya gṛha ṛṣabho dakṣiṇā |
column2: (He offers) to Indra on eleven potsherds in the house of a Rajanya;

column1: ādityaṃ carum mahiṣyai gṛhe dhenur dakṣiṇā nairṛtaṃ carum parivṛktyai gṛhe kṛṣṇānāṃ vrīhīṇāṃ nakhanirbhinnaṃ kṛṣṇā kūṭā dakṣiṇā |
column2: the sacrificial fee is a bull. To Aditya (he offers) an oblation in the house of the chief wife; the sacrificial fee is a cow. To Nirrti (he offers) an oblation in the house of the neglected wife, made up of rice broken by the nails; the sacrificial fee is a black hornless (cow).

column1: āgneyam aṣṭākapālaṃ senānyo gṛhe hiraṇyaṃ dakṣiṇā vāruṇaṃ daśakapālaṃ sūtasya gṛhe mahāniraṣṭo dakṣiṇā mārutaṃ saptakapālaṃ grāmaṇyo gṛhe pṛśnir dakṣiṇā sāvitraṃ dvādaśakapālam |
column2: To Varuna (he offers) on ten potsherds in the house of the minstrel; the sacrificial fee is a great castrated (ox). To the Maruts (he offers) on seven potsherds in the house of the village headman; the sacrificial fee is a dappled (cow). To Savitr (he offers) on twelve potsherds [1] in the house of the carver;

Ye are active, thou art the lord of the waters, thou art the male wave, thou art the male host, ye are the pen-dwellers, ye are the strength of the Maruts, ye have the radiance of the sun, ye have the brightness of the sun, ye are delightful, ye are obedient, ye are powerful, ye are all supporters, ye are supporters of men, ye have the brilliance of Agni, ye are the sap of the waters, of the plants.

column2: Verily he has recourse to Indra of the thunderbolt with his own share; he bestows his thunderbolt on him, the bolt kindles him for prosperity, the kingdom comes to him.

column1: asāv ādityo na vy arocata tasmai devāḥ prāyaścittim aichan tasmā etāṃ daśarṣabhām ālabhanta tayaivāsmin rucam adadhus |
column2: Yonder sun did not shine; the gods desired an atonement for him; for him they offered this offering of ten bulls; verily thereby they restored his brilliance.

column2: For him who desires splendour he should offer this offering of ten bulls;

column2: verily he bestows on him splendour; he becomes resplendent. He should offer in the spring in the morning three with spots on the forehead; in the summer at midday [1] three with white backs; in the autumn in the afternoon three with white tails.

column1: ā labheta prajāpatiḥ sarvā devatās |

column1: vaibhīdaka idhmo bhinatty evainam |

column1: bārhaspatyaṃ śitipṛṣṭham ā labheta grāmakāmo {F yaḥ}{W yaḥ}{GLOS } kāmayeta pṛṣṭhaṃ samānānāṃ syām iti bṛhaspatim eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam pṛṣṭhaṃ samānānāṃ karoti grāmy eva bhavati śitipṛṣṭho bhavati bārhaspatyo hy eṣa devatayā samṛddhayai pauṣṇaṃ śyāmam ā labhetānnakāmas |

column1: annaṃ vai pūṣā pūṣaṇam eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmai |

column1: vaṣaṭkāro vai gāyatriyai śiro 'chinat tasyai rasaḥ parāpatat tam bṛhaspatir upāgṛhṇāt sā śitipṛṣṭhā vaśābhavat |
