column1: indrāgnī eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tābhyām evendriyaṃ vīryam bhrātṛvyasya vṛṅkte vi pāpmanā bhrātṛvyeṇa jayate |
column2: Verily Indra and Agni he has recourse to with their own share, by means of them he over powers the power and strength of his rival, he overcomes the evil foe.

column1: apa vā etasmād indriyaṃ vīryaṃ krāmati yaḥ saṃgrāmam upaprayāti |
column2: Now power and strength depart from him who advances to battle;

column1: aindrāgnam ekādaśakapālaṃ niḥ | vapet saṃgrāmam upaprayāsyan |
column2: let him who is about to advance to battle offer to Indra and Agni an offering on eleven potsherds [2].

column1: indrāgnī eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tāv evāsminn indriyaṃ vīryaṃ dhattaḥ sahendriyeṇa vīryeṇopa pra yāti jayati taṃ saṃgrāmam |
column2: Verily Indra and Agni he has recourse to with their own share; verily they two place power and strength in him; with power and strength he approaches the battle and conquers in it.

column1: vi vā eṣa indriyeṇa vīryeṇardhyate yaḥ saṃgrāmaṃ jayati |
column2: Now power and strength is he bereft of who wins a battle;

column1: aindrāgnam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet saṃgrāmaṃ jitvā |
column2: let him who has won a battle make an offering to Indra and Agni on eleven potsherds.

column1: indrāgnī eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tāv evāsminn indriyaṃ vīryam | dhatto nendriyeṇa vīryeṇa vy ṛdhyate |
column2: Verily Indra and Agni he has recourse to with their own share; verily they two place power and strength in him [3], he is not bereft of power and strength.

column1: apa vā etasmād indriyaṃ vīryaṃ krāmati ya eti janatām aindrāgnam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapej janatām eṣyan |
column2: Now power and strength depart from him who goes to the assembly; let him who is about to go to the assembly make an offering to Indra and Agni on eleven potsherds.

column1: indrāgnī eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tāv evāsminn indriyaṃ vīryaṃ dhattaḥ sahendriyeṇa vīryeṇa janatām eti pauṣṇaṃ carum anu nir vapet pūṣā vā indriyasya vīryasyānupradātā pūṣaṇam eva |
column2: Verily Indra and Agni he has recourse to with their own share; verily they two place power and strength in him, with power and strength he goes to the assembly. Let him next offer an oblation to Pusan. Pusan is the giver of power and strength, verily Pusan [4] he has recourse to with his own share;

column1: svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmā indriyaṃ vīryam anu pra yachati kṣaitrapatyaṃ caruṃ nir vapej janatām āgatya |
column2: verily he gives to him power and strength. When he has gone to the assembly he should offer an oblation to Ksetrapati;

column1: iyaṃ vai kṣetrasya patis |
column2: Ksetrapati is this (earth);

column1: asyām eva prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: verily on this earth he takes firm root.

column1: aindrāgnam ekādaśakapālam upariṣṭān nir vapet |
column2: Thereafter let him make the offering to Indra and Agni on eleven potsherds;

column1: asyām eva pratiṣṭhāyendriyaṃ vīryam upariṣṭād ātman dhatte |
column2: verily taking stand on this earth he next places power and strength in his body.

column1: agnaye pathikṛte puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yo darśapūrṇamāsayājī sann amāvāsyāṃ vā paurṇamāsīṃ vātipādayet patho vā eṣo 'dhy apathenaiti yo darśapūrṇamāsayājī sann amāvāyāṃ vā paurṇamāsīṃ vātipādayati |
column2: To Agni, maker of paths, he should offer a cake on eight potsherds who being a sacrificer at full and new moon passes over the offering either at the new or the full moon; he wanders from the path on trackless way who being a sacrificer at new and full moon passes over the offering either at the new or the full moon;

column1: agnim eva pathikṛtaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam apathāt panthām api nayati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni with his own share; verily he leads him to the path from the trackless way.

column1: anaḍvān dakṣiṇā vahī hy {eṣa < eṣas} samṛddhyai agnaye vratapataye | puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped ya āhitāgniḥ sann avratyam iva caret |
column2: A draught ox is the sacrificial fee, for it is the drawer; (verily it serves) for prosperity. To Agni, lord of vows [1] he should offer a cake on eight potsherds, who having established a sacred firebreaks his vow as it were;

column1: agnim eva vratapatiṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainaṃ vratam ā lambhayati vratyo bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, lord of vows, with his own share; verily he makes good his vow for him; he becomes a keeper of vows.

column1: agnaye rakṣoghne puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapati yaṃ rakṣāṃsi saceran |
column2: To Agni, slayer of Raksases, he should offer a cake on eight potsherds, whom Raksases infest;

column1: agnim eva rakṣohaṇaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmād rakṣāṃsy apa hanti niśitāyāṃ nir vapet |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, slayer of Raksases, with his own share; verily he smites away the Raksases from him.

column1: niśitāyāṃ hi rakṣāṃsi prerate samprerṇāny evaināni hanti pariśrite yājayed rakṣasām ananvavacārāya rakṣoghnī yājyānuvākye bhavato rakṣasāṃ stṛtyai |
column2: He should offer at night [2], for at night the Raksases are active; verily he smites them when active; he should offer in (a place) which is closed in, to prevent the Raksases entering; the Yajya, and the Anuvakya are Raksas-slaying, to lay low the Raksases.

column1: agnaye rudravate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped abhicaran |
column2: To Agni with the Rudras he should offer a cake on eight potsherds when he practises witchcraft;

column1: eṣā vā asya ghorā tanūr yad rudras tasmā evainam ā vṛścati tājag ārtim ārchati |
column2: Rudra is his dread form; verily he cuts him down to him; swiftly he reaches misfortune.

column1: agnaye surabhimate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yasya gāvo vā puruṣāḥ |
column2: He whose cows or men perish or who is afraid should offer to Agni, the fragrant, a cake on eight potsherds [3];

column1: vā pramīyeran yo vā bibhīyāt |
column2: verily by it he applies healing to him;

column1: agnaye kṣāmavate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet saṃgrāme saṃyatte bhāgadheyenaivainaṃ śamayitvā parān abhi nir diśati yam avareṣāṃ vidhyanti jīvati {sa < sas} yam pareṣām pra sa mīyate jayati taṃ saṃgrāmam |
column2: it is offered to the fragrant, to smite away the fetid odour. When a battle is joined he should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the burnt; verily by his own share he pacifies him and indicates his foes; whomsoever of those near (him) they pierce, he lives; whomsoever of the foe, he dies;

column1: abhi vā eṣa etān ucyati yeṣām pūrvāparā anvañcaḥ pramīyante puruṣāhutir hy asya priyatamā | agnaye kṣāmavate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet |
column2: He loves to frequent those whose oldest and youngest die continuously, for the human sacrifice is dearest to him, lie should offer to Agni, the burnt, a cake on eight potsherds;

column1: bhāgadheyenaivainaṃ śamayati naiṣām purāyuṣoparaḥ pra mīyate |
column2: verily with his own share he pacifies him, and none other of them dies before his day.

column1: abhi vā eṣa etasya gṛhān ucyati yasya gṛhān dahati |
column2: He loves to frequent the house of him whose house he burns;

column1: agnaye kṣāmavate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet |
column2: he should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the burnt;

column1: bhāgadheyenaivainaṃ śamayati nāsyāparaṃ gṛhān dahati |
column2: verily he pacifies him with his own share, and he burns not his house again.

column1: agnaye kāmāya puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yaṃ kāmo nopanamet |
column2: He who does not attain his desires should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni as desire;

column1: agnim eva kāmaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainaṃ kāmena sam ardhayati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni as desire with his own share; verily he unites him with his desire;

column1: upainaṃ kāmo namati |
column2: his desire comes to him.

column1: agnaye yaviṣṭhāya puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet spardhamānaḥ kṣetre vā sajāteṣu vā |
column2: He who has a dispute over a field or with his relatives should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the youngest;

column1: agnim eva yaviṣṭhaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tenaivendriyaṃ vīryam bhrātṛvyasya |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, the youngest, with his own share; verily thereby he appropriates the power and strength of his foe [1];

column1: yuvate vi pāpmanā bhrātṛvyeṇa jayate |
column2: he overcomes the evil foe.

column1: agnaye yaviṣṭhāya puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped abhicaryamāṇas |
column2: He against whom witchcraft is practised should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the youngest;

column1: agnim eva yaviṣṭhaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmād rakṣāṃsi yavayati nainam abhicarant stṛṇute |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, the youngest, with his own share; verily he drives away the Raksases from him; he who practises witchcraft does not lay him low.

column1: agnaya āyuṣmate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayeta sarvam āyur iyām iti |
column2: He who desires, 'May I live all my days', should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni of life;

column1: agnim evāyuṣmantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmin |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni of life with his own share;

column1: āyur dadhāti sarvam āyur eti |
column2: verily he bestows life upon him [2];

column1: agnaye jātavedase puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped bhūtikāmas |
column2: He who desires prosperity should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the all-knower;

column1: agnim eva jātavedasaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam bhūtiṃ gamayati bhavaty eva |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, the all-knower, with his own share; verily he makes him attain prosperity;

column1: agnaye rukmate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped rukkāmas |
column2: He who desires radiance should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the radiant;

column1: agnim eva rukmantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmin rucaṃ dadhāti rocata eva |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, the radiant, with his own share; verily he bestows radiance on him;

column1: agnaye tejasvate puroḍāśam | aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet tejaskāmas |
column2: he is radiant. He who desires brilliance should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the brilliant [3];

column1: agnim eva tejasvantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmin tejo dadhāti tejasvy eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, the brilliant, with his own share; verily he bestows brilliance upon him; he becomes brilliant.

column1: agnaye sāhantyāya puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet sīkṣamāṇas |
column2: He who seeks to be strong should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the strong;

column1: agnim eva sāhantyaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tenaiva sahate yaṃ sīkṣate |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, the strong, with his own share; verily thereby he is strong who seeks to be strong.

column1: agnaye 'nnavate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayetānnavānt syām iti |
column2: He who desires, 'May I possess food', should offer to Agni, possessor of food, a cake on eight potsherds;

column1: agnim evānnavantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam annavantaṃ karoty annavān eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, possessor of food, with his own share; verily he makes him to possess food;

column1: agnaye 'nnādāya puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayetānnādaḥ syām iti |
column2: He who desires, 'May I be an eater of food', should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, eater of food;

column1: agnim evānnādaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam annādaṃ karoty annādaḥ |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, eater of food, with his own share; verily he makes him an eater of food;

column1: eva bhavati |
column2: he becomes an eater of food [1].

column1: agnaye 'nnapataye puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayetānnapatiḥ syām iti |
column2: He who desires, 'May I be a lord of food', should offer to Agni, lord of food, a cake on eight potsherds;

column1: agnim evānnapatiṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam annapatiṃ karoty annapatir eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, lord of food, with his own share; verily he makes him a lord of food;

column1: agnaye pavamānāya puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped agnaye pāvakāyāgnaye śucaye jyogāmayāvī yad agnaye pavamānāya nirvapati prāṇam evāsmin tena dadhāti yad agnaye |
column2: he becomes a lord of food. He who is long ill should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the purifying, to Agni, the purifier, to Agni, the pure; in that he offers to Agni, the purifying, thereby he bestows health upon him;

column1: pāvakāya vācam evāsmin tena dadhāti yad agnaye śucaye |
column2: in that (he offers) to Agni, the purifier [2], thereby he bestows speech upon him;

column1: āyur evāsmin tena dadhāty uta yadītāsur bhavati jīvaty eva |
column2: in that (he offers) to Agni, the pure, thereby he bestows life upon him; even if his life is gone, he yet lives.

column1: etām eva nir vapec cakṣuṣkāmo yad agnaye pavamānāya nirvapati prāṇam evāsmin tena dadhāti yad agnaye pāvakāya vācam evāsmin tena dadhāti yad agnaye śucaye cakṣur evāsmin tena dadhāti |
column2: in that he offers to Agni, the purifying, he thereby bestows breath upon him; in that (he offers) to Agni, the purifier, thereby he bestows speech upon him; in that (he offers) to Agni, the pure, thereby he bestows sight upon him [3];

column1: uta yady andho bhavati praiva paśyati |
column2: even if he is blind, he yet sees.

column1: agnaye putravate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet | indrāya putriṇe puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālam prajākāmas |
column2: He who desires offspring should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni with sons, and a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, who has sons;

column1: agnir evāsmai prajām prajanayati vṛddhām indraḥ pra yachati |
column2: verily Agni begets offspring for him and Indra makes it grow.

column1: agnaye rasavate 'jakṣīre caruṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayeta rasavānt syām iti |
column2: He who desires, 'May I be possessed of sap', should offer an oblation cooked in goat's milk to Agni, full of sap;

column1: agnim eva rasavantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainaṃ rasavantaṃ karoti |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, full of sap, with his own share; verily he makes him possessed of sap [4];

column1: rasavān eva bhavaty ajakṣīre bhavati |
column2: he becomes possessed of sap.

column1: āgneyī vā eṣā yad ajā sākṣād eva rasam ava runddhe |
column2: It is cooked in goat's milk; the she-goat is connected with Agni;

column1: agnaye vasumate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayeta vasumānt syām iti |
column2: He who desires, 'May I be possessed of wealth', should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, possessed of wealth;

column1: agnim {F eva}{W eva} vasumantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainaṃ vasumantaṃ karoti vasumān eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Agni, possessed of wealth, with his own share, and he makes him possessed of wealth;

column1: agnaye vājasṛte puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet saṃgrāme saṃyatte vājaṃ |
column2: When battle is joined, he should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the racer, for a race [5] he desires to run, who is fain to conquer in battle;

column1: agniḥ khalu vai devānāṃ vājasṛd agnim eva vājasṛtaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati dhāvati vājaṃ hanti vṛtraṃ jayati taṃ saṃgrāmam atho agnir iva na pratidhṛṣe bhavati |
column2: Agni of the gods is the racer; verily he has recourse to Agni with his own share; he runs the race, he slays the foe, he conquers in the battle, and like Agni he is not to be overcome.

column1: agnaye 'gnivate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yasyāgnāv agnim abhyuddhareyus |
column2: He for whom fire they take out again (from the Garhapatya fire) to place on the Ahavaniya should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni with Agni;

column1: nirdiṣṭabhāgo vā etayor anyo 'nirdiṣṭabhāgo 'nyas tau sambhavantau yajamānam | abhi sam bhavatas |
column2: one of these (fires) has a portion assigned, one has not a portion assigned; they uniting overpower the sacrificer [6], and he is liable to suffer ruin;

column1: sa īśvara ārtim ārtor yad agnaye 'gnivate nirvapati bhāgadheyenaivainau śamayati nārtim ārchati yajamānas |
column2: in that he offers to Agni with Agni, he appeases him with his own share; the sacrificer does not suffer ruin.

column1: agnaye jyotiṣmate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped yasyāgnir uddhṛto 'hute 'gnihotra udvāyed apara ādīpyānūddhṛtya ity āhus tat tathā na kāryaṃ yad bhāgadheyam abhi pūrva uddhriyate kim aparo 'bhy ut |
column2: He whose fire goes out after it has been taken out (from the Garhapatya) before the Agnihotra has been offered should offer a cake on eight potsherds to Agni with light; (they say), 'Should another be taken out, after lighting up (from the Garhapatya)'? That should not be done.

column1: hriyeteti tāny evāvakṣāṇāni saṃnidhāya manthet | itaḥ prathamaṃ jajñe agniḥ svād yoner adhi jātavedāḥ |
column2: Since the former is taken out for a definite share, how should another [7] be taken out for (it)? He should deposit the extinguished embers and produce fire by friction, (with the words), 'Hence first was Agni born, from his own womb, the all-knower;

column1: sa gāyatriyā triṣṭubhā jagatyā devebhyo havyaṃ vahatu prajānann iti chandobhir evainaṃ svād yoneḥ pra janayaty eṣa vāva so 'gnir ity āhur jyotis tvā asya parāpatitam iti yad agnaye jyotiṣmate nirvapati yad evāsya jyotiḥ parāpatitaṃ tad evāva runddhe |
column2: he with Gayatri, Tristubh, Jagati shall bear the oblation to the gods, the wise ones'; with the metres he begets him from his own womb; 'this is the fire', they say, I what falls from it is light'; in that he offers to Agni with light, he wins the light which has fallen from it.

column1: vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped vāruṇaṃ caruṃ dadhikrāvṇe carum abhiśasyamānas |
column2: He who is calumniated should offer on twelve potsherds to Vaiçvanara, an oblation to Varuna, and an oblation to Dadhikravan;

column1: yad vaiśvānaro dvādaśakapālo bhavati saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsareṇaivainaṃ svadayaty apa pāpaṃ varṇaṃ hate vāruṇenaivainaṃ varuṇapāśān muñcati dadhikrāvṇā punāti hiraṇyaṃ dakṣiṇā pavitraṃ vai hiraṇyam punāty evainam ādyam asyānnam bhavati |
column2: in that there is (an offering) on twelve potsherds to Vaiçvanara, and Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily he satisfies him with the year, he smites off the evil hue; by (the offering) to Varuna he frees him from the noose of Varuna; by Dadhikravan he purifies him. The sacrificial fee is gold;

column1: etām eva nir vapet prajākāmaḥ saṃvatsaraḥ |
column2: The same (offering) he should make who desires offspring;

column1: vā etasyāśānto yonim prajāyai paśūnāṃ nir dahati yo 'lam prajāyai san prajāṃ na vindate yad vaiśvānaro dvādaśakapālo bhavati saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsaram eva bhāgadheyena śamayati so 'smai śāntaḥ svād yoneḥ prajām pra {F janayati}{W janayaty}{GLOS janayati} vāruṇenaivainaṃ varuṇapāśān muñcati dadhikrāvṇā punāti hiraṇyaṃ dakṣiṇā pavitraṃ vai hiraṇyam punāty evainam |
column2: the year [1] unpropitiated burns up the womb of offspring, of cattle, for him who being fit for offspring does not obtain offspring; in that there is (an offering) on twelve potsherds for Vaiçvanara, and Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily he propitiates the year with its own share; it propitiated begets offspring for him from his own womb; by (the offering) to Varuna he frees him from the noose of Varuna;

column1: vindate prajām |
column2: he obtains offspring.

column1: vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet putre jāte yad aṣṭākapālo bhavati gāyatriyaivainam brahmavarcasena punāti yan navakapālas trivṛtaivāsmin tejo dadhāti yad daśakapālo virājaivāsminn annādyaṃ dadhāti yad ekādaśakapālas tṛṣṭubhaivāsminn indriyaṃ dadhāti yad dvādaśakapālo jagatyaivāsmin paśūn dadhāti yasmiñ jāta etām iṣṭim nirvapati pūtaḥ |
column2: When a son is born he should offer on twelve potsherds to Vaiçvanara; in that there is (an offering) on eight potsherds, he purifies him with the Gayatri, with splendour; in that there is (an offering) on nine potsherds, he bestows brilliance upon him with the Trivrt (Stoma); in that there is (an offering) on ten potsherds, he bestows proper food upon him with the Viraj; in that there is (an offering) on eleven potsherds, he bestows power upon him with the Tristubh;

column1: eva tejasy annāda indriyāvī paśumān bhavati |
column2: he upon whose birth he offers this sacrifice becomes pure [3], brilliant, an eater of food, powerful, possessed of cattle.

column1: ava vā eṣa suvargāl lokāc chidyate yo darśapūrṇamāsayājī sann amāvāsyāṃ vā paurṇamāsīṃ vātipādayati suvargāya hi lokāya darśapūrṇamāsāv ijyete vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped amāvāsyāṃ vā paurṇamāsīṃ vātipādya saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsaram eva prīṇāty atho saṃvatsaram evāsmā upa dadhāti suvargasya lokasya samaṣṭyai |
column2: He is cut off from the world of heaven who, being a sacrificer at new and full moon, the sacrifice either at the new or the full moon omits, for the new and full moon offerings are made for the world of heaven; if he has omitted the sacrifice either at the new or the full moon, he should offer to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds; Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily he delights the year; verily also he brings up the year for him for the winning of the world of heaven [4];

column1: atho devatā evānvārabhya suvargaṃ lokam eti vīrahā vā eṣa devānāṃ yo 'gnim udvāsayate na vā etasya brāhmaṇā ṛtāyavaḥ purānnam akṣan |
column2: verily also grasping the deities he goes to the world of heaven. He who removes the fire is the slayer of the hero among the gods; formerly righteous Brahmans did not eat his food;

column1: āgneyam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapet | vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālam agnim udvāsayiṣyan yad aṣṭākapālo bhavaty aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatro 'gnir yāvān evāgnis tasmā ātithyaṃ karoti |
column2: he should offer to Agni on eight potsherds, to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds, when he is about to remove the fire; in that there is (an offering) on eight potsherds, the Gayatri has eight syllables, Agni is connected with the Gayatri; to Agni in his full extent he shows hospitality;

column1: atho yathā janaṃ yate 'vasaṃ karoti tādṛk | eva tat |
column2: verily also that is as when one makes preparation for a man about to go to (another) people [5].

column1: dvādaśakapālo vaiśvānaro bhavati dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ khalu vā agner yoniḥ svām evainaṃ yoniṃ gamayati |
column2: (The offering) to Vaiçvanara is on twelve potsherds; the year has twelve months; the birthplace of Agni is the year; verily he makes him go to his own birth place;

column1: ādyam asyānnam bhavati vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vapen mārutaṃ saptakapālaṃ grāmakāmas |
column2: his food becomes fit to eat. He who desires a village should offer on twelve potsherds to Vaiçvanara, and to the Maruts on seven potsherds.

column1: āhavanīye vaiśvānaram adhi śrayati gārhapatye mārutam pāpavasyasasya vidhṛtyai dvādaśakapālo vaiśvānaro bhavati dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsareṇaivāsmai sajātāṃś cyāvayati māruto bhavati |
column2: (the offering) to Vaiçvanara he places on the Ahavaniya, that to the Maruts on the Garhapatya, for the avoidance of confusion. (The offering) to Vaiçvanara is on twelve potsherds; the year has twelve months; verily by the year he removes his rivals for him; there is one to the Maruts [6];

column1: maruto vai devānāṃ viśo devaviśenaivāsmai manuṣyaviśam ava runddhe saptakapālo bhavati saptagaṇā vai maruto gaṇaśa evāsmai sajātān ava runddhe |
column2: the Maruts are the subject class among the gods; verily by the subjects among the gods he wins for him the subjects among men; (the offering) is on seven potsherds; the Maruts are in seven troops;

column1: anūcyamāna ā sādayati viśam evāsmā anuvartmānaṃ karoti |
column2: verily in troops he wins his rivals for him; he deposits (the offering) when (the verses) are being repeated;

column1: ādityaṃ caruṃ nir vapet saṃgrāmam upaprayāsyan |
column2: He who is about to engage in a conflict should offer an oblation to Aditi;

column1: iyaṃ vā aditis |
column2: Aditi is this (earth);

column1: asyām eva pūrve prati tiṣṭhanti vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped āyatanaṃ gatvā saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ khalu vai devānām āyatanam etasmād vā āyatanād devā asurān ajayan yad vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nirvapati devānām evāyatane yatate jayati taṃ saṃgrāmam etasmin vā etau mṛjāte |
column2: verily in time gone by they were used to rest upon it. He who has come to the place should offer to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds; Agni Vaiçvanara is the year, the place of the gods is the year; from that place the gods drove the Asuras in defeat; in that he offers to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds, he strives for the abode of the gods;

column1: yo vidviṣāṇayor annam atti vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped vidviṣāṇayor annaṃ jagdhvā saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsarasvaditam evātti nāsmin mṛjāte saṃvatsarāya vā etau sam amāte yau samamāte tayor yaḥ pūrvo 'bhidruhyati taṃ varuṇo gṛhṇāti vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet samamānayoḥ pūrvo 'bhidruhya saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ samvatsaram evāptvā nirvaruṇam |
column2: Those two wipe (their sin) off upon him [1] who eats the food of two enemies; he who has eaten the food of two enemies should offer to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds; Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily he eats what the year has made sweet; those two do not wipe (their sin) off upon him.

column1: parastād abhi druhyati nainaṃ varuṇo gṛhṇāti |
column2: him of them who first acts with treachery Varuna seizes;

column1: āvyaṃ vā eṣa prati gṛhṇāti yo 'vim pratigṛhṇāti vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped avim pratigṛhya saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsarasvaditām eva pratigṛhṇāti nāvyam prati gṛhṇāti |
column2: Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily having obtained the year thereafter he acts with treachery against one who has lost Varuna's protection [2]; Varuna does not seize him. The nature of the sheep he accepts who accepts a sheep; having accepted a sheep he should offer to Vaiçvanara, Agni Vaiçvanara is the year;

column1: ātmano vā eṣa mātrām āpnoti ya ubhayādat pratigṛhṇāty aśvaṃ vā puruṣaṃ vā vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped ubhayādat |
column2: A measure of himself he obtains who accepts (an animal) with teeth in both jaws, whether horse or man; he who has accepted (an animal) with teeth in both jaws [3] should offer on twelve potsherds to Vaiçvanara;

column1: pratigṛhya saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaraḥ saṃvatsarasvaditam eva prati gṛhṇāti nātmano mātrām āpnoti vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet sanim eṣyan |
column2: Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily he accepts it made suitable by the year; he does not obtain a measure of himself. He who is eager to win wealth should offer to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds;

column1: saṃvatsaro vā agnir vaiśvānaras |
column2: Agni Vaiçvanara is the year;

column1: yadā khalu vai saṃvatsaraṃ janatāyāṃ caraty atha sa dhanārgho bhavati yad vaiśvānaraṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nirvapati saṃvatsarasātām eva sanim abhi pra cyavate dānakāmā asmai prajā bhavanti yo vai saṃvatsaram |
column2: when a man for a year goes about among folk he becomes worthy of wealth. In that he offers to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds, he moves towards wealth gained by the year: people are fain to give him gifts.

column1: prayujya na vimuñcaty apratiṣṭhāno vai sa bhavati |
column2: He, who having yoked the year [4], does not let it go, becomes without support;

column1: etam eva vaiśvānaram punar āgatya nir vapet |
column2: after his return he should offer the same sacrifice to Vaiçvanara;

column1: yam eva prayuṅkte tam bhāgadheyena vi muñcati pratiṣṭhityai yayā rajjvottamāṃ gām ājet tām bhrātṛvyāya pra hiṇuyāt |
column2: (the year) which he yokes he lets go with its own share, for support; the rope with which he drives the last of his cows he should cast against his foe;

column1: nirṛtim evāsmai pra hiṇoti |
column2: verily he casts misfortune upon him.

column1: aindraṃ caruṃ nir vapet paśukāmas |
column2: He who desires cattle should offer an oblation to Indra;

column1: aindrā vai paśavas |
column2: cattle are connected with Indra;

column1: indram eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmai paśūn pra yachati paśumān eva bhavati carur bhavati svād evāsmai yoneḥ paśūn pra janayati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra with his own share; verily he gives him cattle; verily he becomes possessed of cattle; it is an oblation; verily for him from his own place of birth he produces cattle.

column1: indrāyendriyāvate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet paśukāmas |
column2: He who desires cattle should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, the powerful;

column1: indriyaṃ vai paśavas |
column2: cattle are power;

column1: indram evendriyāvantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati saḥ | evāsmā indriyam paśūn pra yachati paśumān eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, the powerful, with his own share; he gives him [1] power and cattle; verily he becomes possessed of cattle.

column1: indrāya gharmavate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped brahmavarcasakāmas |
column2: He who desires splendour should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, possessed of heat;

column1: brahmavarcasaṃ vai gharmas |
column2: heat is splendour;

column1: indram eva gharmavantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmin brahmavarcasaṃ dadhāti brahmavarcasy eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra with his own share; he bestows upon him splendour, verily he becomes resplendent.

column1: indrāyārkavate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped annakāmas |
column2: He who desires food should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra of the hymn;

column1: arko vai devānām annam indram evārkavantaṃ svena bhāgadheyena | upa dhāvati sa evāsmā annam pra yachati |
column2: the hymn is the food of the gods; verily he has recourse to Indra of the hymn with his own share [2]; he gives him food;

column1: annāda eva bhavati |
column2: verily he becomes an eater of food.

column1: indrāya gharmavate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped indrāyendriyāvata indrāyārkavate bhūtikāmas |
column2: He who desires prosperity should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, possessed of heat, and to Indra, the powerful, and to Indra of the hymn;

column1: yad indrāya gharmavate nirvapati śira evāsya tena karoti yad indrāyendriyāvata ātmānam evāsya tena karoti yad indrāyārkavate bhūta evānnādye prati tiṣṭhati bhavaty eva |
column2: in that he offers to Indra, possessed of heat, he thereby makes his head; in that (he offers) to Indra, the powerful, he thereby makes his body; in that (he offers) to Indra of the hymn, he becoming prosperous finds support in food;

column1: indrāya |
column2: verily he prospers.

column1: aṃhomuce puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ pāpmanā gṛhītaḥ syāt pāpmā vā aṃhas |
column2: He who is seized by misfortune should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra [3], deliverer from tribulation, tribulation is misfortune;

column1: indram evāṃhomucaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainam pāpmano 'ṃhaso muñcati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, deliverer from tribulation, with his own share; verily he delivers him from the misfortune, from tribulation.

column1: indrāya vaimṛdhāya puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped yam mṛdho 'bhi praveperan rāṣṭrāṇi vābhi samiyus |
column2: He whom enemies menace or invade his realms should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, repeller of foes;

column1: indram eva vaimṛdhaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmān mṛdhaḥ |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, repeller of foes, with his own share; verily he repels foes from him [4].

column1: indrāya trātre puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped baddho vā pariyatto vā |
column2: He who is bound or beset should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, the protector;

column1: indram eva trātāraṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainaṃ trāyate |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, the protector, with his own share; verily he protects him.

column1: indrāyārkāśvamedhavate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped yam mahāyajño nopanamet |
column2: He to whom the great sacrifice does not resort should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, of the Arka and the Açvamedha;

column1: ete vai mahāyajñasyāntye tanū yad arkāśvamedhau |
column2: the Arka and the Açvamedha are the two end bodies of the great sacrifice;

column1: indram evārkāśvamedhavantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmā antato mahāyajñaṃ cyāvayati | upainaṃ mahāyajño namati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, of the Arka and the Açvamedha, with his own share; verily he moves for him the great sacrifice from the ends, and the great sacrifice resorts to him.

column1: indrāyānvṛjave puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped grāmakāmas |
column2: He who desires a village should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, who goes straight forward;

column1: indram evānvṛjuṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmai sajātān anukān karoti grāmy eva bhavati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, who goes straight forward, with his own share; verily he makes his followers obedient to him;

column1: indrāṇyai caruṃ nir vaped yasya senāsaṃśiteva syāt |
column2: He whose dart is not as it were sharp should offer an oblation to Indrani;

column1: indrāṇī vai senāyai devatā |
column2: the deity of the arrow is Indrani;

column1: indrāṇīṃ eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati saivāsya senāṃ saṃ śyati balbajān api |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indrani with her own share;

column1: idhme saṃ nahyet |
column2: she sharpens his arrow.

column1: gaur yatrādhiṣkannā yamehat tato balbajā ud atiṣṭhan gavām evainaṃ nyāyam apinīya gā vedayati |
column2: where the cow being covered made water, thence grew the Balbaja; verily making him follow the way of the cows he causes him to obtain cows.

column1: indrāya manyumate manasvate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet saṃgrāme saṃyatte |
column2: To Indra, the angry, the wise, he should offer a cake on eleven potsherds when battle is joined;

column1: indriyeṇa vai manyunā manasā saṃgrāmaṃ jayati |
column2: with power, with anger, and with wisdom one wins the battle;

column1: indram eva manyumantam manasvantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsminn indriyam manyum mano dadhāti jayati tam |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, the angry, the wise, with his own share; verily he bestows upon him power, anger, and mind; he wins [2] the battle.

column1: saṃgrāmam etām eva nir vaped yo hatamanāḥ svayampāpa iva syāt | etāni hi vā etasmād apakrāntāni |
column2: The same offering should he make whose mind is affected and who as it were injures himself, for these are departed from him;

column1: athaiṣa hatamanāḥ svayampāpa indram eva manyumantam manasvantaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsminn indriyam manyum mano dadhāti na hatamanāḥ svayampāpo bhavati |
column2: verily he whose mind is affected and who injures himself has recourse to Indra, the angry, the wise, with his own share; verily he bestows upon him power, anger, and wisdom; his mind is not affected and he does not injure himself.

column1: indrāya dātre puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped yaḥ kāmayeta dānakāmā me prajāḥ syuḥ |
column2: He who desires, 'May people be fain to give to me', should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, the giver [3];

column1: indram eva dātāraṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmai dānakāmāḥ prajāḥ karoti dānakāmā asmai prajā bhavanti |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, the giver, with his own share; verily he makes people fain to give to him; people become fain to give to him.

column1: indrāya pradātre puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped yasmai prattam iva san na pradīyeta |
column2: He upon whom what is as it were ready to be given is not bestowed should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, the bestower;

column1: indram eva pradātāraṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsmai pra dāpayati |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, the bestower, with his own share; verily he makes (men) bestow upon him.

column1: indrāya sutrāmṇe puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped aparuddho vā | aparudhyamāno vā |
column2: He who has been expelled or is being expelled should offer a cake on eleven potsherds to Indra, the good protector [4];

column1: indram eva sutrāmāṇaṃ svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evainaṃ trāyate |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra, the good protector, with his own share; verily he protects him;

column1: anaparudhyo bhavati |
column2: he becomes unexpellable.

column1: indro vai sadṛṅ devatābhir āsīt sa na vyāvṛtam agachat sa prajāpatim upādhāvat tasmā etam aindram ekādaśakapālaṃ nir avapat tenaivāsminn indriyam adadhāt |
column2: Indra was equal with the gods, he did not attain distinction, he had recourse to Prajapati, for him, he offered this (offering) to Indra on eleven potsherds, and thereby he bestowed power upon him;

column1: śakvarī yājyānuvākye akarot |
column2: he makes the Yajya and the Puronuvakya of the Çakvari (metre);

column1: vajro vai śakvarī sa enaṃ vajro bhūtyā ainddha |
column2: the Çakvari is the thunderbolt, the thunderbolt kindled him for prosperity [5], he became prosperous;

column1: so 'bhavat so 'bibhed bhūtaḥ pra mā dhakṣyatīti sa prajāpatim punar upādhāvat sa prajāpatiḥ śakvaryā adhi revatīṃ nir amimīta śāntyā apradāhāya yo 'laṃ śriyai sant sadṛṅk samānaiḥ syāt tasmā etam aindram ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vapet |
column2: having become prosperous, be became afraid, (thinking) 'It shall burn me'; he had recourse again to Prajapati; Prajapati from the Çakvari fashioned the (verse containing the word) 'rich', for atonement, to prevent burning. For him who being fit for prosperity is equal with his fellows he should offer this (offering) for Indra on eleven potsherds;

column1: indram eva svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati sa evāsminn indriyaṃ dadhāti revatī puro'nuvākyā bhavati śāntyā apradāhāya śakvarī yājyā vajro vai śakvarī sa enaṃ vajro bhūtyā inddhe bhavaty eva |
column2: verily he has recourse to Indra with his own share; verily he bestows power upon him. The (verse containing the word) 'rich' is the Puronuvakya, for atonement, to prevent burning; the Yajya is in the Çakvari (metre) -, the Çakvari is the thunderbolt, the thunderbolt kindles him for prosperity, he becomes prosperous.

column1: āgnāvaiṣṇavam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped abhicarant sarasvaty ājyabhāgā syād bārhaspatyaś carus |
column2: He who practises witchcraft should offer to Agni and Visnu on eleven potsherds; Sarasvati should have a portion of the butter, and to Brhaspati an oblation (be offered);

column1: agniḥ sarvā devatā viṣṇur yajño devatābhiś caivainaṃ yajñena cābhi carati sarasvaty ājyabhāgā bhavati vāg vai sarasvatī vācaivainam abhi carati bārhaspatyaś carur bhavati brahma vai devānām bṛhaspatir brahmaṇaivainam abhi carati |
column2: in that there is (an offering) on eleven potsherds to Agni and Visnu, and all the gods are Agni and the sacrifice is Visnu, with all the gods and the sacrifice be practises witchcraft against him; Sarasvati has a portion of the butter; Sarasvati is speech; verily with speech he practises against him; the oblation is Brhaspati's, Brhaspati is the holy power (Brahman) of the gods;

column1: prati vai parastād abhicarantam abhi caranti dvedve puro'nuvākye kuryād ati prayuktyai |
column2: Him who practises witchcraft they practise then against; he should double each of the Puronuvakyas, for special employment.

column1: etayaiva yajetābhicaryamāṇo devatābhir eva devatāḥ praticarati yajñena yajñaṃ vācā vācam brahmaṇā brahma sa devatāś caiva yajñaṃ ca madhyato vyavasarpati tasya na kutaś canopāvyādho bhavati nainam abhicarant stṛṇute |
column2: With the same (offering) should he sacrifice who is practised against; verily he sets gods against gods, the sacrifice against the sacrifice, speech against speech, the Brahman against the Brahman; between the gods and the sacrifice he creeps along; from no quarter is be injured; he who practises against him does not lay him low.

column1: āgnāvaiṣṇavam ekādaśakapālaṃ nir vaped yaṃ yajño na |
column2: He to whom the sacrifice does not resort should offer on eleven potsherds to Agni and Visnu [2];

column1: agniḥ sarvā devatā viṣṇur yajño 'gniṃ caiva viṣṇuṃ ca svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tāv evāsmai yajñam pra yachata upainaṃ yajño namati |
column2: all the gods are Agni, the sacrifice is Visnu; verily he has recourse to Agni and Visnu with their own share; verily they give him the sacrifice; the sacrifice resorts to him.

column1: āgnāvaiṣṇavaṃ ghṛte caruṃ nir vapec cakṣuṣkāmas | agner vai cakṣuṣā manuṣyā vi paśyanti yajñasya devā agniṃ caiva viṣṇuṃ ca svena bhāgadheyenopa dhāvati tāv eva |
column2: He who desires sight should offer an oblation in ghee to Agni and Visnu by the eye of Agni men see, (by the eye) of the sacrifice the gods (see) verily he has recourse to Agni and Visnu with their own share; verily they [3] bestow sight upon him;

column1: asmiñ cakṣur dhattaś cakṣuṣmān eva bhavati dhenvai vā etad reto yad ājyam anaḍuhas taṇḍulā mithunād evāsmai cakṣuḥ pra janayati ghṛte bhavati tejo vai ghṛtaṃ tejaś cakṣus tejasaivāsmai tejaś cakṣur ava runddhe |

column1: indriyaṃ vai vīryaṃ vṛṅkte bhrātṛvyo yajamāno 'yajamānasyādhvarakalpām prati nir vaped bhrātṛvye yajamāne nāsyendriyaṃ |
column2: His foe in sacrificing gains the power and strength of him who sacrifices not; when his foe is sacrificing he should offer against him a sort of sacrifice; he does not then gain his power [4] and strength.

column1: vīryaṃ vṛṅkte purā vācaḥ pravaditor nir vaped yāvaty eva vāk tām aproditām bhrātṛvyasya vṛṅkte tām asya vācam pravadantīm anyā vāco 'nu pra vadanti tā indriyaṃ vīryaṃ yajamāne dadhati |
column2: He should offer before speech is uttered; all the speech of his foe he thus gains unuttered, and his speech as uttered other speeches follow after; they bestow upon the sacrificer power and strength.

column1: āgnāvaiṣṇavam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped prātaḥsavanasyākāle sarasvaty ājyabhāgā syād bārhaspatyaś carus |
column2: Just at the time of the morning pressing he should offer on eight potsherds to Agni and Visnu; Sarasvati should have a share of the butter, and to Brhaspati an oblation (be offered);

column2: in that it is (offered) on eight potsherds, and the Gayatri has eight syllables, and the morning pressing is connected with the Gayatri, he obtains thereby the morning pressing [5].

column2: Just at the time of the midday pressing he should offer on eleven potsherds to Agni and Visnu; Sarasvati should have a portion of the butter and to Brhaspati an oblation (be offered);

column2: The first he repeats is connected with the Rathantara (Saman), this world is connected with the Rathantara;

column1: imam eva lokam abhi jayati trir vi gṛhṇāti traya ime lokās |
column2: He divides it thrice; these worlds are three; verily he conquers these worlds.

column1: imān eva lokān abhi jayati bārhatīm uttamām anv āha bārhato vā asau lokas |
column2: The last he repeats is connected with the Brhat (Saman); yonder world is connected with the Brhat;

column1: amum eva lokam abhi jayati pra vaḥ |
column2: verily he conquers yonder world.

column1: vājā ity aniruktām prājāpatyām anv āha yajño vai prajāpatis | yajñam eva prajāpatim ā rabhate pra vo vājā ity anv āha |
column2: 'Forward [2] your viands', he repeats, a verse which has not any indication (of its deity) and (therefore) is addressed to Prajapati. Prajapati is the sacrifice; verily he grasps the sacrifice as Prajapati.

column1: annaṃ vai vājas |
column2: 'Forward your viands', he repeats;

column1: annam evāva runddhe pra vo vājā ity ānv āha tasmāt prācīnaṃ reto dhīyate |
column2: verily he wins food. 'Forward your viands', he repeats; therefore seed is deposited in front.

column1: agna ā yāhi vītaya ity āha tasmāt pratīcīḥ prajā jāyante pra vo vājāḥ |
column2: 'O Agni, come hither for the feast', he repeats; therefore offspring are born at the back. 'Forward your viands', he repeats [3];

column1: ity anv āha māsā vai vājā ardhamāsā abhidyavo devā haviṣmanto gaur ghṛtācī yajño devāñ jigāti yajamānaḥ sumnayus |
column2: 'viands' are the months, 'heavenwards' are the half-months, 'rich in the oblation' are the gods, 'full of butter' is the cow, 'he goes to the gods' (that is) the sacrifice, 'desirous of favour ' is the sacrificer.

column1: idam asīdam asīty eva yajñasya priyaṃ dhāmāva runddhe yaṃ kāmayeta sarvam āyur iyād iti pra vo vājā iti tasyānūcyāgna ā yāhi vītaya iti saṃ tatam uttaram ardharcam ā labheta | prāṇenaivāsyāpānaṃ dadhāra sarvam āyur eti yo vā aratniṃ sāmidhenīnāṃ vedāratnāv eva bhrātṛvyaṃ kurute |
column2: 'Thou art this, thou art this', (with these words) he wins the dear abode of the sacrifice. If he desire for a man, 'May he live all his days', he should repeat for him 'Forward your viands', and then continuously the next half-verse of 'Agni, come hither to the feast' [4]. Verily by expiration does he make steadfast his inspiration, and he lives all his days. He, who knows the elbow of the Samidhenis, puts his enemy in his elbow.

column1: ardharcau saṃ dadhāti |
column2: He joins the half-verses;

column1: eṣa vā aratniḥ sāmidhenīnām |
column2: this is the elbow of the Samidhenis;

column1: ya evaṃ vedāratnāv eva bhrātṛvyaṃ kurute |
column2: he who knows thus puts his foe in his elbow.

column1: ṛṣerṛṣer vā etā nirmitā yat sāmidhenyas tā yad asaṃyuktāḥ syuḥ prajayā paśubhir yajamānasya vi tiṣṭheran |
column2: The Samidhenis were brought out by Rsi after Rsi; if they were not connected together, they would go away from the sacrificer's offspring and cattle.

column1: ardharcau saṃdadhāti saṃ yunakty evainās tā asmai saṃyuktā avaruddhāḥ sarvām āśiṣaṃ duhre |
column2: He unites the half-verses; verily he connects them together, and being so connected and secured they yield him all his desires.

column1: ayajño vā eṣa yo 'sāmā |
column2: Without a Saman there is no sacrifice.

column1: agna ā yāhi vītaya ity āha rāthaṃtarasyaiṣa varṇas taṃ tvā samidbhir aṅgira ity āha vāmadevyasyaiṣa varṇas |
column2: 'O Agni, come hither for the feast', he says; this is the character of the Rathantara. 'Thee with the kindling-sticks, O Angiras', he says; this is the character of the Vamadevya.

column1: bṛhad agne suvīryam ity āha bṛhata eṣa varṇas |
column2: 'The great and powerful one, O Agni', he says. This is the character of the Brhat.

column1: yad etaṃ tṛcam anvāha yajñam eva tat sāmanvantaṃ karoti |
column2: In that he repeats this Trca, he makes the sacrifice have Samans.

column1: agnir amuṣmiM loka āsīd ādityo 'smin tāv imau lokāv aśāntau |
column2: Agni was in yonder world, the sun in this; these worlds were disturbed [1].

column1: te devā abruvan | etemau vi pary ūhāmeti | agna ā yāhi vītaya ity asmiM loke 'gnim adadhur bṛhad agne suvīryam ity amuṣmiM loka ādityam |
column2: The gods said, 'Let us change them about.' (Saying), 'O Agni, come hither for the feast', they placed Agni in this world, and (saying),'The great and powerful one, O Agni', they placed the sun in yonder world.

column1: tato vā imau lokāv aśāmyatām |
column2: Then indeed these worlds became calm.

column1: yad evam anvāhānayor lokayoḥ śāntyai śāmyato 'smā imau lokau ya evaṃ veda pañcadaśa sāmidhenīr anv āha pañcadaśa |
column2: In that he repeats (it) thus, (it serves) for the calming of these worlds; these worlds become calm for him who knows thus. He repeats fifteen Samidhenis [2].

column1: vā ardhamāsasya rātrayas |
column2: the year is made up of half-months.

column1: ardhamāsaśaḥ saṃvatsara āpyate tāsāṃ trīṇi ca śatāni ṣaṣṭiś cākṣarāṇi tāvatīḥ saṃvatsarasya rātrayas |
column2: There are three hundred and sixty syllables in the Samidhenis; there are as many nights in the year; verily by syllables he obtains the year.

column1: akṣaraśa eva saṃvatsaram āpnoti nṛmedhaś ca paruchepaś ca brahmavādyam avadetām asmin dārāv ārdre 'gniṃ janayāva yataro nau brahmīyān iti nṛmedho 'bhy avadat sa dhūmam ajanayat paruchepo 'bhy avadat so 'gnim ajanayat |
column2: Nrmedha and Paruchepa had a theological dispute (and said), 'Let us generate fire in the dry wood (to see) which of us two is the more of a theologian.' Nrmedha spoke; he generated smoke. Paruchepa spoke;

column1: ṛṣa ity abravīt |
column2: he generated fire.

column1: yat samāvad vidva kathā tvam agnim ajījano nāham iti sāmidhenīnām evāhaṃ varṇaṃ vedety abravīt |
column2: 'O Rsi', he said, [3], 'seeing that our knowledge is equal, how didst thou generate fire and not I?' 'I know the character of the Samidhenis', he replied.

column1: agnir devānāṃ dūta āsīd uśanā kāvyo 'surāṇām |
column2: The character of the Samidhenis is the quarter-verse which is repeated with the word 'ghee' in it.

column1: tau prajāpatim praśnam aitām sa prajāpatir agniṃ dūtaṃ vṛṇīmaha ity abhi paryāvartata tato devā abhavan parāsurās | yasyaivaṃ viduṣo 'gniṃ dūtaṃ vṛṇīmaha ity anvāha bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyo bhavati |
column2: 'Thee with the kindlingsticks, Angiras', he says; verily he generates light in the Samidhenis. They are feminine in that they are Rc (verses), they are feminine in that they are Gayatri (verses), they are feminine in that they are Samidhenis.

column1: adhvaravatīm anv āha bhrātṛvyam evaitayā |
column2: He repeats a verse with the word 'Male' in it [4].

column1: dhvarati śociṣkeśas tam īmaha ity āha pavitram evaitat |
column2: verily by it he causes his enemy to perish [5]. 'The flaming locked, him we adore', he says;

column1: yajamānam evaitayā pavayati samiddho agna āhutety āha paridhim evaitam pari dadhāty askandāya yad ata ūrdhvam abhyādadhyād yathā bahiḥparidhi skandati tādṛg eva tat trayo vā agnayo havyavāhano devānāṃ kavyavāhanaḥ pitṝṇāṃ saharakṣā asurāṇām |
column2: verily with it he makes pure the sacrificer. 'Thou art lit, O Agni, worshipped', he says; verily he places around a barrier that may not be climbed. If he were to add anything further, it would be just as when (a libation) falls outside the barriers. There are three Agnis, the oblation bearer of the gods, the bearer of the offering of the Pitrs, the guardian of the Asuras.

column1: ta etarhy ā śaṃsante māṃ variṣyate mām |
column2: They repeat, 'Me will he choose, me' [6].

column1: iti vṛṇīdhvaṃ havyavāhanam ity āha ya eva devānāṃ taṃ vṛṇīte |
column2: 'Choose ye the bearer of the oblation', he says; 'let him choose him who is of the gods.

column1: ārṣeyaṃ vṛṇīte bandhor eva naiti |
column2: verily he departs not from the connexion, (and so it serves) for continuity.

column1: atho saṃtatyai parastād arvāco vṛṇīte tasmāt parastād arvāñco manuṣyān pitaro 'nu pra pipate |
column2: He chooses, beginning at the further end, in order of descent; therefore the Pitrs drink after men in order of descent, beginning at the further end.

column1: agne mahāṃ asīty āha mahān hy eṣa yad agnis |
column2: 'O Agni, thou art great', he says, for Agni is great.

column1: brāhmaṇety āha brāhmaṇo hy {eṣa < eṣas} bhāratety āhaiṣa hi devebhyo havyam bharati deveddha ity āha devā hy etam aindhata manviddha ity āha manur hy etam uttaro devebhya ainddha |
column2: 'O Brahman', he says, for he is a Brahman. 'O Bharata',' he says, for he bears the sacrifice to the gods. 'Kindled by the gods', he says, for the gods kindled him. 'Kindled by Manu', he says, for Manu kindled him after the gods.

column1: ṛṣiṣṭuta ity āharṣayo hy etam astuvan viprānumadita ity āha | viprā hy ete yac chuśruvāṃsaḥ kaviśasta ity āha kavayo hy ete yac chuśruvāṃsas |
column2: 'Praised by the Rsis', he says, for the Rsis praised him. 'Rejoiced in by sages', he says [1], for learned people are sages. 'Celebrated by the poets', he says, for learned people are the poets.

column1: brahmasaṃśita ity āha brahmasaṃśito hy {eṣa < eṣas} ghṛtāhavana ity āha ghṛtāhutir hy asya priyatamā praṇīr yajñānām ity āha praṇīr hy eṣa yajñānām |
column2: 'Quickened by the holy power (Brahman)', he says, for he is quickened by the holy power (Brahman). 'With ghee offering', he says, for ghee is his dearest offering. 'Leader of the sacrifices', he says, for he is the leader of the sacrifices.

column1: rathīr adhvarāṇām ity āhaiṣa hi devarathas |
column2: 'Charioteer of the rites', he says, for he is the chariot of the gods.

column1: atūrto hotety āha na hy etaṃ kaś cana |
column2: 'The Hotr unsurpassed', he says, for no one surpasses him [2].

column1: tarati tūrṇir havyavāḍ ity āha sarvaṃ hy eṣa tarati |
column2: 'Surpassing, bearing the oblation', he says, for he surpasses all.

column1: āspātraṃ juhūr devānām ity āha juhūr hy eṣa devānām | camaso devapāna ity āha camaso hy eṣa devapānas |
column2: 'The mouth dish, the ladle of the gods', he says, for he is the ladle of the gods. 'The bowl from which the gods drink', he says, for he is the bowl from which the gods drink.

column1: arāṃ ivāgne nemir devāṃs tvam paridhūr asīty āha devān hy eṣa paribhūs |
column2: 'O Agni, like a felly the spokes, thou dost surround the gods', he says, for he surrounds the gods.

column1: ā vaha devān devayate yajamānāyeti bhrātṛvyam asmai | janayet | ā vaha devān yajamānāyety āha yajamānam evaitena vardhayati |
column2: If he were to say, 'Bring hither the gods to the pious sacrificer', he would produce an enemy for him [3].2 'Bring hither the gods to the sacrificer', he says;

column1: agnim agna ā vaha somam ā vahety āha devatā eva tad yathāpūrvam upa hvayate |
column2: 'O Agni, bring Agni hither, bring Soma hither', he says; verily he summons the gods in order. 'Bring hither the gods, O Agni;

column1: ā cāgne devān vaha suyajā ca yaja jātaveda ity āha |
column2: and sacrifice to them with a fair sacrifice, O Jatavedas', he says;

column1: agnim eva tat saṃ śyati so 'sya saṃśito devebhyo havyaṃ vahati |
column2: verily he quickens Agni, and quickened by him he bears the oblation to the gods.

column1: agnir hotā | ity āha |
column2: 'Agni the Hotr' [4], he says;

column1: agnir vai devānāṃ hotā ya eva devānāṃ hotā taṃ vṛṇīte smo vayam ity āhātmānam eva sattvaṃ gamayati sādhu te yajamāna devatety āhāśiṣam evaitām ā śāste yad brūyāt |
column2: Agni is the Hotr of the gods; him he chooses who is the Hotr of the gods. 'We are', he says; verily he makes himself attain reality. 'Fair be to thee the deity, O sacrificer', he says;

column1: yo 'gniṃ hotāram avṛthā ity agnino 'bhayato yajamānam pari gṛhṇīyāt pramāyukaḥ syāt |
column2: If he were to say 'Who hast chosen Agni as Hotr', he would surround the sacrificer with Agni on both sides, and he would be liable to perish.

column1: yajamānadevatyā vai juhūr bhrātṛvyadevatyo 'pabhṛt |
column2: The ladle has the sacrificer for its deity, the Upabhrt the enemy as its deity [5].

column1: yad dve iva brūyād bhrātṛvyam asmai janayet |
column2: If he were to say two as it were, he would produce an enemy for him.

column1: ghṛtavatīm adhvaryo srucam āsyasvety āha yajamānam evaitena vardhayati devāyuvam ity āha devān hy eṣāvati viśvavārām ity āha viśvaṃ hy eṣāvati |
column2: 'Take, Adhvaryu, the spoon (sruc) with ghee', he says; verily by it he causes the sacrificer to wax great. 'Pious', he says, for he aids the gods, 'With all boons', he says, for he aids all. 'Let us praise the gods worthy of praise;

column1: īḍāmahai devāṃ īḍenyān namasyāma vā īḍenyāḥ pitaro namasyā devā yajñiyās |
column2: Those worthy of praise are men; those worthy of honour are the Pitrs; those worthy of sacrifice are the gods;

column1: devatā eva tad yathābhāgaṃ yajati |
column2: verily he sacrifices to the deities according to their portions.

column1: {F trīṃs}{W trīṃs}{GLOS trīṃs} tṛcān anu brūyād rājanyasya trayo vā anye rājanyāt puruṣā brāhmaṇo vaiśyaḥ śūdras tān evāsmā anukān karoti pañcadaśānu brūyād rājanyasya pañcadaśo vai rājanyaḥ sva evainaṃ stome prati ṣṭhāpayati tṛṣṭubhā pari dadhyāt |
column2: In the case of a Rajanya let him repeat the Trcas thrice three other sorts of men are there besides the warrior, the Brahman, Vaiçya and Çudra; verily he makes them obedient to him. He should repeat fifteen (Samidhenis) in the case of a Rajanya; the Rajanya is fifteenfold; verily he makes him find support in his own Stoma.

column1: indriyaṃ vai {triṣṭug < triṣṭubh} indriyakāmaḥ khalu vai rājanyo yajate triṣṭubhaivāsmā indriyam pari gṛhṇāti yadi kāmayeta | brahmavarcasam astv iti gāyatriyā pari dadhyāt |
column2: Let him surround it with a Tristubh; the Tristubh is power, the Rajanya sacrifices in desire of power; verily by the Tristubh he secures power for him. If he desires [1], 'May there be splendour', he should surround it with a Gayatri, the Gayatri is splendour;

column1: brahmavarcasaṃ vai gāyatrī brahmavarcasam eva bhavati saptadaśānu brūyād vaiśyasya saptadaśo vai vaiśyaḥ sva evainaṃ stome prati ṣṭhāpayati jagatyā pari dadhyāt |
column2: He should repeat seventeen for a Vaiçya; the Vaiçya is seventeenfold; verily he makes him find support in his own Stoma. He should surround it with a Jagati;

column1: jāgatā vai paśavaḥ paśukāmaḥ khalu vai vaiśyo yajate jagatyaivāsmai paśūn pari gṛhṇāti |
column2: cattle are connected with the Jagati, the Vaiçya sacrifices in desire of cattle; verily by the Jagati he secures cattle for him.

column1: ekaviṃśatim anu brūyāt pratiṣṭhākāmasya |
column2: He should repeat twenty one for one who desires support;

column1: ekaviṃśa stomānām pratiṣṭhā pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: the Ekavinça is the support of the Stomas; (verily twenty-one serve) for support [2].

column1: caturviṃśatim anu brūyād brahmavarcasakāmasya caturviṃśatyakṣarā gāyatrī gāyatrī brahmavarcasam |
column2: He should repeat twenty-four for one who desires splendour: the Gayatri has twenty-four syllables, splendour is the Gayatri;

column1: gāyatriyaivāsmai brahmavarcasam ava runddhe triṃśatam anu brūyād annakāmasya triṃśadakṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājaivāsmā annādyam ava runddhe dvātriṃśatam anubrūyāt pratiṣṭhākāmasya {dvātriṃśadakṣarānuṣṭug < dvātriṃśadakṣarānuṣṭubh} anuṣṭup chandasām pratiṣṭhā pratiṣṭhityai ṣaṭtriṃśatam anu brūyāt paśukāmasya ṣaṭtriṃśadakṣarā bṛhatī bārhatāḥ paśavas |
column2: He should repeat thirty-two, for one who desires support; the Anustubh has thirty-two syllables, the Anustubh is the support of the metres; (verily thirty-two serve) for support. He should repeat thirty-six for one who desires cattle; the Brhati has thirty-six syllables, cattle are connected with the Brhati;

column1: bṛhatyaivāsmai paśūn |
column2: verily by the Brhati he secures cattle for him [3].

column1: ava runddhe catuścatvāriṃśatam anu brūyād indriyakāmasya catuścatvāriṃśadakṣarā {triṣṭug < triṣṭubh} indriyaṃ {triṣṭup < triṣṭubh} triṣṭubhaivāsmā indriyam ava runddhe |
column2: He should repeat forty-four for one who desires power, the Tristubh has forty-four syllables, the Tristubh is power; verily by the Tristubh he secures power for him.

column1: aṣṭācatvāriṃśatam anu brūyāt paśukāmasya |
column2: He should repeat forty-eight for one who desires cattle;

column1: aṣṭācatvariṃśadakṣarā jagatī jāgatāḥ paśavas |
column2: the Jagati has forty-eight syllables, cattle are connected with the Jagati;

column1: jagatyaivāsmai paśūn ava runddhe sarvāṇi chandāṃsy anu brūyād bahuyājinaḥ sarvāṇi vā etasya chandāṃsy avarunddhāni yo bahuyājī |
column2: verily with the Jagati he secures cattle for him. He should repeat all the metres for one who makes many sacrifices, for all the metres are won by him who makes many sacrifices.

column1: aparimitam anu brūyāt | aparimitasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: He should repeat indefinitely to win that which is not definite.

column1: nivītam manuṣyāṇām prācīnāvītam pitṝṇām upavītaṃ devānām upa vyayate devalakṣmam eva tat kurute tiṣṭhann anv āha tiṣṭhan hy āśrutataraṃ vadati tiṣṭhann anv āha suvargasya lokasyābhijityai |
column2: The thread is worn around the neck for men, over the right shoulder for the Pitrs, over the left for the gods. He puts it over the left shoulder; verily he makes the mark of the gods. He repeats standing, for standing he speaks more audibly. He repeats standing, to conquer the world of heaven.

column1: āsīno yajati |
column2: He sacrifices sitting;

column1: asminn eva loke prati tiṣṭhati yat krauñcam anvāhāsuraṃ tat | yan mandram mānuṣaṃ tat | yad antarā tat sadevam antarānūcyam |
column2: verily he finds support in this world. In that he repeats in the Krauñca, note, that is connected with the Asuras, in the low note, that is connected with men, in the intermediate note, that is connected with the gods.

column1: sadevatvāya vidvāṃso vai |
column2: One should repeat in the intermediate note, to secure the gods.

column1: purā hotāro 'bhūvan tasmād vidhṛtā adhvāno 'bhūvan na panthānaḥ sam arukṣan |
column2: Clever indeed [1] were the Hotrs of old; there fore the ways were held apart, and the paths did not conflict.

column1: antarvedy anyaḥ pādo bhavati bahirvedy anyas |
column2: One foot should be within the sacrificial altar, the other outside;

column1: athānv āha | adhvanāṃ vidhṛtyai pathām asaṃrohāya |
column2: then he repeats, to hold the ways apart and to avoid conflict of the paths.

column1: atho parimitaṃ caivāparimitaṃ cāva runddhe | atho grāmyāṃś caiva paśūn āraṇyāṃś cāva runddhe | atho |
column2: Then does he win the past and the future, the measured and the unmeasured does he win, domestic and wild cattle both does he win [2];

column1: devalokaṃ caiva manuṣyalokaṃ cābhi jayati devā vai sāmidhenīr anūcya yajñaṃ nānv apaśyan |
column2: verily also the world of the gods and the world of men he conquers. The gods having repeated the Samidhenis could not see the sacrifice.

column1: sa prajāpatis tūṣṇīm āghāram āghārayat tato vai devā yajñam anv apaśyan yat tūṣṇīm āghāram āghārayati yajñasyānukhyātyai |
column2: Prajapati in silence performed the sprinkling of the butter. Then indeed did the gods see the sacrifice. In that he silently sprinkles, (it serves) to light up the sacrifice.

column1: atho sāmidhenīr evābhy anakti |
column2: Verily also he anoints the kindling-sticks.

column1: alūkṣo bhavati ya evaṃ veda |
column2: He who knows thus becomes soft.

column1: ya evaṃ veda yad ekayāghārayed ekām prīṇīyāt |
column2: He delights in offspring and cattle [3] who knows thus. If he were to sprinkle with one (verse), he would delight one;

column1: yad dvābhyāṃ dve prīṇīyāt |
column2: if with two, (he would delight) two;

column1: yat tisṛbhir ati tad recayet |
column2: if with three, he would make (the offering) go beyond (all others).

column1: manasā ghārayati manasā hy anāptam āpyate tiryañcam ā ghārayaty achambaṭkāram |

column2: The gods said to him, 'The oblation is the sacrifice; let us have a share in it.' He said, 'Lot them offer to you the portions of the oblation, let them pour out (a layer), let them sprinkle (it).' Therefore they offer the portions of the oblation, they pour out (a layer), and sprinkle (it). The theologians say, 'For what reason are the other offerings worn out, but the oblation fresh?' He should reply, 'Because it is Prajapati's [1], for Prajapati is of the gods the fresh one.' The metres ran away from the gods (saying), 'We will not bear the offering, if we have no share.' They kept for them (the offering) divided into four parts, for the Puronuvakya, the Yajya, the deity, the Vasat call. In that he offers (the offering) in four parts, he delights the metres, and they delighted by him carry the offering to the gods.

After anointing it above, he anoints it below, to gain the world of heaven. He spreads (the cake) on all the fragments; so many cakes does he conquer in yonder world. That which is burnt belongs to Nirrti, that which is not cooked to Rudra, that which is cooked to the gods. Therefore one should cook it, without burning it, for the gods.

He sprinkles it before covering it; verily he makes it go among the gods. If one fragment were lost, one month of the year would be omitted, and the sacrificer would perish. If two were lost, two months of the year would be omitted, and the sacrificer would perish.
