column1: uśann uśata ā vaha pit ṝn haviṣe attave |
column2: Eager bring the eager, The fathers, to eat the offering.

column1: tvaṃ soma pracikito manīṣā tvaṃ rajiṣṭham anu neṣi panthām |
column2: Thou, O Soma, art pre-eminent in wisdom; Thou movest along the straightest path;

column1: tava praṇītī pitaro na indo deveṣu ratnam abhajanta dhīrāḥ |
column2: Through thy guidance, O drop, our fathers wisely divided The treasure among the gods.

column1: tvayā hi naḥ pitaraḥ soma pūrve karmāṇi cakruḥ pavamāna dhīrāḥ |
column2: By thee, O Soma Pavamana, our ancient fathers Wisely ordained the offerings;

column1: vanvann avātaḥ paridhīṃr aporṇu vīrebhir aśvair maghavā bhava | naḥ |
column2: Conquering, untroubled, do thou open the barriers; Be generous to us in heroes and horses [1].

column1: tvaṃ soma pitṛbhiḥ saṃvidāno 'nu dyāvāpṛthivī ā tatantha |
column2: Thou, O Soma, in accord with the fathers, Hast stretched over sky and earth;

column1: tasmai ta indo haviṣā vidhema vayaṃ syāma patayo rayīṇām |
column2: To thee, O drop, let us make sacrifice with offering; Let us be lords of wealth.

column1: agniṣvāttāḥ pitara eha gachata sadaḥsadaḥ sadata supraṇītayaḥ |
column2: O fathers, made ready by Agni, come hither; With good leadership sit ye on each seat;

column1: attā havīṃṣi prayatāni barhiṣy athā rayiṃ sarvavīraṃ dadhātana |
column2: Eat ye the offerings set out on the strew; And give us wealth with many heroes.

column1: barhiṣadaḥ pitara ūty arvāg imā vo havyā cakṛmā juṣadhvam |
column2: O fathers that sit on the sacrificial strew, come hither with your aid;

column1: śaṃ yor arapo dadhāta |
column2: We have made these offerings for you;

column1: āham pit ṝnt suvidatrāṃ avitsi napātaṃ ca vikramaṇaṃ ca viṣṇoḥ | barhiṣado ye svadhayā sutasya bhajanta pitvas ta ihāgamiṣṭhāḥ |
column2: I have found the kindly fathers, The scion and the step of Visnu; They that sit on the sacrificial strew and enjoy the drink That is pressed for them with the Svadha call are most eager to come hither.

column1: upahūtāḥ pitaraḥ somyāso barhiṣyeṣu nidhiṣu priyeṣu |
column2: Invoked are the fathers who love the Soma To their dear homes on the sacrificial strew;

column1: ta ā gamantu ta iha śruvantv adhi bruvantu te avantv asmān |
column2: May they come hither; may they hear us here May they speak for us; and may they aid us.

column1: ud īratām avara ut parāsa un madhyamāḥ pitaraḥ somyāsaḥ |
column2: Let them arise, the lower and the higher And the middle fathers who love the Soma;

column1: ya īyur avṛkā ṛtajñās te no 'vantu pitaro haveṣu | idam pitṛbhyo namo astv adya ye pūrvāso ya uparās īyuḥ |
column2: They who lived their lives [3] in goodness and without sin; May these fathers help us when we call. Be this homage to-day to the fathers, Who went before and who went after;

column1: ye pārthive rajasy ā niṣattā ye vā nūnaṃ suvṛjanāsu vikṣu |
column2: Who are seated in the earthly region Or who are now in abodes with fair dwellings.

column1: adhā yathā naḥ pitaraḥ parāsaḥ pratnāso agna ṛtam āśuṣāṇāḥ | śucīd ayan dīdhitim ukthaśāsaḥ kṣāmā bhindanto aruṇīr apa vran |
column2: As our fathers before, Of old, O Agni, furthering right, Sought the pure, the devotion, singing hymns Cleaving the earth they disclosed the red ones.

column1: yad agne | kavyavāhana pit ṝn yakṣy ṛtāvṛdhaḥ | pra ca havyāni vakṣyasi devebhyaś ca pitṛbhya ā |
column2: When, O Agni [4], bearer of oblations, Thou sacrificest to the righteous fathers, Thou shalt bear the oblations To the gods and to the fathers.

column1: tvam agna īḍito jātavedo 'vāḍ ḍhavyāni surabhīṇi kṛtvā |
column2: Thou, O Agni, praised, all-knower, Didst carry the offerings making them fragrant;

column1: prādāḥ pitṛbhyaḥ svadhayā te akṣann addhi tvaṃ deva prayatā havīṃṣi |
column2: Thou didst give them to the fathers who ate them at the Svadha call; Eat thou, O god, the offerings set before thee.

column1: mātalī kavyair yamo aṅgirobhir bṛhaspatir ṛkvabhir vāvṛdhānaḥ | yāṃś ca devā vāvṛdhur ye ca devānt svāhānye svadhayānye madanti |
column2: Matali with the Kavyas, Yama with the Angirases, Brhaspati rejoicing with the Rkvans, Those whom the gods magnified and those who magnified the gods; Some in the Svaha call, some in the Svadha rejoice [5].

column1: imaṃ yama prastaram ā hi sīdāṅgirobhiḥ pitṛbhiḥ saṃvidānaḥ | ā tvā mantrāḥ kaviśastā vahantv enā rājan haviṣā mādayasva |
column2: Sit on this strew, O Yama, In accordance with the Angirases, the fathers Let the verses made by the poets bring thee hither Rejoice, O king, in this offering.

column1: aṅgirobhir ā gahi yajñiyebhir yama vairūpair iha mādayasva |
column2: Come with the Angirases who deserve the sacrifice Yama, rejoice here with the Vairupas;

column1: vivasvantaṃ huve yaḥ pitā te 'smin yajñe barhiṣy ā niṣadya |
column2: summon Virasvant who is thy father, Sitting down on the strew at this sacrifice.

column1: aṅgiraso naḥ pitaro navagvā atharvāṇo bhṛgavaḥ somyāsaḥ |
column2: The Angirases, our fathers, the Navagvas, Atharvans, Bhrgus, who love the Soma;

column1: teṣāṃ vayaṃ sumatau yajñiyānām api bhadre saumanase syāma |
column2: May we be in the favour of those ones worthy of sacrifice, May we have their kindly good will.

column1: prajāpatir akāmayata prajāḥ sṛjeyeti sa tapo 'tapyata sa sarpān asṛjata so 'kāmayata prajāḥ sṛjeyeti sa dvitīyam atapyata sa vayāṃsy asṛjata so 'kāmayata prajāḥ sṛjeyeti sa tṛtīyam atapyata sa etaṃ dīkṣitavādam apaśyat tam avadat tato vai sa prajā asṛjata yat tapas taptvā dīkṣitavādaṃ vadati prajā eva tad yajamānaḥ |
column2: The Supplement to the Soma Sacrifice Prajapati desired, 'May I create offspring.' He did penance, he created serpents. He desired, 'May I create offspring.' He did penance a second time, he created birds. He desired, 'May I create offspring.' He did penance a third time, he saw this speech of the consecrated, he spoke it. Then indeed did he create offspring. In that after undergoing penance he speaks the speech of the consecrated, the sacrificer thus [1] creates offspring.

column1: sṛjate yad vai dīkṣito 'medhyam paśyaty apāsmād dīkṣā krāmati nīlam asya haro vy eti |
column2: If one who is consecrated sees anything impure, the consecration departs from him; his dark colour, his beauty goes away.

column1: abaddham mano daridraṃ cakṣuḥ sūryo jyotiṣāṃ śreṣṭho dīkṣe mā mā hāsīs |
column2: 'Mind unbound; eye weak; sun best of lights;

column1: ity āha nāsmād dīkṣāpa krāmati nāsya nīlaṃ na haro vy eti yad vai dīkṣitam abhivarṣati divyā āpo 'śāntā ojo balaṃ dīkṣām | tapo 'sya nir ghnanti |
column2: O consecration, forsake me not', he says, and consecration departs not from him, his dark colour and his beauty go not away. If rain falls on one who is consecrated, the heavenly waters if unappeased destroy his force, might, consecration [2], and penance.

column1: undatīr balaṃ dhattaujo dhatta balaṃ dhatta mā me dīkṣām mā tapo nir vadhiṣṭa | ity āha |
column2: 'Do ye flowing waters place might (in me), place force, place might; do not destroy my consecration, nor my penance', he says;

column1: etad eva sarvam ātman dhatte nāsyaujo balaṃ na dīkṣāṃ na tapo nir ghnanti |
column2: verily he places all that in himself; they do not destroy his force, might, consecration, or penance.

column1: agnir vai dīkṣitasya devatā so 'smād etarhi tira iva yarhi yāti tam īśvaraṃ rakṣāṃsi hantoḥ |
column2: Agni is the divinity of the consecrated man, and he is concealed as it were from him, when he goes (out), and the Raksases are able to hurt him [3].

column1: bhadrād abhi śreyaḥ prehi bṛhaspatiḥ puraetā te astv ity āha brahma vai devānām bṛhaspatis tam evānvārabhate sa enaṃ sam pārayati |
column2: 'From good to better do thou advance; may Brhaspati be thy forerunner', he says. Brhaspati is the holy power (Brahman) of the gods; verily he grasps hold of him, and he brings him safely through.

column1: edam aganma devayajanam pṛthivyā ity āha devayajanaṃ hy eṣa pṛthivyā āgachati yo yajate viśve devā yad ajuṣanta pūrva ity āha viśve hy etad devā joṣayante yad brāhmaṇā ṛkṣāmābhyāṃ yajuṣā saṃtaranta ity āha |
column2: 'Here we have come (aidam) to the place on earth for sacrifice to the gods', he says, for he comes to the place on earth for sacrifice, who sacrifices. 'Wherein aforetime all the gods rejoiced', he says, for all the gods delight in it, in that the Brahmans so do.

column1: ṛksāmābhyāṃ hy eṣa yajuṣā saṃtarati yo yajate rāyas poṣeṇa sam iṣā mademety āhāśiṣam evaitām ā śāste |
column2: 'Accomplishing (the rite) with Rc, Saman, and Yajus', he says, for he who sacrifices accomplishes (the rite) with Rc, Saman, and Yajus.

column1: eṣa te gāyatro bhāga iti me somāya brūtāt |
column2: 'This is thy Gayatri part', say for me to Soma.

column1: eṣa te traiṣṭubho jāgato bhāga iti me somāya brūtāt |
column2: 'This is thy Tristubh, Jagati, part', say for me to Soma.

column1: chandomānāṃ sāmrājyaṃ gacheti me somāya brūtāt |
column2: 'Become lord of the Chandomas', say for me to Soma.

column1: yo vai somaṃ rājānaṃ sāmrājyaṃ lokaṃ gamayitvā krīṇāti gachati svānāṃ sāmrājyaṃ chandāṃsi khalu vai somasya rājñaḥ sāmrājyo lokaḥ purastāt somasya krayād evam abhi mantrayeta sāmrājyam eva |
column2: He who purchases King Soma after making it go to the world of lordship, becomes lord of his own (people). The world of lordship of King Soma is the metres; he should utter these verses before the purchase of Soma.

column1: enaṃ lokaṃ gamayitvā krīṇāti gachati svānāṃ sāmrājyam yo vai tānūnaptrasya pratiṣṭhāṃ veda praty eva tiṣṭhati brahmavādino vadanti na prāśnanti na juhvaty atha kva tānūnaptram prati tiṣṭhatīti prajāpatau manasīti brūyāt trir ava jighret prajāpatau tvā manasi juhomi |
column2: It is to the world of lordship that he makes it go when he buys (Soma) [1], and he becomes lord of his own. He, who knows the support of the Tanunaptra finds support. The theologians say, 'They do not eat, nor offer; then where does the Tanunaptra find support?' 'In Prajapati, in the mind, he should reply. He should smell at it thrice, (saying), 'In Prajapati thee, in the mind I offer';

column1: ity eṣā vai tānūnaptrasya pratiṣṭhā ya evaṃ veda praty eva tiṣṭhati yaḥ |
column2: this indeed is the support of the Tanunaptra; he who knows thus finds support.

column1: vā adhvaryoḥ pratiṣṭhāṃ veda praty eva tiṣṭhati yato manyetānabhikramya hoṣyāmīti tat tiṣṭhann ā śrāvayet eṣā vā adhvaryoḥ pratiṣṭhā ya evaṃ veda praty eva tiṣṭhati yad abhikramya juhuyāt pratiṣṭhāyā iyāt tasmāt samānatra tiṣṭhatā hotavyam pratiṣṭhityai yo vā adhvaryoḥ svaṃ veda svavān eva bhavati srug vā asya svaṃ vāyavyam asya |
column2: This is the support of the Adhvaryu; he who knows thus finds support. If he were to sacrifice moving about, he would lose his support; therefore he should sacrifice standing in the same place, for support. He who knows the possession of the Adhvaryu, becomes possessed (of what he needs).

column1: svaṃ camaso 'sya svaṃ yad vāyavyaṃ vā camasaṃ vānanvārabhyāśrāvayet svād iyāt tasmād anvārabhyāśrāvyaṃ svād eva naiti yo vai somam apratiṣṭhāpya stotram upākaroty apratiṣṭhitaḥ somo bhavaty apratiṣṭhitaḥ stomo 'pratiṣṭhitāny ukthāny apratiṣṭhito yajamāno 'pratiṣṭhito 'dhvaryus |
column2: If he were to call without holding the Vayu cup or the beaker, he would lose his own; therefore he must hold it when he calls; verily he loses not his own. If he begins the litany without placing the Soma," the Soma is not supported, the Stoma is not supported, the hymns are not supported, the sacrificer is not supported, the Adhvaryu is not supported.

column1: vāyavyaṃ vai somasya pratiṣṭhā camaso 'sya pratiṣṭhā somaḥ stomasya stoma ukthānāṃ grahaṃ vā gṛhītvā camasaṃ vonnīya stotram upākuryāt praty eva somaṃ sthāpayati prati stomam praty ukthāni prati yajamānas tiṣṭhati praty adhvaryuḥ |
column2: The support of the Soma is the Vayu cup, the support of it is the beaker, (the support) of the Stoma is Soma, (the support) of the hymns is the Stoma. He should grasp the cup or fill up the beaker, and then begin the litany; a support to the Soma he verily (eva) gives, to the Stoma, to the hymns; the sacrificer finds support, the Adhvaryu finds support.

column1: yajñaṃ vā etat sam bharanti yat somakrayaṇyai padam |
column2: They gather together the sacrifice when (they gather the dust of) the foot-print of the Soma cow;

column1: yajñamukhaṃ havirdhāne yarhi havirdhāne prācī pravartayeyus tarhi tenākṣam upāñjyāt |
column2: the oblation-holders are the mouth of the sacrifice; when they move forward the oblation-holders, then he should oil the axle with it;

column1: yajñamukha eva yajñam anu saṃ tanoti prāñcam agnim pra haranty ut patnīm ā nayanty anv anāṃsi pra vartayanti |
column2: verily he extends the sacrifice in the mouth of the sacrifice. They lead Agni forward, they take the wife forward, and they make the carts follow after.

column1: atha vā asyaiṣa dhiṣṇiyo hīyate so 'nu dhyāyati sa īśvaro rudro bhūtvā | prajām paśūn yajamānasya śamayitos |
column2: Now the altar of him (Agni) is deserted; he broods on it, and is liable to become terrible (rudrá) [1], and lay to rest the offspring and cattle of the sacrificer.

column1: yarhi paśum āprītam udañcaṃ nayanti tarhi tasya paśuśrapaṇaṃ haret tenaivainam bhāginaṃ karoti yajamāno vā āhavanīyas |
column2: When they are leading northward the sacrificial animal over which the Apris have been said, he should take (from the altar the fire) for cooking it; verily he makes him share in it.

column1: yajamānaṃ vā etad vi karṣante yad āhavanīyāt paśuśrapaṇaṃ haranti sa vaiva syān nirmanthyaṃ vā kuryād yajamānasya sātmatvāya yadi paśor avadānaṃ naśyed ājyasya pratyākhyāyam ava dyet saiva tataḥ prāyaścittis |
column2: The Ahavaniya is the sacrificer; if they take (the fire) for cooking the victim from the Ahavaniya, they tear the sacrificer asunder; the fire should therefore be thus, or he should make it by friction, so that the sacrificer's body may remain together. If a portion of the victim be lost, he should cut off an equivalent portion of the butter;

column1: ye paśuṃ vimathnīran yas tān kāmayeta |
column2: that is then the atonement.

column1: ārtim ārcheyur iti kuvid aṅgeti namovṛktivatyarcāgnīdhre juhuyāt | namovṛktim evaiṣāṃ vṛṅkte tājag ārtim ārchanti |
column2: If men disturb his victim and he wish of them, 'May they come to ruin', he should make an offering in the Agnidh's altar with the Rc containing the word 'paying of homage' (and beginning), 'What then?' Verily he appropriates their paying of homage and speedily do they go to ruin.

column1: prajāpater jāyamānāḥ prajā jātāś ca yā imāḥ |
column2: The offspring, being born of Prajapati And those that have been born, To him declare them;

column1: tasmai prati pra vedaya cikitvāṃ anu manyatām |
column2: Lot the wise one reflect thereon.

column1: imam paśum paśupate te adya badhnāmy agne sukṛtasya madhye | anu manyasva suyajā yajāma juṣṭaṃ devānām idam astu havyam |
column2: This victim, O lord of cattle, for thee to-day, bind, O Agni, in the midst of righteous action; Approve it, and let us sacrifice with a good offering May this offering be welcome to the gods.

column1: prajānantaḥ prati gṛhṇanti pūrve prāṇam aṅgebhyaḥ pary ācarantam |
column2: The ancient wise ones grasp The breath as it speedeth from the limbs;

column1: suvargaṃ yāhi pathibhir devayānair oṣadhīṣu prati tiṣṭhā śarīraiḥ |
column2: Go to heaven by the paths which lead to the gods; Be among the plants with thy members.

column1: yeṣām īśe | paśupatiḥ paśūnāṃ catuṣpadām uta ca dvipadām | niṣkrīto 'yaṃ yajñiyam bhāgam etu rāyas poṣā yajamānasya santu |
column2: What cattle the lord of cattle ruleth [1], Both the four-footed and the two-footed, May he, bought off, go to his sacrificial share; May abundances of wealth fall to the sacrificer.

column1: ye badhyamānam anu badhyamānā abhyaikṣanta manasā cakṣuṣā ca | agnis tāṃ agre pra mumoktu devaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajayā saṃvidānaḥ |
column2: Those, who being bound, contemplated With mind and with eye him who was being bound Let the god Agni first release them, Lord of offspring, in harmony with offspring.

column1: ya āraṇyāḥ paśavo viśvarūpā virūpāḥ santo bahudhaikarūpāḥ |
column2: The cattle of the forest, of all forms, Of various forms, many of one form.

column1: vāyus tāṃ agre pra mumoktu devaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajayā saṃvidānaḥ |
column2: Let the god Vayu first release them, Lord of offspring, in harmony with offspring.

column1: bhuvanasya reto gātuṃ dhatta yajamānāya devāḥ | upākṛtaṃ śaśamānaṃ yad asthāj jīvaṃ devānām apy etu pāthāḥ |
column2: Releasing [2] the seed of being, Do ye further the sacrificer, O gods; May that which hath stood ready and strenuous, Go alive to the place of the gods.

column1: nānā prāṇo yajamānasya paśunā yajño devebhiḥ saha devayānaḥ |
column2: The breath of the sacrificer is apart from the victim; The sacrifice goeth to the gods with the gods;

column1: jīvaṃ devānām apy etu pāthaḥ satyāḥ santu yajamānasya kāmāḥ |
column2: Let it go alive to the place of the gods; Fulfilled may the desires of the sacrificer be.

column1: yat paśur māyum akṛtoro vā padbhir āhate | agnir mā tasmād enaso viśvān muñcatv aṃhasaḥ |
column2: If the victim has uttered a cry, Or striketh its breast with its feet, May Agni release me from that sin, From all misfortune.

column1: śamitāra upetana yajñam | devebhir invitam |
column2: O ye slayers, come To the sacrifice [3] sped by the gods;

column1: pāśāt paśum pra muñcata bandhād yajñapatim pari |
column2: Free the victim from the noose, The lord of the sacrifice from the bond.

column1: aditiḥ pāśam pra mumoktv etaṃ namaḥ paśubhyaḥ paśupataye karomi |
column2: May Aditi loosen this noose; Homage to the cattle, to the lord of cattle, I pay;

column1: arātīyantam adharaṃ kṛṇomi yaṃ dviṣmas tasmin prati muñcāmi pāśam |
column2: cast down the enemy; On him whom we hate I fasten the noose.

column1: tvām u te dadhire havyavāhaṃ śṛtaṃkartāram uta yajñiyaṃ ca | agne sadakṣaḥ satanur hi bhūtvātha havyā jātavedo juṣasva |
column2: Thee they keep to carry the offering, To cook (the victim) and as worthy of sacrifice; 0 Agni, with thy strength and thy body, be present And accept our offerings, O Jatavedas.

column1: jātavedo vapayā gacha devān tvaṃ hi hotā prathamo babhūtha |
column2: O Jatavedas, go with the caul to the gods, For thou art the first Hotr;

column1: ghṛtena tvaṃ tanuvo vardhayasva svāhākṛtaṃ havir adantu devāḥ |
column2: With ghee do thou strengthen their bodies; May the gods eat the offering made with the cry of 'hail!

column1: svāhā devebhyo devebhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: Hail to the gods; to the gods hail!

column1: pājāpatyā vai paśavas teṣāṃ rudro 'dhipatis |
column2: Cattle belong to Prajapati; their overlord is Rudra.

column1: yad etābhyām upākaroti tābhyām evainam pratiprocyā labhata ātmano 'nāvraskāya dvābhyām upākaroti dvipād yajamānaḥ pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: In that he prepares (them) with these two (verses), verily by addressing him with them he secures him, so that his self is not injured. He prepares (them) with two; the sacrificer has two feet;

column1: upākṛtya pañca juhoti pāṅktāḥ paśavaḥ paśūn evāva runddhe mṛtyave vā eṣa nīyate yat paśus taṃ yad anvārabheta pramāyuko yajamānaḥ syāt |
column2: Having prepared them, he offers five libations; cattle are fivefold; I verily he wins cattle. Now the victim is led to death, and if he should lay hold on it, the sacrificer would be likely to die.

column1: nānā prāṇo yajamānasya paśunety āha vyāvṛttyai |
column2: ' The breath of the sacrifice is apart from the victim', he says, for distinction [1].

column1: yat paśur māyum akṛteti juhoti śāntyai śamitāra upetanety āha yathāyajur evaitat |
column2: 'If the victim has uttered a cry'--(with these words) he offers a libation, for calming. 'O ye slayers, come to the sacrifices', he says; that is according to the text.

column1: vapāyāṃ vā āhriyamāṇāyām agner medho 'pa krāmati tvām u te dadhire havyavāham iti vapām abhi juhoti |
column2: When the omentum. is being taken, the strength goes away from Agni. 'Thee they keep to carry the offering'--(with these words) he pours a libation over the omentum;

column2: Ye that are in that world, may they follow you; ye that are in this world, may they follow me. Ye that are in that world, of them be ye the most fortunate; ye that are in this world, of these may be the most fortunate. O Prajapati, none other than thou Comprehendeth all these creatures [6].

column1: yatkāmās te juhumas tan no astu vayaṃ syāma patayo rayīṇām |
column2: What we seek when we sacrifice to thee, let that be ours; May we be lords of riches.

column1: devakṛtasyainaso 'vayajanam asi manuṣyakṛtasyainaso 'vayajanam asi pitṛkṛtasyainaso 'vayajanam asi |
column2: Thou art the expiation of sin committed by the gods, thou art the expiation of sin committed by men, thou art the expiation of sin committed by the fathers.

column1: apsu dhautasya soma deva te nṛbhiḥ sutasyeṣṭayajuṣa stutastomasya śastokthasya yo bhakṣo aśvasanir yo gosanis tasya te pitṛbhir bhakṣaṃkṛtasyopahūtasyopahūto bhakṣayāmi |
column2: Of thee, O god Soma, that art purified in the waters, that art pressed by men, over whom the Yajus is spoken, the Stoma sung, the Çastra recited, who art made by the fathers into food to win horses and cows, and who art invited, I invited eat.

column1: mahīnām payo 'si viśveṣāṃ devānāṃ tanūr ṛdhyāsam adya pṛṣatīnāṃ graham pṛṣatīnāṃ graho 'si viṣṇor hṛdayam asy ekam iṣa viṣṇus tvānu vi cakrame bhūtir dadhnā ghṛtena vardhatāṃ tasya meṣṭasya vītasya draviṇam ā gamyāj jyotir asi vaiśvānaram pṛśniyai dugdham |
column2: Thou art the milk of the great ones, the body of the All-gods; may I to-day accomplish the cup of the speckled ones; thou art the cup of the speckled ones; thou art the heart of Visnu, once hath Visnu stepped apart along thee, O vigorous one; with curds and ghee may prosperity be increased;

column1: yāvatī dyāvāpṛthivī mahitvā yāvac ca sapta sindhavo vitasthuḥ | tāvantam indra te | grahaṃ sahorjā gṛhṇāmy astṛtam |
column2: As great as are sky and earth in mightiness, As great as the expense of the seven rivers, So great is the cup of thee, O Indra [1], Which unvanquished I draw off with strength.

column1: yat kṛṣṇaśakunaḥ pṛṣadājyam avapṛśec chūdrā asya pramāyukāḥ syur yac chvāvamṛśec catuṣpādo 'sya paśavaḥ pramāyukāḥ syur yat skanded yajamānaḥ pramāyukaḥ syāt paśavo vai pṛṣadājyam paśavo vā etasya skandanti yasya pṛṣadājyaṃ skandati yat pṛṣadājyam punar gṛhṇāti paśūn evāsmai punar gṛhṇāti prāṇo vai pṛṣadājyam prāṇo vai |
column2: If a black bird touch the speckled butter, his slaves would be likely to die; if a dog touch it, his fourfooted cattle would be likely to die; if it were to be spilt, the sacrificer would be likely to die. The speckled butter is the cattle; his cattle fall, if his speckled butter falls;

column1: etasya skandati yasya pṛṣadājyaṃ skandati yat pṛṣadājyam punar gṛhṇāti prāṇam evāsmai punar gṛhṇāti hiraṇyam avadhāya gṛhṇāty amṛtaṃ vai hiraṇyam prāṇaḥ pṛṣadājyam amṛtam evāsya prāṇe dadhāti śatamānam bhavati śatāyuḥ puruṣaḥ śatendriya āyuṣy evendriye prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: in that he takes again the speckled butter, he takes again breath for him. He takes it after placing gold (in the ladle), gold is immortality, the speckled butter is the breath; verily he places immortality in his breath. It is of a hundred measures, man has a hundred years of life, a hundred powers; verily on life and power he rests.

column1: aśvam ava ghrāpayati prājāpatyo vā aśvaḥ prājāpatyaḥ prāṇaḥ svād evāsmai yoneḥ prāṇaṃ nir mimīte vi vā etasya yajñaś chidyate yasya pṛṣadājyaṃ skandati vaiṣṇavyarcā punar gṛhṇāti yajño vai viṣṇur yajñenaiva yajñaṃ saṃ tanoti |
column2: verily from his own place of origin he fashions offspring for him. His sacrifice is broken whose speckled butter is spilt. He takes it again with a Rc addressed to Visnu; Visnu is the sacrifice; verily he unites the sacrifice by the sacrifice.

column1: deva savitar etat te prāha tat pra ca suva pra ca yaja bṛhaspatir brahmā |
column2: O God Savitr, he hath declared that to thee; that do thou impel and offer. The Brahman is Brhaspati.

column1: āyuṣmatyā ṛco māgāta tanūpāt sāmnaḥ satyā va āśiṣaḥ santu satyā ākūtayas |
column2: Depart not from the life-giving Rc, from the Saman which protecteth the body.

column1: ṛtaṃ ca satyaṃ ca vadata stuta devasya savituḥ prasave stutasya stutam asy ūrjam mahyaṃ stutaṃ duhām ā mā stutasya stutaṃ gamyāt |
column2: Speak right and truth. Praise ye on the impulse of the god Savitr. The praised of the praised art thou, may the praised milk strength for me, may the praised of the praised come to me.

column1: śastrasya śastram | asy ūrjam mahyaṃ śastraṃ duhām ā mā śastrasya śastraṃ gamyāt |
column2: Thou art the Çastra of the Çastra [1], may the Çastra milk strength for me, may the Çastra of the Çastra come to me.

column1: indriyāvanto vanāmahe dhukṣīmahi prajām iṣam |
column2: With power may we conquer, May we milk offspring and food.

column1: sā me satyāśīr deveṣu bhūyāt |
column2: May my wish be accomplished among the gods.

column1: brahmavarcasam māgamyāt |
column2: May splendour come to me.

column1: yajño babhūva sa ā babhūva sa pra jajñe sa vāvṛdhe |
column2: The sacrifice hath become, it hath come into being, It hath been born, it hath waxed great;

column1: sa devānām adhipatir babhūva so asmāṃ adhipatīn karotu vayaṃ syāma patayo rayīṇām |
column2: It hath become the overlord of the gods, May it make us overlords, May we be lords of wealth.

column1: yajño vā vai |
column2: he after sacrificing becomes better.

column1: yajñapatiṃ duhe yajñapatir vā yajñaṃ duhe sa ya stutaśastrayor doham avidvān yajate taṃ yajño duhe sa iṣṭvā pāpīyān bhavati ya enayor dohaṃ vidvān yajate sa yajñaṃ duhe sa iṣṭvā vasīyān bhavati stutasya stutam asy ūrjam mahyaṃ stutaṃ duhām ā mā stutasya stutaṃ gamyāc chastrasya śastram asy ūrjam mahyaṃ śastraṃ duhām ā mā śastrasya śastraṃ gamyād ity āhaiṣa vai stutaśastrayo dohas taṃ ya evaṃ vidvān yajate duha eva yajñam iṣṭvā vasīyān bhavati |
column2: 'The praised of the praised art thou, may the praised milk strength for me, may the praised of the praised come to me. The Çastra, of the Çastra thou art, may the Çastra milk strength for me, may the Çastra of the Çastra come to me', he says; this is the milking of the Stotra and the Çastra; he who sacrifices knowing thus milks the sacrifice, and by sacrificing becomes better. To the flying eagle hail!

column1: śyenāya patvane svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya namo viṣṭambhāya dharmaṇe svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya namo paridhaye janaprathanāya svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya nama ūrje hotrāṇāṃ svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya namaḥ payase hotrāṇāṃ svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya namaḥ prajāpataye manave svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya nama ṛtam ṛtapāḥ suvarvāṭ svāhā vaṭ svayamabhigūrtāya namas tṛmpantāṃ hotrā madhor ghṛtasya yajñapatim ṛṣaya enasā |
column2: To him who approveth himself homage. To the support, the law, hail! Vat! To him who approveth himself homage. To the enclosing-stick which extendeth men hail!

column1: āhuḥ prajā nirbhaktā anutapyamānā madhavyau stokāv apa tau rarādha saṃ nas tābhyāṃ sṛjatu viśvakarmā ghorā ṛṣayo namo astv ebhyaḥ |
column2: To the lord of the sacrifice the Rsis said, 'By thy sin [1] creatures are famishing and troubled'; He did not secure the two drops of honey; May Viçvakarman unite us with them. Dread are the Rsis;

column1: cakṣuṣa eṣām manasaś ca saṃdhau bṛhaspataye mahi ṣad dyuman namaḥ |
column2: homage be to them, In the union with their eye and mind; To Brhaspati great, real, and glorious reverence;

column1: namo viśvakarmaṇe sa u pātv asmān ananyānt somapān manyamānaḥ | prāṇasya vidvānt samare na dhīra enaś cakṛvān mahi baddha eṣām | taṃ viśvakarman |
column2: Homage to Viçvakarman; may he guard us. Deeming that the Soma-drinkers are his own, Knowing the breath like a valiant man in battle,-- He hath committed a great sin and is bound by them-- Him set free, O Viçvakarman [2], for safety.

column1: pra muñcā svastaye ye bhakṣayanto na vasūny ānṛhuḥ | yān agnayo 'nvatapyanta dhiṣṇiyā iyaṃ teṣām avayā duriṣṭyai sviṣṭiṃ nas tāṃ kṛṇotu viśvakarmā namaḥ pitṛbhyo abhi ye no akhyan yajñakṛto yajñakāmāḥ sudevā akāmā vo dakṣiṇāṃ na nīnima mā nas tasmād enasaḥ pāpayiṣṭa yāvanto vai sadasyas te sarve dakṣiṇyas tebhyo yo dakṣiṇāṃ na |
column2: Those who eating deserved not riches, Whom the fires of the hearths did trouble, That is their offering to expiate the ill sacrifice good sacrifice for us may Viçvakarman make it. Homage to the Pitrs, who have watched around us, Making the sacrifice, loving the sacrifice, the benignant deities; We have not brought you the offering without desires; Trouble us not for this sin.

column1: nayed aibhyo vṛścyeta yad vaiśvakarmaṇāni juhoti sadasyān eva tat prīṇāti |
column2: in that he offers the libations to Viçvakarman, he thus delights those who are in the Sadas.

column1: asme devāso vapuṣe cikitsata yam āśirā dampatī vāmam aśnutaḥ |
column2: Ye gods, have regard to this wonder, The good thing which the husband and wife win with the milk admixture;

column2: male child is born, be findeth riches, And all the house prospereth unhurt. May the husband and wife who give the milk admixture win good; May wealth unharmed attend them dwelling in harmony;

column1: ya āsicat saṃdugdhaṃ kumbhyā saheṣṭena yāmann amatiṃ jahātu saḥ |
column2: May he, who poureth that which hath been milked together with the pot (of Soma), By the sacrifice leave misfortune on his way.

column1: sarpirgrīvī |
column2: Butter-necked [4], fat is his wife;

column1: pīvary asya jāyā pīvānaḥ putrā akṛśāso asya | saha jānir yaḥ sumakhasyamāna indrāyāśiraṃ saha kumbhyādāt | āśīr ma ūrjam uta suprajāstvam iṣaṃ dadhātu draviṇaṃ savarcasam | saṃjayan kṣetrāṇi sahasāham indra kṛṇvāno anyāṃ adharānt sapatnān |
column2: Fat his sons and not meagre, Who with his wife eager to offer a good sacrifice Hath given to Indra the milk admixture together with the pot (of Soma)., May the milk admixture place in me strength and good offspring And food, wealth and fair fame, (Me that am) conquering the fields with might, O Indra, And casting down my rivals.

column1: bhūtam asi bhūte {F mā}{GOLS mā}{W ma} dhā mukham asi mukham bhūyāsam |
column2: Thou art being, place me in being; thou art the mouth, may I be the mouth.

column1: dyāvāpṛthivībhyāṃ tvā pari gṛhṇāmi viśve tvā devā vaiśvānarāḥ |
column2: From sky and earth I take thee. May the All-gods, belonging to all men [5], move thee forward.

column1: pra cyāvayantu divi devān dṛṃhāntarikṣe vayāṃsi pṛthivyām pārthivān dhruvaṃ dhruveṇa haviṣāva somaṃ nayāmasi | yathā naḥ sarvam ij jagad ayakṣmaṃ sumanā asat |
column2: In the sky make firm the gods, in the atmosphere the birds, on earth the creatures of earth. With the firm offering the firm Soma, we transfer, That the whole world may be for us Free of sickness and of kindly intent;

column1: yathā na indra id viśaḥ kevalīḥ sarvāḥ samanasaḥ karat | yathā naḥ sarvā id diśo 'smākaṃ kevalīr asan |
column2: That Indra may make All the clans for us of one mind, That all the quarters May be ours alone.

column1: yad vai hotādhvaryum abhyāhvayate vajram enam abhi pra vartayati |
column2: In that the Hotr addresses the Adhvaryu, he makes the thunder bolt advance towards him;

column1: ukthaśā ity āha prātaḥsavanam pratigīrya trīṇy etāny akṣarāṇi tripadā gāyatrī gāyatram prātaḥsavanaṃ gāyatriyaiva prātaḥsavane vajram antar dhatte |
column2: the syllables herein are three, the Gayatri has three Padas, the morning pressing is connected with the Gayatri; verily with the Gayatri he places the thunderbolt within the morning pressing.

column1: ukthaṃ vācīty āha mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanam pratigīrya catvāry etāny akṣarāṇi catuṣpadā triṣṭup traiṣṭubham mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanaṃ triṣṭubhaiva mādhyaṃdine savane vajram antar dhatte |
column2: the syllables herein are four, the Tristubh has four Padas, the midday pressing is connected with the Tristubh; verily with the Tristubh he places the thunderbolt within the midday pressing [1]. 'The hymn hath been uttered to Indra', he says in response at the third pressing;

column1: ukthaṃ vācīndrāyety āha tṛtīyasavanam pratigīrya saptaitāny akṣarāṇi saptapadā śakvarī śākvaro vajro vajreṇaiva tṛtīyasavane vajram antar dhatte brahmavādino vadanti sa tvā adhvaryuḥ syād yo yathāsavanam pratigare chandāṃsi sampādayet tejaḥ prātaḥsavana ātman dadhītendriyam mādhyaṃdine savane paśūṃs tṛtīyasavana iti |
column2: the syllables herein are seven, the Çakvari has seven Padas, the thunder bolt is connected with the Çakvari; verily with the thunderbolt he places the thunderbolt within the third pressing. The theologians say, 'He indeed would be an Adhvaryu who should produce the metres in the responses according to the pressings; he would bestow brilliance upon himself at the morning pressing, power at the midday pressing, and cattle at the third pressing.' 'O reciter of hymns', he says in response at the morning pressing;

column1: ukthaśā ity āha prātaḥsavanam pratigīrya trīṇy etāny akṣarāṇi | tripadā gāyatrī gāyatram prātaḥsavanam prātaḥsavana eva pratigare chandāṃsi sam pādayati |
column2: the syllables herein are three, [2], the Gayatri has three Padas, the morning pressing is connected with the Gayatri; verily at the morning pressing he produces the metres in the response;

column1: atho tejo vai gāyatrī tejaḥ prātaḥsavanaṃ teja eva prātaḥsavana ātman dhatte |
column2: now the Gayatri is brilliance, the morning pressing is brilliance; verily at the morning pressing he bestows brilliance upon himself.

column1: ukthaṃ vācīty āha mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanam pratigīrya catvāry etāny akṣarāṇi catuṣpadā triṣṭup traiṣṭubham mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanam mādhyaṃdina eva savane pratigare chandāṃsi sam prādayati |
column2: 'The hymn hath been uttered', he says in response at the midday pressing; the syllables herein are four, the Tristubh has four Padas, the midday pressing is connected with the Tristubh; verily at the midday pressing he produces the metres in the response;

column1: atho indriyaṃ vai triṣṭug indriyam mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanam |
column2: now the Tristubh is power, the midday pressing is power [3];

column1: indriyam eva mādhyaṃdine savana ātman dhatte |
column2: verily at the midday pressing he bestows power upon himself.

column1: ukthaṃ vācīndrāyety āha tṛtīyasavanam pratigīrya saptaitāny akṣarāṇi saptapadā śakvarī śākvarāḥ paśavo jāgataṃ tṛtīyasavanaṃ tṛtīyasavana eva pratigare chandāṃsi sam pādayati |
column2: 'The hymn hath been uttered to Indra', he says in response at the third pressing; the syllables herein are seven, the Çakvari has seven Padas, cattle are connected with the Çakvari, the third pressing is connected with the Jagati; verily at the third pressing he produces the metres in the response;

column1: atho paśavo vai jagatī paśavas tṛtīyasavanam paśūn eva tṛtīyasavana ātman dhatte yad vai hotādhvaryum abhyāhvayata āvyam asmin dadhāti tad yan na |
column2: now the Jagati is cattle, the third pressing is cattle; verily at the third pressing he bestows cattle upon himself that the Hotr addresses the Adhvaryu, he puts fear in him;

column1: apahanīta purāsya saṃvatsarād gṛha ā vevīran |
column2: if be were not to smite it off [4], they would have fear in his house before the year (was over).

column1: śoṃsā moda iveti pratyāhvayate tenaiva tad apa hate yathā vā āyatām pratīkṣata evam adhvaryuḥ pratigaram pratīkṣate yad abhipratigṛṇīyād yathāyatayā samṛchate tādṛg eva tat |
column2: 'Recite, let us two rejoice',' he responds, and thereby he smites it off. Just as one looks for the exact interval, so the Adhvaryu looks for the response. If he were to respond in advance, that would be as when one goes to meets the exact interval.

column1: yad ardharcāl lupyeta yathā dhāvadbhyo hīyate tādṛg eva tat prabāhug vā ṛtvijām udgīthā udgītha evodgātṝṇām | ṛcaḥ praṇava ukthaśaṃsinām pratigaro 'dhvaryūṇām |
column2: If the (response) were to be omitted after the half-verse, that would be as when one is left behind those that are running. The Udgithas are similar for the priests, the Udgitha for the Udgatrs, [5], the Rces and the Pranavas for the singers of hymns, the response for the Adhvaryus.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān pratigṛṇāty annāda eva bhavaty āsya prajāyāṃ vājī jāyate |
column2: He, who knowing thus responds, becomes an eater of food, a strong one is born among his offspring.

column1: iyam vai hotāsāv adhvaryus |
column2: The Hotr is this (earth), the Adhvaryu yonder (sky);

column1: yad āsīnaḥ śaṃsaty asyā eva tad dhotā naity āsta iva hīyam atho imām eva tena yajamāno duhe yat tiṣṭhan pratigriṇāty amuṣyā eva tad adhvaryur naiti |
column2: in that he recites sitting, so the Hotr goes not away from the (earth), for this (earth) is seated as it were; verily thereby the sacrifice milks this (earth). In that he responds standing, so the Adhvaryu goes not away from yonder (sky) [6], for yonder (sky) stands as it were;

column1: tiṣṭhatīva hy asāv atho amūm eva tena yajamāno duhe yad āsīnaḥ śaṃsati tasmād itaḥpradānaṃ devā upa jīvanti yat tiṣṭhan pratigṛṇāti tasmād amutaḥpradānam manuṣyā upa jīvanti yat prāṅ āsīnaḥ śaṃsati pratyaṅ tiṣṭhan pratigṛṇāti tasmāt prācīnaṃ reto dhīyate pratīcīḥ prajā jāyante yad vai hotādhvaryum abhyāhvayate vajram enam abhi pra vartayati parāṅ ā vartate vajram eva tan ni karoti |
column2: verily thereby the sacrificer milks yonder (sky). In that he recites sitting, therefore the gods live on that which is given hence; in that he responds standing, therefore men live on what is given thence. In that he recites seated towards the east, and he responds standing towards the west, therefore seed is impregnated in front, offspring are born behind. In that the Hotr addresses the Adhvaryu, he makes the thunderbolt advance towards him;

column1: upayāmagṛhīto 'si vākṣasad asi vākpābhyāṃ tvā kratupābhyām asya yajñasya dhruvasyādhyakṣābhyāṃ gṛhṇāmi |
column2: thou art seated in speech for the guardians of speech, for the guardians of insight, for the overseers of this established sacrifice do I take thee.

column1: upayāmagṛhīto 'sy ṛtasad asi cakṣuṣpābhyāṃ tvā kratupābhyām asya yajñasya dhruvasyādhyakṣābhyāṃ gṛhṇāmi |
column2: for the guardians of sight, &c., do I take thee. Thou art taken with a support; thou art seated in holy lore; for the guardians of the ear, &c., do I take thee.

column1: viṣṇav {F urukramaiṣa}{W urukramaiṣa}{GOLS urukramaiṣa} te somas taṃ rakṣasva |
column2: For the gods thee! For the All-gods thee! For all the gods thee! O Visnu, wide striding, this is thy Soma;

column1: taṃ te duścakṣā māva khyat |
column2: guard it [1] let not the evil-eyed one espy this of thine.

column1: mayi vasuḥ purovasur vākpā vācam me pāhi mayi vasur vidadvasuś cakṣuṣpāś cakṣur me pāhi mayi vasuḥ saṃyadvasuḥ śrotrapāḥ śrotram me pāhi bhūr asi śreṣṭho raśmīnām prāṇapāḥ prāṇam me pāhi dhūr asi śreṣṭho raśmīnām apānapā apānam me pāhi yo na indravāyū mitrāvaruṇau |
column2: In me is the Vasu, whom wealth precedeth, who guardeth the voice; guard my voice. In me is the Vasu, who winneth wealth, who guardeth the eye; guard my eye. In me is the Vasu, who keepeth wealth together, who guardeth the ear;

column1: aśvināv abhidāsati bhrātṛvya utpipīte śubhas patī idam ahaṃ tam adharam pādayāmi yathendrāham uttamaś cetayāni |
column2: guard my inspiration. The foe who, O Indra and Vayu, is hostile to us, Who seeketh to assail us, O lords of splendour, May I here burl him below my feet, So that, O Indra, I may shine as the highest.

column1: pra so agne tavotibhiḥ suvīrābhis tarati vājakarmabhiḥ | yasya tvaṃ sakhyam āvitha |
column2: He by thy help, O Agni, With good heroes, making strength, is victorious, Whose companionship thou dost favour.

Raka is the first fortnight, Kuhu the second, Sinivali the new moon (night), Anumati the full moon (night), Dhatr the moon.

column1: indrāgnī tvā bṛhaspatir asmin yonāv asīṣadan | tā asya sūdadohasaḥ somaṃ śrīṇanti pṛśnayaḥ | janman devānāṃ viśas triṣv ā rocane divaḥ |
column2: Indra and Agni and Brhaspati Have placed thee on this birthplace The dappled kine, streaming with milk, Mix the Soma, Clans in the birthplace of the gods, In the three realms of sky.

column1: sam itaṃ saṃ kalpethāṃ sampriyau rociṣṇū sumanasyamānau | iṣam ūrjam abhi saṃvasānau śaṃ vām manāṃsi saṃ vratā sam u cittāny ākaram |
column2: Be united, be in harmony, in affection, Radiant, with kindly thought, Clothed in food and strength, United have I made your minds, your ordinances, your hearts.

column1: agne purīṣyādhipā bhavā tvaṃ naḥ |
column2: O Agni of the dust be overlord for us;

column1: iṣam ūrjaṃ yajamānāya dhehi |
column2: Bestow food and strength on the sacrificer.

column1: purīṣyas tvam agne rayimān puṣṭimāṃ asi | śivāḥ kṛtvā diśaḥ sarvāḥ svāṃ yonim ihāsadaḥ |
column2: Thou, O Agni, art of the dust, Rich, full of increase, Making all the regions propitious Thou hast sat down on thine own birthplace.

column1: bhavataṃ naḥ samanasau samokasau |
column2: Be ye of one mind for us, One dwelling [1], spotless;

column1: mā yajñaṃ hiṃsiṣṭam mā yajñapatiṃ jātavedasau śivau bhavatam adya naḥ |
column2: Harm not the sacrifice, nor the lord of the sacrifice, O all-knowers; Be ye two auspicious to-day unto us.

column1: māteva putram pṛthivī purīṣyam agniṃ sve yonāv abhār ukhā | tāṃ viśvair devair ṛtubhiḥ saṃvidānaḥ prajāpatir viśvakarmā vi muñcatu |
column2: As a mother her son, the earth, The pan, hath borne Agni of the dust in his own birthplace In unison with the All-gods, the seasons, Let Prajapati, all-worker, release it.

column1: yad asya pāre rajasaḥ śukraṃ jyotir ajāyata | tan naḥ parṣad ati dviśo 'gne vaiśvānara svāhā |
column2: The bright light Born beyond this firmament, May that convey us beyond our foes, Agni Vaiçvanara, hail!

column1: namaḥ su te nirṛte viśvarūpe | ayasmayaṃ vi cṛtā bandham etam |
column2: Homage to thee, O Nirrti of every form [2], Loosen ye this bond made of iron;

column1: yamena tvaṃ yamyā saṃvidānottamaṃ nākam adhi rohayemam |
column2: Do thou in accord with Yama and Yami Mount this highest vault.

column1: yat te devī nirṛtir ābabandha dāma grīvāsv avicartyam | idaṃ te tad vi ṣyāmy āyuṣo na madhyād athā jīvaḥ pitum addhi pramuktaḥ |
column2: The bond that Nirrti, the goddess, Bound on thy neck, not to be loosened, This I loosen for thee as from the middle of life; Then living, let loose, do thou eat the food.

column1: yasyās te asyāḥ krūra āsañ juhomy eṣām bandhānām avasarjanāya | bhūmir iti tvā janā vidur nirṛtiḥ |
column2: Thee in whose cruel mouth here I make offering, For the loosening of these bonds, As 'earth' men know thee, As 'Nirrti' [3], I know thee on every side.

column1: asunvantam ayajamānam icha stenasyetyāṃ taskarasyānv eṣi |
column2: Seek the man who poureth not offering nor sacrifices;

column1: anyam asmad icha ṣa ta ityā namo devi nirṛte tubhyam astu |
column2: Seek another than us, that is thy road; Homage be to thee, O Nirrti, O goddess.

column1: devīm ahaṃ nirṛtiṃ vandamānaḥ piteva putraṃ dasaye vacobhiḥ |
column2: Praising Nirrti, the goddess, Like a father his son, I weary her with my words;

column1: viśvasya yā jāyamānasya veda śiraḥśiraḥ prati sūrī vi caṣṭe |
column2: She who knoweth all that is born, Discerneth, the lady, every head.

column1: niveśanaḥ saṃgamano vasūnāṃ viśvā rūpābhi caṣṭe | śacībhiḥ | deva iva savitā satyadharmendro na tasthau samare pathīnām |
column2: Abode and collector of riches, Every form she discerneth with might [4], Like the god Savitr of true laws, Like Indra, she standeth at the meeting of the ways.

column1: saṃ varatrā dadhātana nir āhāvān kṛṇotana |
column2: Make firm the straps, Fasten the buckets;

column2: We shall drain the well full of water, That never is exhausted, never faileth. The well with buckets fastened, With strong straps, that yieldeth abundantly, Full of water, unexhausted, I drain.

column1: udriṇaṃ siñce akṣitam |
column2: The sages yoke the ploughs;

column2: They stretch apart the yokes, Wise with goodwill among the gods. Yoke the ploughs, stretch apart the yokes, Here sow in the womb made ready the seed [5] Through our song be there audience with profit for us;

column1: girā ca śruṣṭiḥ sabharā asan no nedīya it sṛṇyā pakvam āyat |
column2: May the ripe (grain) be brought low by the sickle.

column1: lāṅgalam pavīravaṃ suśevaṃ sumatitsaru | ud it kṛṣati gām avim prapharvayaṃ ca pīvarīm | prasthāvad rathavāhanam |
column2: The plough, of keen share, Propitious, with well-polished handle, Plougheth up a cow, a sheep, And a fat blooming maid, chariot support with a platform.

column1: śunaṃ naḥ phālā vi tudantu bhūmiṃ śunaṃ kīnāśā abhi yantu vāhān |
column2: With prosperity may our ploughs cleave the ground, With prosperity may the ploughers go round the yokes;

column1: śunam parjanyo madhunā payobhiḥ śunāsīrā śunam asmāsu dhattam |
column2: Prosperity (may) Parjanya (give) with honey and milk, And do ye, O Çuna and Sira, accord prosperity to us.

column1: kāmaṃ kāmadughe dhukṣva mitrāya varuṇāya ca |
column2: Wishes, O milker of wishes, do thou milk To Mitra and Varuna;

column1: indrāyāgnaye pūṣṇa oṣadhībhyaḥ prajābhyaḥ |
column2: To Indra, to Agni, to Pusan, To the plants, and to offspring.

column2: The furrow anointed with ghee, with honey, Approved by the All-gods, the Maruts, Full of strength, swelling with milk, Do thou, O furrow, turn towards us with milk.

column1: yā jātā oṣadhayo devebhyas triyugam purā | mandāmi babhrūṇām ahaṃ śataṃ dhāmāni sapta ca |
column2: The plants born Three generations before the gods, Of the brown ones I celebrate The seven and a hundred abodes.

column1: śataṃ vo amba dhāmāni sahasram uta vo ruhaḥ | athā śatakratvo yūyam imam me agadaṃ kṛta |
column2: A hundred, O mother, are your abodes, thousand too your shoots, Therefore do ye, with a hundred powers, Make him whole for me.

column1: puṣpāvatīḥ prasūvatīḥ phalinīr aphalā uta | aśvā iva sajitvarīr vīrudhaḥ pārayiṣṇavaḥ |
column2: With flowers, with shoots, Fruit-bearing and without fruit, Like steeds victorious The plants are strong to help.

column1: oṣadhīr iti mātaras tad vo devīr upa bruve |
column2: 'Plants', O ye mothers, hail you, O goddesses;

column1: rapāṃsi vighnatīr ita rapaḥ |
column2: Go bearing away defilement, Defilement [1] destroying.

column1: aśvatthe vo niṣadanam parṇe vo vasatiḥ kṛtā |
column2: In the Açvattha is your seat, In the Parna is your dwelling made;

column2: Cows shall in truth be your share If ye shall gain this man. In that in strength I seize These plants in my hand, The soul of the disease perisheth, As before one that taketh alive.

column1: yad oṣadhayaḥ saṃgachante rājānaḥ samitāv iva | vipraḥ sa ucyate bhiṣag rakṣohāmīvacātanaḥ |
column2: When the plants come together Like princes at the assembly, Sage is the physician called, Slayer of Raksases, overpowerer of diseases.

column1: niṣkṛtir nāma vo mātāthā yūyaṃ stha saṃkṛtīḥ |
column2: Remover is your mother by name, And ye are helpers;

column1: sarāḥ patatriṇīḥ |
column2: Ye are winged streams [2];

column1: sthana yad āmayati niṣ kṛta |
column2: Remove whatever is unwell.

column1: anyā vo anyām avatv anyānyasyā upāvata |

column1: aśvāvatīṃ somavatīm ūrjayantīm udojasam | ā vitsi sarvā oṣadhīr asmā ariṣṭatātaye |
column2: Rich in steeds, rich in Soma, Full of strength, full of power, have found all the plants For his safety.

column1: yāḥ phalinīr yā aphalā apuṣpā yāś ca puṣpiṇīḥ | bṛhaspatiprasūtās tā no muñcantv aṃhasaḥ | yāḥ |

column1: mā vo riṣat khanitā yasmai cāhaṃ khanāmi vaḥ |
column2: May the digger of you come to no ill, Nor he for whom I dig you;

column1: dvipac catuṣpad asmākaṃ sarvam astv anāturam{FN corrected in IS Ed: anāturam} |
column2: May all our bipeds and quadrupeds Be free from disease.

column1: vapāṃ te agnir iṣito 'va sarpatu |

column2: O Agni, that of thee which is pure, which is bright, Which is cleansed, which is fit for offering, That we bear to the gods.

column2: May it enter us, in cattle and in plants; abandon decline, lack of food, and ill-health.

column1: irajyann agne prathayasva jantubhir asme rāyo amartya |
column2: Do thou extend over men, O Agni, Ruling over wealth for us, O immortal one;

column1: sa darśatasya vapuṣo vi rājasi pṛṇakṣi sānasiṃ rayim |
column2: Thou art the master of a glorious form, Thou fillest glorious wealth.

column2: O son of strength, O all-knower, Rejoice in our fair praises [2], being adored in our prayers; In thee have they placed food, rich in seed, Of wondrous aid, of prosperous birth.

column1: pāvakavarcāḥ śukravarcā anūnavarcā ud iyarṣi bhānunā |
column2: With pure radiance, with bright radiance, With undiminished radiance, thou comest forth with thy light;

column2: Visiting thy parents thou aidest them; Thou fillest both worlds.

column1: ṛtāvānam mahiṣaṃ viśvacarṣaṇim agniṃ sumnāya dadhire puro janāḥ | śrutkarṇaṃ saprathastamam tvā girā daivyam mānuṣā yugā | niṣkartāram adhvarasya pracetasaṃ kṣayantaṃ rādhase mahe | rātim bhṛgūṇām uśijaṃ kavikratum pṛṇakṣi sānasim |
column2: The righteous, the bull, common to all men, Agni, men place before them for favour, Thee with their speech, that art ready to hear and most extending, The divine, the generations of men. Preparer of the sacrifice, the wise, Who ruleth for great gain, The giver of the Bhrgus, the eager, skilled in the sacrifice Thou fillest glorious wealth.

column1: cita stha paricita ūrdhvacitaḥ śrayadhvaṃ tayā devatayāṅgirasvad dhruvāḥ sīdata |
column2: Ye are pilers, ye are pilers around, do ye pile upwards as a support, with that deity, sit ye firm in the manner of Angiras.

column1: ā pyāyasva sam etu te viśvataḥ soma vṛṣṇiyam |
column2: Swell up, let thy strength be gathered From all sides, O Soma.

column1: bhavā vājasya saṃgathe |
column2: Be strong in the gathering of might.

column1: saṃ te payāṃsi sam u yantu vājāḥ saṃ vṛṣṇiyāny abhimātiṣāhaḥ |
column2: Let thy milk draughts, thy strength be united, The mightinesses of him who overcometh the foe;

column1: āpyāyamāno amṛtāya soma divi śravānsy uttamāni dhiṣva | abhy asthād viśvāḥ pṛtanā arātīs tad agnir āha tad u soma āha |
column2: Swelling for immortality, O Soma, Place in the sky the highest glories, He hath overcome every foe, every enemy; That Agni saith, that saith Soma too;

column1: bṛhaspatiḥ savitā tan ma āha puṣā mādhāt sukṛtasya loke |
column2: Brhaspati, Savitr, say this of me, Pusan hath placed me in the world of good action.

column2: When first thou didst cry on birth, Arising from the ocean or the dust, The wings of the eagle, the limbs of the gazelle, That is thy famed birth, O steed.

column1: apām pṛṣṭham asi yonir agneḥ samudram abhitaḥ pinvamānam |
column2: Thou art the back of the waters, the birthplace of Agni, The ocean swelling on either side;

column1: vardhamānam mahaḥ | ā ca puṣkaraṃ divo mātrayā varṇā prathasva |
column2: Growing to might [1] as the lotus flower, Do thou extend in width with the measure of heaven.

column1: brahma jajñānam prathamam purastād vi sīmataḥ suruco vena āvaḥ | sa budhniyā upamā asya viṣṭhāḥ sataś ca yonim asataś ca vivaḥ |
column2: The holy power born first in the east Vena hath disclosed from the shining boundary, He hath revealed its fundamental nearest forms, The womb of being and of not being.

column1: hiraṇyagarbhaḥ sam avartatāgre bhūtasya jātaḥ patir eka āsīt |
column2: The golden germ first rose; Born he was the only lord of creation;

column1: sa dādhāra pṛthivīṃ dyām utemāṃ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema |
column2: He supporteth the earth and the sky; To what god shall we offer with oblation.

column1: drapsaś caskanda pṛthivīm anu | dyām imaṃ ca yonim anu yaś ca pūrvaḥ |
column2: The drop hath fallen on the earth [2], the sky, On this seat, and on the one which was aforetime;

column1: tṛtīyaṃ yonim anu saṃcarantaṃ drapsaṃ juhomy anu sapta hotrāḥ |
column2: The drop that wandereth over the third seat offer in the seven Hotras.

column1: namo astu sarpebhyo ye ke ca pṛthivīm anu | ye antarikṣe ye divi tebhyaḥ sarpebhyo namaḥ |
column2: Homage to the serpents Which are on the earth, The serpents in the atmosphere, in the sky, To those serpents homage.

column2: Those that are the missiles of sorcerers, Or those that are among the trees, Or those that lie in the wells, To those serpents honour.

column1: dhruvāsi dharuṇāstṛtā viśvakarmaṇā sukṛtā |
column2: Thou art firm, supporting, unoverpowered, Well wrought by Viçvakarman;

column1: mā tvā samudra ud vadhīn mā suparṇo 'vyathamānā pṛthivīṃ dṛṃha |
column2: Let not the ocean smite thee, nor the eagle; Unshaking do thou make firm the earth.

column1: prajāpatis tvā sādayatu pṛthivyāḥ pṛṣṭhe vyacasvatīm prathasvatīm pratho 'si pṛthivy asi bhūr asi bhūmir asy aditir asi viśvadhāyā viśvasya bhuvanasya dhartrī pṛthivīṃ yacha pṛthivīṃ dṛṃha pṛthivīm mā hiṃsīr viśvasmai prāṇāya vyānāyodānāya pratiṣṭhāyai |
column2: May Prajapati seat thee on the back of earth, capacious, extending; thou art extent, thou art earth, thou art the world, thou art the earth, thou art Aditi all-sustaining, sustainer of all the world; sustain the earth, make firm the earth, harm not the earth, for all expiration, cross-breathing, up-breathing, for support [1], for motion;

column1: caritrāyāgnis tvābhi pātu mahyā svastyā chardiṣā śaṃtamena tayā devatayāṅgirasvad dhruvā sīda kāṇḍātkāṇḍāt prarohantī paruṣaḥparuṣaḥ pari |
column2: may Agni protect thee with great prosperity, with most auspicious covering; with that deity, in the manner of Angiras, do thou sit firm.

column1: evā no dūrve pra tanu sahasreṇa śatena ca |
column2: Arising from every stem, From every joint, Do thou, O Durva, extend us With a thousand, a hundred.

column1: yā śatena pratanoṣi sahasreṇa virohasi tasyās te devīṣṭake vidhema haviṣā vayam |
column2: Thou that extendest with a hundred, That arisest with a thousand, To thee, O goddess, O brick, Let us sacrifice with oblation.

column1: aṣāḍhāsi sahamānā sahasvārātīḥ sahasvārātīyataḥ sahasva pṛtanāḥ sahasva pṛtanyataḥ sahasravīryā |
column2: Unovercomable art thou, overcoming, overcome our enemies, over come those that practise enmity. Overcome the foe, overcome the foemen of a thousandfold strength [2] art thou;

column1: asi sā mā jinva |
column2: do thou inspirit me.

column1: madhu vātā ṛtāyate madhu kṣaranti sindhavaḥ |

column1: mādhvīr naḥ santv oṣadhīḥ |
column2: Be sweet to us the plants.

column1: madhu naktam utoṣasi madhumat pārthivaṃ rajaḥ | madhu dyaur astu naḥ pitā |
column2: Sweet is the night, and sweet At dawn the air of earth, Sweet be the sky, our father.

column1: madhumān no vanaspatir madhumāṃ astu sūryaḥ | mādhvīr gāvo bhavantu naḥ |
column2: Sweet to us be the lord of the forest, Sweet the sun, Sweet be the cows to us.

column1: mahī dyauḥ pṛthivī ca na imaṃ yajñam mimikṣatām |
column2: May the two great ones, sky and earth, Mingle for us this sacrifice;

column1: pipṛtāṃ no bharīmabhiḥ |

column1: ayam puro harikeśaḥ sūryaraśmis tasya rathagṛtsaś ca rathaujāś ca senānigrāmaṇyau puñjikasthalā ca kṛtasthalā cāpsarasau yātudhānā hetī rakṣāṃsi prahetis |
