column1: asi stanayitnusanir asi vṛṣṭisanir asi |
column2: thou art the winner of thunder; thou art the winner of rain.

column1: agner yāny asi devānām agneyāny asi vāyor yāny asi devānāṃ vāyoyāny asi |
column2: Thou art the path of Agni; thou art the gods' path of Agni. Thou art the path of Vayu; thou art the gods' path of Vayu.

column1: antarikṣasya yāny asi devānām antarikṣayāny asi |
column2: thou art the gods' path of the atmosphere. Thou art the atmosphere;

column1: antarikṣam asy antarikṣāya tvā salilāya tvā sarṇīkāya tvā satīkāya tvā ketāya tvā pracetase tvā vivasvate tvā divas tvā jyotiṣa ādityebhyas tvā |
column2: To the ocean thee, to water thee, to the watery thee, to impulse thee, to the wise thee, to the radiant thee, to the light of the sky thee, to the Adityas thee! To the Rc thee, to radiance thee, to the shining thee, to the blaze thee, to the light thee!

column1: ṛce tvā ruce tvā dyute tvā bhāse tvā jyotiṣe tvā yaśodāṃ tvā yaśasi tejodāṃ tvā tejasi payodāṃ tvā payasi varcodāṃ tvā varcasi draviṇodāṃ tvā draviṇe sādayāmi tenarṣiṇā tena brahmaṇā tayā devatayāṅgirasvad dhruvā sīda |
column2: thee, giving brilliance, in brilliance; thee, giving milk, in milk; thee, giving radiance, in radiance; thee giving wealth, in wealth I place; with this seer, the holy power, this deity, sit firm in the manner of Angiras.

column1: bhūyaskṛd asi varivaskṛd asi prācy asy ūrdhvāsy antarikṣasad asy antarikṣe sīda |
column2: thou art the maker of wide room; thou art the eastern; thou art the zenith; thou art the sitter in the atmosphere, sit on the atmosphere.

column1: apsuṣad asi śyenasad asi gṛdhrasad asi suparṇasad asi nākasad asi pṛthivyās tvā draviṇe sādayāmy antarikṣasya tvā draviṇe sādayāmi divas tvā draviṇe sādayāmi diśāṃ tvā draviṇe sādayāmi draviṇodāṃ tvā draviṇe sādayāmi prāṇam me pāhy apānam me pāhi vyānam me |
column2: Thou art the sitter on the waters; thou art the sitter on the hawk thou art the sitter on the vulture; thou art the sitter on the eagle; thou art the sitter on the vault.

column1: pāhy āyur me pāhi viśvāyur me pāhi sarvāyur me pāhi |
column2: In the wealth of earth I place thee; in the wealth of the atmosphere I place thee;

column1: agne yat te paraṃ hṛn nāma tāv ehi saṃ rabhāvahai pāñcajanyeṣv apy edhy agne yāvā ayāvā evā ūmāḥ sabdaḥ sagaraḥ sumekaḥ |
column2: O Agni, thy highest name, the heart, Come let us join together, Be thou, O Agni, among those of the five races. (Thou art) the Yavas, the Ayavas, the courses, the helpers, the Sabda, the ocean, the firm one.

column1: agninā viśvāṣāṭ sūryeṇa svarāṭ kratvā śacīpatis |
column2: (Thou I art) all overcoming through Agni; self-ruling through the sun;

column1: ṛṣabheṇa tvaṣṭā yajñena maghavān dakṣiṇayā suvargas |
column2: lord of strength through might; creator with the bull; bountiful through the sacrifice;

column1: manyunā vṛtrahā sauhārdyena tanūdhād |
column2: slayer of enemies through rage; supporter of the body through kindliness;

column1: annena gayaḥ pṛthivyāsanot |
column2: through the earth he hath won;

column1: ṛgbhir annādas |
column2: (thou art) eater of food with verses;

column1: vaṣaṭkāreṇarddhaḥ sāmanā tanūpās | virājā jyotiṣmān brahmaṇā somapās |
column2: protector of the body through the Saman; full of light with the Viraj; drinker of Soma through the holy power;

column1: gobhir yajñaṃ dādhāra kṣatreṇa manuṣyān aśvena ca rathena ca vajrī |
column2: with cows he supporteth the sacrifice; with lordly power men; with horse and car bearer of the bolt;

column1: ṛtubhiḥ prabhuḥ saṃvatsareṇa paribhūs tapasānādhṛṣṭaḥ sūryaḥ san tanūbhiḥ |
column2: lord with the seasons; enclosing with the year; unassailable through penance; the sun with bodies.

column1: prajāpatir manasā | andho 'chetas |
column2: (Thou art) Prajapati in mind, when come to the Soma;

column1: dhātā dīkṣāyām |
column2: the creator in the consecration;

column1: savitā bhṛtyām pūṣā somakrayaṇyām |
column2: Savitr in the bearing; Pusan in the cow for the purchase of the Soma;

column1: varuṇa upanaddhas |
column2: Varuna when bound (in the cloth);

column1: asuraḥ krīyamāṇas |
column2: Asura in the being bought;

column1: mitraḥ krītaḥ śipiviṣṭa āsāditas |
column2: Mitra when purchased; Çipivista when put in place;

column1: naraṃdhiṣaḥ prohyamānas |
column2: delighter of men when being drawn forward;

column1: adhipatir āgataḥ prajāpatiḥ praṇīyamānas |
column2: the overlord on arrival; Prajapati being led on;

column1: agnir āgnīdhre bṛhaspatir āgnīdhrāt praṇīyamānas |
column2: Agni at the Agnidh's altar; Brhaspati on being led from the Agnidh's altar;

column1: indro havirdhāne |
column2: Indra at the oblation-holder;

column1: aditir āsāditas |
column2: Aditi when put in place;

column1: viṣṇur upāvahriyamāṇas | atharvopottas |
column2: Visnu when being taken down; Atharvan when made wet;

column1: yamo 'bhiṣutas |
column2: Yama when pressed out;

column1: apūtapā ādhūyamānas | vāyuḥ pūyamānas |
column2: drinker of unpurified (Soma) when being cleansed; Vayu when purifying;

column1: mitraḥ kṣīraśrīs | manthī saktuśrīs |
column2: Mitra as mixed with milk; the Manthin when mixed with groats;

column1: vaiśvadeva unnītas |
column2: that of the All-gods when taken out;

column1: rudra āhutas |
column2: Rudra when offered;

column1: vāyur āvṛttas |
column2: Vayu when covered up;

column1: nṛcakṣāḥ pratikhyātas |
column2: the gazer on men when revealed;

column1: bhakṣa āgataḥ pitṝṇāṃ nārāśaṃsas |
column2: the river when going to the final bath;

column1: samudro 'vagataḥ salilaḥ praplutaḥ suvar udṛcaṃ gataḥ |
column2: the ocean when gone; the water when dipped; the heaven when arrived at completion.

column1: kṛttikā nakṣatram agnir devatāgne ruca stha prajāpater dhatuḥ somasyarce tvā ruce tvā dyute tvā bhāse tvā jyotiṣe tvā rohiṇī nakṣatram prajāpatir devatā mṛgaśīrṣaṃ nakṣatraṃ somo devatārdrā nakṣatraṃ rudro devatā punarvasū nakṣatram aditir devatā tiṣyo nakṣatram bṛhaspatir devatāśreṣā nakṣatraṃ sarpā devatā maghā nakṣatram pitaro devatā phalgunī nakṣatram |
column2: (Thou art) Krttikas, the Naksatra, Agni, the deity; ye are the radiances of Agni, of Prajapati, of the creator, of Soma; to the Re thee, to radiance thee, to the shining thee, to the blaze thee, to the light thee (Thou art) Rohini the Naksatra, Prajapati the deity; Mrgaçirsa the Naksatra, Soma the deity; Ardra the Naksatra, Rudra the deity;

column1: aryamā devatā phalgunī nakṣatram bhago devatā hasto nakṣatraṃ savitā devatā citrā nakṣatram indro devatā svātī nakṣatraṃ vāyur devatā viśākhe nakṣatram indrāgnī devatā anūrādhā nakṣatram mitro devatā rohiṇī nakṣatram indro devatā vicṛtau nakṣatram pitaro devatāṣāḍhā nakṣatram āpo devatāṣāḍhā nakṣatraṃ viśve devā devatā śroṇā nakṣattraṃ viṣṇur devatā śraviṣṭhā nakṣatraṃ vasavaḥ |
column2: the two Phalgunis the Naksatra, Bhaga the deity; Hasta the Naksatra, Savitr the deity; Citra the Naksatra, Indra the deity; Svati the Naksatra, Vayu the deity; the two Viçakhas the Naksatra, Indra and Agni the deity;

column1: devatā śatabhiṣaṅ nakṣatram indro devatā proṣṭhapadā nakṣatram aja ekapād devatā proṣṭhapadā nakṣatram ahir budhniyo devatā revatī nakṣatram pūṣā devatāśvayujau nakṣatram aśvinau devatāpabharaṇīr nakṣatraṃ yamo devatā pūrṇā paścād yat te devā adadhuḥ |
column2: Prosthapadas the Naksatra, the goat of one foot the deity; the Prosthapadas the Naksatra, the serpent of the deep the deity; Revati the Naksatra, Pusan the deity; the two Açvayujs the Naksatra, the Açvins the deity; the Apabharanis the Naksatra, Yama the deity.

column1: madhuś ca mādhavaś ca vāsantikāv ṛtū śukraś ca śuciś ca graiṣmāv ṛtū nabhaś ca nabhasyaś ca vārṣikāv ṛtū iṣaś corjaś ca śāradāv ṛtū sahaś ca sahasyaś ca haimantikāv ṛtū tapaś ca tapasyaś ca śaiśirāv ṛtū agner antaḥśleṣo 'si kalpetāṃ dyāvāpṛthivī kalpantām āpa oṣadhīḥ kalpantām agnayaḥ pṛthaṅ mama jyaiṣṭhyāya savratāḥ |
column2: (Ye are) Isa and Urja, the months of autumn. (Ye are) Saha and Sahasya, the months of winter. (Ye are) Tapa and Tapasya, the months of the cool season. Thou art the internal bond of the fire, Be sky and earth in place, Be waters and plants in place, Be the fires severally in place In unison for my greatness [1] May the fires which of one mind Are between sky and earth, Taking place according to the months of the cool season, Attend (on them), as the gods on Indra.

column1: ye 'gnayaḥ samanaso 'ntarā dyāvāpṛthivī śaiśirāv ṛtū abhi kalpamānā indram iva devā abhi saṃ viśantu saṃyac ca pracetāś cāgneḥ somasya sūryasya |
column2: (Thou art) the uniter and forethinker of Agni, Soma, Surya. Thou art the dread, the terrible, of the fathers, of Yama, of Indra.

column1: ugrā ca bhīmā ca pitṝṇāṃ yamasyendrasya dhruvā ca pṛthivī ca devasya savitur marutāṃ varuṇasya dhartrī ca dharitrī ca mitrāvaruṇayor mitrasya dhātuḥ prācī ca prātīcī ca vasūnāṃ rudrāṇām |
column2: Thou art the firm (quarter) and the earth of the god Savitr, the Maruts, Varuna. Thou art the support, the upholder, of Mitra and Varuna, Mitra, Dhatr, Thou art the eastern, the western (quarter) of the Vasus, the Rudras [2], the Adityas.

column1: te te 'dhipatayas tebhyo namas te no mṛḍayantu te yaṃ dviṣmo yaś ca no dveṣṭi taṃ vo jambhe dadhāmi sahasrasya pramā asi sahasrasya pratimā asi sahasrasya vimā asi sahasrasyonmā asi sāhasro 'si sahasrāya tvā |
column2: These are thine overlords, to them honour, be they gracious to us, him whom we hate and who hateth us I place in your jaws. Thou art the measure of a thousand, thou art the image of a thousand, thou art the size of a thousand, thou art the replica of a thousand, thou art of a thousand, for a thousand thee!

column1: imā me agna iṣṭakā dhenavaḥ santv ekā ca śataṃ ca sahasraṃ cāyutaṃ ca | niyutaṃ ca prayutaṃ cārbudaṃ ca nyarbudaṃ ca samudraś ca madhyaṃ cāntaś ca parārdhaś cemā me agna iṣṭakā dhenavaḥ santu ṣaṣṭhiḥ sahasram ayutam akṣīyamāṇā ṛtasthā sthartāvṛdho ghṛtaścuto madhuścuta ūrjasvatīḥ svadhāvinīs tā me agna iṣṭakā dhenavaḥ santu virājo nāma kāmadughā amutrāmuṣmiM loke |
column2: May these bricks, O Agni, be milch cows for me, one, and a hundred, and a thousand, and ten thousand [3], and a hundred thousand, and a million, and ten million, and a hundred million, and a thousand million, and ten thousand million, and a hundred thousand million, and ten hundred thousand million, and a hundred hundred thousand million; may these bricks, O Agni, be for me milch cows, sixty, a thousand, ten thousand unperishing; ye are standing on holy order, increasing holy order, dripping ghee, dripping honey, full of strength, full of power; may these bricks, O Agni, be for me milkers of desires named the glorious yonder in yon world.

column1: samid diśām āśayā naḥ suvarvin madhor ato mādhavaḥ pātv asmān |
column2: The Horse Sacrifice May the kindling-stick of the quarters, that winneth the heaven, (Guard us) according to our hopes; from Madhu may Madhava protect us;

column1: agnir devo duṣṭarītur adābhya idaṃ kṣatraṃ rakṣatu pātv asmān |
column2: Agni, the god, hard to overcome, the undeceivable, May he guard our kingly power, may he protect us.

column1: rathaṃtaraṃ sāmabhiḥ pātv asmān gāyatrī chandasāṃ viśvarūpā | trivṛn no viṣṭhayā stomo ahnāṃ samudro vāta idam ojaḥ pipartu |
column2: May the Rathantara with the Samans protect us, The Gayatri with every form of metres, The Trivrt Stoma with the order of the days, The ocean, the wind, make full this strength.

column1: ugrā diśām abhibhūtir vayodhāḥ śuciḥ śukre ahany ojasīnā |
column2: (May) the dread among the quarters, the overpowering, giver of strength, Pure, full of might on a bright day (protect us);

column1: indrādhipatiḥ pipṛtād ato no mahi | kṣatraṃ viśvato dhārayedam |
column2: Indra, as overlord, make full, And for us [1] on all sides do thou preserve this great kingly power.

column1: bṛhat sāma kṣatrabhṛd vṛddhavṛṣṇiyaṃ triṣṭubhaujaḥ śubhitam ugravīram |
column2: (May) the Brhat Saman, which supporteth kingly power, with vast strength, The force made beautiful by the Tristubh, that of fierce strength (protect us);

column1: indra stomena pañcadaśena madhyam idaṃ vātena sagareṇa rakṣa |
column2: Indra, with the fifteenfold Stoma Do thou guard this in the midst with the wind, with the ocean.

column1: prācī diśāṃ sahayaśā yaśasvatī viśve devāḥ prāvṛṣāhnāṃ{FN corrected in IS Ed: prāvṛṣāhnāṃ} suvarvatī |
column2: (May) the eastern among the quarters, famous and renowned, ye All-gods, heavenly with the rain of the days (protect us);

column1: idaṃ kṣatraṃ duṣṭaram astv ojo 'nādhṛṣṭaṃ sahasriyaṃ sahasvat |
column2: Let this kingly power be unassailable, Force unoverpowerable, a thousandfold and mighty.

column1: vairūpe sāmann iha tac chakema jagatyainaṃ vikṣv ā veśayāmaḥ |
column2: Here in the Vairupa Saman may we have strength for this; With the Jagati we place him in the people;

column1: viśve devāḥ saptadaśena | varca idaṃ kṣatraṃ salilavātam ugram |
column2: ye All-gods [2] through the seventeenfold (Stoma) this radiance, This kingly power with the ocean wind (be) dread.

column1: dhartrī diśāṃ kṣatram idaṃ dādhāropasthāśānām mitravad astv ojaḥ |
column2: The supporter among the quarters doth support this lordly power, The stay of the regions; may force rich in friends be ours;

column1: mitrāvaruṇā śaradāhnāṃ cikitnū asmai rāṣṭrāya mahi śarma yachatam |
column2: Mitra and Varuna, ye wise ones with the autumn of the days, Do ye accord great protection to this kingdom.

column1: vairāje sāmann adhi me manīṣānuṣṭubhā sambhṛtaṃ vīryaṃ sahaḥ |
column2: In the Vairaja Saman is my devotion; By the Anustubh (be) manly strength collected;

column1: idaṃ kṣatram mitravad ārdradānu mitrāvaruṇā rakṣatam ādhipatyaiḥ |
column2: This kingly power rich in friends, with dripping wet, Do ye, O Mitra and Varuna, guard through your overlordship.

column1: samrāḍ diśāṃ sahasāmnī sahasvaty ṛtur hemanto viṣṭhayā naḥ pipartu |
column2: May the victorious among quarters, with the Saman, the strong one, The season winter in order make us full;

column1: avasyuvātāḥ | bṛhatīr nu śakvarīr imaṃ yajñam avantu no ghṛtācīḥ |
column2: May the great ones, the Çakvari (verses), with favouring winds [8] Aid this sacrifice, full of ghee.

column1: suvarvatī sudughā naḥ payasvatī diśāṃ devy avatu no ghṛtācī |
column2: May the heavenly of the quarters, the easily milked, the rich in milk, The goddess aid us, full of ghee;

column1: tvaṃ gopāḥ puraetota paścād bṛhaspate yāmyāṃ yuṅgdhi vācam |
column2: Thou art the protector, who goest in front and behind; Brhaspati, yoke a voice in the south.

column1: ūrdhvā diśāṃ rantir āśauṣadhīnāṃ saṃvatsareṇa savitā no ahnām | revat sāmātichandā u chandojātaśatruḥ syonā no astu |
column2: 1 (May) the upright of the quarters, the bounteous region of the plants, And Savitr with the year of the days (aid us); The Revat Saman, and the Atichandas metre; Without a foe, be kindly to us.

column1: stomatrayastriṃśe bhuvanasya patni vivasvadvāte abhi naḥ | gṛṇāhi |
column2: O thou of the three-and-thirtyfold Stoma, lady of the world, Breathed on by Vivasvant, do thou be gracious to us [4];

column1: ghṛtavatī savitar ādhipatyaiḥ payasvatī rantir āśā no astu |
column2: Rich in ghee, O Savitr, through thy overlordship, Be the bounteous region rich in milk, for us.

column1: dhruvā diśāṃ viṣṇupatny aghorāsyeśānā sahaso yā manotā | bṛhaspatir mātariśvota vāyuḥ saṃdhuvānā vātā abhi no gṛṇantu |
column2: The firm among the quarters, lady of Visnu, the mild, Ruling over this strength, the desirable, Brhaspati, Matariçvan, Vayu, The winds blowing together be gracious to us.

column1: viṣṭambho divo dharuṇaḥ pṛthivyā asyeśānā jagato viṣṇupatnī | viśvavyacā iṣayantī subhūtiḥ śivā no astv aditir upasthe |
column2: Prop of the sky, supporter of the earth, Ruling this world, lady of Visnu, All-extending, seeking food, with prosperity, May Aditi be auspicious to us in her life.

column1: vaiśvānaro na ūtyā pṛṣṭo divi |
column2: Vaiçvanara to our help. Present in the sky.

column1: anu no 'dyānumatis |
column2: Us to-day Anumati.

column1: anv id anumate tvam |
column2: O Anumati, thou.

column1: kayā naś citra ā bhuvat ko adya yuṅkte | namas te rudra manyava uto ta iṣave namaḥ |
column2: With what to us radiant shall he be? Who to-day yoketh? The Offerings to Rudra Homage to thy wrath, O Rudra, To thine arrow homage also;

column1: namas te astu dhanvane bāhubhyām uta te namaḥ |
column2: Homage to thy bow, And homage to thine arms.

column1: śivā śaravyā yā tava tayā no rudra mṛḍaya | yā te rudra śivā tanūr aghorāpāpakāśinī | tayā nas tanuvā śaṃtamayā giriśantābhi cākaśīhi |
column2: With thy most kindly arrow, And kindly bow, With thy kindly missile, Be gentle to us, O Rudra. That body of thine, O Rudra, which is kindly, Not dread, with auspicious look, With that body, most potent to heal, haunter of the mountains, do thou look on us.

column1: yām iṣuṃ giriśanta haste | bibharṣy astave | śivāṃ giritra tāṃ kuru mā hiṃsīḥ puruṣaṃ jagat |
column2: The arrow which, O haunter of mountains, In thy hand [1] thou bearest to shoot, That make thou kindly, O guardian of mountains; Harm not the world of men.

column1: śivena vacasā tvā giriśāchā vadāmasi | yathā naḥ sarvam ij jagad ayakṣmaṃ sumanā asat |
column2: With kindly utterance thee We address, O liver on the mountains, That all our folk Be free from sickness and of good cheer.

column1: adhy avocad adhivaktā prathamo daivyo bhiṣak | ahīṃś ca sarvāñ jambhayant sarvāś ca yātu dhānyaḥ |
column2: The advocate hath spoken in advocacy, The first divine leech, Confounding all the serpents And all sorceries.

column1: asau yas tāmro aruṇa uta babhruḥ sumaṅgalaḥ | ye cemāṃ rudrā abhito dikṣu | śritāḥ sahasraśo 'vaiṣāṃ heḍa īmahe |
column2: The dusky, the ruddy, The brown, the auspicious, And the Rudras which in thousands Lie around this (earth) in the quarters [2], Their wrath do we deprecate.

column1: asau yo 'vasarpati nīlagrīvo vilohitaḥ | utainaṃ gopā adṛśann adṛśann udahāryaḥ | utainaṃ viśvā bhūtāni sa dṛṣṭo mṛḍayāti naḥ |
column2: He who creepeth away, Blue-necked and ruddy, Him the cowherds have seen, Have seen the bearers of water And him all creatures; May be, seen, be gentle unto us.

column1: namo astu nīlagrīvāya sahasrākṣāya mīḍuṣe | atho ye asya satvāno 'haṃ tebhyo 'karaṃ namaḥ |
column2: Homage to the blue-necked, Thousand-eyed one, the bountiful And to those that are his warriors have paid my homage.

column1: pra muñca dhanvanas tvam ubhayor ārtniyor jyām | yāś ca te hasta iṣavaḥ |
column2: Unfasten from the two notches Of thy bow the bowstring, And cast thou down The arrows in thy hand [3].

column1: avatatya dhanus tvaṃ sahasrākṣa śateṣudhe | niśīrya śalyānām mukhā śivo naḥ sumanā bhava |
column2: 1 Unstringing thy bow, Do thou of a thousand eyes and a hundred quivers, Destroying the points of thine arrows, Be gentle and kindly to us.

column1: vijyaṃ dhanuḥ kapardino viśalyo bāṇavāṃ uta |
column2: Unstrung is the bow of him of the braided hair And arrowless his quiver;

column1: aneśann asyeṣava ābhur asya niṣaṅgathiḥ | yā te hetir mīḍhuṣṭama haste babhūva te dhanuḥ | tayāsmān viśvatas tvam ayakṣamayā pari bhuja |
column2: His arrows have departed, Empty is his quiver. O most bountiful one, the missile That is in thy hand, thy bow, With it on all sides do thou guard us, Free from sickness. Homage to thy weapon, Unstrung, dread;

column1: ubhābhyām uta te namo bāhubhyāṃ tava dhanvane | pari te dhanvano hetir asmān vṛṇaktu viśvataḥ |
column2: And homage to thy two hands, To thy bow. May the missile from thy bow Avoid us on every side, And do thou lay far from us This quiver that is thine.

column1: namo hiraṇyabāhave senānye diśāṃ ca pataye namas | namo vṛkṣebhyo harikeśebhyaḥ paśūnām pataye namas | namaḥ saspiñjarāya tviṣīmate pathīnām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the golden-armed leader of hosts, and to the lord of the quarters homage! Homage to the trees with green tresses, to the lord of cattle homage! Homage to the one who is yellowish-red like young grass, to the radiant, to the lord of paths homage!

column1: namo babhluśāya vivyādhine 'nnānām pataye namas | namo harikeśāyopavītine puṣṭānām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the brown one, to the piercer, to the lord of food homage! Homage to the green-haired, wearer of the cord, to the lord of prosperity homage!

column1: namo bhavasya hetyai jagatām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the dart of Bhava, to the lord of the moving world homage!

column1: namo rudrāyātatāvine kṣetrāṇām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to Rudra, with bent bow, to the lord of fields homage!

column1: namaḥ sūtāyāhantyāya vanānām pataye namas | namaḥ |
column2: Homage to the minstrel, the inviolate, to the lord of the woods homage!

column1: rohitāya sthapataye vṛkṣāṇām pataye namas | namo mantriṇe vāṇijāya kakṣāṇām pataye namas |
column2: Homage [1] to the ruddy one, the ruler, to the lord of woods homage! Homage to the minister, the trader, to the lord of thickets homage!

column1: namo bhuvantaye vārivaskṛtāyauṣadhīnām pataye namas | nama uccairghoṣāyākrandayate pattīnām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the extender of the world, the offspring of the maker of room, to the lord of plants homage! Homage to the loud calling, the screaming, to the lord of footmen homage!

column1: namaḥ kṛtsnavītāya dhāvate satvanām pataye namaḥ | namaḥ sahamānāya nivyādhina āvyādhinīnām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the wholly covered, to the running, to the lord of warriors homage! Homage to the strong, the piercing, to the lord of assailers homage!

column1: namaḥ kakubhāya niṣaṅgiṇe stenānām pataye namas | namo niṣaṅgiṇa eṣudhimate taskarāṇām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the leader, the holder of the quiver, to the lord of thieves homage! Homage to the holder of the quiver, to the owner of the quiver, to the lord of robbers homage!

column1: namo vañcate parivañcate stāyūnām pataye namas | namo nicerave paricarāyāraṇyānām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the cheater, the swindler, to the lord of burglars homage! Homage to the glider, to the wanderer around, to the lord of the forests homage!

column1: namaḥ sṛkāvibhyo jighāṃsadbhyo muṣṇatām pataye namas | namo 'simadbhyo ñaktaṃ caradbhyaḥ prakṛntānām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the bolt-armed destructive ones, to the lord of pilferers homage! Homage to the bearers of the sword, the night wanderers, to the lord of cut-purses homage!

column1: nama uṣṇīṣiṇe giricarāya kuluñcānām pataye namas |
column2: Homage to the turbaned wanderer on the mountains, to the lord of pluckers homage!

column1: iṣumadbhyo dhanvāvibhyaś ca vo namas | nama ātanvānebhyaḥ pratidadhānebhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage [1] to you, bearers of arrows, and to you, bowmen, homage! Homage to you that string (the bow), and to you that place (on the arrow), homage!

column1: nama āyachadbhyo visṛjadbhyaś ca vo namas | namo 'syadbhyo vidhyadbhyaś ca vo namas | nama āsīnebhyaḥ śayānebhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you that bend (the bow), and to you that let go the arrow) homage! Homage to you that hurl, and to you that pierce homage! Homage to you that art seated, and to you that lie homage!

column1: namas tiṣṭhadbhyo dhāvadbhyaś ca vo namas | namaḥ sabhābhyaḥ sabhāpatibhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you that stand, and to you that run homage! Homage to you assemblies, and to you, lords of assemblies, homage!

column1: namo aśvebhyo 'śvapatibhyaś ca vo namaḥ |
column2: Homage to you horses, and to you, lords of horses, homage!

column1: nama āvyādhinībhyo vividhyantībhyaś ca vo namas | nama ugaṇābhyas tṛṃhatībhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you that wound, and to you that pierce homage! Homage to you that are in bands, and to you that are destructive homage!

column1: namo gṛtsebhyo gṛtsapatibhyaś ca vo namas | namo vrātebhyo vrātapatibhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you sharpers, and to you, lords of sharpers, homage! Homage to you hosts, and to you, lord of hosts, homage!

column1: namo gaṇebhyo gaṇapatibhyaś ca vo namas | namo virūpebhyo viśvarūpebhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you troops, and to you, lords of troops, homage Homage to you of misshapen form, and to you of all forms homage!

column1: namo mahadbhyaḥ kṣullakebhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you that are great, and to you that are small homage!

column1: namo rathibhyo 'rathebhyaś ca vo namas | namo rathebhyaḥ | rathapatibhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you that have chariots, and to you that are chariotless homage! Homage to you chariots [1], and to you, lords of chariots, homage!

column1: namaḥ senābhyaḥ senānibhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you hosts, and to you, lords of hosts, homage!

column1: namaḥ kṣattṛbhyaḥ saṃgrahītṛbhyaś ca vo namas | namas takṣabhyo rathakārebhyaś ca vo namas | namaḥ kulālebhyaḥ karmārebhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you, doorkeepers, and to you, charioteers, homage! Homage to you, carpenters, and to you, makers of chariots, homage! Homage to you, potters, and to you, smiths, homage!

column1: namaḥ puñjiṣṭebhyo niṣādebhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you, Puñjistas, and to you, Nisadas, homage!

column1: nama iṣukṛdbhyo dhanvakṛdbhyaś ca vo namas | namo mṛgayubhyaḥ śvanibhyaś ca vo namas |
column2: Homage to you, makers of arrows, and to you, makers of bows, homage! Homage to you, hunters, and to you, dog-leaders, homage!

column1: namaḥ śvabhyaḥ śvapatibhyaś ca vo namaḥ |
column2: Homage to you dogs, and to you, lords of dogs, homage!

column1: namo bhavāya ca rudrāya ca namaḥ śarvāya ca paśupataye ca namo nīlagrīvāya ca śitikaṇṭhāya ca namaḥ kapardine ca vyuptakeśāya ca namaḥ sahasrākṣāya ca śatadhanvane ca namo giriśāya ca śipiviṣṭāya ca namo mīḍhuṣṭamāya ceṣumate ca namo hrasvāya ca vāmanāya ca namo bṛhate ca varṣīyase ca namo vṛddhāya ca saṃvṛdhvane ca |
column2: Homage to the wearer of braids, and to him of shaven hair. Homage to him of a thousand eyes, and to him of a hundred bows. Homage to him who haunteth the mountains, and to Çipivista. Homage to the most bountiful, and to the bearer of the arrow. Homage to the short, and to the dwarf.

column1: namo agriyāya ca prathamāya ca nama āśave cājirāya ca namaḥ śīghriyāya ca śībhyāya ca nama ūrmyāya cāvasvanyāya ca namaḥ srotasyāya ca dvīpyāya ca |
column2: Homage to him who hath waxed, and to the waxing. Homage to the chief, and to the first. Homage to the swift, and to the active. Homage to the rapid, and to the hasty. Homage to him of the wave, and to the roaring.

column1: namo jyeṣṭhāya ca kaniṣṭhāya ca namaḥ pūrvajāya cāparajāya ca namo madhyamāya cāpagalbhāya ca namo jaghanyāya ca budhniyāya ca namaḥ sobhyāya ca pratisaryāya ca namo yāmyāya ca kṣemyāya ca nama urvaryāya ca khalyāya ca namaḥ ślokyāya cāvasānyāya ca namo vanyāya ca kakṣyāya ca namaḥ śravāya ca pratiśravāya ca |
column2: Homage to the oldest, and to the youngest. Homage to the first born, and to the later born. Homage to the midmost, and to the immature. Homage to the hindmost, and to him in the depth. Homage to Sobhya, and to him of the amulet.

column1: nama āśuṣeṇāya cāśurathāya ca namaḥ śūrāya cāvabhindate ca namo varmiṇe ca varūthine ca namo bilmine ca kavacine ca namaḥ śrutāya ca śrutasenāya ca |
column2: Homage to him of the ploughed field, and to him of the threshing-floor. Homage to him of fame, and to him at his end. Homage to him of the wood, and to him of the thicket. Homage to sound, and to echo [1].

column1: namo dundubhyāya cāhanavyāya ca namo dhṛṣṇave ca pramṛśāya ca namo dūtāya ca prahitāya ca namo niṣaṅgiṇe ceṣudhimate ca namas tīkṣṇeṣave cāyudhine ca namaḥ svāyudhāya ca sudhanvane ca namaḥ srutyāya ca pathyāya ca namaḥ kāṭyāya ca nīpyāya ca namaḥ sūdyāya ca sarasyāya ca namo nādyāya ca vaiśantāya ca |
column2: Homage to him of the good weapon, and to him of the good bow. Homage to him of the stream,' and to him of the way. Homage to him of the hole,' and to him of the pool. Homage to him of the ditch, and to him of the lake. Homage to him of the stream, and to him of the tank 1 Homage to him of the cistern, and to him of the well.

column1: namaḥ kūpyāya cāvaṭyāya ca namo varṣyāya cāvarṣyāya ca namo meghyāya ca vidyutyāya ca nama īdhriyāya cātapyāya ca namo vātyāya ca reṣmiyāya ca namo vāstavyāya ca vāstupāya ca |
column2: Homage to him of the cloud, and to him of the lightning. Homage to him of the cloudy sky, and to him of the heat. Homage to him of the wind, and to him of the storm. Homage to him of the dwelling, and to him who guardeth the dwelling.

column1: namaḥ somāya ca rudrāya ca namas tāmrāya cāruṇāya ca namaḥ śaṃgāya ca paśupataye ca nama ugrāya ca bhīmāya ca namo agrevadhāya ca dūrevadhāya ca namo hantre ca hanīyase ca namo vṛkṣebhyo harikeśebhyas |

column1: namas tārāya namaḥ śambhave ca mayobhave ca namaḥ śaṃkarāya ca mayaskarāya ca namaḥ śivāya ca śivatarāya ca |
column2: Homage to the deliverer. Homage to the source of health, and to the source of delight. Homage to the maker of health, and to the maker of delight.

column1: namas tīrthyāya ca kūlyāya ca namaḥ pāryāya cāvārtyāya ca namaḥ prataraṇāya cottaraṇāya ca nama ātāryāya cālāṭyāya ca namaḥ śaṣpyāya ca phenyāya ca namaḥ sikatyāya ca pravāhyāya ca |
column2: Homage to the auspicious, and to the more auspicious. Homage to him of the ford, and to him of the bank. Homage to him beyond, and to him on this side. Homage to him who crosseth over, and to him who crosseth back. Homage to him of the crossing, and to him of the ocean.

column1: nama iriṇyāya ca prapathyāya ca namaḥ kiṃśilāya ca kṣayaṇāya ca namaḥ kapardine ca pulastaye ca namo goṣṭhyāya ca gṛhyāya ca namas talpyāya ca gehyāya ca namaḥ kāṭyāya ca gahvareṣṭhāya ca namo hradayyāya ca niveṣyyāya ca namaḥ pāṃsavyāya ca rajasyāya ca namaḥ śuṣkyāya ca harityāya ca namo lopyāya colapyāya ca |
column2: Homage to him of braided hair, and to him of plain hair. Homage to him who dwelleth in the cowshed, and to him of the house. Homage to him of the bed, and to him of the dwelling. Homage to him of the hole,' and to him of the abyss. Homage to him of the lake, and to him of the whirlpool.

column1: nama ūrvyāya ca sūrmyāya ca namaḥ parṇyāya ca parṇaśadyāya ca namo 'paguramāṇāya cābhighnate ca nama ākkhidate ca prakkhidate ca namo vaḥ kirikebhyo devānāṃ hṛdayebhyas |
column2: Homage to him of the leaf, and to him of the leaf-fall. Homage to him who growleth, and to him who smiteth away. Homage to him who draggeth, and to him who repelleth. Homage to you, sparkling hearts of the gods.

column1: namo vikṣīṇakebhyas |
column2: Homage to the destroyed.

column1: namo vicinvatkebhyas | nama ānirhatebhyas | nama āmīvatkebhyaḥ |
column2: Homage to the intelligent. Homage to the unconquerable. Homage to the destroyers.

column1: drāpe andhasas pate daridran nīlalohita | eṣām puruṣāṇām eṣām paśūnām mā bher māro mo eṣāṃ kiṃ canāmamat |
column2: O chaser, lord of the Soma plants, waster, red and blue, Frighten not nor injure (Any) of these people, of these cattle; Be not one of these injured.

column1: yā te rudra śivā tanūḥ śivā viśvāhabheṣajī | śivā rudrasya bheṣajī tayā no mṛḍa jīvase |
column2: That auspicious form of thine, O Rudra, Auspicious and ever healing, Auspicious and healing (form of) Rudra, With that show mercy on us for life.

column1: imāṃ rudrāya tavase kapardine kṣayadvīrāya pra bharāmahe matim | yathā naḥ śam asad dvipade catuṣpade viśvam puṣṭam grāme asmin |
column2: This prayer we offer up to the impetuous Rudra, With plaited hair, destroyer of men, That health be for our bipeds and quadrupeds, And that all in this village be prosperous [1] and free from ill.

column1: mṛḍā no rudrota no mayas kṛdhi kṣayadvīrāya namasā vidhema te |
column2: Be merciful to us, O Rudra, and give us delight; With honour let us worship thee, destroyer of men;

column1: yac chaṃ ca yoś ca manur āyaje pitā tad aśyāma tava rudra praṇītau |
column2: The health and wealth which father Manu won by sacrifice, May we attain that, O Rudra, under thy leadership.

column1: mā no mahāntam uta mā no arbhakam mā na ukṣantam uta mā na ukṣitam |
column2: Neither our great, nor our small, Our waxing or what has waxed, Do thou slay, nor father nor mother;

column1: rudra rīriṣaḥ |
column2: Injure not, O Rudra, our dear bodies [2].

column1: mā nas toke tanaye mā na āyuṣi mā no goṣu mā no aśveṣu rīriṣaḥ |
column2: Harm us not in our children, our descendants, our life; Harm us not in our cattle, in our horses;

column1: vīrān mā no rudra bhāmito vadhīr haviṣmanto namasā vidhema te |
column2: Smite not in anger our heroes, O Rudra; With oblations lot us serve thee with honour.

column1: ārāt te goghna uta pūruṣaghne kṣayadvīrāya sumnam asme te astu | rakṣā ca no adhi ca deva brūhy adhā ca naḥ śarma yacha dvibarhāḥ |
column2: From afar to thee, slayer of cows, and slayer of men, Destroyer of heroes, be goodwill for us; Guard us and accord us aid And grant us protection in abundance.

column1: śrutaṃ gartasadaṃ yuvānam mṛgaṃ na bhīmam upahatnum ugram |
column2: Praise [3] the famous youth, mounted on the chariot seat, Dread and destructive like a fierce wild beast;

column1: mṛḍā jaritre rudra stavāno anyaṃ te asman ni vapantu senāḥ |
column2: Being praised, O Rudra, be merciful to the singer; Let thy missiles smite down another than us.

column1: pari ṇo rudrasya hetir vṛṇaktu pari tveṣasya durmatir aghāyoḥ |
column2: May the missile of Rudra spare us, May the wrath of the brilliant evil worker (pass over us);

column1: mīḍuṣṭama śivatama śivo naḥ sumanā bhava |
column2: O most bounteous, most auspicious, Be auspicious and favourably inclined to us;

column1: parame vṛkṣa āyudhaṃ nidhāya kṛttiṃ vasāna ā cara pinākam | bibhrad ā gahi |
column2: Placing down thy weapon on the highest tree, Clad in thy skin, come, And approach us bearing the spear [4].

column1: vikirida vilohita namas te astu bhagavaḥ |
column2: 1 O blood-red scatterer, Homage to thee, O adorable one;

column1: yās te sahasraṃ hetayo 'nyam asman ni vapantu tāḥ |
column2: May thy thousand missiles Smite down another than us.

column1: sahasrāṇi sahasradhāḥ bāhuvos tava hetayaḥ |
column2: A thousandfold in thousands Are the missiles in thine arms;

column1: tāsām īśāno bhagavaḥ parācīnā mukhā kṛdhi |
column2: adorable one, do thou turn away The points of those which thou dost rule.

column1: sahasrāṇi sahasraśo ye rudrā adhi bhūmyām | teṣāṃ sahasrayojane 'va dhanvāni tanmasi |
column2: The Rudras that are over the earth In thousands by thousands, Their bows we unstring At a thousand leagues.

column1: nīlagrīvāḥ śitikaṇṭhāḥ śarvā adhaḥ kṣamācarāḥ | nīlagrīvāḥ śitikaṇṭhā divaṃ rudrā upaśritāḥ | ye vṛkṣeṣu saspiñjarā nīlagrīvā vilohitāḥ | ye bhūtānām adhipatayo viśikhāsaḥ kapardinaḥ | ye anneṣu vividhyanti pātreṣu pibato janān |
column2: The Bhavas in this great ocean, The atmosphere-- The Çarvas of black necks, and white throats, Who wander below on the earth-- The Rudras who abide in the sky, Of black necks and white throats-- Those who of black necks and ruddy, Grass green, are in the trees-- The overlords of creatures, Without top-knot, with braided hair-- Those that assault men in their food And in their cups as they drink-- Those that guard the paths, Bearing food, warriors-- Those that resort to fords [1], With spears and quivers-- The Rudras that so many and yet more Occupy the quarters, their bows we unstring At a thousand leagues.

column1: (mn) namo rudrebhyo ye pṛthivyāṃ ye 'ntarikṣe ye divi yeṣām annaṃ vāto varṣam iṣavas tebhyo daśa prācīr daśa dakṣiṇā daśa prātīcīr daśodīcīr daśordhvās tebhyo namas te no mṛḍayantu te yaṃ dviṣmo yaś ca no dveṣṭi taṃ vo jambhe dadhāmi |
column2: m n Homage to the Rudras on the earth, in the atmosphere, in the sky, whose arrows are food, wind, and rain, to them ten eastwards, ten to the south, ten to the west, ten to the north, ten upwards; to them homage, be they merciful to us, him whom we hate and him who hateth us, I place him within your jaws.

column1: aśmann ūrjam parvate śiśriyāṇāṃ vāte parjanye varuṇasya śuṣme | adbhya oṣadhībhyo vanaspatibhyo 'dhi sambhṛtāṃ tāṃ na iṣam ūrjaṃ dhatta marutaḥ saṃrarāṇāḥ |
column2: The Preparation of the Fire The strength resting on the stone, the bill, On the wind, on Parjanya, on the breath of Varuna, Brought together from the waters, from the plants, from the trees; That food and strength do ye, O Maruts, bounteously bestow upon us.

column1: aśmaṃs te kṣud amuṃ te śug ṛchatu yaṃ dviṣmaḥ samudrasya tvāvākayāgne pari vyayāmasi |
column2: In the stone is thy hunger; let thy pain reach N. N., whom we hate. With the wind of the ocean We envelop thee, O Agni;

column1: pāvako asmabhyaṃ śivo bhava |
column2: Be thou purifying and auspicious to us.

column1: himasya tvā jarāyuṇāgne pari vyayāmasi |
column2: With the caul of winter We envelop thee, O Agni;

column1: pāvako asmabhyaṃ śivo bhava |
column2: Be thou purifying and auspicious to us.

column1: upa | jmann upa vetase 'vattaraṃ nadīṣv ā |

column2: Who (cometh) to battle, Moving with strength as on Etaça's course, In the heat unathirst, immortal.

column1: agne pāvaka rociṣā mandrayā deva jihvayā | ā devān | vakṣi yakṣi ca |
column2: O Agni, the purifying, with thy light, god, with thy pleasant tongue, Bring hither the gods [2], and sacrifice.

column1: sa naḥ pāvaka dīdivo 'gne devāṃ ihā vaha | upa yajñaṃ haviś ca naḥ |
column2: Do thou, O shining and purifying one, Agni, bring hither the gods To our sacrifice and our oblation.

column1: apām idaṃ nyayanaṃ samudrasya niveśanam |
column2: 1 This is the meeting of the waters, The abode of the ocean;

column1: anyaṃ te asmat tapantu hetayaḥ pāvako asmabhyaṃ śivo bhava |
column2: May thy bolts afflict another than us; Be thou purifying and auspicious to us.

column1: namas te harase śociṣe namas te astv arciṣe |
column2: Homage to thy heat, thy blaze Homage be to thy light;

column1: anyaṃ te asmat tapantu hetayaḥ pāvako asmabhyaṃ śivo bhava |
column2: May thy bolts afflict another than us; Be thou purifying and auspicious to us.

column2: [3] To him that sitteth in the waters, hail! To him that sitteth in the wood, hail! To him that sitteth on the strew, hail!

column2: The gods who above the gods attained godhead, Who lead the way to this holy power, Without whom no place whatever is pure, Neither on the heights of sky or earth are they.

column1: prāṇadāḥ | apānadā vyānadāś cakṣurdā varcodā varivodāḥ |
column2: Giver of expiration art thou [4], of inspiration, of cross-breathing, Giver of eyesight, giver of splendour, giver of wide room;

column1: imaṃ no yajñaṃ vihave juṣasvāsya kurmo harivo medinaṃ tvā |

column1: viśvasyāṃ viśi praviviśivāṃsam īmahe sa no muñcatv aṃhasaḥ |
column2: Him who hath entered into every concourse do we implore, May he relieve us from tribulation.

column1: yasyedam prāṇan nimiṣad yad ejati yasya jātaṃ janamānaṃ ca kevalam | staumy agniṃ nāthito johavīmi sa no muñcatv aṃhasaḥ |
column2: Him whose is that which breatheth, which winketh, which moveth, Whose alone is that which has been born and is being born, Agni I praise; I invoke seeking aid, May he relieve us from tribulation.

column1: indrasya manve prathamasya pracetaso vṛtraghna stomā upa mām upāguḥ | yo dāśuṣaḥ sukṛto havam upa gantā | sa no muñcatv aṃhasaḥ |
column2: Of Indra first I reckon, the wise one; Praise of the slayer of Vrtra hath come to me, He who cometh at the call of the generous doer of good deeds [1], May he relieve us from tribulation.

column1: yaḥ saṃgrāmaṃ nayati saṃ vāśī yudhe yaḥ puṣṭāni saṃsṛjati trayāṇi |
column2: Him who in might leadeth forth the host for battle, Who commingleth the three possessions;

column1: satumīndraṃ nāthito johavīmi sa no muñcatv aṃhasaḥ |
column2: Indra I praise; I invoke seeking aid, May he relieve us from tribulation.

column1: manve vām mitrāvaruṇā tasya vittaṃ satyaujasā dṛṃhaṇā yaṃ nudethe |
column2: Of you, O Mitra and Varuna, I reckon Take heed of him, O ye of true strength, strong ones, whom ye afflict;

column1: yā rājānaṃ sarathaṃ yātha ugrā tā no muñcatam āgasaḥ |
column2: Ye who go in might against the king in his chariot, May ye relieve us from sin.

column1: yo vāṃ ratha ṛjuraśmiḥ satyadharmā mithuś carantam upayāti dūṣayan |
column2: You whose chariot with straight reins, of true path, Approacheth to spoil him who acteth falsely, Mitra and Varuna I praise [2];

column1: staumi | mitrāvaruṇā nāthito johavīmi tau no muñcatam āgasaḥ |
column2: I invoke seeking aid, May ye relieve us from sin.

column1: vāyoḥ savitur vidathāni manmahe yāv ātmanvad bibhṛto yau ca rakṣataḥ |
column2: We venerate the ordinances of Vayu and of Savitr, Who support that which hath life and guard it, Who surround all things;

column1: yau viśvasya paribhū babhūvatus tau no muñcatam āgasaḥ |
column2: May ye relieve us from sin.

column1: upa śreṣṭhā na āśiṣo devayor dharme asthiran |
column2: The best blessings have come to us In the realm of the two gods;

column1: staumi vāyuṃ savitāraṃ nāthito johavīmi tau no muñcatam āgasaḥ | rathītamau rathīnām ahva ūtaye śubhaṃ gamiṣṭhau suyamebhir aśvaiḥ |
column2: praise Vayu and Savitr; I invoke seeking aid, May ye relieve us from sin. Best charioteers of carmen, I hail for aid, That go most smoothly with well-guided steeds;

column1: vāṃ devau deveṣv aniśitam ojas tau no muñcatam āgasaḥ |
column2: Ye [3] whose might among the gods, O gods, is unextinguished, May ye relieve us from sin.

column1: yad ayātaṃ vahatuṃ sūryāyās tricakreṇa saṃsadam ichamānau | staumi devāv aśvinau nāthito johavīmi tau no muñcatam āgasaḥ |
column2: What time ye came to the wedding of Surya, Choosing a seat together on the three-wheeled (chariot), praise you, Açvins, gods, invoke seeking aid, May ye relieve us from sin.

column1: marutām manve adhi no bruvantu premāṃ vācaṃ viśvām avantu viśve |
column2: Of the Maruts I reckon; may they aid us; May they all help this every prayer (of ours);

column1: āśūn huve suyamān ūtaye te no muñcantv enasaḥ |
column2: The swift, easily controlled (ones) I call to help, May they relieve us from evil.

column1: tigmam āyudhaṃ vīḍitaṃ sāhasvad divyaṃ śardhaḥ | pṛtanāsu jiṣṇu | staumi devān maruto nāthito johavīmi te no muñcantv enasaḥ |
column2: The sharp weapon, strong and mighty, The divine host [4] keen in the battles, praise the gods, the Maruts; I invoke seeking aid, May they relieve us from evil.

column1: devānām manve adhi no bruvantu premāṃ vācaṃ viśvām avantu viśve |
column2: Of the gods I reckon; may they aid us; May they all help this every prayer;

column1: āśūn huve suyamān ūtaye te no muñcantvenasaḥ |
column2: The swift, easily controlled (ones) I call to help, That they may relieve us from evil.

column1: yad idam mābhiśocati pauruṣeyeṇa daivyena | satumi viśvān devān nāthito johavīmi te no muñcantv enasaḥ |
column2: That which now consumeth me From deed of men or gods, praise the All-gods; I invoke seeking aid, May they free us from evil.

column1: anu no 'dyānumatis |
column2: Us to-day Anumati.

column1: id anumate tvam |
column2: O Anumati, thou [5].

column1: vaiśvānaro na ūtyā pṛṣṭo divi ye aprathetām amitebhir ojobhir ye pratiṣṭhe abhavatāṃ vasūnām |
column2: Vaiçvanara for aid to us. Present in sky. Those that expanded with unmeasured might, Those that became the supports of wealth, praise sky and earth;

column1: staumi dyāvāpṛthivī nāthito johavīmi te no muñcatam aṃhasaḥ |
column2: I invoke seeking aid, May ye relieve us from tribulation.

column1: urvī rodasī varivaḥ kṛṇotaṃ kṣetrasya patnī adhi no brūyātam |
column2: O ye broad firmaments, make room for us; rulers of the field, aid us;

column1: staumi dyāvāpṛthivī nāthito johavīmi te no muñcatam aṃhasaḥ |
column2: praise sky and earth; I invoke seeking aid, May ye relieve us from tribulation.

column1: yat te vayam puruṣatrā yaviṣṭhāvidvāṃsaś cakṛmā kac cana | āgaḥ | kṛdhī sv asmāṃ aditer anāgā vy enāṃsi śiśratho viṣvag agne |
column2: Whatever sin we commit against thee, As men are wont in ignorance, O most young [6], Make us blameless before Aditi, Remove our evil deeds on all sides, O Agni.

column1: yathā ha tad vasavo gauryaṃ cit padi ṣitām amuñcatā yajatrāḥ | evā tvam asmat pra muñcā vy aṃhaḥ prātāry agne pratarāṃ na āyuḥ |
column2: Even as ye did set free, O bright ones, ye that are worthy of offering, the buffalo cow bound by the foot, So do thou remove from us tribulation; Be our life prolonged further, O Agni.

column1: sāvitrāṇi juhoti prasūtyai caturgṛhītena juhoti catuṣpādaḥ paśavaḥ paśūn evāva runddhe catasro diśas |
column2: The Placing of the Fire in the Fire-pan He offers the Savitr offerings, for instigation. He offers with (an oblation) ladled up four times, cattle have four feet;

column1: dikṣv eva prati tiṣṭhati chandāṃsi devebhyo 'pākrāman na vo 'bhāgāni havyaṃ vakṣyāma iti tebhya etac caturgṛhītam adhārayan puro'nuvākyāyai yājyāyai devatāyai vaṣaṭkārāya yac caturgṛhītaṃ juhoti chandāṃsy eva tat prīṇāti tāny asya prītāni devebhyo havyaṃ vahanti yaṃ kāmayeta |
column2: the quarters are four; verily he finds support in the quarters. The metres departed from the gods (saying), 'We will not carry your oblation without sharing (in it)'; for them they kept this (oblation) ladled up four times, for the Puronuvakya the Yajya, the deity, the Vasat call; in that he offers what has been ladled up four times, he delights the metres, and they delighted carry to the gods his oblation.

column1: pāpīyānt syād ity ekaikaṃ tasya juhuyāt |
column2: If he desire of a man [1], 'May he become worse', he should offer each separately for him;

column1: āhutībhir evainam apa gṛhṇāti pāpīyān bhavati yaṃ kāmayeta vasīyānt syād iti sarvāṇi tasyānudrutya juhuyāt |
column2: verily he makes him severed from the libations; he becomes worse. If he desire of a man, 'May he become better', he should offer all for him continuously;

column1: āhutyaivainam abhi kramayati vasīyān bhavati |
column2: verily he makes him master of the libation; he becomes better.

column1: atho yajñasyaivaiṣābhikrāntis | eti vā eṣa yajñamukhād ṛddhyā yo 'gner devatāyā eti |
column2: This is the mastering of the sacrifice. He abandons prosperity in the beginning of the sacrifice who departs from Agni as the deity;

column1: aṣṭāv etāni sāvitrāṇi bhavanti | aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatraḥ |
column2: these offerings to Savitr number eight, the Gayatri has eight syllables, Agni is connected with the Gayatri [2];

column1: agnis tenaiva yajñamukhād ṛddhyā agner devatāyai naiti |
column2: verily he does not abandon prosperity at the beginning of the sacrifice, nor Agni as the deity.

column1: aṣṭau sāvitrāṇi bhavanty āhutir navamī trivṛtam eva yajñamukhe vi yātayati yadi kāmayeta chandāṃsi yajñayaśasenārpayeyam ity ṛcam antamāṃ kuryāt |
column2: The offerings to Savitr number eight, the libation (as a whole) is the ninth; verily he extends the threefold (Stoma) at the beginning of the sacrifice. If he desire, 'May I confer on the metres the glory of the sacrifice', he should make a Re verse last;

column1: chandāṃsy eva yajñayaśasenārpayati yadi kāmayeta yajamānaṃ yajñayaśasenārpayeyam iti yajur antamaṃ kuryāt | yajamānam eva yajñayaśasenārpayati |
column2: If he desire, 'May I confer on the sacrificer the glory of the sacrifice', he should make a Yajus formula last; verily he confers on the sacrificer the glory of the sacrifice.

column1: ṛcā stomaṃ sam ardhayeti |
column2: 'By the Rc make the Stoma to flourish', he says [3], for prosperity.

column1: āha samṛddhyai caturbhir abhrim ā datte catvāri chandāṃsi chandobhir eva devasya tvā savituḥ prasava ity āha prasūtyai |
column2: With four (verses) he takes up the spade; the metres are four; verily (he takes it up) with the metres. 'On the instigation of god Savitr', he says, for instigation.

column1: agnir devebhyo nilāyata sa veṇum prāviśat sa etām ūtim anu sam acarad yad veṇoḥ suṣiram |
column2: Agni went away from the gods, he entered the reed; he resorted to the hole which is formed by the perforation of the reed;

column1: suṣirābhrir bhavati sayonitvāya sa yatrayatrāvasat tat kṛṣṇam abhavat kalmāsī bhavati rūpasamṛddhyai |
column2: the spade is perforated to make it his birthplace; wherever he lived, that became black; (the spade) is stained, for perfection of form;

column1: ubhayataḥkṣṇūr bhavati | itaś cāmutaś cārkasyāvaruddhyai vyāmamātrī bhavati |
column2: it is pointed at both ends, for the winning of light both hence and from yonder world; it is a fathom long;

column1: etāvad vai puruṣe vīryam |
column2: so much is the strength in man;

column1: vīryasammitā |
column2: (verily it is) commensurate with his strength;

column1: aparimitasyāvaruddhyai yo vanaspatīnām phalagrahiḥ sa eṣāṃ vīryāvān phalagrahir veṇus | vaiṇavī bhavati vīryasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: it is unlimited in girth, to win what is unlimited; that tree which has fruit is strong among trees, the reed bears fruit, (the spade) is of reed, to win strength.

column1: vyṛddhaṃ vā etad yajñasya yad ayajuṣkeṇa kriyate |
column2: That part of the sacrifice is unsuccessful which is performed with no Yajus.

column1: imām agṛbhṇan raśanām ṛtasyety aśvābhidhānīm ā datte yajuṣkṛtyai yajñasya samṛddhyai pratūrtaṃ vājinn ā dravety aśvam abhi dadhāti rūpam evāsyaitan mahimānaṃ vyācaṣṭe yuñjāthāṃ rāsabhaṃ yuvam iti gardabham asaty eva gardabham prati ṣṭhāpayati tasmād aśvād gardabho 'sattaras |
column2: 'This bond of order they grasped', (with these words) he takes up the horse's halter, to make a Yajus and to make successful the sacrifice. 'Swiftly run hither, O steed', (with these words) he halters the horse; verily he proclaims its greatness in this form. 'Yoke ye the ass', (with these words) (he halters) the ass; verily he establishes the ass on the non-existent;

column1: yogeyoge tavastaram ity āha |
column2: 'In each need more strong', he says [1];

column1: yoge yoga evainaṃ yuṅkte vājevāje havāmaha ity āha |
column2: verily in each need he yokes him; 'in each contest we invoke', he says;

column1: annaṃ vai vājas |
column2: verily he wins food.

column1: annam evāva runddhe sakhāya indram ūtaya ity āha | indriyam evāva runddhe |
column2: 'As friends, Indra to aid us', he says;

column1: agnir devebhyo nilāyata tam prajāpatir anv avindat prājāpatyo 'śvas |
column2: verily he wins power. Agni went away from the gods, him Prajapati found;

column1: aśvena sam bharaty anuvittyai pāpavasyasaṃ vā etat kriyate yac chreyasā ca pāpīyasā ca samānaṃ karma kurvanti pāpīyān |
column2: Now confusion occurs in that they perform the same thing with a better and worse (instrument), for the ass is worse than the horse [2]; they lead the horse in front to avoid confusion;

column1: hy aśvād gardabhas | aśvam pūrvaṃ nayanti pāpavasyasasya vyāvṛttyai tasmāc chreyāṃsam pāpīyān paścād anv eti bahur vai bhavato bhrātṛvyas |
column2: therefore the worse follows after the better. Many are the foes of the man who waxes great, he waxes great as it were who piles the fire, the steed has a thunderbolt;

column1: bhavatīva khalu vā eṣa yo 'gnim cinute vajry aśvaḥ pratūrvann ehy avakrāmann aśastīr ity āha vajreṇaiva pāpmānam bhrātṛvyam ava krāmati rudrasya gāṇapatyād ity āha raudrā vai paśavo rudrād eva |
column2: 'hastening come hither, trampling the enemy', he says; verily he tramples with the thunderbolt on the evil foe; 'from the lordship of Rudra', he says; cattle are connected with Rudra; verily having begged from Rudra [3] cattle he acts for his own interest.

column1: paśūn niryācyātmane karma kurute pūṣṇā sayujā sahety āha pūṣā vā adhvanāṃ saṃnetā samaṣṭyai purīṣāyatano vā eṣa yad agnis |
column2: 'With Pusan as fellow', he says; Pusan is the leader together of roads; (verily it serves) for attainment. The fire has dust for its abode;

column1: aṅgiraso vā etam agre devatānāṃ sam abharan pṛthivyāḥ sadhasthād agnim purīṣyam aṅgirasvad achehīty āha sāyatanam evainaṃ devatābhiḥ sam bharati |
column2: the Angirases brought it together before the deities; 'from the abode of earth do thou approach Agni of the dust in the mode of Angiras', he says; verily he brings it together in one abode with the deities.

column1: agnim purīṣyam aṅgirasvad achema ity āha yena |
column2: 'We approach Agni of the dust in the manner of Angiras', he says;

column1: saṃgachate vājam evāsya vṛṅkte prajāpataye pratiprocyāgniḥ sambhṛtya ity āhus |
column2: verily he appropriates the strength of him whom he meets [4]. 'The fire should be brought together after announcing it to Prajapati', they say;

column1: iyaṃ vai prajāpatis tasyā etac chrotraṃ yad valmīkas |
column2: Prajapati is this earth, the ant-heap is its ear;

column1: agnim purīṣyam aṅgirasvad bhariṣyāma iti valmīkavapām upa tiṣṭhate sākṣād eva prajāpataye pratiprocyāgniṃ sam bharati | agnim purīṣyam aṅgirasvad bharāma ity āha yena saṃgachate vājam evāsya vṛṅkte |
column2: 'we will bear Agni of the dust in the manner of Angiras', (with these words) he pays reverence to the mound of an ant-heap; verily after announcing it to Prajapati face to face, he brings together the fire. 'We bear Agni of the dust in the manner of Angiras', he says;

column1: anv agnir uṣasām agram | akhyad ity āha | anukhyātyai | āgatya vājy adhvana ākramya vājin prāthivīm ity āha |
column2: 'Agni hath gazed along the forefront of the dawns' [5], he says, to light up (the heaven). 'The steed coming, from the way', 'Coming to earth, O steed', he says;

column1: ichaty evainam pūrvayā vindaty uttarayā dvābhyām ā kramayati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: verily he wishes for it with the first and obtains it with the second; with two (verses) he makes it come, for support;

column1: tasmād anurūpāḥ paśavaḥ pra jāyante dyaus te pṛṣṭham pṛthivī sadhastham ity āha |
column2: (with two) of the same form, therefore cattle are born of the same form. 'Thy back is the sky, thy abode earth', he says;

column1: ebhyo vā etaṃ lokebhyaḥ prajāpatiḥ sam airayat |
column2: Prajapati quickened him from these worlds;

column1: rūpam evāsyaitan mahimānaṃ vyācaṣṭe vajrī vā eṣa yad aśvas |
column2: verily he proclaims its greatness in this form.

column1: dadbhir anyatodadbhyo bhūyāM lomabhir ubhayādadbhyas |
column2: The steed is possessed of the thunderbolt, by its incisors it is more puissant than those with one row of incisors, by its hair than those with two rows;

column1: yaṃ dviṣyāt tam adhaspadaṃ dhyāyet |
column2: him whom he hates he should conceive as beneath its feet;

column1: vajreṇaivainaṃ stṛṇute |
column2: verily with the thunderbolt he lays him low.

column1: ut krāmod akramīd iti dvābhyām ut kramayati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'The strong steed hath stepped forth', with these two (verses) he makes it step forth;

column1: anurūpābhyām | tasmād anurūpāḥ paśavaḥ pra jāyante |
column2: (with two) of the same form, therefore cattle are born of the same form.

column1: apa upa sṛjati yatra vā āpa upagachanti tad oṣadhayaḥ prati tiṣṭhanti | oṣadhīḥ pratitiṣṭhantīḥ paśavo 'nu prati tiṣṭhanti paśūn yajñas | yajñaṃ yajamānas |
column2: He pours water down; where there are waters, there Plants take root, and where plants take root cattle find support through them, the sacrifice (finds support) in cattle, the sacrificer in the sacrifice, offspring in the sacrificer;

column1: yajamānam prajās tasmād apa upa sṛjati pratiṣṭhityai yad adhvaryur anagnāv āhutiṃ juhuyād andho 'dhvaryuḥ | syād rakṣāṃsi yajñaṃ hanyus |
column2: therefore he pours water down, for support. If the Adhvaryu were to pour the libation on that which is without fire, the Adhvaryu would be [1] blind, the Raksases would destroy the sacrifice;

column1: hiraṇyam upāsya juhoti |
column2: he puts gold down and offers;

column1: agnivaty eva juhoti nāndho 'dhvaryur bhavati na yajñaṃ rakṣāṃsi ghnanti jigharmy agnim manasā ghṛtenety āha manasā hi puruṣo yajñam abhigachati pratikṣyantam bhuvanāni viśvety āha sarvaṃ hy eṣa pratyaṅ kṣeti pṛthuṃ tiraścā vayasa bṛhantam ity āha |
column2: verily he pours on what has fire, the Adhvaryu does not become blind, the Raksases do not destroy the sacrifice. 'I touch Agni with mind, with ghee', he says, for with mind man approaches the sacrifice; 'who lordeth it over all the worlds', he says, for he lords it over all;

column1: alpo hy eṣa jāto mahān | bhavati vyaciṣṭham annaṃ rabhasaṃ vidānam ity āha |
column2: 'broad, vast, with pervading vital power', he says, for he born small becomes great [2]; 'most extensive, impetuous, winning food', he says;

column1: annam evāsmai svadayati sarvam asmai svadate ya evaṃ veda |
column2: verily he makes pleasant food for him; all is pleasant for him who knows thus.

column1: ā tvā jigharmi vacasā ghṛtenety āha tasmād yat puruṣo manasābhigachati tad vācā vadati |
column2: 'I touch thee with speech, with ghee', he says; therefore what a man conceives with mind he utters with speech;

column1: arakṣasety āha rakṣasām apahatyai martyaśrī spṛhayadvarṇo agnir ity āha |
column2: 'with friendly (mind) he says, to smite away the Raksases; 'with mortal glory, with engaging colour, Agni', he says;

column1: apacitim evāsmin dadhāti |
column2: verily he bestows beauty upon him;

column1: apacitimān bhavati ya evaṃ |
column2: he is possessed of beauty who knows thus [3].

column1: veda manasā tvai tām āptum arhati yām adhvaryur anagnāv āhutiṃ juhoti manasvatībhyāṃ juhoti |
column2: By mind must he obtain that libation which the Adhvaryu offers in that which is without fire; he offers with two verses containing the word 'mind', to obtain the two libations;

column1: āhutyor āptyai dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityai yajñamukheyajñamukhe vai kriyamāṇe yajñaṃ rakṣāṃsi jighāṃsanti |
column2: with two (he offers), for support. As the beginning of the sacrifice is performed the Raksases are fain to destroy the sacrifice;

column1: etarhi khalu vā etad yajñamukhaṃ yarhy enad āhutir aśnute pari likhati rakṣasām apahatyai tisṛbhiḥ pari likhati trivṛd vā agnis |
column2: now then is this (place) the beginning of the sacrifice when the libation comes upon it; he draws a line around, to smite away the Raksases; with three (verses) he draws a line around, Agni is threefold;

column1: yāvān evāgnis tasmād rakṣāṃsy apa hanti |
column2: verily from the whole extent of Agni he smites away the Raksases [4];

column1: gāyatriyā pari likhati tejo vai gāyatrī tejasaivainam pari gṛhṇāti triṣṭubhā pari likhati | indriyaṃ vai {triṣṭug < triṣṭubh} indriyeṇaivainam pari gṛhṇāti |
column2: with a Gayatri verse he draws a line around, the Gayatri is brilliance; verily with brilliance, he encircles him; with a Tristubh verse he draws a line around, the Tristubh is power;

column1: anuṣṭubhā pari likhati |
column2: verily he encircles him with power;

column1: anuṣṭup sarvāṇi chandāṃsi paribhūḥ paryāptyai madhyato 'nuṣṭubhā vāg vā {anuṣṭup < anuṣṭubh} tasmān madhyato vācā vadāmas |
column2: with an Anustubh verse he draws a line around, the Anustubh, envelops all the metres, (verily it serves) for complete attainment; with the Anustubh in the middle (he draws), the Anustubh is speech, therefore from the middle we speak with speech;

column1: gāyatriyā prathamayā pari likhaty athānuṣṭubhātha triṣṭubhā tejo vai gāyatrī yajño 'nuṣṭug indriyaṃ {triṣṭup < triṣṭubh} tejasā caivendriyeṇa cobhayato yajñam pari gṛhṇāti |
column2: with the Gayatri first he draws, then with the Anustubh, then with the Tristubh; the Gayatri is brilliance, the Anustubh the sacrifice, the Tristubh power; verily he encircles the sacrifice, with brilliance and power, on both sides.

column1: devasya tvā savituḥ prasava iti khanati prasūtyā atho dhūmam evaitena janayati jyotiṣmantaṃ tvāgne supratīkam ity āha jyotir evaitena janayati so 'gnir jātaḥ prajāḥ śucārpayat taṃ devā ardharcenāśamayan |
column2: 'On the instigation of the god Savitr thee', (with these words) he digs, for instigation. Then with it he produces smoke; 'Full of light, thee, O Agni, of fair aspect', he says, and thereby he produces light. Agni on birth afflicted creatures with pain, him the gods appeased by the half-verse;

column1: śivam prajābhyo 'hiṃsantam ity āha prajābhya evainaṃ śamayati dvābhyāṃ khanati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'auspicious and harmless to offspring', he says; verily he makes him appeased for offspring. He digs with two (verses), for support.

column1: apām pṛṣṭham asīti puṣkaraparṇam ā |
column2: the lotus leaf is the back of the waters;

column1: haraty apāṃ vā etat pṛṣṭhaṃ yat puṣkaraparṇaṃ rūpeṇaivainad ā harati puṣkaraparṇena sam bharati yonir vā agneḥ puṣkaraparṇaṃ sayonim evāgniṃ sam bharati kṛṣṇājinena sam bharati yajño vai kṛṣṇājinaṃ yajñenaiva yajñaṃ sam bharati yad grāmyāṇām paśūnāṃ carmaṇā sambhared grāmyān paśūñ chucārpayet kṛṣṇājinena sam bharaty āraṇyān eva paśūn |
column2: verily he gathers Agni with his own birthplace. He gathers with a black antelope skin; the black antelope skin is the sacrifice; verily he gathers the sacrifice with the sacrifice. If he were to gather with the skin of tame animals he would afflict with pain tame animals;

column1: śucārpayati tasmāt samāvat paśūnām prajāyamānānām āraṇyāḥ paśavaḥ kanīyāṃsaḥ śucā hy ṛtās |
column2: verily he afflicts with pain wild animals [2]; therefore of animals of even birth the wild animals are the smaller, for they are afflicted with pain.

column1: lomataḥ sam bharaty ato hy asya medhyam |
column2: He gathers on the hairy side, for on that side is it pure.

column1: kṛṣṇājinaṃ ca puṣkaraparṇaṃ ca saṃ stṛṇātīyaṃ vai kṛṣṇājinam asau puṣkaraparṇam ābhyām evainam ubhayataḥ pari gṛhṇāti |
column2: He strews the lotus leaf and the black antelope skin together; the black antelope skin is this (earth), the lotus leaf yonder (sky); verily on both sides he encircles him with these two.

column1: agnir devebhyo nilāyata tam atharvānv apaśyat |
column2: Agni departed from the gods, Atharvan perceived him;

column1: atharvā tvā prathamo nir amanthad agna iti |
column2: 'Atharvan first pressed thee out, O Agni' [3], he says;

column1: āha ya evainam anvapaśyat tenaivainaṃ sam bharati tvām agne puṣkarād adhīty āha puṣkaraparṇe hy enam upaśritam avindat tam u tvā dadhyaṅṅ ṛṣir ity āha dadhyaṅ vā ātharvaṇas tejasvy āsīt teja evāsmin dadhāti tam u tvā pāthyo vṛṣety āha pūrvam evoditam uttareṇābhi gṛṇāti |
column2: 'Thee, O Agni, from the lotus', he says, for in the lotus leaf he found him reposing. 'Thee the sage, Dadhyañc', he says; Dadhyañc, son of Atharvan, was full of brilliance; verily he bestows brilliance upon him. 'Thee Pathya Vrsan', he says;

column1: catasṛbhiḥ sam bharati catvāri chandāṃsi chandobhir eva gāyatrībhir brāhmaṇasya gāyatro hi brāhmaṇas triṣṭugbhī rājanyasya traiṣṭubho hi rājanyo yaṃ kāmayeta vasīyānt syād ity ubhayībhis tasya sam bharet tejaś caivāsmā indriyaṃ ca samīcī dadhāty aṣṭābhiḥ sam bharaty aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatro 'gnir yāvān evāgnis taṃ sam bharati sīda hotar ity āha devatā evāsmai saṃ sādayati ni hoteti manuṣyānt saṃ sīdasveti vayāṃsi janiṣvā hi jenyo agre ahnām ity āha devamanuṣyān evāsmai saṃsannān pra janayati |
column2: He gathers with four (verses), the metres are four; verily (he gathers) with the metres. (He gathers) with Gayatri verses for a Brahman, for the Brahman is connected with the Gayatri; with Tristubh verses for a Rajanya, for the Rajanya is connected with the Tristubh; if he desire of a man, 'May he be richer', he should gather for him with both sets;

column1: krūram iva vā asyā etat karoti yat khanati |
column2: In that he digs he acts as it were harshly to this (earth);

column1: apa upa sṛjati |
column2: he pours water down, the waters are appeased;

column1: āpo vai śāntāḥ śāntābhir evāsyai śucaṃ śamayati saṃ te vāyur mātariśvā dadhātv ity āha prāṇo vai vāyuḥ prāṇenaivāsyai prāṇaṃ saṃ dadhāti saṃ te vayur ity āha tasmād vāyupracyutā divo vṛṣṭir īrte tasmai ca devi vaṣaḍ astu |
column2: Vayu is breath; verily with breath he unites her breath; 'may for thee Vayu', he says; therefore the rain speeds from the sky, made to fall by Vayu. 'To him, O goddess, be Vasat with thee' [1], he says;

column1: tubhyam ity āha ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva vṛṣṭiṃ dadhāti tasmāt sarvān ṛtūn varṣati yad vaṣaṭkuryād rakṣāṃsi yajñaṃ hanyus |
column2: verily upon the seasons he bestows rain; therefore in all the seasons it rains. If he were to utter the Vasat cry, his Vasat cry would be exhausted;

column1: vaḍ ity āha paro'kṣam eva vaṣaṭ karoti nāsya yātayāmā vaṣaṭkāro bhavati na yajñaṃ rakṣāṃsi ghanati sujāto jyotiṣā sahety anuṣṭubhopa nahyati |
column2: if he were not to utter the Vasat cry, the Raksases would destroy the sacrifice; 'Vat', he says; verily, mysteriously he utters the Vasat cry; his Vasat cry is not exhausted, the Raksases do not destroy the sacrifice.

column1: anuṣṭup |
column2: 'Well born with light', (with these words) he ties up with an Anustubh verse;

column1: sarvāṇi chandāṃsi chandāṃsi khalu vā agneḥ priyā tanūḥ priyayaivainaṃ tanuvā pari dadhāti veduko vāso bhavati ya evaṃ veda vāruṇo vā agnir upanaddhas |
column2: all the metres are the Anustubh [2], Agni's dear body is the metres; verily he encircles him with his dear body; likely to win a garment is he who knows thus. Agni when tied up is connected with Varuna;

column1: ud u tiṣṭha svadhvarordhva ū ṣu ṇa ūtaya iti sāvitrībhyām ut tiṣṭhati savitṛprasūta evāsyordhvāṃ varuṇa menim ut sṛjati dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityai sa jāto garbho asi | rodasyor ity āha |
column2: 'Arise, thou of fair sacrifice', 'Arise, erect, to aid us', with two (verses) addressed to Savitr he rises up; verily, instigated by Savitr, he sends aloft the wrath of Varuna that is in him; with two (verses) (he arises), for support. 'Born, thou art the child [3] of the two worlds, he says;

column1: ime vai rodasī tayor eṣa garbho yad agnis tasmād evam āha |
column2: the two worlds are these two (sky and earth), Agni is the child of the two;

column1: agne cārur vibhṛta oṣadhīṣv ity āha yadā hy etaṃ vibharanty atha cārutaro bhavati pra mātṛbhyo adhi kanikradad gā ity āha |
column2: 'O Agni, brilliant, distributed among the plants', he says, for when they distribute him, then he becomes more brilliant. 'Thou didst come thundering from thy mothers', he says;

column1: oṣadhayo vā asya mātaras tābhya evainam pra cyāvayati sthiro bhava vīḍvaṅga iti gardabha ā sādayati |
column2: his mothers are the plants; verily from them he makes him to fall. 'Be firm, of strong limbs', (with these words) he places (Agni) on the ass [4];

column1: saṃ nahyaty evainam etayā sthemne gardabhena sam bharati tasmād gardabhaḥ paśūnām bhārabhāritamas |
column2: verily thereby he yokes it for strength. He gathers with the ass; therefore the ass is the best burdengatherer of animals.

column1: gardabhena sam bharati tasmād gardabho 'py anāleśety anyān paśūn medyati |
column2: therefore the ass, even when grazing is bad, becomes fat beyond other animals, for by it they gather food and light.

column1: annaṃ hy enenārkaṃ sambharanti gardabhena sam bharati tasmād gardabho dviretāḥ san kaniṣṭham paśūnām pra jāyate | agnir hy asya yoniṃ nirdahati prajāsu vā eṣa etarhy ārūḍhaḥ |
column2: He gathers with the ass; therefore the ass, being of double seed, is born as the least of animals, for Agni burns his place of birth. Now he is mounted upon offspring [5], and is strong to burn with pain offspring.

column1: sa īśvaraḥ prajāḥ śucā pradahaḥ śivo bhava prajābhya ity āha prajābhya evainaṃ śamayati mānuṣībhyas tvam aṅgira ity āha mānavyo hi prajās |
column2: 'Be auspicious, for offspring', he says; verily he makes him calm for offspring. '(For offspring) of man, O Angiras', he says, for offspring are of men.

column1: mā dyāvāpṛthivī abhi śūśuco māntarikṣam mā vanaspatīn ity āha |
column2: 'Scorch not sky and earth, nor the atmosphere, nor the trees', he says;

column1: ebhya evainaṃ lokebhyaḥ śamayati praitu vājī kanikradad ity āha vājī hy {eṣa < eṣas} nānadad rāsabhaḥ patveti | āha rāsabha iti hy etam ṝṣayo 'vadan bharann agnim purīṣyam ity āha |
column2: verily he makes him calm for these worlds. 'Let the steed advance, thundering', he says, for he is a steed. 'The sounding, the donkey, the flier' [6], he says, for the seers called him the 'donkey'. 'Bearing Agni of the dust', he says, for he bears Agni.

column1: agniṃ hy eṣa bharati mā pādy āyuṣaḥ purety āha |
column2: 'May he fall not before his day', he says; verily he bestows life upon him;

column1: āyur evāsmin dadhāti tasmād gardabhaḥ sarvam āyur eti tasmād gardabhe purāyuṣaḥ pramīte bibhyati vṛṣāgniṃ vṛṣaṇam bharann ity āha vṛṣā hy {eṣa < eṣas} vṛṣāgnis |
column2: therefore an ass lives all its days; therefore are men afraid when an ass perishes before its day. 'The strong, bearing the strong Agni', he says, for he is strong, and Agni is strong.

column1: apāṃ garbham | samudriyam ity āha | apāṃ hy eṣa garbho yad agnis |
column2: 'Germ of the waters [7], him of the ocean', he says, for Agni is the germ of the waters.

column1: agna ā yāhi vītaya iti vā imau lokau vy aitām agna ā yāhi vītaya iti yad āha | anayor lokayor vītyai pracyuto vā eṣa āyatanād agataḥ pratiṣṭhām |
column2: 'O Agni, come hither for enjoyment', (at these words) the two worlds burst apart; in that he says, 'O Agni, come hither for enjoyment', it is for the separation (vityai) of these worlds.

column1: sa etarhy adhvaryuṃ ca yajamānaṃ ca dhyāyati |
column2: He, having left his place and not having reached a support, then thinks of the Adhvaryu and the sacrificer;

column1: ṛtaṃ satyam ity āha |
column2: 'holy order and truth', he says;

column1: iyaṃ vā ṛtam asau | satyam anayor evainam prati ṣṭhāpayati nārtim ārchaty adhvaryur na yajamānas |
column2: holy order is this (earth), truth [8] is yonder (sky); verily in these two he establishes him, and neither the Adhvaryu nor the sacrificer is ruined.

column1: varuṇo vā eṣa yajamānam abhy aiti yad agnir upanaddhas |
column2: Agni when tied up, as Varuna, attacks the sacrificer;

column1: oṣadhayaḥ prati gṛhṇītāgnim etam ity āha śāntyai vyasyan viśvā amatīr arātīr ity āha rakṣasām apahatyai niṣīdan no apa durmatiṃ hanad ity āha pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'O plants, do ye accept Agni here', he says, for atonement. 'Casting aside all hostilities, all evil imaginings', he says, to smite away the Raksases. 'Sitting down, may he smite away from us misfortune', he says, for support.

column1: oṣadhayaḥ prati modadhvam | enam ity āha |
column2: 'O plants, do ye rejoice [9] in him', he says;

column1: oṣadhayo vā agner bhāgadheyam |
column2: Agni's portion is the plants;

column1: tābhir evainaṃ sam ardhayati puṣpāvatīḥ supippalā ity āha tasmād oṣadhayaḥ phalaṃ gṛhṇanti |
column2: verily he unites him with them. 'Rich in flowers and having fair leaves', he says; therefore plants produce fruit.

column1: ayaṃ vo garbha ṛtviyaḥ pratnaṃ sadhastham āsadad ity āha yābhya evainam pracyāvayati tāsv evainam prati ṣṭhāpayati dvābhyām upāvaharati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'This germ of yours, of due season, hath sat him in his ancient seat', he says; verily in those he establishes them from whom he makes him to fall. With two verses he deposits (it), for support.

column1: vāruṇo vā agnir upanaddhas |
column2: Agni when tied up is connected with Varuna;

column1: vi pājaseti vi sraṃsayati savitṛprasūta evāsya viṣūcīṃ varuṇameniṃ vi sṛjati |
column2: verily, instigated by Savitr, he lets loose on all sides the wrath of Varuna that is in him.

column1: apa upa sṛjati |
column2: He pours water down;

column1: āpo vai śāntāḥ śāntābhir evāsya śucaṃ śamayati tisṛbhir upa sṛjati trivṛd vā agnis |
column2: with three (verses) he pours (it) down, Agni is three fold; verily he calms Agni's pain throughout his whole extent.

column1: yāvān evāgnis tasya śucaṃ śamayati mitraḥ saṃsṛjya pṛthivīm ity āha mitro vai śivo devānām |
column2: 'Mitra having united the earth', he says; Mitra is the auspicious one of the gods; verily [1] with him he unites him, for atonement.

column1: enaṃ saṃ sṛjati śāntyai yad grāmyāṇām pātrāṇāṃ kapālaiḥ saṃsṛjed grāmyāṇi pātrāṇi śucārpayet |
column2: If he were to unite him with sherds of domestic pots, he would afflict domestic pots with pain; he unites (him) with fragments of broken pots;

column1: armakapālaiḥ saṃ sṛjati |
column2: He unites (him) with goat-hair;

column1: etāni vā anupajīvanīyāni tāny eva śucārpayati śarkarābhiḥ saṃ sṛjati dhṛtyai |
column2: verily he unites him with his dear form, and thus with brilliance. He unites him with the hairs of a black antelope skin [2];

column1: atho śaṃtvāya | ajalomaiḥ saṃ sṛjati |
column2: verily he unites the sacrifice with the sacrifice.

column1: yajñenaiva yajñaṃ saṃ sṛjati rudrāḥ sambhṛtya pṛthivīm ity āha |
column2: 'The Rudras, having gathered together the earth', he says; these deities first gathered him together;

column1: etā vā etaṃ devatā agre sam abharan tābhir evainaṃ sam bharati makhasya śiro 'sīty āha yajño vai makhasa tasyaitac chiro yad ukhā tasmād evam āha yajñasya pade stha ity āha yajñasya hy ete |
column2: 'Thou art the head of Makha', he says; Makha is the sacrifice, the firepan is his head; therefore he says thus. 'Ye are the two feet of the sacrifice', he says, for these are the two feet of the sacrifice [3]; and also (it serves) for support.

column1: pade atho pratiṣṭhityai prānyābhir yachaty anv anyair mantrayate mithunatvāya tryuddhiṃ karoti traya ime lokā eṣāṃ lokānām āptyai chandobhiḥ karoti vīryaṃ vai chandāṃsi vīryeṇaivaināṃ karoti yajuṣā bilaṃ karoti vyāvṛttyai |
column2: He hands (the pan) over with one set (of verses), and addresses it with another, to make a pairing. He makes it with a triple stand; these worlds are three; (verily it serves) to obtain these worlds. He makes (it) with the metres;

column1: iyatīṃ karoti prajāpatinā yajñamukhena sammitām |
column2: He makes it so great, of equal girth with Prajapati, the beginning of the sacrifice.

column1: dvistanāṃ karoti dyāvāpṛthivyor dohāya catustanāṃ karoti paśūnāṃ dohāya |
column2: He makes it with two breasts, for the milking of sky and earth; he makes it of four breasts, for the milking of cattle;

column1: aṣṭāstanāṃ karoti chandasāṃ dohāya navāśrim abhicarataḥ kuryāt trivṛtam eva vajraṃ sambhṛtya bhrātṛvyāya pra harati stṛtyai kṛtvāya sa mahīm ukhām iti ni dadhāti devatāsv evainām prati ṣṭhāpayati |
column2: he makes it of eight breasts, for the milking of the metres. For him who practises witchcraft he should make it nine cornered; verily gathering together the threefold thunderbolt he hurls it at his foe, to lay him low. 'Having made the great pan', (with these words) he deposits (it); verily he establishes it among the deities.

column1: saptabhir dhūpayati sapta vai śīrṣaṇyāḥ prāṇāḥ śira etad yajñasya yad ukhā śīrṣann eva yajñasya prāṇān dadhāti tasmāt sapta śīrṣan prāṇās |
column2: With seven (verses) he fumigates; the breaths in the head are seven, the pan is the head of the sacrifice; verily he places the breaths in the head of the sacrifice; therefore seven are the breaths in the head.

column1: aśvaśakena dhūpayati prājāpatyo vā aśvaḥ sayonitvāya |
column2: He fumigates with horse-dung; the horse is connected with Prajapati;

column1: aditis tvety āha |
column2: 'May Aditi thee', he says;

column1: iyaṃ vā aditis |
column2: Aditi is this (earth);

column1: adityaivādityāṃ khanaty asyā akrūraṃkārāya na hi svaḥ svaṃ hinasti devānāṃ tvā patnīr ity āha devānām |
column2: verily with Aditi in Aditi he digs, to avoid injury to it, for one hurts not oneself. 'May the wives of the gods thee', he says; the wives of the gods made it first [1];

column1: vā etām patnayo 'gre 'kurvan tābhir evaināṃ dadhāti dhiṣaṇās tvety āha vidyā vai dhiṣaṇās |
column2: verily with them he places it. 'May the Dhisanas thee', he says; the Dhisanas are the sciences;

column1: vidyābhir evainām abhīnddhe gnās tvety āha chandāṃsi vai gnās |
column2: verily he enkindles it with the sciences. 'May the wives thee', he says;

column1: chandobhir evaināṃ śrapayati varūtrayas tvety āha hotrā vai varūtrayas |
column2: 'May the protectors, he says; the protectors are the Hotr's offices; verily with the Hotr's offices he cooks it.

column1: hotrābhir evainām pacati janayas tvety āha devānāṃ vai patnīḥ |
column2: 'May the women thee', he says; the women are the wives of the gods [2]; verily with them he cooks it.

column1: janayas tābhir evainām pacati ṣaḍbhiḥ pacati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: With six (verses) he cooks; the seasons are six; verily with the seasons he cooks it.

column1: ṛtubhir evainām pacati dviḥ pacantv ity āha tasmād dviḥ saṃvatsarasya sasyam pacyate vāruṇy ukhābhīddhā maitriyopaiti śāntyai devas tvā savitod vapatv ity āha savitṛprasūta evainām brahmaṇā devatābhir ud vapati |
column2: therefore twice in the year does the corn ripen. The pan when enkindled is connected with Varuna; he approaches it with (a verse) addressed to Mitra, for atonement. 'May the god Savitr dig thee out', he says; verily, instigated by Savitr, he digs it out with holy power and with the deities.

column1: apadyamānā pṛthivy āśā diśa ā pṛṇa |
column2: 'Breaking not, O earth, fill the regions, the quarters' [3], he says;

column1: ity āha tasmād agniḥ sarvā diśo 'nu vi bhāti |
column2: therefore Agni shines along all the quarters.

column1: ut tiṣṭha bṛhatī bhavordhvā tiṣṭha dhruvā tvam ity āha pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'Arise, become great, stand upright, be thou firm', he says, for support.

column1: asuryam pātram anāchṛṇṇam ā chṛṇatti devatrākar ajakṣīreṇā chṛṇatti paramaṃ vā etat payo yad ajakṣīram parameṇaivainam payasā chṛṇatti yajuṣā vyāvṛttyai chandobhir ā chṛṇatti chandobhir vā eṣā kriyate chandobhir eva chandāṃsy ā chṛṇatti |
column2: A bowl that is not poured upon is connected with the Asuras; he pours upon it; verily he makes it to be with the gods; with goats' milk he pours upon it; the milk of the goat is the highest form of draught;

column1: ekaviṃśatyā māṣaiḥ puruṣaśīrṣam achaiti |
column2: With twenty-one beans he approaches the head of the man;

column1: amedhyā vai māṣā amedhyam puruṣaśīrṣam amedhyair evāsyāmedhyaṃ niravadāya medhyaṃ kṛtvā harati |
column2: beans are impure, the man's head is impure; verily by the impure he redeems its impurity and making it pure takes it.

column1: ekaviṃśatir bhavanti |
column2: There are twentyone;

column1: ekaviṃśo vai puruṣaḥ puruṣasyāptyai vyṛddhaṃ vā etat prāṇair amedhyaṃ yat puruṣaśīrṣam |
column2: man is composed of twenty-one parts; (verily they serve) to obtain man. The man's head is impure as bereft of the breaths;

column1: saptadhā vitṛṇṇāṃ valmīkavapām prati ni dadhāti sapta vai śīrṣaṇyāḥ prāṇāḥ prāṇair evainat sam ardhayati medhyatvāya yāvantaḥ |
column2: he deposits (it near) an ant-heap pierced in seven places; the breaths in the head are seven; verily he unites it with the breaths, to make it pure.

column1: vai mṛtyubandhavas teṣāṃ yama ādhipatyam parīyāya yamagāthābhiḥ pari gāyati yamād evainad vṛṅkte tisṛbhiḥ pari gāyati traya ime lokās |
column2: Of all those [1] that were comrades of death Yama holds the overlordship; he sings the verses of Yama; verily from Yama he redeems it; with three he sings; three are these worlds;

column1: ebhya evainal lokebhyo vṛṅkte tasmād gāyate na deyam | gāthā hi tad vṛṅkte |
column2: verily from these worlds he redeems it; therefore one should not give to one who sings, for the Gatha appropriates it.

column1: agnibhyaḥ paśūn ā labhate kāmā vā agnayaḥ kāmān evāva runddhe yat paśūn nālabhetānavaruddhā asya |
column2: the fires are desires; verily he wins his desires. If he were not to offer the animals, then he would not obtain animals [2];

column1: paśavaḥ syus | yat paryagnikṛtān utsṛjed yajñaveśasaṃ kuryāt |
column2: if he were to let them go after circumambulation with fire, he would disturb the sacrifice;

column1: yat saṃsthāpayed yātayāmāni śīrṣāṇi syus |
column2: if he were to keep them until the conclusion, the heads would be exhausted;
