column1: yat paśūn ālabhate tenaiva paśūn ava runddhe yat paryagnikṛtān utsṛjati śīrṣṇām ayātayāmatvāya prājāpatyena saṃ sthāpayati yajño vai prajāpatir yajña eva yajñam prati ṣṭhāpayati prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata sa riricāno 'manyata sa etā āprīr apaśyat tābhir vai sa mukhataḥ |
column2: in that he offers the animals, he wins thereby animals; in that he lets them go after circumambulation with fire, (it serves) to prevent the exhaustion of the heads; he concludes (the rite) with (an animal) for Prajapati; Prajapati is the sacrifice; verily he concludes the sacrifice in the sacrifice.

column1: ātmānam āprīṇīta yad etā āpriyo bhavanti yajño vai prajāpatis | yajñam evaitābhir mukhata ā prīṇāti |
column2: In that there are these April verses, and Prajapati is the sacrifice, he satisfies the sacrifice from the beginning with them.

column1: aparimitachandaso bhavanti |
column2: They are of unlimited metres;

column1: aparimitaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpater āptyai |
column2: Prajapati is unlimited; (verily they serve) to obtain Prajapati.

column1: ūnātiriktā mithunāḥ prajātyai lomaśaṃ vai nāmaitac chandaḥ prajāpateḥ paśavo lomaśāḥ paśūn evāva runddhe sarvāṇi vā etā rūpāṇi sarvāṇi rūpāṇy agnau citye kriyante tasmād etā agneś cityasya |
column2: The pairs are deficient and redundant, for propagation; hairy by name is that metre of Prajapati, animals are hairy; verily he wins animals. There are all forms in these; all forms are made when Agni has to be piled up, therefore these appertain to Agni, to be piled [4].

column1: bhavanti |
column2: Twenty-one kindling-(verses) be repeats;

column1: ekaviṃśatiṃ sāmidhenīr anv āha rug vā ekaviṃśo rucam eva gachati | atho pratiṣṭhām eva pratiṣṭhā hy ekaviṃśas |
column2: the twenty-onefold (Stoma) is light; verily he attains light, and a support besides, for the twenty-one fold (Stoma) is support.

column1: caturviṃśatim anv āha caturviṃśatir ardhamāsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro 'gnir vaiśvānaraḥ sākṣād eva vaiśvānaram ava runddhe parācīr anv āha parāṅ iva hi suvargo lokaḥ samās tvāgna ṛtavo vardhayantv ity āha samābhir evāgniṃ vardhayati |
column2: Twenty-four (verses) he recites; the year has twenty-four half-months, Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily straightway he wins Vaiçvanara. He recites them straight on, for the world of heaven is as it were going straight away. 'Let the half-years, the seasons, increase thee, O Agni ', he says;

column1: ṛtubhiḥ saṃvatsaram |
column2: verily with the half-years he causes Agni to increase [5], with the seasons the year.

column1: viśvā ā bhāhi pradiśaḥ pṛthivyā ity āha tasmād agniḥ sarvā diśo 'nu vi bhāti praty auhatām aśvinā mṛtyum asmād ity āha mṛtyum evāsmād apa nudati |
column2: 'Illuminate all the quarters of the earth', he says; therefore Agni illuminates all the quarters. 'The Açvins removed death from him', he says; verily from him he repels death.

column1: ud vayaṃ tamasas parīty āha pāpmā vai tamaḥ pāpmānam evāsmād apa hanti |
column2: 'We from the darkness', he says; the darkness is the evil one; verily from him he smites away the evil one.

column1: aganma jyotir uttamam ity āha |
column2: 'We have come to the highest light', he says;

column1: asau vā ādityo jyotir uttamam ādityasyaiva sāyujyaṃ gachati na saṃvatsaras tiṣṭhati nāsya śrīs tiṣṭhati yasyaitāḥ kriyante jyotiṣmatīm uttamām anv āha jyotir evāsmā upariṣṭād dadhāti suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai |
column2: the highest light is yonder sun; verily he attains unity with the sun. The year lags not, his future fails not, for whom these are performed. The last he recites with the word 'light' in it; verily he bestows on him light above, to reveal the world of heaven.

column1: ṣaḍbhir dīkṣayati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: With six (verses) he consecrates; the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtubhir evainaṃ dīkṣayati saptabhir dīkṣayati sapta chandāṃsi chandobhir evainaṃ dīkṣayati viśve devasya netur ity anuṣṭubhottamayā juhoti vāg vā {anuṣṭup < anuṣṭubh} tasmāt prāṇānāṃ vāg uttamā |
column2: verily he consecrates him with the seasons. With seven he consecrates; the metres are seven; verily he consecrates him with the metres. 'Let every man of the god that leads', with the final Anustubh he offers;

column1: ekasmād akṣarād anāptam prathamam padam |
column2: The first quarter foot is deficient by one syllable;

column1: tasmād yad vāco 'nāptaṃ tan manuṣyā upa jīvanti pūrṇayā juhoti pūrṇa iva hi prajāpatiḥ |
column2: therefore men live upon the incomplete part of speech. He offers with a full (one), for Prajapati is full as it were;

column1: prajāpater āptyai nyūnayā juhoti nyūnād dhi prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata prajānāṃ sṛṣṭyai yad arciṣi pravṛñjyād bhūtam ava rundhīta yad aṅgāreṣu bhaviṣyat |
column2: he offers with one that is deficient, for from the deficient Prajapati created offspring; (verily it serves) for the creation of offspring. If he were to heat it on the flame, he would win what has been, if on the embers, what is to be;

column1: aṅgāreṣu pra vṛṇakti bhaviṣyad evāva runddhe bhaviṣyad dhi bhūyo bhūtāt |
column2: he heats it on the embers; verily he wins what is to be, for what is to be is greater than what has been.

column1: dvābhyām pra vṛṇakti dvipād yajamānaḥ pratiṣṭhityai brahmaṇā vā eṣā yajuṣā sambhṛtā yad ukhā sā yad bhidyetārtim ārchet | yajamāno hanyetāsya yajñas |
column2: the sacrificer has two feet; (verily it serves) for support. The pan is gathered together with holy power and the Yajus; if it should break, the sacrificer would be ruined [2], and his sacrifice destroyed.

column1: mitraitām ukhāṃ tapety āha brahma vai mitras |
column2: 'O Mitra, do thou heat this pan', he says; Mitra is holy power;

column1: brahmann evainām prati ṣṭhāpayati nārtim ārchati yajamāno nāsya yajño hanyate yadi bhidyeta tair eva kapālaiḥ saṃ sṛjet saiva tataḥ prāyaścittis |
column2: verily on holy power he establishes it; the sacrificer is not ruined, nor is his sacrifice destroyed. If it should break, he should unite it with the selfsame potsherds; that is the atonement for it.

column1: yo gataśrīḥ syān mathitvā tasyāva dadhyāt |
column2: If a man has attained prosperity, he should for him deposit (the fire) after producing it by friction;

column1: bhūto vā {eṣa < eṣas} sa svāṃ |
column2: this is one that has succeeded;

column1: devatām upaiti yo bhūtikāmaḥ syāt |
column2: verily he approaches his own deity [3].

column1: ya ukhāyai sambhavet sa eva tasya syāt |
column2: For him who desires prosperity should be used (the fire) which comes to life from the pan, for from it is it produced, it is self-produced by name;

column1: ato hy eṣa sambhavati |
column2: verily he becomes prosperous.

column1: eṣa vai svayambhūr nāma bhavaty eva yaṃ kāmayeta bhrātṛvyam asmai janayeyam ity anyatas tasyāhṛtyāva dadhyāt sākṣād evāsmai bhrātṛvyaṃ janayati |
column2: If he desire of a man, 'May I produce a foe for him', he should take for him (fire) from elsewhere, and deposit it; verily straightway he produces a foe for him.

column1: ambarīṣād annakāmasyāva dadhyāt | ambarīṣe vā annam bhriyate sayony evānnam |
column2: From a frying-pan he should (take fire) and deposit (it) for one who desires food; in a frying-pan food is kept;

column1: ava runddhe muñjān ava dadhāti |
column2: He deposits Muñja grass;

column1: ūrg vai muñjās |
column2: Muñja is strength;

column1: ūrjam evāsmā api dadhāti |
column2: verily he bestows upon him strength.

column1: agnir devebhyo nilāyata sa krumukam prāviśat krumukam ava dadhāti yad evāsya tatra nyaktaṃ tad evāva runddhe |
column2: Agni departed from the gods, he entered the Krumuka wood; he deposits Krumuka; verily he wins what of Agni is there imbued.

column1: ājyena saṃ yauti |
column2: With butter he joins (it);

column1: etad vā agneḥ priyaṃ dhāma yad ājyam priyeṇaivainaṃ dhāmnā sam ardhayaty atho tejasā |
column2: butter is the dear home of Agni; verily he unites him with his dear abode, and with brilliance also [5].

column1: vaikaṃkarīm ā dadhāti bhā evāva runddhe śamīmayīm ā dadhāti śāntyai sīda tvam mātur asyā upastha iti tisṛbhir jātam upa tiṣṭhate traya ime lokās |
column2: verily he wins radiance; he puts on one of Çami, for atonement. 'Do thou sit down in the lap of this mother', with three (verses) he adores (the fire) when born; three are these worlds;

column1: eṣv eva lokeṣv āvidaṃ gachati |
column2: verily he attains reputation in these worlds;

column1: atho prāṇān evātman dhatte |
column2: verily also he bestows breaths on himself.

column1: na ha sma vai purāgnir aparaśuvṛkṇaṃ dahati tad asmai prayoga evarṣir asvadayat |
column2: Formerly Agni would not burn what was not cut by the axe, but Prayoga, the seer, made that acceptable to him.

column1: yad agne yāni kāni ceti samidham ā dadhāti |
column2: 'Whatever logs we place on thee', (with these words) he puts on a kindling-stick;

column1: aparaśuvṛkṇam evāsmai svadayati sarvam asmai svadate ya evaṃ veda |
column2: verily he makes what is not cut by the axe acceptable to him; all is acceptable to him who knows thus.

column1: audumbarīm ā dadhāti |
column2: He puts on one of Udumbara wood;

column1: ūrg vā udumbaras |
column2: the Udumbara is strength;

column1: ūrjam evāsmā api dadhāti prajāpatir agnim asṛjata taṃ sṛṣṭaṃ rakṣāṃsi |
column2: verily he confers strength upon him. Prajapati created Agni; him on creation the Raksases [1] were fain to destroy;

column1: sa etad rākṣoghnam apaśyat tena vai sa rakṣāṃsy apāhata yad rākṣoghnam bhavaty agner eva tena jātād rakṣāṃsy apa hanti |
column2: he saw that (hymn) of the Raksas-slaying (one); therewith he smote away the Raksases; in that it is (the hymn) of the Raksas-slaying one, thereby he drives away the Raksases from Agni when born.

column1: āśvatthīm ā dadhāti |
column2: He puts on one of Açvattha wood;

column1: aśvattho vai vanaspatīnāṃ sapatnasāho vijityai vaikaṅkatīm ā dadhāti bhā evāva runddhe śamīmayīm ā dadhāti śāntyai saṃśitam me brahmod eṣām bāhū atiram ity uttame audumbarī |
column2: He puts on one of Vikankata; verily he wins light. He puts on one of Çami wood, for atonement. 'Sharpened is my holy power', 'Their arms have I uplifted', (with these words) he makes him speak over the last two Udumbara (sticks) [2];

column1: vācayati brahmaṇaiva kṣatraṃ saṃ śayati kṣatreṇa brahma tasmād brāhmaṇo rājanyavān aty anyam brāhmaṇaṃ tasmād rājanyo brāhmaṇavān aty anyaṃ rājanyam mṛtyur vā eṣa yad agnis | amṛtaṃ hiraṇyam |
column2: verily by means of the holy power he quickens the kingly power, and by the kingly power the holy power; therefore a Brahman who has a princely person is superior to another Brahman; therefore a prince who has a Brahman is superior to another prince. Now Agni is death, gold is immortality;

column1: rukmam antaram prati muñcate |
column2: he puts a gold plate within;

column1: amṛtam eva mṛtyor antar dhatte |
column2: verily he severs immortality from death;

column1: ekaviṃśatinirbādho bhavati | ekaviṃśatir vai devalokā dvādaśa māsāḥ pañcartavas traya ime lokā asāv ādityaḥ |
column2: it has twenty-one projections, the worlds of the gods are twenty-one, the twelve months, the four seasons, these three worlds, and as twenty-first yonder sun [3]; so many are the worlds of the gods;

column1: ekaviṃśa etāvanto vai devalokās tebhya eva bhrātṛvyam antar eti nirbādhair vai devā asurān nirbādhe 'kurvata tan nirbādhānāṃ nirbādhatvam |
column2: verily from them he severs his foe. By means of the projections the gods reduced the Asuras to straits (nirbadé); that is the reason why projections (nirbadháh) have their names;

column1: nirbādhī bhavati bhrātṛvyān eva nirbādhe kurute sāvitriyā prati muñcate prasūtyai naktoṣāsety uttarayā |
column2: it is covered with projections; verily he reduces his foes to straits. He puts (it) on with a verse addressed to Savitr, for instigation.

column1: ahorātrābhyām evainam ud yachate devā agniṃ dhārayan draviṇodā ity āha prāṇā vai devā draviṇodās | ahorātrābhyām evainam udyatya |
column2: 'The gods, granters of wealth, support Agni', be says; the gods, granters of wealth, are the breaths; verily having raised him with day and night [4] he supports him with the breaths.

column1: prāṇair dādhāra |
column2: Sitting he puts (it) on;

column1: āsīnaḥ prati muñcate tasmād āsīnāḥ prajāḥ pra jāyante kṛṣṇājinam uttaram |
column2: therefore offspring are born sitting; the black antelope skin is above;

column1: tejo vai hiraṇyam brahma kṛṣṇājinam |
column2: gold is brilliance, the black antelope skin is holy power;

column1: tejasā caivainam brahmaṇā cobhayataḥ pari gṛhṇāti ṣaḍudyāmaṃ śikyam bhavati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: verily on both sides he encircles him, with brilliance and with holy power. The sling is of six fathoms in extent; the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtubhir evainam ud yachate yad dvādaśodyāmaṃ saṃvatsareṇaiva mauñjam bhavati |
column2: verily he raises him with the seasons; if it is of twelve fathoms, (he raises him) with the year. It is of Muñja grass;

column1: ūrg vai muñjās |
column2: the Muñja is strength;

column1: ūrjaivainaṃ sam ardhayati suparṇo 'si garutmān ity avekṣate rūpam evāsyaitan mahimānaṃ vyācaṣṭe divaṃ gacha suvaḥ patety āha suvargam evainaṃ lokaṃ gamayati |
column2: 'Thou art the bird of fair feathers', (with these words) he gazes; verily he declares his greatness in that form. 'Go to the sky, fly to the heaven', he says; verily he makes him to go to the world of heaven.

column1: samiddho añjan kṛdaram matīnāṃ ghṛtam agne madhumat pinvamānaḥ | vājī vahan vājinaṃ jātavedo devānāṃ vakṣi piryam ā sadhastham |
column2: The Apri Hymn for the Horse Sacrifice Enkindled, decking the store-room of prayers, Swelling with sweet butter, O Agni, Steed bearing the strong drink, O all-knower, Carry it to the dear place of the gods.

column1: ghṛtenāñjant sam patho devayānān prajānan vājy apy etu devān |
column2: With ghee adorning the paths leading to the gods, Let the strong one, wise, go to the gods;

column1: anu tvā sapte pradiśaḥ sacantāṃ svadhām asmai yajamānāya dhehi |
column2: May thee, O courser, the regions attend, Bestow strength on this sacrificer.

column1: īḍyaś cāsi vandyaś ca vājinn āśuś cāsi medhyaś ca sapte |
column2: To be praised thou art, and to be celebrated, O steed; Swift and pure art thou, O courser;

column1: agniṣ ṭvā | devair vasubhiḥ sajoṣāḥ prītaṃ vahniṃ vahatu jātavedāḥ |
column2: May Agni in unison with the gods, the Vasus, Bear thee [1], a glad messenger, he the all-knower.

column1: stīrṇam barhiḥ suṣṭarīmā juṣāṇoru pṛthu prathamānam pṛthivyām | devebhir yuktam aditiḥ sajoṣāḥ syonaṃ kṛṇvānā suvite dadhātu |
column2: Rejoicing in the strewn grass, well strewed, That doth extend wide and broad on the earth, Joined with the gods, may Aditi in unison, Bestowing pleasantness, cause it to prosper.

column1: etā u vaḥ subhagā viśvarūpā vi pakṣobhiḥ śrayamāṇā ud ātaiḥ | ṛṣvāḥ satīḥ kavaṣaḥ śumbhamānā dvāro devīḥ suprāyaṇā bhavantu |
column2: These happy (doors), all formed, Opening with their sides, with the centre, Lofty and sounding, adorning themselves, The doors divine, may they be of pleasant entrance.

column1: antarā mitrāvaruṇā carantī mukhaṃ yajñānām abhi saṃvidāne | uṣāsā vām | suhiraṇye suśilpe ṛtasya yonāv iha sādayāmi |
column2: Moving between Mitra and Varuna, Well knowing the beginning of sacrifices, The two dawns for you [2], rich in gold, rich in adornment, settle here in the birthplace of holy order.

column1: prathamā vāṃ sarathinā suvarṇā devau paśyantau bhuvanāni viśvā | apiprayaṃ codanā vām mimānā hotārā jyotiḥ pradiśā diśantā |
column2: First for you have I made glad the two, who share one car, fair of hue, The gods that gaze on all the worlds, Those that ordain your ordinances, The two Hotrs, that indicate the light in its place.

column1: ādityair no bhāratī vaṣṭu yajñaṃ sarasvatī saha rudrair na āvīt | iḍopahūtā vasubhiḥ sajoṣā yajñaṃ no devīr amṛteṣu dhatta |
column2: May Bharati with the Adityas love our sacrifice; Sarasvati with the Rudras hath holpen us, And Ida invoked with the Vasus in unison; Our sacrifice, O goddesses, place ye with the immortals.

column1: tvaṣṭā vīraṃ devakāmaṃ jajāna tvaṣṭur arvā jāyata āśur aśvaḥ |
column2: Tvastr begot the hero with love for the gods; From Tvastr is born the courser, the swift steed [3];

column1: tvaṣṭedaṃ viśvam bhuvanaṃ jajāna bahoḥ kartāram iha yakṣi hotaḥ |
column2: Tvastr produced all this world; The maker of much do thou offer to, as Hotr.

column1: aśvo ghṛtena tmanyā samakta upa devāṃ ṛtuśaḥ pātha etu | vanaspatir devalokam prajānann agninā havyā svaditāni vakṣat |
column2: May the steed, anointed with glee, of his own impulse Go to the gods in due season to their abode; May the forest lord knowing the world of the gods, Bear the oblations made ready by Agni.

column1: prajāpates tapasā vāvṛdhānaḥ sadyo jāto dadhiṣe yajñam agne |
column2: Waxing with the fervour of Prajapati, Immediately on birth, O Agni, thou didst support the sacrifice As harbinger with the oblation offered with Hail!

column1: svāhākṛtena haviṣā purogā yāhi sādhyā havir adantu devāḥ |
column2: Do thou go; let the gods eat the oblation duly.

column1: viṣṇumukhā vai devāś chandobhir imāM lokān anapajayyam abhy ajayan yad viṣṇukramān kramate viṣṇur eva bhūtvā yajamānaś chandobhir imāM lokān anapajayyam abhi jayati viṣṇoḥ kramo 'sy abhimātihety āha gāyatrī vai pṛthivī traiṣṭhubham antarikṣam | jāgatī dyaus |
column2: The Preparation of the Ground for the Fire Headed by Visnu the gods won finally these worlds by the metres; in that he strides the strides of Visnu, the sacrificer becoming Visnu wins finally these worlds. 'Thou art the step of Visnu, overcoming hostility', he says; the earth is connected with the Gayatri, the atmosphere with the Tristubh, the sky with the Jagati, the quarters with the Anustubh;

column1: chandobhir evemāM lokān yathāpūrvam abhi jayati prajāpatir agnim asṛjata so 'smāt sṛṣṭaḥ |
column2: verily he wins in order these worlds with the metres. Prajapati created Agni; he being created went away from him [1];

column1: parāṅ ait tam etayānv ait |
column2: he followed him with this (verse), 'He hath cried';

column1: akrandat iti tayā vai so 'gneḥ priyaṃ dhāmāvārunddha yad eṭam anvāhāgner evaitayā priyaṃ dhāmāva runddhe |
column2: with it he won the home dear to Agni; in that he repeats this (verse), he wins thereby the home dear to Agni.

column1: īśvaro vā eṣa parāṅ pradagho yo viṣṇukramān kramate catasṛbhir ā vartate catvāri chandāṃsi chandāṃsi khalu vā agneḥ priyā tanūḥ priyām evāsya tanuvam abhi |
column2: Now he who steps the strides of Visnu is apt as he goes away to be burnt up; he turns with four (verses); the. metres are four, Agni's dear body is the metres; verily he turns round on his dear body [2];

column1: paryāvartate dakṣiṇā paryāvartate svam eva vīryam anu paryāvartate tasmād dakṣiṇo 'rdha ātmano vīryāvattaras |
column2: he turns round from left to right; verily he turns round on his own strength; therefore the right side of the body is the stronger;

column1: atho ādityasyaivāvṛtam anu paryāvartate śunaḥśepam ājīgartiṃ varuṇo 'gṛhṇāt sa etām vāruṇīm apaśyat tayā vai sa ātmānaṃ varuṇapāśād amuñcat |
column2: verily also does he turn with the turning of the sun. Varuna seized Çunahçepa Ajigarti, he saw this verse addressed to Varuna, by it he freed himself from the noose of Varuna;

column1: varuṇo vā etaṃ gṛhṇāti ya ukhām pratimuñcate |
column2: Varuna seizes him who takes the fire-pan;

column1: ud uttamaṃ varuṇa pāśam asmad ity āha |
column2: 'From us the highest knot, O Varuna', he says;

column1: varuṇapāśān muñcati |
column2: verily thereby he frees himself from Varuna's noose [3].

column1: ā tvāhārṣam ity āha |
column2: 'I have drawn thee', he says, for he draws him.

column1: ā hy enaṃ harati dhruvas tiṣṭhāvicācalir ity āha pratiṣṭhityai viśas tvā sarvā vāñchantv ity āha viśaivainaṃ sam ardhayati |
column2: 'Be thou firm and motionless', he says, for support. 'Let all the folk desire thee', he says; verily with the folk he unites him.

column1: asmin rāṣṭram adhi śrayety āha rāṣṭram evāsmin dhruvam akar yaṃ kāmayeta rāṣṭraṃ syād iti tam manasā dhyāyet |
column2: 'In him establish the kingdom', he says; verily in him he makes the kingdom to abide. If he desire of a man, 'May he be a ruler', he should think of him with his mind;

column1: rāṣṭram eva bhavati |
column2: verily he becomes a ruler [4].

column1: agre bṛhann uṣasām ūrdhvo asthād ity āha |
column2: 'In greatness he hath risen erect in the van of the dawns', he says;

column1: agram evainaṃ samānānāṃ karoti nirjagmivān tamasa ity āha tama evāsmād apa hanti jyotiṣāgād ity āha jyotir evāsmin dadhāti catasṛbhiḥ sādayati catvāri chandāṃsi chandobhir eva |
column2: verily he smites away darkness from him. 'He hath come with the light', he says; verily he bestows light upon him. He places him with four (verses); the metres are four;

column1: atichandasottamayā varṣma vā eṣa chandasāṃ yad atichandās |
column2: with an Atichandas as the last; the Atichandas is the highest of metres;

column1: varṣmaivainaṃ samānānāṃ karoti sadvatī |
column2: verily he makes him the highest of his peers;

column1: bhavati sattvam evainaṃ gamayati vātsapreṇopa tiṣṭhate |
column2: it contains [5] the word 'sit' (sad); verily he makes him attain reality (sat-tvám).

column1: etena vai vatsaprīr bhālandano 'gneḥ priyaṃ dhāmāvārunddha | agner evaitena priyaṃ dhāmāva runddhe |
column2: With (the hymn) of Vatsapri he reverences (him); by that did Vatsapri Bhalandana win the home dear to Agni; verily by it he wins the home dear to Agni.

column1: ekādaśam bhavati |
column2: It has eleven (verses);

column1: ekadhaiva yajamāne vīryaṃ dadhāti stomena vai devā asmiM loka ārdhnuvañ chandobhir amuṣmin |
column2: verily in eleven places he bestows strength on the sacrificer. By the Stoma the gods prospered in this world, by the metres in yonder world;

column1: stomasyeva khalu vā etad rūpaṃ yad vātsapram |
column2: the hymn of Vatsapri is the type of the Stoma;

column1: yad vātsapreṇopatiṣṭhate | imam eva tena lokam abhi jayati yad viṣṇukramān kramate 'mum eva tair lokam abhi jayati pūrvedyuḥ pra krāmaty uttaredyur upa tiṣṭhate tasmād yoge 'nyāsām prajānām manaḥ kṣeme 'nyāsām |
column2: in that he pays reverence with (the hymn) of Vatsapri [6], he wins with it this world; in that he strides the steps of Visnu, he wins by them yonder world. On the first day he strides forth, on the next day he pays reverence; therefore the minds of some creatures are set on energy, those of others on rest;

column1: tasmād yāyāvaraḥ kṣemyasyeśe tasmād yāyāvaraḥ kṣemyam adhyavasyati muṣṭī karoti vācaṃ yachati yajñasya dhṛtyai |
column2: therefore the active lords it over him who takes his ease therefore the active fixes upon a man who takes his ease. He clenches his fist, he restrains his speech, for support.

column1: annapate 'nnasya no dehīty āha |
column2: 'O lord of food, accord us food', he says;

column1: agnir vā annapatiḥ sa evāsmā annam pra yachati |
column2: the lord of food is Agni; verily he grants him food.

column1: anamīvasya śuṣmiṇa ity āha |
column2: 'Uninjurious, impetuous', he says;

column1: ayakṣmasyeti vāvaitad āha pra pradātāraṃ tāriṣa ūrjaṃ no dhehi dvipade catuṣpada ity āha |
column2: he means in fact 'free from disease'. 'Do thou further the donor, bestow strength on our bipeds, our quadrupeds', he says;

column1: āśiṣam evaitām ā śāste |
column2: verily he invokes this blessing.

column1: ud u tvā viśve devā ity āha prāṇā vai viśve devāḥ |
column2: 'May the All-gods bear thee up', he says; the All-gods are the breaths [1];

column1: prāṇair evainam ud yachate |
column2: verily with the breaths he raises him.

column1: agne bharantu cittibhir ity āha yasmā evainaṃ cittāyodyachate tenaivainaṃ sam ardhayati catasṛbhir ā sādayati catvāri chandāṃsi chandobhir eva |
column2: 'O Agni, with their thoughts', he says; with the purpose for which he raises him, he verily unites him. He places (him) with four (verses); the metres are four;

column1: atichandasottamayā varṣma vā eṣā chandasāṃ yad atichandā varṣmaivainaṃ samānānāṃ karoti sadvatī bhavati sattvam evainaṃ gamayati pred agne jyotiṣmān |
column2: verily with the metres (he places him); with an Atichandas as the last; the Atichandas is the highest of the metres; verily he makes him the highest of his peers;

column1: yāhīty āha jyotir evāsmin dadhāti tanuvā vā eṣa hinasti yaṃ hinasti mā hiṃsīs tanuvā prajā ity āha prajābhya evainaṃ śamayati rakṣāṃsi vā etad yajñaṃ sacante yad ana utsarjati |
column2: verily he bestows light upon him. With his body he injures him whom he injures; 'Harm not our offspring with thy body', he says; verily for his offspring he makes him gentle. The Raksases infest that sacrifice where the axle creaks;

column1: akrandad ity anv āha rakṣasām apahatyai |
column2: 'He hath cried', he repeats, to smite away the Raksases.

column1: anasā vahanti |
column2: They bear (him) with a cart;

column1: apacitim evāsmin dadhāti tasmād anasvī ca rathī cātithīnām apacitatamau |
column2: therefore he that has a cart and he that has a chariot are of guests [3] the most honoured: honour is his who knows thus.

column1: apacitimān bhavati ya evaṃ veda samidhāgniṃ duvasyateti ghṛtānuṣiktām avasite samidham ā dadhāti yathātithaya āgatāya sarpiṣvad ātithyaṃ kriyate tādṛg eva tat |
column2: 'With kindling-wood serve Agni', (with these words) he puts a kindling-stick, made wet with ghee, upon him when put in place; that is as when hospitality with melted butter is offered to a guest on arrival;

column1: gāyatriyā brāhmaṇasya gāyatro hi brāhmaṇas triṣṭubhā rājanyasya traiṣṭubho hi rājanyas |
column2: (he puts it on) with a Gayatri for a Brahman, for the Brahman is connected with the Gayatri, with a Tristubh for a Rajanya, for the Rajanya is connected with the Tristubh.

column1: apsu bhasma pra veśayati |
column2: He casts the ash into the waters;

column1: apsuyonir vā agniḥ svām evainaṃ yoniṃ gamayati tisṛbhiḥ pra veśayati trivṛd vai | agnis |
column2: with three (verses) he casts (it); Agni is threefold [4]; verily he makes Agni attain support through all his extent.

column1: yāvān evāgnis tam pratiṣṭhāṃ gamayati parā vā eṣo 'gniṃ vapati yo 'psu bhasma praveśayati jyotiṣmatībhyām ava dadhāti jyotir evāsmin dadhāti dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityai parā vā eṣa prajām paśūn vapati yo 'psu bhasma praveśayati punar ūrjā saha rayyeti punar udaiti prajām eva paśūn ātman dhatte punas tvādityāḥ |
column2: verily he bestows light upon him; with two (he places it), for support. He throws away offspring and cattle who puts the ash in the waters; 'Return with strength', 'With wealth', (with these words) he comes back; verily he bestows upon himself offspring and cattle.

column1: rudrā vasavaḥ sam indhatām ity āha |
column2: 'May the Adityas [5], the Rudras, the Vasus kindle thee again', he says;

column1: etā vā etaṃ devatā agre sam aindhata tābhir evainaṃ sam inddhe bodhā sa bodhīty upa tiṣṭhate bodhayaty evainam |
column2: these deities first kindled him; verily by them he kindles him. 'Hearken', 'Be thou', (with these words) he pays reverence; verily he awakens him;

column1: tasmāt suptvā prajāḥ pra budhyante yathāsthānam upa tiṣṭhate tasmād yataḥsthānam paśavaḥ punar etyopa tiṣṭhante |
column2: therefore after sleeping creatures awake. In his place he pays reverence, and therefore cattle returning go to their place.

column1: yāvatī vai pṛthivī tasyai yama ādhipatyam parīyāya yo vai yamaṃ devayajanam asyā aniryācyāgniṃ cinute yamāyainaṃ sa cinute |
column2: Yama holds the overlordship of the whole extent of earth; he who without asking from Yama a place of it for divine sacrifice piles up the fire is piling it for Yama.

column1: apetety adhyavasāyayati yamam eva devayajanam asyai niryācyātmane 'gniṃ cinute |
column2: verily having asked from Yama a place of it for divine sacrifice, he piles the fire for himself.

column1: iṣvagreṇa vā asyā anāmṛtam ichanto nāvindan te devā etad yajur apaśyan |
column2: Seeking they could not find so much as an arrow point of it which was not covered with death; the gods saw this Yajus, 'Go hence';

column1: apeteti yad etenādhyavasāyayati | anāmṛta evāgniṃ cinute |
column2: in that he makes him fix with this [1], he piles the fire on a place freed from death.

column1: ud dhanti yad evāsyā amedhyaṃ tad apa hanti | apo 'vokṣati śāntyai sikatā ni vapati |
column2: He throws up (the earth); verily he smites away any impurity in it; he sprinkles water on, for atonement. He puts down sand;

column1: etad vā agner vaiśvānarasya rūpam |
column2: that is the form of Agni Vaiçvanara;

column1: rūpenaiva vaiśvānaram ava runddhe |
column2: verily by his form he wins Vaiçvanara.

column1: ūṣān ni vapati puṣṭir vā eṣā prajananaṃ yad ūṣāḥ puṣṭyām eva prajanane 'gniṃ cinute |
column2: He puts down salt; salt is the nourishment and the propagating; verily he piles the fire in nourishment, in propagation, and also in concord;

column1: paśūnāṃ yad ūṣās |
column2: for the salt is the concord [2] of cattle.

column1: dyāvāpṛthivī sahāstām |
column2: Sky and earth were together;

column1: te viyatī abrūtām astv eva nau saha yajñiyam iti yad amuṣyā yajñiyam āsīt tad asyām adadhāt ta ūṣā abhavan yad asyā yajñiyam āsīt tad amuṣyām adadhāt tad adaś candramasi kṛṣṇam ūṣān nivapann ado dhyāyed dyāvāpṛthivyor eva yajñiye 'gniṃ cinute |
column2: separating they said, 'Let us share together what is worthy of sacrifice'. What of yonder (sky) was worthy of sacrifice, it placed in this (earth), that became salt; what of this (earth) was worthy of sacrifice, it placed in yonder (sky) and that is yonder black in the moon; when he puts down the salt he should think of yonder (black); verily he piles the fire in that of sky and earth which is worthy of sacrifice.

column1: ayaṃ so agnir iti viśvāmitrasya |
column2: 'This is that Agni' is Viçvamitra's [3] hymn;

column1: etena vai viśvāmitro 'gneḥ priyaṃ dhāmāvārunddha |
column2: by that Viçvamitra won the abode dear to Agni;

column1: agner evaitena priyaṃ dhāmāva runddhe chandobhir vai devāḥ suvargaṃ lokam {āyañ < āyan} catasraḥ prācīr upa dadhāti catvāri chandāṃsi chandobhir eva tad yajamānaḥ suvargaṃ lokam eti teṣāṃ suvargaṃ lokaṃ yatāṃ diśaḥ sam avlīyanta te dve purastāt samīcī upādadhata dve |
column2: By the metres the gods went to the world of heaven; he places four (bricks) pointing east the metres are four; verily by the metres the sacrificer goes to the world of heaven. As they went to the world of heaven, the quarters were confused; they put down two in front, facing the same way, and two [4] behind, facing the same way;

column1: paścāt samīcī tābhir vai te diśo 'dṛṃhan yad dve purastāt samīcī upadadhāti dve paścāt samīcī diśāṃ vidhṛtyai |
column2: In that he places two in front, facing the same way, and two behind, facing the same way, (it serves) to make firm the quarters; again, the metres are cattle;

column1: atho paśavo vai chandāṃsi paśūn evāsmai samīco dadhāti |
column2: verily he makes cattle available for him.

column1: aṣṭāv upa dadhāti |
column2: He places eight (bricks);

column1: aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatro 'gnir yāvān evāgnis taṃ cinute |
column2: the Gayatri has eight syllables, Agni is connected with the Gayatri;

column1: aṣṭāv upa dadhāti |
column2: He places eight;

column1: aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatrī suvargaṃ lokam añjasā veda suvargasya lokasya |
column2: the Gayatri has eight syllables; the Gayatri knows in truth the world of heaven;

column1: prajñātyai trayodaśa lokampṛṇā upa dadhāti |
column2: (verily it serves) to reveal the world of heaven [5]. He places thirteen worldfillers;

column1: ekaviṃśatiḥ sam padyante pratiṣṭhā vā ekaviṃśaḥ pratiṣṭhā gārhapatyas |
column2: they make twenty-one, the twenty-onefold Stoma is a support, the Garhapatya is a support, verily he finds support in the support of the twenty-onefold (Stoma), the Garhapatya;

column1: ekaviṃśasyaiva pratiṣṭhāṃ gārhapatyam anu prati tiṣṭhati praty agniṃ cikyānas tiṣṭhati ya evaṃ veda pañcacitīkaṃ cinvīta prathamaṃ cinvānaḥ pāṅkto yajñaḥ pāṅktāḥ paśavas |
column2: he who knows thus finds support in the fire which he has piled. He who first piles (the fire) should pile in five layers; the sacrifice is fivefold, cattle are fivefold;

column1: yajñam eva paśūn ava runddhe tricitīkaṃ cinvīta dvitīyaṃ cinvānas traya ime lokās |
column2: verily he wins the sacrifice and cattle. He who piles for a second time should pile in three layers; these worlds are three;

column1: eṣv eva lokeṣu | prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily he finds support [6] in these worlds.

column1: ekacitīkaṃ cinvīta tṛtīyaṃ cinvānas |
column2: He who piles for a third time should pile in one layer;

column1: ekadhā vai suvargo lokas |
column2: the world of heaven is in one place;

column1: ekavṛtaiva suvargaṃ lokam eti purīṣeṇābhy ūhati tasmān māṃsenāsthi channam |
column2: verily he goes to the world of heaven by the single (layer). He makes (them) firm with mortar; therefore the bone is covered with meat;

column1: na duścarmā bhavati ya evaṃ veda pañca citayo bhavanti pañcabhiḥ purīṣair abhy ūhati daśa sam padyante dasākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājy evānnādye prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: he who knows thus does not become diseased of skin. There are five layers, he makes firm with five (sets of) dust; they make up ten, the Viraj has ten syllables, the Viraj is food; verily he finds support in the Viraj, in proper food.

column1: vi vā etau dviṣāte yaś ca purāgnir yaś cokhāyām |
column2: The Agni that was before and the one in the fire-pan are at variance;

column1: sam itam iti catasṛbhiḥ saṃ ni vapati catvāri chandāṃsi chandāṃsi khalu vā agneḥ priyā tanūḥ priyayaivainau tanuvā saṃ śāsti sam itam ity āha tasmād brahmaṇā kṣatraṃ sam eti yat saṃnyupya viharati tasmād brahmaṇā kṣatraṃ vy eti |
column2: 'Be united', with four (verses) he unites them together; the metres are four, Agni's dear body is the metres; verily with his dear body he puts them in order. 'Be united, he says; therefore the kingly power unites with the holy power;

column1: ṛtubhiḥ | vā etaṃ dīkṣayanti sa ṛtubhir eva vimucyas |
column2: With the seasons [1] they consecrate him; with the seasons likewise he must be set free;

column1: māteva putram pṛthivī purīṣyam ity āha |
column2: 'As a mother her son, the earth Agni of the dust', he says;

column1: ṛtubhir evainaṃ dīkṣayaitvartubhir vi muñcati vaiśvānaryā śikyam ā datte svadayaty evainad |
column2: verily having consecrated him with the seasons, with the season he sets him free. With (a verse) addressed to Vaiçvanara, he takes the sling;

column1: nairṛtīḥ kṛṣṇās tisras tuṣapakvā bhavanti nirṛtyai vā etad bhāgadheyaṃ yat tuṣā nirṛtyai rūpaṃ kṛṣṇam |
column2: verily he makes it ready. For Nirrti there are three (bricks) black, dried by a chaff fire; chaff is the portion of Nirrti, black is the form of Nirrti;

column1: rūpeṇaiva nirṛtiṃ niravadayate |
column2: verily by her own form he propitiates Nirrti.

column1: imāṃ diśaṃ yanti |
column2: They go to this quarter;

column1: eṣā |
column2: this [2] is the quarter of Nirrti;

column1: vai nirṛtyai {dik < diś} svāyām eva diśi nirṛtiṃ niravadayate svakṛta iriṇa upa dadhāti pradare vā |
column2: verily in her own quarter he propitiates Nirrti. He places (it) in a self-made hole or a cleft;

column1: etad vai nirṛtyā āyatanam |
column2: that is the abode of Nirrti;

column1: sva evāyatane nirṛtiṃ niravadayate śikyam abhy upa dadhāti nairṛto vai pāśaḥ sākṣād evainaṃ nirṛtipāśān muñcati tisra upa dadhāti tredhāvihito vai puruṣas |
column2: verily he propitiates Nirrti in her own abode. He places (them) over against the sling, the noose is connected with Nirrti; verily he frees him straightway from the noose of Nirrti. He places three, man is threefold in arrangement;

column1: yāvān eva puruṣas tasmān nirṛtim ava yajate parācīr upa | dadhāti parācīm evāsmān nirṛtim pra ṇudate |
column2: verily he removes by sacrifice Nirrti from the whole extent of man. He places them going away (from the place of sacrifice); verily he drives away Nirrti from him [3].

column1: apratīkṣam ā yanti nirṛtyā antarhityai mārjayitvopa tiṣṭhante medhyatvāya gārhapatyam upa tiṣṭhante nirṛtiloka eva caritvā pūtā devalokam upāvartante |
column2: They return without looking round, to conceal Nirrti. Having purified, they pay reverence, for purity. To the Garhapatya they pay reverence; verily having wandered in the world of Nirrti, they return, purified, to the world of the gods.

column1: ekayopa tiṣṭhante |
column2: They pay reverence with one (verse);

column1: ekadhaiva yajamāne vīryaṃ dadhati niveśanaḥ saṃgamano vasūnām ity āha prajā vai paśavo vasu prajayaivainam paśubhiḥ sam ardhayanti |
column2: verily in one place they bestow strength on the sacrificer. 'Abode and collector of riches', he says; rich are offspring and cattle; verily he unites him with offspring and cattle.

column1: puruṣamātreṇa vi mimīte yajñena vai puruṣaḥ sammitas |
column2: With man's measure he metes out; man is commensurate with the sacrifice;

column1: yajñaparuṣaivainaṃ vi mimīte yāvān puruṣa ūrdhvabāhus tāvān bhavati |
column2: verily he metes him with a member of the sacrifice; so great is he as a man with arms extended;

column1: etāvad vai puruṣe vīryam |
column2: so much strength is there in man;

column1: vīryeṇaivainaṃ vi mimīte pakṣī bhavati na hy apakṣaḥ patitum arhati |
column2: verily with strength he metes him. Winged is he, for wingless he could not fly;

column1: aratninā pakṣau drāghīyāṃsau bhavatas tasmāt pakṣapravayāṃsi vayāṃsi vyāmamātrau pakṣau ca puchaṃ ca bhavati |
column2: these wings are longer by an ell; therefore birds have strength by their wings. The wings and the tail are a fathom in breadth;

column1: etāvad vai puruṣe vīryam | vīryasammitas |
column2: so much is the strength in man [1], he is commensurate in strength.

column1: veṇunā vi mimīte |
column2: He metes with a bamboo;

column1: āgneyo vai venuḥ sayonitvāya yajuṣā yunakti yajuṣā kṛṣati vyāvṛttyai ṣaḍgavena kṛṣati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: With a Yajus he yokes (the team), with a Yajus he ploughs, for discrimination. He ploughs with a (team) of six oxen; the seasons are six; verily with the seasons he ploughs him.

column1: ṛtubhir evainaṃ kṛṣati yad dvādaśagavena saṃvatsarenaiveyaṃ vā agner atidāhād abibhet saitad dviguṇam apaśyat kṛṣṭaṃ cākṛṣṭaṃ ca tato vā imāṃ nāty adahat |
column2: In that (he ploughs) with (a team) of twelve oxen, (he ploughs) with the year. This (earth) was afraid of excessive burning by Agni; she saw this of two sorts, ploughed and unploughed [2], then indeed he did not burn her excessively;

column1: yat kṛṣṭaṃ cākṛṣṭaṃ ca |
column2: in that there is ploughed and unploughed, (it serves to prevent) her being excessively burned.

column1: bhavaty asyā anatidāhāya dviguṇaṃ tvā agnim udyantum arhatīty āhus |
column2: 'He should restrain Agni when twofold', they say;

column1: yat kṛṣṭaṃ cākṛṣṭaṃ ca bhavati | agner udyatyai |
column2: in that there is ploughed and unploughed (it serves) to restrain Agni.

column1: etāvanto vai paśavo dvipādaś ca catuṣpādaś ca tān yat prāca utsṛjed rudrāyāpi dadhyāt |
column2: So many are animals, bipeds and quadrupeds; if he were to let them loose to the east, he would give them over to Rudra;

column1: yad dakṣiṇā pitṛbhyo ni dhuvet |
column2: if to the south, he would deliver them to the Pitrs;

column1: yat pratīco rakṣāṃsi hanyus |
column2: if to the west, the Raksases would destroy them;

column1: udīca ut sṛjati |
column2: to the north he let them loose;

column1: eṣā vai devamanuṣyāṇāṃ śāntā dik |
column2: this is the auspicious quarter of gods and men (3);

column1: tām evainān anūt sṛjati |
column2: verily he lets them loose in that direction.

column1: atho khalv imāṃ diśam ut sṛjati | asau vā ādityaḥ prāṇaḥ prāṇam evainān anūt sṛjati dakṣiṇā paryāvartante svam eva vīryam anu paryāvartante tasmād dakṣiṇo 'rdha ātmano vīryāvattaras |
column2: Again he lets them loose to this quarter, the breath is yonder sun: verily he lets them loose following the breath. From left to right they turn, around their own strength they turn; therefore the right side of the body is the stronger;

column1: atho ādityasyaivāvṛtam anu paryāvartante tasmāt parāñcaḥ paśavo vi tiṣṭhante pratyañca ā vartante tisrastisraḥ sītāḥ |
column2: verily they turn with the turning of the sun. Therefore cattle depart from (us), and come back towards (us). Three by three he ploughs the furrows [4];

column1: kṛṣati trivṛtam eva yajñamukhe vi yātayati |
column2: verily he extends the threefold (Stoma) in the beginning of the sacrifice.

column1: oṣadhīr vapati brahmaṇānnam ava runddhe | arke 'rkaś cīyate caturdaśabhir vapati sapta grāmyā oṣadhayaḥ saptāraṇyās |
column2: He scatters plants, by holy power he wins food, in the Arka the Arka is piled. With fourteen verses he scatters; the domesticated plants are seven, the wild are seven;

column1: ubhayīṣām avaruddhyai |
column2: (verily they serve) to win both sets.

column1: annasyānnasya vapati | annasyānnasyāvaruddhayi kṛṣṭe vapati kṛṣṭe hy oṣadhayaḥ pratitiṣṭhanti |
column2: He scatters (seeds) of diverse kinds of food, to win diverse foods. He scatters on the ploughed (ground), for in the ploughed plants find support.

column1: anusītaṃ vapati prajātyai dvādaśasu sītāsu vapati dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsareṇaivāsmā annam pacati yad agnicit |
column2: He scatters along the furrows, for propagation. In twelve furrows he scatters; the year has twelve months; verily with the year he cooks food for him.

column1: anavaruddhasyāśnīyād avaruddhena vy ṛdhyeta ye vanaspatīnām phalagrahayas tān idhme 'pi prokṣet |
column2: Those trees which bear fruit he should sprinkle in the kindling-wood, to obtain what has not been obtained.

column1: anavaruddhasyāvaruddhyai digbhyo loṣṭānt sam asyati diśām eva vīryam avarudhya diśāṃ vīrye 'gniṃ cinute yaṃ dviṣyād yatra sa syāt tasyai diśo loṣṭam ā haret | iṣam ūrjam aham ita ā dada itīṣam evorjaṃ tasyai diśo 'va runddhe kṣodhuko bhavati yas tasyāṃ diśi bhavati |
column2: verily winning the strength of the quarters, he piles the fire in the strength of the quarters; he should take a clod from the quarter where is he whom he hates, (saying), 'Food and strength do I take hence', verily he wins from that quarter food and strength, and hungry is he who is in that quarter. He scatters over the high altar, for on the high altar is the fire piled;

column1: uttaravedim upa vapati |
column2: verily he wins cattle;

column1: atho yajñaparuṣo 'nantarityai |
column2: (verily it serves) for the avoidance of passing over a limb of the sacrifice.

column1: agne tava śravo vaya iti sikatā ni vapati |
column2: 'O Agni, strength and fame are thine', (with these words) he scatters sand;

column1: etad vā agner vaiśvānarasya sūktam |
column2: that is the hymn of Agni Vaiçvanara;

column1: sūktenaiva vaiśvānaram ava runddhe ṣaḍbhir ni vapati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaṇ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro 'gnir vaiśvānaraḥ sākṣād eva vaiśvānaram ava runddhe samudraṃ vai nāmaitac chandaḥ samudram anu prajāḥ pra jāyante yad etena siktā nivapati prajānām prajananāya |
column2: the year has six seasons, Agni Vaiçvanara is the year; verily straightway he wins Vaiçvanara. This metre is called the ocean; offspring are born like the ocean; in that he scatters sand with this (hymn), (it is) for the propagation of offspring.

column1: indraḥ | vṛtrāya vajram prāharat sa tredhā vy abhavat sphyas tṛtīyaṃ rathas tṛtīyaṃ yūpas tṛtīyam |
column2: Indra [1] hurled his bolt at Vrtra; it parted into three, one third the wooden sword, one-third the chariot, one-third the sacrificial post;

column1: ye 'ntaḥśarā aśīryanta tāḥ śarkarā abhavan tac charkarāṇāṃ śarkaratvam |
column2: the interior reeds which were crushed became gravel; that is the explanation of gravel;

column1: vajro vai śarkarāḥ paśur agnis |
column2: gravel is a thunderbolt, the fire is an animal;

column1: yac charkarābhir agnim pariminoti vajreṇaivāsmai paśūn pari gṛhṇāti tasmād vajreṇa paśavaḥ parigṛhītās tasmāt stheyān astheyaso nopa harate trisaptābhiḥ |
column2: in that he supports the fire with gravel, he encircles with the bolt cattle for him; therefore cattle are encircled with the bolt; therefore the stronger does not receive the weaker.

column1: paśukāmasya pari minuyāt sapta vai śīrṣaṇyāḥ prāṇāḥ prāṇāḥ paśavaḥ prāṇair evāsmai paśūn ava runddhe triṇavābhir bhrātṛvyavatas trivṛtam eva varjaṃ sambhṛtya bhrātṛvyāya pra harati stṛtyai |
column2: there are seven breaths in the head, cattle are the breaths; verily he wins cattle for him by the breaths. With twentyseven (should he support it) for one who has foes; thus making the threefold bolt he hurls it at his foe, to lay him low.

column1: aparimitābhiḥ pari minuyād aparimitasyāvaruddhyai yaṃ kāmayetāpaśuḥ syād ity aparimitya tasya śarkarāḥ sikatā vy ūhet |
column2: He should support (it) with unnumbered ones, to win what is unnumbered. If he desire of a man, 'May he be without cattle', then without piling the gravel in support, he should separate the sand;

column1: aparigṛhīta evāsya viṣūcīnaṃ retaḥ parā siñcati |
column2: verily he pours forth for him the seed on all sides in (a place) not encircled;

column1: apaśur eva bhavati |
column2: verily he becomes without cattle [3].

column1: yaṃ kāmayeta paśumānt syād iti parimitya tasya śarkarāḥ siktā vy {ūhed < ūhet} parigṛhīta evāsmai samīcīnaṃ retaḥ siñcati paśumān eva bhavati saumyā vy ūhati somo vai retodhās |
column2: If he desire of a man, 'May he be rich in cattle,' he should separate the sand, after piling the gravel; verily he pours forth for him the seed in one direction in an encircled (place), and he becomes rich in cattle. With (a verse) addressed to Soma he separates (the sand); Soma is impregnator of seed; verily he impregnates seed;

column1: reta eva tad dadhāti gāyatriyā brāhmaṇasya gāyatro hi brāhmaṇas triṣṭubhā rājanyasya traiṣṭubho hi rājanyaḥ śamyum bārhaspatyam medho nopānamat so 'gnim prāviśat |
column2: with a Gayatri for a Brahman, for the Brahman is connected with the Gayatri, with a Tristubh for a Rajanya, for the Rajanya is connected with the Tristubh. To Çamyu, son of Brhaspati, the sacrifice did not resort; it entered the fire [4];

column1: so 'gneḥ kṛṣṇo rūpaṃ kṛtvod āyata so 'śvam prāviśat so 'śvasyāvāntaraśapho 'bhavat |
column2: it departed from the fire in the form of a black antelope, it entered the horse, it became the intermediate hoof of the horse;

column1: yad aśvam ākramayati ya eva medho 'śvam prāviśat tam evāva runddhe prajāpatināgniś cetavya ity āhuḥ prājāpatyo 'śvas |
column2: in that he makes the horse advance, he wins the sacrifice which has entered the horse. 'By Prajapati must the fire be piled', they say;

column1: yad aśvam ākramayati prajāpatinaivāgniṃ cinute puṣkaraparṇam upa dadhāti yonir vā agneḥ puṣkaraparṇam |
column2: in that he makes the horse advance, by Prajapati he piles the fire. He puts down a lotus leaf; the lotus leaf is the birthplace of the fire;

column1: sayonim evāgniṃ cinute |
column2: verily he piles the fire with its own birthplace.

column1: apām pṛṣṭham asīty upa dadhāti |
column2: 'Thou art the back of the waters', (with these words) he puts (it) down;

column1: apāṃ vā etat pṛṣṭhaṃ {F yat}{W yat}{GLOS yat} puṣkaraparṇam |
column2: the lotus leaf is the back of the waters;

column1: rūpeṇaivainad upa dadhāti |
column2: verily with its form he puts it down.

column1: brahma jajñānam iti rukmam upa dadhāti brahmamukhā vai prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata brahmamukhā eva tat prajā yajamānaḥ sṛjate brahma jajñānam ity āha tasmād brāhmaṇo mukhyas |
column2: Prajapati created creatures with the Brahman class as first; verily the sacrificer creates offspring with the Brahman as first; 'the holy power born', he says; therefore the Brahman is the first; the first he becomes who knows thus.

column1: mukhyo bhavati ya evaṃ veda brahmavādino vadanti na pṛthivyāṃ nāntarikṣe na divy agniś cetavya iti yat pṛthivyāṃ cinvīta pṛthivīṃ śucārpayet |
column2: The theologians say, 'Nor on earth, nor in the atmosphere, nor on sky should the fire be piled'; if he were to pile (it) on earth, he would afflict the earth with pain;

column1: nauṣadhayo na vanaspatayaḥ |
column2: nor trees, nor plants would [1] be born;

column1: pra jāyeran yad antarikṣe cinvītāntarikṣaṃ śucārpayet | na vayāṃsi pra jāyeran yad divi cinvīta divaṃ śucārpayet | na parjanyo varṣet |
column2: if he should pile (it) in the atmosphere, he would afflict the atmosphere with pain, the birds would not be born; if he should pile (it) in the sky, he would afflict the sky with pain, Parjanya would not rain.

column1: rukmam upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down a gold disk;

column1: amṛtaṃ vai hiraṇyam amṛta evāgniṃ cinute prajātyai hiraṇmayam puruṣam upa dadhāti yajamānalokasya vidhṛtyai yad iṣṭakāyā ātṛṇṇam anūpadadhyāt paśūnāṃ ca yajamānasya ca prāṇam api dadhyāt |
column2: gold is immortality; verily in immortality he piles the fire, for propagation. He puts down a golden man, to support the world of the sacrificer; if he were to put it over the perforation in the brick, he would obstruct the breath of cattle and of the sacrificer;

column1: dakṣiṇataḥ | prāñcam upa dadhāti dādhāra yajamānalokam |
column2: he puts it down on the south side [2] with head to the east: he supports the world of the sacrificer;

column1: na paśūnāṃ ca yajamānasya ca prāṇam api dadhāti |
column2: he does not obstruct the breath of cattle and the sacrificer.

column1: atho khalv iṣṭakāyā ātṛṇṇam anūpa dadhāti prāṇānām utsṛṣṭyai drapsaś caskandety abhi mṛśati hotrāsv evainam prati ṣṭhāpayati srucāv upa dadhāti |
column2: Or rather he does place it over the perforation of the brick, to allow the breath to pass out. 'The drop hath fallen', (with these words) he touches it; verily he establishes it in the Hotr's offices.

column1: ājjyasya {F pūrṇāṃ}{W pūrṇāṃ}{GLOS pūrṇāṃ} kārṣmaryamayīṃ dadhnaḥ pūrṇām audumbarīm iyaṃ vai kārṣmaryamayy asāv audumbarī |
column2: He puts down two ladles, one made of Karsmarya and full of butter, one of Udumbara and full of curds; that made of Karsmarya is this (earth), that of Udumbara is yonder (sky);

column1: ime evopa dhatte tūṣṇīm upa dadhāti na hīme yajuṣāptum arhati dakṣiṇāṃ kārṣmaryamayīm uttarām audumbarīm |
column2: verily he deposits these two (earth and sky) [3]. In silence he puts (them) down, for he should not obtain them with a Yajus; the Karsmarya on the south, the Udumbara on the north;

column1: tasmād asyā asāv uttarā |
column2: therefore is yonder (sky) higher than this (earth);

column1: ājyasya pūrṇāṃ kārṣmaryamatīm | vajro vā ājyaṃ vajraḥ kārṣmaryas |
column2: the Karsmarya filled with butter, the butter is a thunderbolt, the Karsmarya is a thunderbolt;

column1: vajreṇaiva yajñasya dakṣiṇato rakṣāṃsy apa hanti dadhnaḥ pūrṇām audumbarīm paśavo vai dadhy ūrg udumbaraḥ paśuṣv evorjaṃ dadhāti pūrṇe upa dadhāti pūrṇe evainam |
column2: verily by the thunderbolt he smites away the Raksases from the south of the sacrifice; the Udumbara filled with curds, curds are cattle, the Udumbara is strength; verily he confers strength upon cattle. He puts (them) down filled;

column1: amuṣmiM loka upa tiṣṭhete virājy agniś cetavya ity āhuḥ srug vai {virāḍ < virāj} yat srucāv upadadhāti virājy evāgniṃ cinute yajñamukheyajñamukhe vai kriyamāṇe yajñaṃ rakṣāṃsi jighāṃsanti yajñamukhaṃ rukmas |
column2: verily filled they wait on him [4] in yonder world. 'In the Viraj should the fire be piled', they say; the Viraj is the ladle; in that he puts down two ladles, he piles Agni in the Viraj. As each beginning of the sacrifice is being performed, the Raksases seek to destroy the sacrifice;

column1: yad rukmaṃ vyāghārayati yajñamukhād eva rakṣāṃsy apa hanti pañcabhir vyāghārayati pāṅkto yajñas |
column2: in that he pours butter over the gold disk, he smites away the Raksases from the beginning of the sacrifice. With five (verses) he pours butter; the sacrifice is fivefold;

column1: yāvān eva yajñas tasmād rakṣāṃsy apa hanti akṣṇayā vyāghārayati tasmād akṣṇayā paśavo 'ṅgāni pra haranti pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: verily he smites away the Raksases from the whole extent of the sacrifice; he pours butter transversely; therefore animals move their limbs transversely, for support.

column1: svayamātṛṇṇām upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the naturally perforated brick;

column1: iyaṃ vai svayamātṛṇṇā |
column2: the naturally perforated brick is this (earth);

column1: imām evopa dhatte |
column2: verily he puts down the (earth).

column1: aśvam upa ghrāpayati prāṇam evāsyāṃ dadhāti |
column2: He makes the horse sniff it; verily he bestows breath upon it;

column1: atho prājāpatyo vā aśvaḥ prajāpatinaivāgniṃ cinute prathameṣṭakopadhīyamānā paśūnāṃ ca yajamānasya ca prāṇam api dadhāti svayamātṛṇṇā bhavati prāṇānām utsṛṣṭyā atho suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai |
column2: now the horse is connected with Prajapati; verily he piles the fire with Prajapati. The first brick that is put down obstructs the breath of cattle and of the sacrificer; it is a naturally perforated one, to permit the breath to pass, and also to reveal the world of heaven.

column1: agnāv agniś cetavya ity āhus |
column2: 'In the fire must the fire be piled', they say;

column1: agnir vaiśvānaro yad brāhmaṇas tasmai prathamām iṣṭakāṃ yajuṣkṛtām pra yachet tām brāhmaṇas copa dadhyātām agnāv eva tad agniṃ cinute |
column2: the Brahman [1] is Agni Vaiçvanara, and to him should he hand over the first brick over which a Yajus has been recited; with the Brahman he should deposit it; verily in the fire he piles the fire.

column1: īśvaro vā eṣa ārtim ārtor yo 'vidvān iṣṭakām upadadhāti trīn varān dadyāt trayo vai prāṇāḥ prāṇānāṃ spṛtyai dvāv eva deyau dvau hi prāṇau |
column2: Now he who ignorantly puts down a brick is liable to experience misfortune. Three boons should he give, the breaths are three; (verily they serve) to guard the breaths; two only should be given, for the breaths are two;

column1: eka eva deyas | eko hi prāṇaḥ paśuḥ |
column2: one only should be given, for the breath is one.

column1: vā eṣa yad agnis |
column2: The fire is an animal here [2];

column1: na khalu vai paśava āyavase ramante dūrveṣṭakām upa dadhāti paśūnāṃ dhṛtyai dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityai kāṇḍātkāṇḍāt prarohantīty āha kāṇḍenakāṇḍena hy eṣā pratitiṣṭhai |
column2: animals do not find pleasure in want of grass; a brick of Durva grass he puts down, to support animals; with two (verses), for support. 'Arising from every stem', he says, for it finds support with every stem; 'do thou, O Durva, extend us with a thousand, a hundred', he says;

column1: evā no dūrve pra tanu sahasreṇa śatena cety āha sāhasraḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpater āptyai devalakṣmaṃ vai tryālikhitā tām uttaralakṣmāṇaṃ devā upādadhatādharalakṣmāṇam asurās |
column2: Prajapati is connected with a thousand; (verily it serves) to obtain Prajapati. The fact that it has three lines on it is a mark of the gods; the gods put it down with the mark uppermost, the Asuras with the mark undermost [3];

column1: yam | kāmayeta vasīyānt syād ity uttaralakṣmāṇaṃ tasyopa dadhyāt |
column2: if he desire of a man, 'May he become richer', he should put it down for him mark uppermost;

column1: vasīyān eva bhavati yaṃ kāmayeta pāpīyānt syād ity adharalakṣmāṇaṃ tasyopa dadhyāt |
column2: if he desire of a man, 'May he become worse off', he should put his down mark undermost;

column1: asurayonim evainam anu parā bhāvayati pāpīyān bhavati tryālikhitā bhavati |
column2: verily he makes him depressed in accordance with its birthplace among the Asuras, and he becomes worse off. (The brick) has three lines on it;

column1: ime vai lokās tryālikhitā |
column2: that with three lines is these worlds;

column1: ebhya eva lokebhyo bhrātṛvyam antar eti |
column2: verily he excludes its foe from these worlds.

column1: aṅgirasaḥ suvargaṃ lokaṃ vataḥ puroḍāśaḥ kūrmo bhūtvānu prāsarpat |
column2: When the Angirases went to the world of heaven, the sacrificial cake becoming a tortoise crawled after them [4];

column1: yat kūrmam upadadhāti yathā kṣetravid añjasā nayaty evam evainaṃ kūrmaḥ suvargaṃ lokam añjasā nayati medho vā eṣa paśūnāṃ yat kūrmas |
column2: in that he puts down a tortoise, just as one who knows a place leads straight (to it), so the tortoise leads him straight to the world of heaven. The tortoise is the intelligence of animals;

column1: yat kūrmam upadadhāti svam eva medham paśyantaḥ paśava upa tiṣṭhante śmaśānaṃ vā etat kriyate yan mṛtānām paśūnāṃ śīrṣāṇy upadhīyante yaj jīvantaṃ kūrmam upadadhāti tenāśmaśānacit |
column2: in that he puts down the tortoise, animals resort there, seeing their own intelligence; in that the heads of the dead animals are deposited, a burial-ground is made; in that he puts down the living tortoise, he is no maker of a burial-ground, the tortoise is suitable for a dwelling [5].

column1: vāstavyo vā eṣa yat |
column2: verily he makes him ready;

column1: grāmyaṃ vā etad annaṃ yad dadhy āraṇyam madhu yad dadhnā madhumiśreṇābhyanakty ubhayasyāvaruddhyai mahī dyauḥ pṛthivī ca na ity āha |
column2: curds is a food of the village, honey of the wild; in that he anoints with curds mixed with honey, (it serves) to win both. 'May the two great ones, heaven and earth', he says;

column1: ābhyām evainam ubhayataḥ pari gṛhṇāti prāñcam upa dadhāti tasmāt |
column2: verily with them he encircles him on both sides. He puts it down to the east,' to attain the world of heaven;

column1: purastāt pratyañcaḥ paśavo medham upa tiṣṭhante yo vā apanābhim agniṃ cinute yajamānasya nābhim anu pra viśati sa enam īśvaro hiṃsitos |
column2: he puts it down to the east facing west; therefore [6] to the east facing west the animals attend the sacrifice. If he piles the fire without a navel, (the fire) enters the navel of the sacrificer, and is liable to injure him.

column1: ulūkhalam upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the mortar;

column1: eṣā vā agner nābhiḥ sanābhim evāgniṃ cinute 'hiṃsāyai |
column2: this is the navel of the fire; verily he piles the fire with its navel, to avoid injury.

column1: audumbaram bhavati | ūrg vā udumbaras |
column2: (The mortar) is of Udumbara wood; the Udumbara is strength;

column1: ūrjam evāva runddhe madhyata upa dadhāti madhyata evāsmā ūrjaṃ dadhāti tasmān madhyata ūrjā bhuñjate |
column2: in the middle he puts it down; verily in the middle he bestows strength upon him; therefore in the middle men enjoy strength.

column1: iyad bhavati prajāpatinā yajñamukhena sammitam ava hanti |
column2: So large is it, commensurate with Prajapati, the mouth of the sacrifice.

column1: annam evākar vaiṣṇavyarcopa dadhāti viṣṇur vai yajñas | vaiṣṇavā vanaspatayas |
column2: he puts (it) down with (a verse) addressed to Visnu; the sacrifice is Visnu, the trees are connected with Visnu;

column1: yajña eva yajñam prati ṣṭhāpayati |
column2: verily in the sacrifice he establishes the sacrifice.

column1: eṣāṃ vā etal lokānāṃ jyotiḥ sambhṛtaṃ yad ukhā yad ukhām upadadhāty ebhya evā lokebhyo jyotir ava runddhe madhyata upa dadhāti madhyata evāsmai jyotir dadhāti tasmān madhyato jyotir upāsmahe sikatābhiḥ pūrayati |
column2: The pan is the concentrated light of these lights; in that he puts down the pan, verily he wins the light from these worlds; in the middle he puts (it) down; verily he bestows upon it light; therefore in the middle we reverence the light;

column1: etad vā agner vaiśvānarasya rūpam |
column2: that is the form of Agni Vaiçvanara;

column1: rūpeṇaiva vaiśvānaram ava runddhe yaṃ kāmayeta kṣodhukaḥ syād ity ūnāṃ tasyopa |
column2: verily by his form he wins Vaiçvanara. If he desire of a man, 'May he become hungry', he should put down for one (a pan) deficient in size [1];

column1: dadhyāt kṣodhuka eva bhavati yaṃ kāmayeta | anupadasyad annam adyād iti pūrṇāṃ tasyopa dadhyāt |
column2: if he desire of a man, 'May he eat food that fails not', he should put it down full;

column1: anupadasyad evānnam atti sahasraṃ vai prati puruṣaḥ paśūnāṃ yachati sahasram anye paśavas |
column2: verily he eats food that fails not. The man accords a thousand of cattle, the other animals a thousand;

column1: madhye puruṣaśīrṣam upa dadhāti savīryatvāya |
column2: in the middle he puts down the head of the man, to give it strength.

column1: ukhāyām api dadhāti pratiṣṭhām evainad gamayati vyṛddhaṃ vā etat prāṇair amedhyaṃ yat puruṣaśīrṣam amṛtaṃ khalu vai prāṇāḥ |
column2: In the pan he puts (it) down; verily he makes it attain support; the head of the man is impure as devoid of breaths;

column1: amṛtaṃ hiraṇyam prāṇeṣu hiraṇyaśalkān praty asyati pratiṣṭhām evainad gamayitvā prāṇaiḥ sam ardhayati dadhnā madhumiśreṇa pūrayati |
column2: the breaths are immortality [2], gold is immortality; on the (organs of the) breaths he hurls chips of gold; verily he makes it attain support, and unites it with the breaths.

column1: madhvyo 'sānīti śṛtātaṅkyena medhyatvāya grāmyaṃ vā etad annaṃ yad dadhy āraṇyam madhu yad dadhnā madhumiśreṇa pūrayaty ubhayasyāvaruddhyai paśuśīrṣāṇy upa dadhāti paśavo vai paśuśīrṣāṇi paśūn evāva runddhe yaṃ kāmayeta |
column2: He fills (it) with curds mixed with honey, (saying) 'May I be fit to drink honey'; (he fills with curds) to be curdled with hot milk, for purity. The curds are the food of the village, honey of the wild; in that he fills (it) with curds mixed with honey, (it serves) to win both. He puts down the heads of the animals;

column1: apaśuḥ syād iti viṣūcīnāni tasyopa dadhyāt |
column2: If he desire of a man, 'May he have no cattle'[3], he should put them down, looking away, for him;

column1: viṣūca evāsmāt paśūn dadhāti |
column2: verily he makes cattle look away from him;

column1: apaśur eva bhavati yaṃ kāmayeta paśumānt syād iti samīcīnāni tasyopa dadhyāt samīca evāsmai paśūn dadhāti paśumān eva bhavati purastāt pratīcīnam aśvasyopa dadhāti paścāt prācīnam ṛṣabhasya |
column2: If he desire of a man, 'May he be rich in cattle', he should put (them) down looking with (the man's head); verily he makes the cattle look with him; he becomes rich in cattle. He puts (the head) of the horse in the east looking west, that of the bull in the west looking east;

column1: apaśavo vā anye goaśvebhyaḥ paśavas |
column2: the beasts other than the oxen and the horses are not beasts at all;

column1: goaśvān evāsmai samīco dadhāti |
column2: verily he makes the oxen and the horses look with him.

column1: etāvanto vai paśavaḥ | dvipādaś ca catuṣpādaś ca tān vā etad agnau pra dadhāti yat paśuśīrṣāṇy upadadhāti |
column2: So many are the animals [4], bipeds and quadrupeds; them indeed he puts down in the fire, in that he puts down the heads of the animals.

column1: amum āraṇyam anu te diśāmīty āha grāmyebhya eva paśubhya āraṇyān paśūñ chucam anūt sṛjati tasmāt samāvat paśūnām prajāyamānānām āraṇyāḥ paśavaḥ kanīyāṃsaḥ śucā hy ṛtāḥ sarpaśīrṣam upa dadhāti yaiva sarpe tviṣis tām evāva runddhe |
column2: 'I appoint for thee N.N. of the forest', he says; verily from the cattle of the village he sends pain to those of the wild; therefore of animals born at one time the animals of the wild are the smaller, for they are afflicted with pain. He puts down the head of a snake;

column1: yat samīcīnam paśuśīrṣair upadadhyād grāmyān paśūn daṃśukāḥ syus |
column2: If he were to put it down looking with the heads of the animals, (the snakes) would bite the animals of the village;

column1: yad viṣūcīnam āraṇyān yajur eva vadet | ava tāṃ tviṣiṃ runddhe yā sarpe na grāmyān paśūn hinasti nāraṇyān atho khalūpadheyam eva yad upadadhāti tena tāṃ tviṣim ava runddhe yā sarpe yad yajur vadati tena śāntam |
column2: if turned away, those of the wild; he should speak a Yajus, he wins the brilliance that is in the snake, he injures not the animals of the village, nor those of the wild.

column1: paśur vā eṣa yad agnis |
column2: Or rather should it be put down;

column1: yoniḥ khalu vā eṣā paśor vi kriyate yat prācīnam aiṣṭakād yajuḥ kriyate reto 'pasyās |
column2: in that he utters a Yajus, thereby is it appeased. The First Layer of Bricks The fire is an animal, now the birthplace of the animal is changed in that before the putting up of the bricks the Yajus is performed.

column1: apasyā upa dadhāti yonāv eva reto dadhāti pañcopa dadhāti pāṅktāḥ paśavaḥ paśūn evāsmai pra janayati pañca dakṣiṇatas |
column2: The water bricks are seed; be puts down the water bricks; verily he places seed in the womb. Five he puts down (on the east) cattle are fivefold;

column1: vajro vā apasyās |
column2: verily he produces cattle for him;

column1: vajreṇaiva yajñasya dakṣiṇato rakṣāṃsy apa hanti pañca paścāt |
column2: verily with the thunderbolt he smites away the Raksases from the south of the sacrifice; five he puts down on the west [1], pointing east;

column1: prācīr upa dadhāti paścād vai prācīnaṃ reto dhīyate paścād evāsmai prācīnaṃ reto dadhāti pañca purastāt pratīcīr upa dadhāti pañca paścāt prācīs tasmāt prācīnaṃ reto dhīyate pratīcīḥ prajā jāyante pañcottarataś chandasyāḥ paśavo vai chandasyāḥ paśūn eva prajātānt svam āyatanam abhi pary ūhate |
column2: verily from behind he deposits seed for him in front. Five he puts down on the east, pointing west; five on the west pointing east; therefore seed is impregnated in front, offspring are born at the back. On the north he puts down five metre bricks;

column1: iyaṃ vā agner atidāhād abibhet saitāḥ |
column2: This (earth) was afraid of excessive burning by the fire;

column1: apasyā apaśyat tā upādhatta tato vā imāṃ nāty adahat |
column2: she saw these [2] water bricks, she put them down, then (the fire) did not burn her excessively;

column1: yad apasyā upadadhāty asyā anatidāhāya uvāca heyam adad it sa brahmaṇānnaṃ yasyaitā upadhīyāntai ya u cainā evaṃ vedad iti prāṇabhṛta upa dadhāti retasy eva prāṇān dadhāti tasmād vadan prāṇan paśyañ chṛṇvan paśur jāyate |
column2: She said, 'He shall eat food with holy power, for whom these shall be put down, and he who shall know them thus.' He puts down the breath-supporting (bricks); verily he places the breaths in the seed; therefore an animal is born with speech, breath, sight, and bearing.

column1: ayam puraḥ |
column2: 'This one in front [3], the existent';

column1: bhuva iti purastād upa dadhāti prāṇam evaitābhir dādhāra |
column2: (with these words) he puts down on the east; verily with these he supports breath.

column1: ayaṃ dakṣiṇā viśvakarmeti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: 'This one on the right, the all-worker', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: mana evaitābhir dādhāra |
column2: verily with these he supports mind.

column1: ayam paścād viśvavyacā iti paścāt |
column2: 'This one behind, the all-extending', (with these words he puts down) on the west;

column1: cakṣur evaitābhir dādhāra |
column2: verily with these he supports sight.

column1: idam uttarāt suvar ity uttarataḥ śrotram evaitābhir dādhāra |
column2: 'This one on the left, the light', (with these words he puts down) on the north; verily with these he supports hearing.

column1: iyam upari matir ity upariṣṭāt |
column2: 'This one above, thought', (with these words he puts down) above;

column1: vācam evaitābhir dādhāra daśadaśopa dadhāti savīryatvāya |
column2: verily with these he supports speech. Ten by ten he puts (them) down, to give strength.

column1: upa dadhāti tasmād akṣṇayā paśavo 'ṅgāni pra haranti pratiṣṭhityai yāḥ prācīs tābhir vasiṣṭha ārdhnot |
column2: Transversely [4] he puts (them) down; therefore transversely do animals move their limbs, for support.

column1: yā dakṣiṇā tābhir bharadvājas | yāḥ prātīcīs tābhir viśvāmitras | yā udīcīs tābhir jamadagnis |
column2: With those (put down) on the east Vasistha prospered, with those on the south Bharadvaja, with those on the west Viçvamitra, with those on the north Jamadagni, with those above Viçvakarman.

column1: yā ūrdhvās tābhir viśvakarmā ya evam etāsām ṛddhiṃ vedardhnoty eva ya āsām evam bandhutāṃ veda bandhumān bhavati ya āsām evaṃ klptiṃ veda kalpate |
column2: He who knows thus the prosperity in these (bricks) prospers; he who knows thus their relationship becomes rich in relations;

column1: asmai ya āsām evam āyatanaṃ vedāyatanavān bhavati ya āsām evam pratiṣṭhāṃ veda praty eva tiṣṭhati prāṇabhṛta upadhāya saṃyata upa dadhāti prāṇān evāsmin dhitvā saṃyadbhiḥ saṃ yachati tat saṃyatāṃ saṃyattvam atho prāṇa evāpānaṃ dadhāti tasmāt prāṇāpānau saṃ caratas |
column2: he who knows thus their ordering, (things) go orderly [5] for him; he who knows thus their abode becomes possessed of an abode; he who knows thus their support becomes possessed of support. Having put down the breath-supporters he puts down the unifying (bricks); verily having deposited in him the breaths he unifies them with the unifying (bricks);

column1: viṣūcīr upa dadhāti tasmād viṣvañcau prāṇāpānau yad vā agner asaṃyatam |
column2: therefore expiration and inspiration go in different directions. The ununified part of the fire [6] is not worthy of heaven;

column1: asuvargyam asya tat suvargyo 'gnis |
column2: the fire is worthy of heaven;

column1: yat saṃyata upadadhāti sam evainaṃ yachati suvargyam evākas tryavir vayaḥ kṛtam ayānām ity āha vayobhir evāyān ava runddhe |
column2: in that he puts down the unifying (bricks), he unifies it; verily he makes it worthy of heaven. 'The eighteen-month-old calf the strength, the Krta of throws at dice', he says;

column1: ayair vayāṃsi sarvato vāyumatīr bhavanti tasmād ayaṃ sarvataḥ pavate |
column2: On all sides (these verses) have the word wind', and therefore the (wind) blows on all sides.

column1: gāyatrī triṣṭub jagaty anuṣṭuk paṅktyā saha | bṛhaty uṣṇihā kakut sūcībhiḥ śimyantu tvā |
column2: The Horse Sacrifice (continued) May the Gayatri, the Tristubh, the Jagati, The Anustubh, with the Pankti, The Brhati, the Usnih, and the Kakubh, Pierce thee with needles.

column1: dvipadā yā catuṣpadā tripadā yā ca ṣaṭpadā | sachandā yā ca vichandāḥ sūcībhiḥ śimyantu tvā |
column2: May the two-footed, the four-footed, The three-footed, the six-footed, The metrical, the unmetrical, Pierce thee with needles.

column1: mahānāmnī revatayo viśvā āśāḥ prasūvarīḥ | meghyā vidyuto vācaḥ sūcībhiḥ śimyantu tvā |
column2: May the Mahanamnis, the Revatis, All the regions that are rich in fruits, The lightnings of the clouds, the voices. Pierce thee with needles.

column1: rajatā hariṇīḥ sīsā yujo yujyante karmabhiḥ | aśvasya vājinas tvaci sūcībhiḥ śimyantu tvā |
column2: The silver, the gold, the leaden, Are yoked as workers with the works, On the skin of the strong horse, May they pierce thee with needles.

column1: nārīḥ | te patnayo loma vi cinvantu manīṣayā | devānām patnīr diśaḥ sūcībhiḥ śimyantu tvā |
column2: May the ladies [1], the wives, With skill separate thy hair, The wives of the gods, the quarters, Pierce thee with needles.

column1: kuvid aṅga yavamanto yavaṃ cid yathā dānty anupūrvaṃ viyūya | ihehaiṣāṃ kṛṇuta bhojanāni ye barhiṣo namovṛktiṃ na jagmuḥ |
column2: What then? As men who have barley Reap the barley in order, removing it, Hither bring the food of those Who have not gone to the reverential cutting of the strew.

column1: kas tvā chyati kas tvā vi śāsti kas te gātrāṇi śimyati | ka u te śamitā kaviḥ | ṛtavas ta ṛtudhā paruḥ śamitāro vi śāsatu | saṃvatsarasya dhāyasā śimībhiḥ śimyantu tvā |
column2: Who cutteth thee? Who doth divide thee Who doth pierce thy limbs? Who, too, is thy wise dissector? May the seasons in due season, The dissectors, divide thy joints, And with the splendour of the year May they pierce thee with needles.

column1: daivyā adhvaryavas tvā chyantu vi ca śāsatu |
column2: May the divine Adhvaryus cut thee, And divide thee;

column1: gātrāṇi parvaśas te śimāḥ kṛṇvantu śimyantaḥ |
column2: May the piercers piercing Joint thy limbs.

column1: ardhamāsāḥ parūṃṣi te māsāś chyantu śimyantaḥ | ahorātrāṇi maruto viliṣṭaṃ |
column2: May the half-months, the months, Cut thy joints, piercing, May the days and nights, the Maruts, Make whole thine injuries [1].

column1: pṛthivī te 'ntarikṣeṇa vāyuś chidram bhiṣajyatu | dyaus te nakṣatraiḥ saha rūpaṃ kṛṇotu sādhuyā |
column2: May the earth with the atmosphere, May Vayu heal thy rent, May the sky with the Naksatras Arrange thy form aright.

column1: śaṃ te parebhyo gātrebhyaḥ śam astv avarebhyaḥ |
column2: Healing to thy higher limbs, Healing to thy lower;

column1: śam asthabhyo majjabhyaḥ śam u te tanuve bhuvat |
column2: Healing to bones, marrow, Healing too to thy body!

column1: utsannayajño vā eṣa yad agniḥ kiṃ vāhaitasya kriyate kiṃ vā na yad vai yajñasya kriyamāṇasyāntaryanti pūyati vā asya tat |
column2: The Second and Later Layers of Bricks Now this fire (ritual) is an extensive sacrifice; what part of it is performed or what not? The part of the sacrifice which is performed that is omitted becomes rotten;

column1: āśvinīr upa dadhāti |
column2: be puts down the Açvin (bricks);

column1: aśvinau vai devānām bhiṣajau tābhyām evāsmai bheṣajaṃ karoti pañcopa dadhāti pāṅkto yajñas |
column2: the Açvins are the physicians of the gods; verily by them be produces medicine for it. Five he puts down; the sacrifice is fivefold;

column1: yāvān eva yajñas tasmai bheṣajaṃ karoti |
column2: verily he produces medicine for the whole extent of the sacrifice.

column1: ṛtavyā upa dadhāti | ṛtūnāṃ klptyai |
column2: He puts down the seasonal (bricks), to arrange the seasons [1].

column1: pañcopa dadhāti pañca vā ṛtavas |
column2: Five he puts down; the seasons are five;

column1: yāvanta evartavas tān kalpayati samānaprabhṛtayo bhavanti samānodarkās tasmāt samānā ṛtavas |
column2: verily he arranges the seasons in their whole number. They begin and end alike; therefore the seasons are alike;

column1: ekena padena vyāvartante tasmād ṛtavo vyāvartante prāṇabhṛta upa dadhāti |
column2: they differ in one foot; therefore the seasons differ likewise. He puts down the breath-supporters;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva prāṇān dadhāti tasmāt samānāḥ santa ṛtavo na jīryanti |
column2: verily he places the breaths in the months; therefore being alike the seasons do not grow old;

column1: atho pra janayaty evainān eṣa vai vāyur yat prāṇas |
column2: moreover he generates them. The breath is the wind;

column1: upadadhāti tasmāt sarvān ṛtūn anu vāyur ā varīvartti vṛṣṭisanīr upa dadhāti vṛṣṭim evāva runddhe yad ekadhopadadhyād ekam ṛtuṃ varṣet |
column2: in that having put down the seasonal (bricks) he puts down the breath-sup porters [2], therefore the wind accompanies all the seasons. He puts down the rain-winners; verily he wins rain. If he were to put them down in one place, then would fall rain in one season only;

column1: anuparihāraṃ sādayati tasmāt sarvān ṛtūn varṣati yat prāṇabhṛta upadhāya vṛṣṭisanīr upadadhāti tasmād vāyupracyutā divo vṛṣṭir īrte paśavo vai vayasyās |
column2: therefore it rains in all the seasons. Since having put down the breath-supporters he puts down the rain-winners, therefore the rain starts from the sky, impelled downwards by the wind. The strengthening (bricks) are cattle;

column1: nānāmanasaḥ khalu vai paśavo nānāvratās te 'pa evābhi samanasaḥ |
column2: cattle have various purposes and various customs, but only as regards water are they of one purpose [3];

column1: yaṃ kāmayeta | apaśuḥ syād iti vayasyās tasyopadhāyāpasyā upa dadhyād asaṃjñānam evāsmai paśubhiḥ karoti |
column2: if he desire of a man, 'May he be without cattle', he should put down for him the strengthening (bricks) and then put down the water (bricks);

column1: apaśur eva bhavati yaṃ kāmayeta paśumānt syād ity apasyās tasyopadhāya vayasyā upa dadhyāt saṃjñānam evāsmai paśubhiḥ karoti paśumān eva bhavati catasraḥ purastād upa dadhāti tasmāc catvāri cakṣuṣo rūpāṇi dve śukle dve kṛṣṇe |
column2: verily he becomes without cattle. If he desire of a man, 'May he possess cattle', he should put down for him the water (bricks) and then put down the strengthening (bricks); verily he makes concord for him with cattle and he becomes possessed of cattle. He puts down four in front; therefore the eye has four forms, two white, two black [4].

column1: mūrdhanvatīr bhavanti tasmāt purastān mūrdhā pañca dakṣiṇāyāṃ śroṇyām upa dadhāti pañcottarasyāṃ tasmāt paścād varṣīyān purastātpravaṇaḥ paśus |
column2: The (verses) contain the word 'head'; therefore the head (of the fire) is in front. Five he puts down in the right hip, five in the left; therefore the animal is broader behind and receding in front;

column1: basto vaya iti dakṣiṇe 'ṃsa upa dadhāti vṛṣṇir vaya ity uttare |
column2: 'The goat in strength', (with these words he puts down) on the right shoulder; (with) 'The ram in strength', on the left;

column1: aṃsāv eva prati dadhāti vyāghro vaya iti dakṣiṇe pakṣa upa dadhāti siṃho vaya ity uttare pakṣayor eva vīryaṃ dadhāti puruṣo vaya iti madhye tasmāt puruṣaḥ paśūnām adhipatiḥ |
column2: 'The tiger in strength', (with these words) he puts down in the right wing, (with) 'The lion in strength' on the left; verily he gives strength to the wings. (With) 'The man in strength' (he puts down) in the middle; therefore man is overlord of animals.

column1: indrāgnī avyathamānām iti svayamātṛṇṇām upa dadhāti |
column2: 'O Indra and Agni, (the brick) that quaketh not', (with these words) he puts down the naturally perforated (brick);

column1: indrāgnibhyāṃ vā imau lokau vidhṛtau |
column2: these worlds are separated by Indra and Agni;

column1: anayor lokayor vidhṛtyai |
column2: (verily it serves) to separate these worlds.

column1: adhṛteva vā eṣā yan madhyamā citis | antarikṣam iva vā eṣā |
column2: Now the middle layer is, as it were, insecure, it is as it were the atmosphere;

column1: indrāgnī ity āha |
column2: 'Indra and Agni', he says;

column1: indrāgnī vai devānām ojobhṛtau |
column2: Indra and Agni are the supporters of force among the gods;

column1: ojasaivainām antarikṣe cinute dhṛtyai svayamātṛṇṇām upa dadhāti |
column2: verily he piles it with force in the atmosphere, for support. He puts down the naturally perforated (brick);

column1: antarikṣaṃ vai svayamātṛṇṇā |
column2: the naturally perforated (brick) is the atmosphere;

column1: antarikṣam evopa dhatte |
column2: verily he puts down the atmosphere [1].

column1: ghrāpayati prāṇam evāsyāṃ dadhāti |
column2: He makes the horse sniff it; verily he puts breath in it;

column1: atho prājāpatyo vā aśvaḥ prajāpatinaivāgniṃ cinute svayamātṛṇṇā bhavati prāṇānām utsṛṣṭyai | atho suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai |
column2: now the horse is connected with Prajapati; verily by Prajapati he piles the fire. It is a naturally perforated (brick), to allow the passage of the breaths, and also for the lighting up of the world of heaven.

column1: devānāṃ vai suvargaṃ lokaṃ yatāṃ diśaḥ sam avlīyanta ta etā diśyā apaśyan tā upādadhata tābhir vai te diśo 'dṛṃhan yad diśyā upadadhāti diśaṃ vidhṛtyai daśa prāṇabhṛtaḥ purastād upa |
column2: When the gods went to the world of heaven, the quarters were in confusion; they saw these regional (bricks), they put them down, and by them they made firm the quarters; in that he put down the regional bricks, (it is) to support the quarters. Ten breath supporters he places in the east [2];

column1: dadhāti nava vai puruṣe prāṇā nābhir daśamī prāṇān eva purastād dhatte tasmāt purastāt prāṇās |
column2: the breaths in man are nine, the navel is the tenth; verily he places the breaths in front; therefore the breaths are in front.

column1: jyotiṣmatīm uttamāṃ upa dadhāti tasmāt prāṇānāṃ vāg jyotir uttamās |
column2: He puts down the last with the word 'light'; there fore speech, which is the last, is the light of the breaths.

column1: daśopa dadhāti daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} virāṭ chandasāṃ jyotis |
column2: He put down ten; the Viraj has ten syllables, the light of the metres is the Viraj;

column1: jyotr eva purastād dhatte tasmāt purastāj jyotir upāsmahe chandāṃsi paśuṣv ājim ayus tān bṛhaty ud ajayat tasmād bārhatāḥ |
