column2: verily he puts the light in the east; therefore we revere the light in the east. The metres ran a race for the cattle; the Brhati won them; there fore cattle are called connected with the Brhati [3].

column1: paśava ucyante mā chanda iti dakṣiṇata upa dadhāti tasmād dakṣiṇāvṛto māṣāḥ pṛthivī chanda iti paścāt pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'Ma metre', (with these words) he puts down on the south; therefore the months turn south wards; (with) 'Earth metre' (he puts down) on the west, for support;

column1: agnir devatety uttarata ojo vā agnir oja evottarato dhatte tasmād uttarato'bhiprayāyī jayati ṣaṭtriṃśat sam padyante ṣaṭtriṃśadakṣarā bṛhatī bārhatāḥ paśavas |
column2: (with) 'Agni, the deity' (he puts down) on the north; Agni is might; verily on the north he places might; therefore he that advances to the north is victorious. They make up thirty-six;

column1: bṛhatyaivāsmai paśūn ava runddhe bṛhatī chandasāṃ svārājyam parīyāya yasyaitāḥ |
column2: the Brhati has thirty-six syllables, cattle are connected with the Brhati; verily by the Brhati he wins cattle for him.

column1: upadhīyante gachati svārājyam |
column2: he for whom these [4] are put down attains sovereignty.

column1: sapta vālakhilyāḥ purastād upa dadhāti sapta paścāt sapta vai śīrṣaṇyāḥ prāṇā dvāv avāñcau prāṇānāṃ savīryatvāya mūrdhāsi rāḍ iti purastād upa dadhāti yantrī rāḍ iti paścāt prāṇān evāsmai samīco dadhāti |
column2: He puts down seven Valakhilya, (bricks) in the east, seven in the west; in the head there are seven breaths, two below; (verily they serve) to give the breaths strength. 'The head thou art, ruling', (with these words) he puts down on the east; 'Thou art the prop ruling', (with these words) he puts down on the west;

column1: devā vai yad yajñe 'kurvata tad asurā akurvata te devā etā akṣṇayāstomīyā apaśyan tā anyathānūcyānyathopādadhata tad asurā nānvavāyan tato devā abhavan parāsurās |
column2: Whatever the gods did at the sacrifice the Asuras did. The gods saw these Aksnayastomiya (bricks), they put them down on one place after reciting in another; the Asuras could not follow it; then the gods prospered, the Asuras were defeated.

column1: yad akṣṇayāstomīyā anyathānūcyānyathopadadhāti bhrātrivyābhibhūtyai bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyo bhavati |
column2: In that he puts down the Aksnayastomiyas in one place after reciting in another, (it is) to overcome foes: he prospers himself, his foe is defeated.

column1: āśus trivṛd iti purastād upa dadhāti yajñamukhaṃ vai trivṛt |
column2: 'The swift, the triple', (with these words) he puts down on the east; the triple is the beginning of the sacrifice [1];

column1: yajñamukham eva purastād vi yātayati vyoma saptadaśa iti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: verily in the east he establishes the beginning of the sacrifice. 'The sky, the seventeenfold ', (with these words be puts down) on the south;

column1: annaṃ vai vyoma | annaṃ saptadaśas |
column2: the sky is food, the seventeenfold is food;

column1: annam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇenānnam adyate dharuṇa ekaviṃśa iti paścāt pratiṣṭhā vā ekaviṃśaḥ pratiṣṭhityai bhāntaḥ pañcadaśa ity uttaratas |
column2: verily on the south he places food; therefore with the right (hand) is food eaten. 'Support, the twenty-onefold', (with these words he puts down) on the west; the twenty-onefold is support;

column1: ojo vai bhāntas |
column2: (verily it serves) for support.

column1: ojaḥ pañcadaśas |
column2: 'The shining, the fifteenfold', (with these words he puts down) on the north;

column1: oja evottarato dhatte tasmād uttarato'bhiprayāyī jayati pratūrtir aṣṭādaśa iti purastāt |
column2: therefore he that advances to the north is victorious. 'Speed, the eighteenfold', (with these words) he puts down on the east [2];

column1: upa dadhāti dvau trivṛtāv abhipūrvaṃ yajñamukhe vi yātayati |
column2: two threefold ones he establishes in the beginning of the sacrifice in order.

column1: abhivartaḥ saviṃśa iti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: 'Attack, the twentyfold', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: annaṃ saviṃśas | annam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇenānnam adyate varco dvāviṃśa iti paścāt |
column2: verily he places food on the south therefore with the right is food eaten. 'Radiance, the twenty-twofold', (with these words he puts down) on the west;

column1: yad viṃśatir dve tena virājau yad dve pratiṣṭhā tena virājor evābhipūrvam annādye prati tiṣṭhati tapo navadaśa ity uttaratas tasmāt savyaḥ |
column2: in that there are twenty, thereby there are two Viraj verses; in that there are two there is support; verily in order he finds support in the Viraj verses and in the eating of food. 'Fervour, the nineteenfold', (with these words he puts down) on the north;

column1: hastayos tapasvitaras |
column2: therefore the left hand [3] has the greater fervour.

column1: yoniś caturviṃśa iti purastād upa dadhāti caturviṃśatyakṣarā gāyatrī gāyatrī yajñamukham |
column2: 'The womb, the twenty-fourfold', (with these words) he puts down on the east; the Gayatri has twenty-four syllables, the beginning of the sacrifice is the Gayatri;

column1: yajñamukham eva purastād vi yātayati garbhāḥ pañcaviṃśa iti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: verily on the east he establishes the beginning of the sacrifice. 'The embryo, the twenty-fivefold', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: annaṃ vai garbhās | annam pañcaviṃśas |
column2: embryos are food, the twenty-fivefold is food;

column1: annam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇenānnam adyate |
column2: verily he places food on the south; therefore with the right is food eaten.

column1: ojas triṇava iti paścāt |
column2: 'Force the twenty sevenfold', (with these words he puts down) on the west;

column1: ime vai lokās triṇavas |
column2: the twenty-seven fold is these worlds;

column1: eṣv eva lokeṣu prati tiṣṭhati sambharaṇas trayoviṃśa iti |
column2: verily he finds support in these worlds. 'Maintenance, the twenty-fourfold', (with these words he puts down) on the north [4];

column1: uttaratas tasmāt savyo hastayoḥ sambhāryataraḥ kratur ekatriṃśa iti purastād upa dadhāti vāg vai kratus |
column2: therefore the left hand is most to be maintained. 'Inspiration, the thirty-onefold', (with these words) he puts down on the east;

column1: yajñamukhaṃ vāc |
column2: inspiration is speech, speech is the beginning of the sacrifice;

column1: yajñamukham eva purastād vi yātayati bradhnasya viṣṭapaṃ catustriṃśa iti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: verily he establishes the beginning of the sacrifice on the east. 'The surface of the tawny one, the thirty fourfold', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: asau vā ādityo bradhnasya viṣṭapam brahmavarcasam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇo 'rdho brahmavarcasitaraḥ pratiṣṭhā trayastriṃśa iti paścāt pratiṣṭhityai nākaḥ ṣaṭtriṃśa ity uttarataḥ suvargo vai loko nākaḥ suvargasya lokasya samaṣṭyai |
column2: therefore the right side is the more resplendent. 'Support, the thirty threefold', (with these words he puts down) on the west, for support. 'The vault, the thirtysixfold', (with these words he puts down) on the north'; the vault is the world of heaven; (verily it serves) to attain the world of heaven.

column1: agner bhāgo 'sīti purastād upa dadhāti yajñamukhaṃ vā agnis | yajñamukhaṃ dīkṣā yajñamukham brahma yajñamukhaṃ trivṛt |
column2: Agni is the beginning of the sacrifice, consecration is the beginning of the sacrifice, holy power is the beginning of the sacrifice, the threefold is the beginning of the sacrifice;

column1: yajñamukham eva purastād vi yātayati nṛcakṣasām bhāgo 'sīti dakṣiṇataḥ śuśruvāṃso vai nṛcakṣasas |
column2: verily on the east he establishes the beginning of the sacrifice. 'Thou art the portion of them that gaze on men', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: annaṃ dhātā jātāyaivāsmā annam api dadhāti tasmāj jāto 'nnam atti janitraṃ spṛtaṃ saptadaśa stoma ity āha |
column2: verily on birth he gives him food; therefore on birth he eats food. 'The birthplace saved, the seventeenfold Stoma', he says;

column1: annaṃ vai janitram | annaṃ saptadaśas |
column2: the birthplace is food [1], the seventeen fold is food;

column1: annam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇenānnam adyate mitrasya bhāgo 'sīti paścāt prāṇo vai mitro 'pāno varuṇaḥ prāṇāpānāv evāsmin dadhāti divo vṛṣṭir vātā spṛtā ekaviṃśa stoma ity āha pratiṣṭhā vā ekaviṃśaḥ pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: therefore with the right food is eaten. 'Thou art the portion of Mitra', (with these words he puts down) on the west; Mitra is expiration, Varuna inspiration; verily he confers on him expiration and inspiration. 'The rain from the sky, the winds saved, the twenty-onefold Stoma', he says;

column1: indrasya bhāgo 'sīty uttaratas |
column2: 'Thou art the portion of Indra', (with these words he puts down) on the north;

column1: ojo vā indras | ojo viṣṇus | ojaḥ kṣatram ojaḥ pañcadaśaḥ |
column2: Indra is force, Visnu, is force, the lordly power is force, the fifteenfold is force [2];

column1: yajñamukham eva purastād vi yātayati | ādityānām bhāgo 'sīti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: verily on the north he places force; therefore he that advances to the north is victorious.

column1: annaṃ vā ādityās |
column2: verily on the east he establishes the beginning of the sacrifice.

column1: annam marutas | annaṃ garbhās | annam pañcaviṃśas |
column2: the Adityas are food, the Maruts are food, embryos are food, the twenty-fivefold is food;

column1: annam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣṇenānnam adyate |
column2: verily be places food on the south; therefore with the right food is eaten.

column1: adityai bhāgaḥ |
column2: (verily it serves) for support.

column1: asīti paścāt pratiṣṭhā vā aditiḥ pratiṣṭhā pūṣā pratiṣṭhā triṇavaḥ pratiṣṭhityai devasya savitur bhāgo 'sīty uttaratas |
column2: 'Thou art the portion of the god Savitr', (with these words he puts down) on the north;

column1: brahma vai devaḥ savitā brahma bṛhaspatis | brahma catuṣṭomas |
column2: the god Savitr is holy power, Brhaspati is holy power, the fourfold Stoma is holy power;

column1: brahmavarcasam evottarato dhatte tasmād uttaro 'rdho brahmavarcasitaraḥ sāvitravatī bhavati prasūtyai tasmād brāhmaṇānām udīcī saniḥ prasūtā dhartraś catuṣṭoma iti purastād upa dadhāti yajñamukhaṃ vai dhartraḥ |
column2: therefore the northern half is more resplendent. (The verse) contains a word connected with Savitr; (verily it serves) for instigation; therefore is their gain produced in the north for Brahmans. 'The support, the fourfold Stoma', (with these words) he puts down on the east;

column1: yajñamukhaṃ catuṣṭomas |
column2: the support is the beginning of the sacrifice [4], the fourfold Stoma is the beginning of the sacrifice;

column1: yajñamukham eva purastād vi yātayati yāvānām bhāgo 'sīti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: verily he establishes on the east the beginning of the sacrifice. 'Thou art the portion of the Yavas', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: māsā vai yāvā ardhamāsā ayāvās tasmād dakṣiṇāvṛto māsās |
column2: the Yavas' are the months, the Ayavas are the half-months; therefore the months turn to the south;

column1: annaṃ vai yāvās | annam prajās |
column2: the Yavas are food, offspring is food;

column1: annam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇenānnam adyate |
column2: verily he places food on the south; therefore with the right food is eaten.

column1: ṛbhūṇām bhāgo 'sīti paścāt pratiṣṭhityai vivarto 'ṣṭācatvāriṃśa ity uttaratas |
column2: 'Thou art the portion of the Rbhus', (with these words he puts down) on the west, for support. 'The revolving, the forty-eightfold', (with these words he puts down) on the north, to confer strength on these two worlds;

column1: anayor lokayoḥ savīryatvāya tasmād imau lokau samāvadvīryau |
column2: therefore these two worlds are of even strength [5].

column1: yasya mukhyavatīḥ purastād upadhīyante mukhya eva bhavati | āsya mukhyo jāyate yasyānnavatīr dakṣiṇato 'tty annam āsyānnādo jāyate yasya pratiṣṭhāvatīḥ paścāt praty eva tiṣṭhati yasyaujasvatīr uttarata ojasvy eva bhavati |
column2: He becomes first for whom these are placed on the east as the beginning (of the sacrifice), and his son is born to be first; he eats food for whom on the south these (are placed) rich in food, and a son is born to him to eat food; he finds support for whom these (are placed) on the west, full of support;

column1: āsyaujasvī jāyate |
column2: The fire is a hymn;

column1: arko vā eṣa yad agnis tasyaitad eva stotram etac chastram |
column2: I verily in that this arrangement [6] is made are its Stotra and Çastra produced;

column1: vidhīyate 'rka eva tad arkyam anu vi dhīyate |
column2: verily in the hymn the Arkya (Saman and Çastra) is produced;

column1: atty annam āsyānnādyo jāyate yasyaiṣā vidhā vidhīyate ya u cainām evaṃ veda sṛṣṭīr upa dadhāti yathāsṛṣṭam evāva runddhe na vā idaṃ divā na naktam āsīd avyāvṛttam |
column2: he eats food, and his son is born to eat food, for whom this arrangement is made, and he too who knows it thus. He puts down the creating (bricks); verily he wins things as created. Now there was neither day nor night in the world, but it was undiscriminated;

column1: te devā etā vyuṣṭīr apaśyan tā upādadhata tato vā idaṃ vy auchat |
column2: the gods saw these dawn (bricks), they put them down; then did this shine forth;

column1: yasyaitā upadhīyante vy evāsmā uchati |
column2: for him for whom these are put down the dawn breaks;

column1: atho tama evāpa hate |
column2: verily he smites away the dark.

column1: agne jātān pra ṇudā naḥ sapatnān iti purastād upa dadhāti jātān eva bhrātṛvyān pra ṇudate sahasā jātān iti paścāt |
column2: 'O Agni, drive away those foes of ours that are born', (with these words) he puts down on the east; verily he drives away his foes on birth. 'That are born with force', (with these words he puts down) on the west;

column1: janiṣyamāṇān eva prati nudate catuścatvāriṃśa stoma iti dakṣiṇatas |
column2: verily he repels those that are to be born. 'The forty-fourfold Stoma', (with these words he puts down) on the south;

column1: brahmavarcasaṃ vai catuścatvāriṃśas |
column2: the forty-fourfold is splendour;

column1: brahmavarcasam eva dakṣiṇato dhatte tasmād dakṣiṇo 'rdho brahmavarcasitaraḥ ṣoḍaśa stoma ity uttaratas |
column2: therefore the right side is the more resplendent. 'The sixteenfold Stoma', (with these words he puts down) on the north;

column1: ojo vai ṣoḍaśas |
column2: the sixteenfold is force;

column1: oja evottarato dhatte tasmāt |
column2: therefore [1] he that advances to the north is victorious.

column1: uttarato'bhiprayāyī jayati vajro vai catuścatvāriṃśo vajraḥ ṣoḍāśas |
column2: The forty-fourfold is a thunderbolt, the sixteenfold is a thunder bolt;

column1: yad ete iṣṭake upadadhāti jātāṃś caiva janiṣyamāṇāṃś ca bhrātṛvyān praṇudya vajram anu pra harati stṛtyai purīṣavatīm madhya upa dadhāti purīṣaṃ vai madhyam ātmanaḥ sātmānam evāgniṃ cinute sātmāmuṣmiM loke bhavati ya evaṃ veda |
column2: in that he puts down these two bricks, he hurls the bolt after the foe born and to be born whom he has repelled, to lay them low. He puts down in the middle (a brick) full of dust, the middle of the body is faeces (púrisa); verily he piles the fire with its own body, and with his own body he is in yonder world who knows thus.

column1: etā vā asapatnā nāmeṣṭakās |
column2: These bricks are called the unrivalled;

column1: nāsya sapatno bhavati paśur vā eṣa yad agnis |
column2: no rival is his for whom they are put down [2]. The fire is an animal;

column1: virāja uttamāyāṃ cityām upa dadhāti virājam evottamām paśuṣu dadhāti tasmāt paśumān uttamāṃ vācaṃ vadati daśadaśopa dadhāti savīryatvāya |
column2: he puts down the Viraj (bricks) in the highest layer; verily be confers upon cattle the highest Viraj; therefore he that is possessed of cattle speaks the highest speech. Ten by ten he puts (them) down, to confer power on them.

column1: akṣṇayopa dadhāti tasmād akṣṇayā paśavo 'ṅgāni pra haranti pratiṣṭhityai yāni vai chandāṃsi suvargyāṇy āsan tair devāḥ suvargaṃ lokam āyan tenarṣayaḥ |
column2: Transversely he puts (them) down; therefore cattle move their limbs transversely, for support. By those metres which were heavenly, the gods went to the world of heaven; for that the seers toiled [3];

column1: aśrāmyan te tapo 'tapyanta tāni tapasāpaśyan tebhya etā iṣṭakā nir {amimat|
column2: they practised fervour, these they saw by fervour, and from them they fashioned these bricks.

column1: < amimata} |evaś chando varivaś chanda iti tā upādadhata tābhir vai te suvargaṃ lokam āyan yad etā iṣṭakā upadadhāti yāny eva chandāṃsi suvargyāṇi tair eva yajamānaḥ suvargaṃ lokam eti yajñena vai prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata tā stomabhāgair evāsṛjata yat |
column2: 'The course metre; the space metre', (with these words) they put them down; with these they went to the world of heaven; in that he puts down these bricks, the sacrifice goes to the world of heaven with the metres that are heavenly. By the sacrifice Prajapati created creatures;

column1: stomabhāgā upadadhāti prajā eva tad yajamānaḥ sṛjate bṛhaspatir vā etad yajñasya tejaḥ sam abharad yad stomabhāgās |
column2: in that [4] he puts down the Stomabhagas, the sacrificer creates offspring. In the Stomabhagas Brhaspati collected the brilliance of the sacrifice;

column1: yat stomabhāgā upadadhāti satejasam evāgniṃ cinute bṛhaspatir vā etāṃ yajñasya pratiṣṭhām apaśyad yat stomabhāgās |
column2: in that he puts down the Stomabhaga (bricks) he piles the fire with its brilliance. 1n the Stomabhagas Brhaspati saw the support of the sacrifice;

column1: yat stomabhāgā upadadhāti yajñasya pratiṣṭhityai saptasaptopa dadhāti savīryatvāya tisro madhye pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: in that he puts down the Stomabhagas, (it is) for the support of the sacrifice. Seven by seven he puts down, to confer strength, three in the middle, for support.

column1: raśmir ity evādityam asṛjata pretir iti dharmam anvitir iti divam |
column2: (With the words) 'ray', he created Aditya; with 'advance', right; with 'following', the sky;

column1: saṃdhir ity antarikṣam pratidhir iti pṛthivīm |
column2: with 'union', the atmosphere; with 'propping', the earth;

column1: viṣṭambha iti vṛṣṭim pravety ahar anuveti rātrim uśig iti vasūn praketa iti rudrān |
column2: with 'prop', the rain; with blowing forward', the day; with 'blowing after', the night; with eager', the Vasus; with 'intelligence', the Rudras;

column1: sudītir ity ādityān oja iti pit ṝn |
column2: with 'brilliant', the Adityas; with 'force', the Pitrs;

column1: tantur iti prajāḥ pṛtanāṣāḍ iti paśūn revad ity oṣadhīs |
column2: with 'thread', offspring; with 'enduring the battle', cattle; with 'wealthy', plants.

column1: abhijid asi yuktagrāvā |
column2: 'Thou art the victorious, with ready stone [1];

column1: indrāya tvendraṃ jinvety eva dakṣiṇato vajram pary auhad abhijityai tāḥ prajā apaprāṇā asṛjata tāsv adhipatir asīty eva prāṇam adadhāt |
column2: for Indra thee Quicken Indra', (with these words) he fastened the thunderbolt on his right side, for victory. He created offspring without expiration; on them he bestowed expiration (with the words) 'Thou art the overlord';

column1: yantety apānam |
column2: inspiration (with the word) 'Restrainer';

column1: saṃsarpa iti cakṣus |
column2: the eye (with) 'the gliding';

column1: vayodhā iti śrotram |
column2: the ear (with) 'the bestower of strength'.

column1: tāḥ prajāḥ prāṇatīr apānatīḥ paśyantīḥ śṛṇvatīr na mithunī abhavan tāsu trivṛd asīty eva mithunam adadhāt tāḥ prajā mithunī |
column2: Now these offspring, though having expiration and inspiration, hearing and seeing, did not couple; upon them he bestowed copulation (with the words) 'Thou art the Trivrt'.

column1: bhavantīr na prājāyanta tāḥ saṃroho 'si nīroho 'sīty eva prājanayat tāḥ prajāḥ prajātā na praty atiṣṭhan tā vasuko 'si veṣaśrir asi vasyaṣṭir asīty evaiṣu lokeṣu praty asthāpayat | yad āha vasuko 'si veṣaśrir asi vasyaṣṭir asīti prajā eva prajātā eṣu lokeṣu prati ṣṭhāpayati sātmāntarikṣaṃ rohati saprāṇo 'muṣmiM loke prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: These offspring though coupling [2] were not propagated; he made them propagate (with the words) 'Thou art the mounter, thou art the descender'. These offspring being propagated did not find support; he made them find support in these worlds (with the words) 'Thou art the wealthy, thou art the brilliant, thou art the gainer of good', verily he makes offspring when propagated find support in these worlds, he with his body mounts the atmosphere, with his expiration he finds support in yonder world, of expiration and inspiration he is not liable to be deprived who knows thus.

column1: nākasadbhir vai devāḥ suvargaṃ lokam āyan tan nākasadāṃ nākasattvam |
column2: By the 'sitters on the vault' the gods went to the world of heaven;

column1: yan nākasada upadadhāti nākasadbhir eva tad yajamānaḥ suvargaṃ lokam eti suvargo vai loko nākas |
column2: In that he puts down the 'sitters on the vault', the sacrificer thus goes by the 'sitters on the vault' to the world of heaven; the vault is the world of heaven;

column1: yasyaitā upadhīyante nāsmā akam bhavati yajamānāyatanaṃ vai nākasadas |
column2: for him for whom these are put down there is no misfortune (ná-ákam);

column1: yan nākasada upadadhāty āyatanam eva tad yajamānaḥ kurute pṛṣṭhānāṃ vā etat tejaḥ sambhṛtaṃ yan nākasadas |
column2: the 'sitters on the vault' are the home of the sacrificer; in that he puts down the 'sitters on the vault', the sacrificer thus makes himself a home.

column1: upadadhāti pṛṣṭhānām eva tejo 'va runddhe pañcacoḍā upa dadhāti |
column2: in that he puts down the 'sitters on the vault' [1], verily he wins the brilliance of the Prsthas. He puts down the five crested;

column1: apsarasa evainam etā bhūtā amuṣmiM loka upa śere |
column2: verily becoming Apsarases they wait on him in yonder world;

column1: atho tanūpānīr evaitā yajamānasya yaṃ dviṣyāt tam upadadhad dhyāyet |
column2: verily also they are the bodyguards of the sacrificer. He should think of whomever he hates as he puts (them) down;

column1: etābhya evainaṃ devatābhya ā vṛścati tājag ārtim ārchati |
column2: verily he cuts him off for these deities; swiftly he goes to ruin.

column1: uttarā nākasadbhya upa dadhāti yathā jāyām ānīya gṛheṣu niṣādayati tādṛg eva tat |
column2: He puts (them) above the 'sitters on the vault'; that is as when having taken a wife one seats her in the house [2];

column1: paścāt prācīm uttamām upa dadhāti tasmāt paścāt prācī patny anv āste svayamātṛṇṇāṃ ca vikarṇīṃ cottame upa dadhāti prāṇo vai svayamātṛṇṇāyur vikarṇī prāṇaṃ caivāyuś ca prāṇānām uttamau dhatte tasmāt prāṇaś cāyuś ca prāṇānām uttamau nānyām uttarām iṣṭakām upa dadhyāt |
column2: he puts the highest on the west, pointing east; therefore the wife attends on the west, facing east. He puts as the highest the naturally perforated and the earless (bricks); the naturally perforated is breath, the earless is life; verily he places breath and life as the highest of the breaths;

column1: yad anyām uttarām iṣṭakām upadadhyāt paśūnām | ca yajamānasya ca prāṇaṃ cāyuś cāpi dadhyāt tasmān nānyottareṣṭakopadheyā svayamātṛṇṇām upa dadhāti |
column2: No brick higher (than these) should he put down; if he were to put another brick higher, he would obstruct the breath and life of cattle [3] and of the sacrificer; there fore no other brick should be put down higher.

column1: asau vai svayamātṛṇṇāmūm evopa dhatte |
column2: the naturally perforated brick is yonder (sky);

column1: aśvam upa ghrāpayati prāṇam evāsyāṃ dadhāti |
column2: verily he puts down yonder (sky). He makes the horse sniff it;

column1: atho prājāpatyo vā aśvaḥ prajāpatinaivāgniṃ cinute svayamātṛṇṇā bhavati prāṇānām utsṛṣṭyā atho suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai |
column2: again the horse is connected with Prajapati; verily by Prajapati he piles the fire. It is naturally perforated, to let out the breaths, and also to light up the world of heaven.

column1: eṣā vai devānāṃ vikrāntir yad vikarṇī yad vikarṇīm upadadhāti devānām eva vikrāntim anu vi kramate |
column2: The earless is the triumph of the gods; in that he puts down the earless, he triumphs with the triumph of the gods;

column1: uttarata upa dadhāti tasmād uttarataupacāro 'gnis |
column2: to the north he puts it down; therefore to the north of the fire is action carried on;

column1: vāyumatī bhavati samiddhyai |
column2: (the verse) has the word 'wind', for kindling.

column1: chandāṃsy upa dadhāti paśavo vai chandāṃsi paśūn evāva runddhe chandāṃsi vai devānāṃ vāmam paśavas |
column2: He puts down the metre bricks; the metres are cattle; verily he wins cattle; the good thing of the gods, cattle, are the metres;

column1: vāmam eva paśūn ava runddhe |
column2: verily he wins the good thing, cattle.

column1: etāṃ ha vai yajñasenaś caitriyāyaṇaś citiṃ vidāṃ cakāra tayā vai sa paśūn avārunddha yad etām upadadhāti paśūn evāva runddhe gāyatrīḥ purastād upa dadhāti tejo vai gāyatrī teja eva |
column2: Yajñasena Caitriyayana taught this layer; by this he won cattle; in that he puts it down, he wins cattle. He puts down the Gayatris on the east; the Gayatri is brilliance;

column1: mukhato dhatte mūrdhanvatīr bhavanti mūrdhānam evainaṃ samānānāṃ karoti triṣṭubha upa dadhāti |
column2: verily at the beginning he places brilliance [1]; they contain the word 'head'; verily he makes him the head of his equals. He puts down the Tristubhs;

column1: indriyaṃ vai {triṣṭug < triṣṭubh} indriyam eva madhyato dhatte jagatīr upa dadhāti jāgatā vai paśavaḥ paśūn evāva runddhe |
column2: the Tristubh is power; verily he places power in the middle He puts down the Jagatis; cattle are connected with the Jagati;

column1: anuṣṭubha upa dadhāti prāṇā vā {anuṣṭup < anuṣṭubh} prāṇānām utsṛṣṭyai bṛhatīr uṣṇihāḥ paṅktīr akṣarapaṅktīr iti viṣurūpāṇi chandāṃsy upa dadhāti viṣurūpā vai paśavaḥ paśavaḥ |
column2: verily he wins cattle. He puts down the Anustubhs; the Anustubh is breath; (verily it serves) to let the breaths out. Brhatis, Usnihs, Panktis, Aksarapanktis, these various metres he puts down;

column1: chandāṃsi viṣurūpān eva paśūn ava runddhe viṣurūpam asya gṛhe dṛśyate yasyaitā upadhīyante ya u cainā evaṃ veda |
column2: cattle are various, the metres are cattle [2]; verily he wins various cattle; variety is seen in his house for whom these are put down, and who knows them thus.

column1: atichandasam upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down an Atichandas;

column1: atichandā vai sarvāṇi chandāṃsi sarvebhir evainaṃ chandobhiś cinute varṣma vā eṣā chandasāṃ yad atichandās |
column2: all the metres are the Atichandas; verily he piles it with all the metres. The Atichandas is the highest of the metres;

column1: yat atichandasam upadadhāti varṣmaivainaṃ samānānāṃ karoti dvipadā upa dadhāti dvipād yajamānaḥ pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: in that he puts down an Atichandas, be makes him the highest of his equals. He puts down two-footed (bricks); the sacrificer has two feet; (verily they serve) for support.

column1: sarvābhyo vai devatābhyo 'gniś cīyate {F yat}{W yat} sayujo nopadadhyād devatā asyāgniṃ vṛñjīran yat sayuja upadadhāty ātmanaivainaṃ sayujaṃ cinute nāgninā vy ṛdhyate |
column2: For all the gods is the fire piled up; if he were not to put (them) down in unison, the gods would divert his fire; in that he puts (them) down in unison, verily he piles them in unison with himself; he is not deprived of his fire;

column1: atho yathā puruṣaḥ snāvabhiḥ saṃtata evam evaitābhir agniḥ saṃtatas |
column2: moreover, just as man is held together by his sinews, so is the fire held together by these (bricks).

column1: agninā vai devāḥ suvargaṃ lokam āyan tā amūḥ kṛttikā abhavan yasyaitā upadhīyante suvargam eva | lokam eti gachati prakāśaṃ citram eva bhavati maṇḍaleṣṭakā upa dadhāti |
column2: By the fire the gods went to the world of heaven; they became yonder Krttikas; he for whom these are put down goes to the world of heaven, attains brilliance, and becomes a resplendent thing. He puts down the circular bricks;

column1: ime vai lokā maṇḍaleṣṭakās | ime khalu vai lokā devapurās |
column2: the circular bricks are these worlds; the citadels of the gods are these worlds;

column1: devapurā eva pra viśati nārtim ārchaty agniṃ cikyānas |
column2: verily he enters the citadels of the gods; he is not ruined who has piled up the fire.

column1: viśvajyotiṣa upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the all-light (bricks);

column1: imān evaitābhir lokāñ jyotiṣmataḥ kurute |
column2: verily by them he makes these worlds full of light;

column1: atho prāṇān evaitā yajamānasya dādhrati |
column2: verily also they support the breaths of the sacrificer;

column1: etā vai devatāḥ suvargyās tā evānvārabhya suvargaṃ lokam eti |
column2: they are the deities of heaven; verily grasping them he goes to the world of heaven.

column1: vṛṣṭisanīr upa dadhāti vṛṣṭim evāva runddhe yad ekadhopadadhyād ekam ṛtuṃ varṣet |
column2: If he were to put (them) down in one place, it would rain for one season; he puts down after carrying them round in order;

column1: anuparihāraṃ sādayati tasmāt sarvān ṛtūn varṣati purovātasanir asīty āha |
column2: therefore it rains all the seasons. 'Thou art the bringer of the east wind', he says;

column1: etad vai vṛṣṭyai rūpam |
column2: that is the form of rain;

column1: rūpeṇaiva vṛṣṭim ava runddhe saṃyānībhir vai devā imāM lokānt sam ayus tat saṃyānīnāṃ saṃyānitvam |
column2: verily by its form he wins rain. With the Samyanis the gods went (sám ayus) to these worlds;

column1: yat saṃyānīr upadadhāti yathāpsu nāvā saṃyāty evam | evaitābhir yajamāna imāM lokānt saṃ yāti plavo vā eṣo 'gner yat saṃyānīs |
column2: that is why the Samyanis have their name; in that he puts down the Samyanis, just as one goes in the waters with a ship, so [1] the sacrificer with them goes to these worlds.

column1: yat saṃyānir upadadhāti plavam evaitam agnaya upa dadhāti | uta yasyaitāsūpahitāsv āpo 'gniṃ haranty ahṛta evāsyāgnis |
column2: in that he puts down the Samyanis, verily he puts down a boat for the fire; moreover, when these have been put down, if the waters strive to drag away his fire, verily it remains unmoved.

column1: ādityeṣṭakā upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the Aditya bricks;

column1: ādityā vā etam bhūtyai prati nudante yo 'lam bhūtyai san bhūtiṃ na prāpnoti |
column2: it is the Adityas who repel from prosperity him who being fit for prosperity does not obtain prosperity;

column1: ādityāḥ | evainam bhūtiṃ gamayanti |
column2: verily the Adityas [2] make him attain prosperity.

column1: asau vā etasyādityo rucam ā datte yo 'gniṃ citvā na rocate yad ādityeṣṭakā upadadhāy asāv evāsminn ādityo rucaṃ dadhāti yathāsau devānāṃ rocata evam evaiṣa manuṣyāṇāṃ rocate ghṛteṣṭakā upa dadhāti |
column2: It is yonder Aditya who takes away the brilliance of him who having piled up a fire does not display splendour; in that he puts down the Aditya bricks, yonder sun confers radiance upon him; just as yonder sun is radiant, so he is radiant among men. He puts down ghee bricks;

column1: etad vā agneḥ priyaṃ dhāma yad ghṛtam priyeṇaivainaṃ dhāmnā sam ardhayati | atho tejasā |
column2: the ghee is the home dear to Agni; verily he unites him with his dear home [3], and also with brilliance.

column1: anuparihāraṃ sādayati |
column2: He places (them) after carrying (them) round;

column1: aparivargam evāsmin tejo dadhāti prajāpatir agnim acinuta sa yaśasā vy ārdhyata sa etā yaśodā apaśyat tā upādhatta tābhir vai sa yaśa ātmann adhatta yad yaśodā upadadhāti yaśa eva tābhir yajamāna ātman dhatte pañcopa dadhāti pāṅktaḥ puruṣas |
column2: verily he confers upon him brilliance not to be removed. Prajapati piled up the fire, he lost his glory, he saw these bestowers of glory, he put them down; verily with them he conferred glory upon himself; five he puts down; man is fivefold;

column1: yāvān eva puruṣas tasmin yaśo dadhāti |
column2: verily he confers glory on the whole extent of man.

column1: devāsurāḥ saṃyattā āsan kanīyāṃso devā āsan bhūyāṃso 'surās te devā etā iṣṭakā apaśyan tā upādadhata bhūyaskṛd asīty eva bhūyāṃso 'bhavan vanaspatibhir oṣadhībhis |
column2: The gods and the Asuras were in conflict; the gods were the fewer, the Asuras the more; the gods saw these bricks, they put them down; 'Thou art the furtherer', (with these words) they became multiplied with the trees, the plants;

column1: varivaskṛd asītīmām ajayan prācy asīti prācīṃ diśam ajayan |
column2: (with) 'Thou art the eastern', they conquered the eastern quarter; (with) 'Thou art the zenith', they conquered yonder (sky);

column1: ūrdhvāsīty amūm ajayan |
column2: (with) 'Thou art the sitter on the atmosphere;

column1: antarikṣasad asy antarikṣe sīdety antarikṣam ajayan tato devā abhavan | parāsurās |
column2: sit on the atmosphere', they conquered the atmosphere; then the gods prospered [1], the Asuras were defeated.

column1: yasyaitā upadhīyante bhūyān eva bhavati | abhīmāM lokāñ jayati bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyo bhavati |
column2: He for whom those are put down becomes greater, conquers these worlds, and prospers himself; his foe is defeated.

column1: apsuṣad asi śyenasad asīty āha |
column2: thou art the sitter on the hawk', he says;

column1: etad vā agne rūpam |
column2: that is the form of Agni;

column1: rūpeṇaivāgnim ava runddhe pṛthivyās tvā draviṇe sādayāmīty āha |
column2: verily by his form he wins Agni. 'In the wealth of earth I place thee', he says;

column1: imān evaitābhir lokān draviṇāvataḥ kurute |
column2: verily with these (bricks) he makes these worlds wealthy.

column1: āyuṣyā upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the life-giving (bricks);

column1: āyur eva | asmin dadhāti |
column2: verily he bestows life upon him [2].

column1: agne yat te paraṃ hṛn nāmety āha |
column2: 'O Agni, thy highest name, the heart', he says;

column1: etad vā agneḥ priyaṃ dhāma priyam evāsya dhāmopāpnoti tāv ehi saṃ rabhāvahā ity āha vy evainena pari dhatte pāñcajanyeṣv apy edhy agna ity āha |
column2: that is the home dear to Agni; verily he obtains his dear home. 'Come, let us join together', he says; verily with him to aid he encircles him.

column1: eṣa vā agniḥ pāñcajanyo yaḥ pañcacitīkas tasmād evam āha |
column2: 'Be thou, O Agni, among those of the five races.' The fire of the five layers is the fire of the five races; therefore he speaks thus.

column1: ṛtvayā upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the seasonal (bricks);

column1: ṛtūnām eva priyaṃ dhāmāva runddhe sumeka ity āha saṃvatsaro vai sumekaḥ saṃvatsarasyaiva priyaṃ dhāmopāpnoti |
column2: the seasonal (bricks) are the abode dear to the seasons; verily he wins the abode dear to the seasons. 'The firm one', he says; the firm one is the year;

column1: prajāpater akṣy aśvayat tat parāpatat tad aśvo 'bhavat |
column2: The Horse Sacrifice (continued) The eye of Prajapati swelled, that fell away, that became a horse;

column1: yad aśvayat tad aśvasyāśvatvam |
column2: because it swelled (áçvayat), that is the reason why the horse (áçva) has its name.

column1: tad devā aśvamedhenaiva praty adadhus |
column2: By the horse sacrifice the gods replaced it.

column1: eṣa vai prajāpatiṃ sarvaṃ karoti yo 'śvamedhena yajate sarva eva bhavati sarvasya vā eṣā prāyaścittiḥ sarvasya bheṣajam |
column2: He who sacrifices with the horse sacrifice makes Prajapati whole; verily he becomes whole; this is the atonement for everything, and the cure for everything.

column1: sarvaṃ vā etena pāpmānaṃ devā ataran |
column2: All evil by it the gods overcame;

column1: api vā etena brahmahatyām ataran |
column2: by it also the gods overcame (the sins of) Brahman- slaying;

column1: sarvam pāpmānam | tarati tarati brahmahatyāṃ yo 'śvamedhena yajate ya u cainam evaṃ veda |
column2: all evil [1] he overcomes, he overcomes Brahman-slaying who sacrifices with the horse sacrifice, and he who knows it thus.

column1: uttaraṃ vai tat prajāpater akṣy aśvayat tasmād aśvasyottarato 'va dyanti dakṣiṇato 'nyeṣām paśūnām |
column2: It was the left eye of Prajapati that swelled; therefore they cut off from the horse on the left side, on the right from other animals.

column1: vaitasaḥ kaṭo bhavati |
column2: The mat is of reeds;

column1: apsujo vetasaḥ sva evainaṃ yonau prati ṣṭhāpayati catuṣṭoma stomo bhavati saraḍ ḍha vā aśvasya sakthy āvṛhat tad devāś catuṣṭomenaiva praty adadhus |
column2: the horse has its birthplace in the waters, the reed is born in the waters; verily he establishes it in its own birthplace. The Stoma is the fourfold one; the bee tore the thigh of the horse, the gods made it whole with the fourfold Stoma;

column1: yac catuṣṭoma stomo bhavaty aśvasya sarvatvāya |
column2: in that there is the fourfold Stoma, (it is) to make whole the horse.

column1: devāsurāḥ saṃyattā āsan te na vy ajayanta sa etā indras tanūr apaśyat tā upādhatta tābhir vai sa tanuvam indriyaṃ vīryam ātmann adhatta tato devā abhavan parāsurās |
column2: The Piling of the Fire Altar (continued) The gods and the Asuras were in conflict, they could not decide the issue; Indra saw these bodies, he put them down; with them he conferred upon himself power, strength, and body; then the gods prospered, the Asuras were defeated.

column1: yad indratanūr upadadhāti tanuvam eva tābhir indriyaṃ vīryaṃ yajamāna ātman dhatte |
column2: In that he puts down Indra's bodies, the sacrificer with them bestows on himself power, strength, and body;

column1: atho sendram evāgniṃ satanuṃ cinute bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyaḥ |
column2: verily also he piles up the fire with Indra and with a body; be prospers himself, his foe is [1] defeated.

column1: bhavati yajño devebhyo 'pākrāmat tam avarudhaṃ nāśaknuvan ta etā yajñatanūr apaśyan tā upādadhata tābhir vai te yajñam avārundhata yad yajñatanūr upadadhāti yajñam eva tābhir yajamāno 'va runddhe trayastriṃśatam upa dadhāti trayastriṃśad vai devatās |
column2: The sacrifice departed from the gods; they could not recover it; they saw these bodies of the sacrifice, they put them down, and by them they recovered the sacrifice. In that he puts down the bodies of the sacrifice, the sacrificer by them wins the sacrifice. Three and thirty he puts down;

column1: devatā evāva runddhe |
column2: verily he wins the gods;

column1: atho sātmānam evāgniṃ satanuṃ cinute sātmāmuṣmiM loke | bhavati ya evaṃ veda jyotiṣmatīr upa dadhāti jyotir evāsmin dadhāti |
column2: verily also he piles up the fire with itself and with a body; he becomes with his body in yonder world [2], who knows thus. He puts down the lighted (bricks); verily he confers light upon it;

column1: etābhir vā agniś cito jvalati tābhir evainaṃ sam inddhe |
column2: the fire blazes piled up with these (bricks); verily with them he kindles it;

column1: ubhayor asmai lokayor jyotir bhavati nakṣatreṣṭakā upa dadhāti |
column2: in both worlds is there light for him. He puts down the constellation bricks;

column1: etāni vai divo jyotīṃṣi tāny evāva runddhe sukṛtāṃ vā etāni jyotīṃṣi yan nakṣatrāṇi tāny evāpnoti |
column2: these are the lights of the sky; verily he wins them; the Naksatras are the lights of the doers of good deeds;

column1: atho anūkāśam evaitāni |
column2: verily he wins them;

column1: jyotīṃṣi kurute suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai yat saṃspṛṣṭā upadadhyād vṛṣṭyai lokam api dadhyād avarṣukaḥ parjanyaḥ syāt |
column2: verily also he makes these lights into a reflection [3] to light up the world of heaven. If he were to place them in contact, he would obstruct the world of rain, Parjanya would not rain;

column1: asaṃspṛṣṭā upa dadhāti vṛṣṭyā eva lokaṃ karoti varṣukaḥ parjanyo bhavati purastād anyāḥ pratīcīr upa dadhāti paścād anyāḥ prācīs tasmāt prācīnāni ca pratīcīnāni ca nakṣatrāṇy ā vartante |
column2: he puts them down without touching; verily he produces the world of rain, Parjanya is likely to rain; on the east he puts down some pointing west, on the west some pointing east; therefore the constellations move both west and east.

column1: ṛtavyā upa dadhāti | ṛtūnāṃ klptyai dvaṃdvam upa dadhāti tasmād dvaṃdvam ṛtavas |
column2: He puts down the seasonal (bricks), to arrange the seasons. He puts down a pair; therefore the seasons are in pairs.

column1: adhṛteva vā eṣā yan madhyamā citis |
column2: This middle layer is as it were unsupported;

column1: antarikṣam iva vā eṣā dvaṃdvam anyāsu citīṣūpa dadhāti catasro madhye dhṛtyai |
column2: it is as it were the atmosphere; he puts down a pair on the other layers, but four in the middle one, for support.

column1: antaḥśleṣaṇaṃ vā etāś citīnāṃ yad ṛtavyās | yad ṛtavyā upadadhāti citīnāṃ vidhṛtyai |
column2: The seasonal (bricks) are the internal cement of the layers; in that he puts down the seasonal (bricks), (it is) to keep apart the layers.

column1: avakām anūpa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down next an Avaka plant;

column1: eṣā vā agner yoniḥ sayonim | evāgniṃ cinute |
column2: this is the birthplace of Agni; verily he piles up the fire with its birthplace [1].

column1: uvāca ha viśvāmitras | adad it sa brahmaṇānnaṃ yasyaitā upadhīyāntai ya u cainā evaṃ vedad iti saṃvatsaro vā etam pratiṣṭhāyai nudate yo 'gniṃ citvā na pratitiṣṭhati pañca pūrvāś citayo bhavanty atha ṣaṣṭhīṃ citiṃ cinute ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ saṃvatsaras |
column2: Viçvamitra says, 'He shall eat food with holy power, for whom these shall be put down, and he who shall know them thus'. It is the year which repels from support him who having piled up the fire does not find support; there are five layers preceding, and then he piles up the sixth; the year has six seasons;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva saṃvatsare prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: verily in the seasons the year finds support.

column1: etā vai | adhipatnīr nāmeṣṭakās |
column2: These are the bricks [2], called the over-ladies;

column1: yasyaitā upadhīyante 'dhipatir eva samānānām bhavati yaṃ dviṣyāt tam upadadhad dhyāyet |
column2: he for whom they are put down becomes the overlord of his equals; he should think of him whom he hates as he puts (them down);

column1: etābhya evainaṃ devatābhya ā vṛścati ārtim ārchati |
column2: verily he cuts him off for those deities;

column1: aṅgirasaḥ suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanto yā yajñasya niṣkṛtir āsīt tām ṛṣibhyaḥ praty auhan tad dhiraṇyam abhavat |
column2: swiftly he goes to ruin. The Angirases, going to the world of heaven, made over to the seers the accomplishment of the sacrifice; it became gold;

column1: yad dhiraṇyaśalkaiḥ prokṣati yajñasya niṣkṛtyai |
column2: in that he anoints with fragments of gold, (it is) for the completion of the sacrifice;

column1: atho bheṣajam evāsmai karoti |
column2: verily also he makes healing for it [3];

column1: atho rūpeṇaivainaṃ sam ardhayati | atho hiraṇyajyotiṣaiva suvargaṃ lokam eti sāhasravatā prokṣati sāhasraḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpater āptyai |
column2: moreover he unites it with its form, and with golden light he goes to the world of heaven. He anoints with that which contains the word 'of a thousand'; Prajapati is of a thousand; (verily it serves) to win Prajapati.

column1: imā me agna iṣṭakā dhenavaḥ santv ity āha |
column2: 'May these bricks, O Agni, be for me milch cows', he says;

column1: dhenūr evaināḥ kurute tā enaṃ kāmadughā amutrāmuṣmiM loka upa tiṣṭhante |
column2: verily he makes them milch cows; they, milking desires, wait upon him yonder in yonder world.

column1: rudro vā eṣa yad agniḥ sa etarhi jāto yarhi sarvaś citaḥ sa yathā vatso jāta stanam prepsaty evaṃ vā eṣa etarhi bhāgadheyam prepsati tasmai yad āhutiṃ na juhuyād adhvaryuṃ ca yajamānaṃ ca dhyāyet |
column2: The fire is Rudra; he is born then when he is completely piled up; just as a calf on birth desires the teat, so he here seeks his portion; if he were not to offer a libation to him, he would suck the Adhvaryu and the sacrificer.

column1: śatarudrīyaṃ juhoti bhāgadheyenaivainaṃ śamayati nārtim ārchaty adhvaryur na yajamānas |
column2: He offers the Çatarudriya (oblation); verily he appeases him with his own portion; neither Adhvaryu nor sacrificer goes to ruin.

column1: yad grāmyāṇām paśūnām | payasā juhuyād grāmyān paśūñ chucārpayet |
column2: If he were to offer with the milk of domesticated animals [1], he would afflict domestic animals with pain;

column1: yad āraṇyānām āraṇyān |
column2: if (with that) of wild (animals), wild (animals);

column1: jartilayavāgvā vā juhuyād gavīdhukayavāgvā vā na grāmyān paśūn hinasti nāraṇyān atho khalv āhus | anāhutir vai jartilāś ca gavīdhukāś ceti |
column2: he should offer with groats of wild sesame or with groats of Gavidhuka grass; he harms neither domesticated nor wild animals. Then they say, 'Wild sesame and Gavidhuka grass are not a proper offering';

column1: ajakṣīreṇa juhoti | āgneyī vā eṣā yad ajā |
column2: he offers with goat's milk, the female goat is connected with Agni;

column1: āhutyaiva juhoti na grāmyān paśūn hinasti nāraṇyān aṅgirasaḥ suvargaṃ lokaṃ yantaḥ |
column2: he harms neither domesticated nor wild animals. The Angirases going to the world of heaven [2] spilled the cauldron on the goat;

column1: ajāyāṃ gharmam prāsiñcan | sā śocantī parṇam parājihīta so 'rko 'bhavat tad arkasyārkatvam arkaparṇena juhoti sayonitvāya |
column2: she in pain dropped a feather (like hair), it became the Arka (plant); that is why the Arka has its name. He offers with a leaf of the Arka, to unite it with its birthplace.

column1: udaṅ tiṣṭhañ juhoti |
column2: He offers standing facing north;

column1: eṣā vai rudrasya {dik < diś} svāyām eva diśi rudraṃ niravadayate caramāyām iṣṭakāyāṃ juhoti |
column2: this is the quarter of Rudra; verily he propitiates him in his own quarter. He offers on the last brick;

column1: antata eva rudraṃ niravadayate tredhāvibhaktaṃ juhoti traya ime lokās |
column2: verily at the end he propitiates Rudra. He offers dividing it into three; these worlds are three;

column1: imān eva lokānt samāvadvīryān karoti |
column2: verily he makes these worlds of even strength;

column1: iyaty agre juhoti |
column2: at this height he offers [3], then at this, then at this;

column1: atheyaty atheyati traya ime lokās |
column2: these worlds are three;

column1: ebhya evainaṃ lokebhyaḥ śamayati tisra uttarā āhutīr juhoti ṣaṭ sam padyante ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: verily he appeases him for these worlds. Three further libations he offers; they make up six, the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtubhir evainaṃ śamayati yad anuparikrāmaṃ juhuyād antaravacāriṇaṃ rudraṃ kuryāt |
column2: verily with the seasons he appeases him. If he were to offer while wandering round, he would make Rudra come within (the sacrifice).

column1: atho khalv āhuḥ kasyāṃ vāha diśi rudraḥ kasyāṃ veti |
column2: Or rather they say, 'In what quarter is Rudra or in what?' He should offer them while wandering round;

column1: anuparikrāmam eva hotavyam aparivargam evainaṃ śamayati |
column2: verily he appeases him completely [4].

column1: etā vai devatāḥ suvargyā yā uttamās tā yajamānaṃ vācayati tābhir evainaṃ suvargaṃ lokaṃ gamayati yaṃ dviṣyāt tasya saṃcare paśūnāṃ ny asyet |
column2: The highest (bricks) are the heavenly deities; over them he makes the sacrificer speak; verily by them he makes him attain the world of heaven; he should throw (the leaf) down in the path of the cattle of him whom he hates;

column1: yaḥ prathamaḥ paśur abhitiṣṭhati sa ārtim ārchati |
column2: the first beast that steps upon it goes to ruin.

column1: aśmann ūrjam iti pari ṣiñcati mārjayaty evainam atho tarpayaty eva sa enaṃ tṛpto 'kṣudhyann aśocann amuṣmiM loka upa tiṣṭhate tṛpyati prajayā paśubhir ya evaṃ veda tāṃ na iṣam ūrjaṃ dhatta marutaḥ saṃrarāṇā ity āha |
column2: 'The strength on the stone', (with these words) he moistens (the fire), and so purifies it; verily also he delights it; it delighted attends him, causing him neither hunger nor pain in yonder world; he rejoices in offspring, in cattle who knows thus. 'That food and strength, do ye, O Maruts, bounteously bestow on us', he says;

column1: annaṃ vā ūrj | annam marutas |
column2: strength is food, the Maruts are food;

column1: annam evāva runddhe |
column2: verily he wins food.

column1: aśmaṃs te kṣudh |
column2: 'In the stone is thy hunger;

column1: amuṃ te śuk |
column2: let thy pain reach N.N.

column1: ṛchatu yaṃ dviṣma ity āha yam eva dveṣṭi tam asya kṣudhā ca śucā cārpayati triḥ pariṣiñcan pary eti trivṛd vā agnis |
column2: [1], whom we hate', he says; verily he afflicts him whom he hates with its hunger and pain. He goes round thrice, moistening; the fire is threefold;

column1: yāvān evāgnis tasya śucaṃ śamayati triḥ punaḥ pary eti ṣaṭ sam padyante ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: verily he calms the pain of the whole extent of the fire. Thrice again he goes round; they make up six, the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtubhir evāsya śucaṃ śamayati |
column2: verily with the seasons he calms its pain.

column1: apāṃ vā etat puṣpaṃ yad vetasas | apām |
column2: The reed is the flower of the waters, the Avaka is the cream of the waters [2];

column1: vetasaśākhayā cāvakābhiś ca vi karṣati |
column2: he draws over (it) with a branch of reeds and with Avaka plants;

column1: āpo vai śāntāḥ śāntābhir evāsya śucaṃ śamayati yo vā agniṃ citam prathamaḥ paśur adhikrāmatīśvaro vai taṃ śucā pradahas |
column2: the waters are appeased; verily with them appeased he calms his pain. The beast that first steps over the fire when piled, it is liable to burn it up with its heat.

column1: maṇḍūkena vi karṣati |
column2: He draws over (it) with a frog;

column1: eṣa vai paśūnām anupajīvanīyas | na vā eṣa grāmyeṣu paśuṣu hito nāraṇyeṣu tam eva śucārpayati |
column2: this of animals is the one on which one does not subsist, for neither among the domesticated nor the wild beasts has it a place;

column1: aṣṭābhir vi karṣati |
column2: With eight (verses) he draws across [3];

column1: aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatro 'gnis |
column2: the Gayatri has eight syllables, the fire is connected with the Gayatri;

column1: yāvān evāgnir tasya śucaṃ śamayati pāvakavatībhis |
column2: verily he calms the pain of the whole extent of the fire.

column1: annenaivāsya śucaṃ śamayati mṛtyur vā eṣa yad agnis |
column2: verily by food he calms its pain. The fire is death;

column1: brahmaṇa etad rūpaṃ yat kṛṣṇājinam |
column2: the black antelope skin is the form of holy power;

column1: kārṣṇī upānahāv upa muñcate brahmaṇaiva mṛtyor antar dhatte antar mṛtyor dhatte | antar annādyād ity āhus |
column2: verily by the holy power he shuts himself away from death. 'He shuts himself away from death, and away from eating food', they say;

column1: anyām upamuñcate 'nyāṃ nāntaḥ |
column2: one he puts on, the other not;

column1: eva mṛtyor dhatte vānnādyaṃ runddhe namas te harase śociṣa ity āha namaskṛtya hi vasīyāṃsam upacaranti |
column2: verily he shuts himself away [4] from death and wins the eating of food. 'Honour to thy heat, thy blaze', he says, for paying honour they wait on a richer man;

column1: anyaṃ te asmat tapantu hetaya ity āha yam eva dveṣṭi tam asya śucārpayati pāvako asmabhyaṃ śivo bhavety āha |
column2: 'may thy bolts afflict another than us', he says; verily him whom he hates he afflicts with its pain; 'be thou purifying and auspicious to us', he says;

column1: annaṃ vai pāvakas |
column2: the purifying (one) is food;

column1: annam evāva runddhe dvābhyām adhi krāmati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: verily he wins food. With two (verses) he strides over (it), for support;

column1: apasyavatībhyāṃ śāntyai |
column2: (with two) containing (the word) 'water', for soothing.

column1: nṛṣade vaḍ iti vyāghārayati paṅktyāhutyā yajñamukham ā rabhate |
column2: 'To him that sits in man hail!' (with these words) he pours butter on; verily with the Pankti and the offering he takes hold of the beginning of the sacrifice.

column1: akṣṇayā vyāghārayati tasmād akṣṇayā paśavo 'ṅgāni pra haranti pratiṣṭhityai yad vaṣaṭkuryād yātayāmāsya vaṣaṭkāraḥ syāt |
column2: He pours on butter transversely; therefore animals move their limbs transversely, for support. If he were to utter the Vasat cry, his Vasat cry would be exhausted;

column1: yan na vaṣaṭkuryād rakṣāṃsi yajñaṃ hanyus |
column2: if he were not to utter the Vasat cry, the Raksases would destroy the sacrifice;

column1: vaḍ ity āha paro'kṣam eva vaṣaṭ karoti nāsya yātayāmā vaṣaṭkāro bhavati na yajñaṃ rakṣāṃsi ghnanti hutādo vā anye devāḥ |
column2: verily, mysteriously he utters the Vasat cry; his Vasat, cry is not exhausted, the Raksases do not destroy the sacrifice. Some of the gods eat the offerings [1], others do not;

column1: ahutādo 'nye tān agnicid evobhayān prīṇāti ye devā devānām iti dadhnā madhumiśreṇāvokṣati hutādaś caiva devān ahutādaś ca yajamānaḥ prīṇāti te yajamānam prīṇanti dadhnaiva hutādaḥ prīṇāti madhuṣāhutādas |
column2: 'Those gods among gods', (with these words) he anoints (it) with curds mixed with honey; verily the sacrificer delights the gods who eat and those who do not eat the offerings; they delight the sacrificer. He delights those who eat the offerings with curds, and those who do not with honey;

column1: grāmyaṃ vā etad annaṃ yad dadhy āraṇyam madhu yad dadhnā madhumiśreṇāvokṣaty ubhayasyāvaruddhyai grumuṣṭināvokṣati prājāpatyaḥ |
column2: curds is a food of the village, honey of the wild; in that he anoints with curds mixed with honey, (it serves) to win both. He anoints with a large handful (of grass);

column1: vai grumuṣṭiḥ sayonitvāya dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: (verily it serves) to unite it with its birthplace; with two (verses) he anoints, for support.

column1: anuparicāram avokṣati |
column2: He anoints going round in order;

column1: aparivargam evainān prīṇāti vi vā eṣa prāṇaiḥ prajayā paśubhir ṛdhyate yo 'gniṃ cinvann adhikrāmati prāṇadā apānadā ity āha prāṇān evātman dhatte varcodā varivodā ity āha prajā vai varcaḥ paśavo varivaḥ prajām eva paśūn ātman dhatte |
column2: verily he delights them completely. Now he is deprived of the breaths, of offspring, of cattle who piling the fire steps upon it. 'Giver of expiration art thou, of inspiration', he says; verily he bestows on himself the breaths; 'giver of splendour, giver of wide room', he says;

column1: indro vṛtram ahan taṃ vṛtraḥ |
column2: splendour is offspring; wide room is cattle;

column1: hataḥ ṣoḍaśabhir bhogair asināt sa etām agnaye 'nīkavata āhutim apaśyat tām ajuhot tasyāgnir anīkavānt svena bhāgadheyena prītaḥ ṣoḍaśadhā vṛtrasya bhogān apy adahat |
column2: Indra slew Vrtra; him Vrtra [3] slain grasped with sixteen coils; he saw this libation to Agni of the front; he offered it, and Agni of the front, being delighted with his own portion, burnt in sixteen places the coils of Vrtra;

column1: vaiśvakarmaṇena pāpmano nir amucyata yad agnaye 'nīkavata āhutiṃ juhoty agnir evāsyānīkavānt svena bhāgadheyena prītaḥ pāpmānam api dahati vaiśvadarmaṇena pāpmano nir mucyate yaṃ kāmayeta ciram pāpmanaḥ |
column2: in that he offers a libation to Agni of the front, Agni of the front, delighted with his own portion, burns away his evil, and he is set free from his evil by the offering to Viçvakarman. If he desire of a man, 'May he be set free slowly from evil' [4], he should offer one by one for him;

column1: nir mucyetety ekaikaṃ tasya juhuyāt |
column2: verily, slowly he is set free from evil;

column1: ciram eva pāpmano nir mucyate yaṃ kāmayeta tājak pāpmano nir mucyeteti sarvāṇi tasyānudrutya juhyāt tājag eva pāpmano nir mucyate |
column2: if he desire of a man, 'Swiftly may he be set free from evil', he should run over all of them for him and make one offering; swiftly is he set free from evil.

column1: atho khalu nānaiva sūktābhyāṃ juhoti nānaiva sūktayor vīryaṃ dadhāti |
column2: Or rather he sacrifices separately with each hymn; verily severally he places strength in the two hymns;

column1: atho pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: (verily they serve) for support.

column1: ud enam uttarāṃ nayeti samidha ā dadhāti yathā janaṃ yate 'vasaṃ karoti tādṛg eva tat tisra ā dadhāti trivṛd vā agnis |
column2: 'Do thou lead him forward', (with these words) he puts on the kindling-sticks; that is as when one provides hospitality for one who has come on a visit. He puts down three; the fire is threefold;

column1: yāvān evāgnis tasmai bhāgadheyaṃ karoti |
column2: verily he provides his portion for the whole extent of the fire.

column1: audumbarīr bhavanti | ūrg vā udumbaras |
column2: They are of Udumbara wood, the Udumbara is strength;

column1: ūrjam evāsmā api dadhāti |
column2: verily he gives him strength.

column1: ud u tvā viśve devā ity āha prāṇā vai viśve devāḥ prāṇaiḥ |
column2: 'May the All-gods thee', he says; the All-gods are the breaths;

column1: evainam ud yachate |
column2: verily with the breaths [1] he raises him up;

column1: agne bharantu cittibhir ity āha yasmā evainaṃ cittāyodyachate tenaivainaṃ sam ardhayati pañca diśo daivīr yajñam avantu devīr ity āha diśo hy eṣo 'nu pracyavate |
column2: I bear up with their thoughts, O Agni', he says; verily he unites him with the thought for which he lifts him up. 'May the five regions divine aid the sacrifice, the goddesses', he says, for he moves forward along the quarters.

column1: apāmatiṃ durmatim bādhamānā ity āha rakṣasām apahatyai rāyas poṣe yajñapatim ābhajantīr ity āha paśavo vai rāyas poṣaḥ |
column2: 'Driving away poverty and hostility', he says, for smiting away the Raksases. 'Giving to the lord of the sacrifice increase of wealth,' he says; increase of wealth is cattle [2];

column1: paśūn evāva runddhe ṣaḍbhir harati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: verily he wins cattle. He takes (him) with six (verses); the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtubhir evainaṃ harati dve parigṛhyavatī bhavato rakṣasām apahatyai sūryaraśmir harikeśaḥ purastād ity āha prasūtyai tataḥ pāvakā āśiṣo no juṣantām ity āha |
column2: verily with the seasons he takes him; two have (the word) 'embracing', for the smiting away of the Raksases. 'With the rays of the sun, with tawny hair, before us', he says, for instigation. 'Then let our pure invocations be accepted', he says;

column1: annaṃ vai pāvakas |
column2: verily he wins food.

column1: annam evāva runddhe devāsurāḥ saṃyattā āsan te devā etad apratiratham apaśyan tenaiva te 'prati |
column2: The gods and the Asuras were in conflict; the gods saw the unassailable (hymn) and with it they conquered the Asuras [3];

column1: asurān ajayan tad apratirathasyāpratirathatvam |
column2: that is why the unassailable (hymn) has its name.

column1: yad apratirathaṃ dvitīyo hotānvāhāpraty eva tena yajamāno bhrātṛvyāñ jayati |
column2: In that the second Hotr recites the unassailable (hymn) the sacrificer conquers his foes therewith unassailably;

column1: atho anabhijitam evābhi jayati daśarcam bhavati daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} virājemau lokau vidhṛtau |
column2: verily also he conquers what has not been conquered. (The hymn) has ten verses; the Viraj has ten syllables, by the Viraj are kept apart these two worlds;

column1: anayor lokayor vidhṛtyai |
column2: (verily it serves) to keep apart these two worlds.

column1: atho daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājy evānnādye prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: Again the Viraj has ten syllables, the Viraj is food; verily he finds support in the Viraj, in eating food.

column1: asad iva vā antarikṣam antarikṣam ivāgnīdhram āgnīdhre |
column2: The atmosphere is as it were unreal; the Agnidh's altar is as it were the atmosphere;

column1: aśmānaṃ ni dadhāti sattvāya dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityai vimāna eṣa divo madhya āsta ity āha vy evaitayā mimīte madhye divo nihitaḥ pṛśnir aśmety āha |
column2: with two (verses), for support. 'As measurer, he standeth in the midst of the sky', he says; verily with this he measures; 'in the middle of the sky is the dappled stone set down', he says; the dappled is food;

column1: annaṃ vai pṛśni |
column2: verily he wins food.

column1: annam evāva runddhe catasṛbhir ā puchād eti catvāri chandāṃsi chandobhir eva |
column2: With four (verses) he goes up to the tail; the metres are four; verily (he goes) with the metres.

column1: indraṃ viśvā avīvṛdhann ity āha vṛddhim evopāvartate vājānāṃ satpatim patim |
column2: 'All have caused Indra to wax', he says; verily he attains increase. 'True lord and lord of strength' [5], he says;

column1: annaṃ vai vājas |
column2: verily he wins food.

column1: annam evāva runddhe sumnahūr yajño devāṃ ā ca vakṣad ity āha prajā vai paśavaḥ sumnam prajām eva paśūn ātman dhatte yakṣad agnir devo devāṃ ā ca vakṣad ity āha svagākṛtyai vājasya mā prasavenodgrābheṇod agrabhīd ity āha |
column2: 'Let the sacrifice invoke favour, and bring the gods', he says; favour is offspring and cattle; verily be bestows on himself offspring and cattle. 'Let the god, Agni, offer and bring to us the gods', he says, to make the cry, Godspeed! 'He hath seized me with the impulse of strength, with 'elevation', he says;

column1: asau vā āditya udyann udgrābha eṣa nimrocan nigrābhas |
column2: elevation is yonder sun in rising; depression is it when setting;

column1: brahmaṇaivātmānam udgṛhṇāti brahmaṇā bhrātṛvyaṃ ni gṛhṇāti |
column2: verily with holy power he elevates himself, with holy power he depresses his foe.

column1: prācīm anu pradiśam prehi vidvān ity āha devalokam evaitayopāvartate kramadhvam agninā nākam ity āha |
column2: 'Along the eastern quarter do thou advance, wise one', he says; verily with this (verse) he moves to the world of heaven. 'Mount ye, with Agni, to the vault', he says;

column1: imān evaitayā lokān kramate pṛthivyā aham ud antarikṣam āruham ity āha |
column2: verily with this he mounts these worlds. 'From earth have I mounted to the atmosphere,' he says;

column1: imān evaitayā lokānt samārohati suvar yanto nāpekṣanta ity āha suvargam evaitayā lokam eti |
column2: verily with it he mounts these worlds. 'Going to the heaven they look not away', he says; verily he goes to the world of heaven.

column1: agne prehi | prathamo devayatām ity āha |
column2: 'O Agni, advance [1] first of worshippers', he says;

column1: ubhayeṣv evaitayā devamanuṣyeṣu cakṣur dadhāti pañcabhir adhi krāmati pāṅkto yajñas |
column2: verily with it he bestows eyesight upon both gods and men. He steps upon (the altar) with five (verses); the sacrifice is fivefold;

column1: yāvān eva yajñas tena saha suvargaṃ lokam eti naktoṣāseti puro'nuvākyām anv āha prattyai |
column2: verily he goes to the world of heaven with the full extent of the sacrifice. 'Night and dawn', he recites as the Puronuvakya, for preparation.

column1: agne sahasrākṣety āha sāhasraḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpater āptyai tasmai te vidhema vājāya svāhety āha |
column2: O Agni, of a thousand eyes', he says; Prajapati is of a thousand; (verily it serves) to obtain Prajapati. 'To thee as such let us pay honour;

column1: annaṃ vai vājas |
column2: to strength hail!' he says;

column1: annam evāva |
column2: verily he wins food [2].

column1: runddhe dadhnaḥ pūrṇām audumbarīṃ svayamātṛṇṇāyāṃ juhoti |
column2: He offers on the naturally perforated brick (a ladle) of Udumbara wood filled with curds;

column1: ūrg udumbaras | asau svayamātṛṇṇā |
column2: curds are strength, the Udumbara is strength, the naturally perforated is yonder (sky);

column1: amuṣyām evorjaṃ dadhāti tasmād amuto 'rvācīm ūrjam upa jīvāmas tisṛbhiḥ sādayati trivṛd vā agnis |
column2: therefore we live on strength coming hitherward from yonder. He puts (it) in place with three (verses); the fire is threefold;

column1: yāvān evāgnis tam pratiṣṭhāṃ gamayati preddho agne dīdihi puro na ity audumbarīm ā dadhāti |
column2: verily be makes the whole extent of the fire attain support. 'Enkindled, O Agni, shine before us', (with these words) he takes (the kindling-stick) of Udumbara wood;

column1: eṣa vai sūrmī karṇakāvatī |
column2: this is a pipe with projections;

column1: etayā ha sma | vai devā asurāṇāṃ śatatarhāṃs tṛṃhanti yad etayā samidham ādadhāti vajram evaitac chataghnīṃ yajamāno bhrātṛvyāya pra harati stṛtyai |
column2: by it [3] the gods made piercings of hundreds of the Asuras; in that he takes up the kindling-stick with this (verse), the sacrificer hurls the hundred-slaying (verse) as a bolt at his enemy, to lay him low without fail.

column1: vidhema te parame janmann agna iti vaikaṅkatīm ā dadhāti bhā evāva runddhe tāṃ savitur vareṇyasya citrām iti śamīmayīṃ śāntyai |
column2: 'Let us pay homage to thee in thy highest birth, O Agni ', (with these words) he takes up (the kindling-stick) of Vikankata wood; verily he wins radiance.

column1: agnir vā ha vā agnicitaṃ duhe 'gnicid vāgniṃ duhe tām |
column2: The fire milks the piler-up of the fire; the piler-up, milks the fire;

column1: savitur vareṇyasya citrām ity āha |
column2: 'that [4] various of Savitr, the adorable', he says;

column1: eṣa vā agner dohas tam asya kaṇva eva śrāyaso 'vet tena ha samainaṃ sa duhe yad etayā samidham ādadhāty agnicid eva tad agniṃ duhe sapta te agne samidhaḥ sapta jihvā ity āha saptaivāsya sāptāni prīṇāti pūrṇayā juhoti pūrṇa iva hi prajāpatiḥ prajāpateḥ |
column2: This of it Kanva Çrayasa knew, and with it he was wont to milk it; in that be takes up the kindling-stick with the verse, the piler-up of the fire milks the fire. 'Seven are thy kindling-sticks, O Agni, seven tongues'; verily he delights seven sevens of his. With a full (ladle) he offers, for Prajapati is as it were full, to obtain Prajapati [5].

column1: āptyai nyūnayā juhoti nyūnād dhi prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata prajānāṃ sṛṣṭyai |
column2: He offers with a half-filled (ladle), for from the half-filled Prajapati created creatures, for the creation of offspring.

column1: agnir devebhyo nilāyata sa diśo 'nu prāviśat |
column2: Agni departed from the gods; he entered the quarters;

column1: juhvan manasā diśo dhyāyet |
column2: he who sacrifices should think in his mind of the quarters;

column1: digbhya evainam ava runddhe dadhnā purastāj juhoty ājyenopariṣṭāt tejaś caivāsmā indriyaṃ ca samīcī dadhāti dvādaśakapālo vaiśvānaro bhavati dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro 'gnir vaiśvānaraḥ sākṣāt |
column2: verily from the quarters he wins him; with curds he offers at first, with butter afterwards; verily he bestows upon him brilliance and power in accord. There is (an offering) to Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds; the year has twelve months, Agni Vaiçvanara is the year;

column1: eva vaiśvānaram ava runddhe yat prayājānūyājān kuryād vikastiḥ sā yajñasya darvihomaṃ karoti yajñasya pratiṣṭhityai rāṣṭraṃ vai vaiśvānaro viṇ marutas |
column2: he offers an oblation with a ladle, for the support of the sacrifice. Vaiçvanara is the kingly power, the Maruts the people; having offered the offering to Vaiçvanara, he offers those to the Maruts;

column1: vaiśvānaraṃ hutvā mārutāñ juhoti rāṣṭra eva viśam anu badhnāti |
column2: He utters aloud (the direction to the Agnidh) for Vaiçvanara, he offers the offerings of the Maruts muttering;

column1: uccair vaiśvānarasyā śrāvayaty upāṃśu mārutāñ juhoti tasmād rāṣṭraṃ viśam ati vadati mārutā bhavanti maruto vai devānāṃ viśas |
column2: therefore the kingly power speaks above the people. (The offerings) are for the Maruts; the people of the gods are the Maruts;

column1: devaviśenaivāsmai manuṣya viśam ava runddhe sapta bhavanti saptagaṇā vai marutas |
column2: verily he wins for him by the people of the gods the people among men. There are seven; the Maruts are in seven troops;

column1: gaṇaśa eva viśam ava runddhe gaṇena gaṇam anudrutya juhoti viśam evāsmā anu vartmānaṃ karoti |
column2: verily in troops he wins the people for him; running over troop by troop he offers; verily he makes the people obedient to him.

column1: vasor dhārāṃ juhoti vasor me dhārāsad iti vā eṣā hūyate ghṛtasya vā enam eṣā dhārāmuṣmiM loke pinvamānopa tiṣṭhate |
column2: 'May a stream of wealth be mine', (with this hope) is the offering made; this stream of ghee waits upon him in yonder world, swelling up. He offers with butter;

column1: ājyena juhoti tejo vā ājyaṃ tejo vasor dhārā tejasaivāsmai tejo 'va runddhe |
column2: butter is brilliance, the stream of wealth is brilliance; verily by brilliance he wins brilliance for him.

column1: atho kāmā vai vasor dhārā kāmān evāva runddhe yaṃ kāmayeta prāṇān asyānnādyaṃ vi |
column2: Again the stream of wealth is desires; verily he wins desires. If he desire of a man, 'May I separate his breaths and his eating of food' [1], he should offer separately for him;

column1: chindyām iti vigrāhaṃ tasya juhuyāt prāṇān evāsyānnādyaṃ vi chinatti yaṃ kāmayeta prāṇān asyānnādyaṃ saṃ tanuyām iti saṃtatāṃ tasya juhuyāt prāṇān evāsyānnādyaṃ saṃ tanoti dvādaśa dvādaśāni juhoti dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsareṇaivāsmā annam ava runddhe |
column2: if he desire of a man, 'May I continue his breaths and his eating of food', he should offer for him in a continuous stream; verily he continues his breaths and his eating of food. Twelve sets of twelve he offers; the year has twelve months; verily by the year he wins food for him.

column1: annaṃ ca me 'kṣuc ca ma ity āha |
column2: 'May for me food, for me freedom from hunger', he says;

column1: etad vai | annasya rūpam |
column2: that [2] is the form of food;

column1: agniś ca ma āpaś ca ma ity āha |
column2: 'May for me fire, for me the waters', be says;

column1: eṣā vā annasya yoniḥ sayony evānnam ava runddhe |
column2: this is the birthplace of food; verily he wins food with its birthplace.

column1: ardhendrāṇi juhoti devatā evāva runddhe yat sarveṣām ardham indraḥ prati tasmād indro devatānām bhūyiṣṭhabhāktamas |
column2: He offers those where Indra, is half; verily he wins the deities; since Indra is half of all and a match, therefore Indra is the most appropriating of gods;

column1: indram uttaram āha |
column2: he says Indra later;

column1: indriyam evāsminn upariṣṭād dadhāti yajñāyudhāni juhoti yajñaḥ | vai yajñāyudhāni yajñam evāva runddhe |
column2: He offers the weapons of the sacrifice; the weapons of the sacrifice are the sacrifice [3]; verily he wins the sacrifice.

column1: atho etad vai yajñasya rūpam |
column2: Again this is the form of the sacrifice;

column1: rūpeṇaiva yajñam ava runddhe |
column2: verily he wins the sacrifice by its form.

column1: avabhṛthaś ca me svagākāraś ca ma ity āha svagākṛtyai |
column2: 'May for me the final bath and the cry of Godspeed!' he says, to utter Godspeed!

column1: agniś ca me gharmaś ca ma ity āha |
column2: 'May the fire for me, the cauldron', he says;

column1: etad vai brahmavarcasasya rūpam |
column2: that is the form of splendour;

column1: rūpenaiva brahmavarcasam ava runddhe |
column2: verily by the form he wins splendour.

column1: ṛk ca me sāma ca ma ity āha |
column2: 'May the Rc for me, the Saman', he says [4];

column1: etad vai chandasāṃ rūpam |
column2: that is the form of the metres;

column1: rūpeṇaiva chandāṃsy ava runddhe garbhāś ca me vatsāś ca ma ity āha |
column2: verily by the form he wins the metres. 'May the embryo for me, the calves', he says;

column1: etad vai paśūnāṃ rūpam |
column2: that is the form of cattle;

column1: rūpeṇaiva paśūn ava runddhe kalpāñ juhoti | aklptasya klptyai yugmadayuje juhoti mithunatvāya |
column2: verily by the form he wins cattle. He offers the orderers, to order the disordered. He offers the even and the odd, for pairing;

column1: uttarāvatī bhavatas | abhikrāntyai |
column2: they are in ascending ratio, for ascent.

column1: ekā ca me tisraś ca ma ity āha devachandasaṃ vā ekā ca tisraś ca |
column2: 'May one for me, three', he says;

column1: manuṣyachandasaṃ catasraś cāṣṭau ca devachandasaṃ caiva manuṣyachandasaṃ cāva runddhe |
column2: one and three are the metres of the gods [51, four and eight the metres of men; verily he wins both the metres of gods and men.

column1: ā trayastriṃśato juhoti trayastriṃśad vai devatās |
column2: Up to thirty-three he offers; the gods are three and thirty;

column1: devatā evāva runddhe |
column2: verily he wins the gods;

column1: āṣṭācatvāriṃśato juhoti | aṣṭācatvāriṃśadakṣarā jagatī jāgatāḥ paśavas |
column2: up to forty-eight he offers, the Jagati has forty eight syllables, cattle are connected with the Jagati: verily by the Jagati he wins cattle for him.

column1: jagatyaivāsmai paśūn ava runddhe vājaś ca prasavaś ceti dvādaśaṃ juhoti dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsara eva prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: 'Strength, instigation', (with these words) he offers a set of twelve; the year has twelve months; verily he finds support in the year.

column1: agnir devebhyo 'pākrāmad bhāgadheyam ichamānas taṃ devā abruvan | upa na ā vartasva havyaṃ no vaheti so 'bravīt |
column2: Agni departed from the gods, desiring a portion; the gods said to him, 'come back to us, carry the oblation for us.' He said, 'Let me choose a born;

column1: varaṃ vṛṇai mahyam eva vājaprasavīyaṃ juhavann iti tasmād agnaye vājaprasavīyaṃ juhvati yad vājaprasavīyaṃ juhoty agnim eva tad bhāgadheyena sam ardhayati |
column2: let them offer to me the Vajaprasaviya'; therefore to Agni they offer the Vajaprasaviya. In that he offers the Vajaprasaviya, he unites Agni with his own portion; verily also this is his consecration.

column1: atho abhiṣeka evāsya {sa < sas} caturdaśabhir juhoti sapta grāmyā oṣadhayaḥ sapta |
column2: He offers with fourteen (verses); there are seven domesticated, seven wild [ 1] animals;

column1: ubhayīṣām avaruddhyai |
column2: (verily it serves) to win both sets.

column1: annasyānnasya juhoti | annasyānnasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: He offers of every kind of food, to win every kind of food.

column1: audumbareṇa sruveṇa juhoti |
column2: He offers with an offering-spoon of Udumbara wood;

column1: ūrg vā udumbara ūrg annam ūrjaivāsmā ūrjam annam ava runddhe |
column2: the Udumbara is strength, food is strength; verily by strength he wins for him strength and food.

column1: agnir vai devānām abhiṣikto 'gnicin manuṣyāṇām |
column2: Agni is the consecrated of gods, the piler of the fire of men;

column1: tasmād agnicid varṣati na dhāvet | avaruddhaṃ hy asyānnam annam iva khalu vai varṣam |
column2: therefore when it rains a piler of the fire should not run, for he has thus obtained food; rain is as it were food;

column1: yad dhāved annādyād dhāvet |
column2: if he were to run he would be running from food.

column1: upāvarteta |
column2: He should go up to it;

column1: annādyam evābhi |
column2: verily be goes up -to food [2].

column1: upāvartate naktoṣāseti kṛṣṇāyai śvetavatsāyai payasā juhoti |
column2: 'Night and dawn', (with these words) he offers with the milk of a black cow with a white calf;

column1: ahnaivāsmai rātrim pra dāpayati rātriyāhar ahorātre evāsmai pratte kāmam annādyaṃ duhāte rāṣṭrabhṛto juhoti rāṣṭram evāva runddhe ṣaḍbhir juhoti sāḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: verily day and night being bestowed upon him milk his desire and the eating of food. He offers the supporters of the kingly power; verily he wins the kingdom. He offers with six (verses); the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva prati tiṣṭhati bhuvanasya pata iti rathamukhe pañcāhutīr juhoti vajro vai rathas |
column2: verily he finds support in the seasons. 'O lord of the world', (with these words) he offers five libations at the chariot mouth;

column1: vajreṇaiva diśaḥ |
column2: the chariot is a thunderbolt;

column1: abhi jayati |
column2: verily with the thunderbolt he conquers the quarters [3].

column1: agnicitaṃ ha vā amuṣmiM loke vāto 'bhi pavate vātanāmāni juhoti |
column2: In yonder world the wind blows over the piler of the fire; he offers the names of the winds;

column1: abhy evainam amuṣmiM loke vātaḥ pavate trīṇi juhoti traya ime lokās |
column2: verily over him in yonder world the wind blows; three he offers, these worlds are three;

column1: ebhya eva lokebhyo vātam ava runddhe samudro 'si nabhasvān ity āha |
column2: verily from these worlds he wins the wind. 'Thou art the ocean, full of mist', he says;

column1: etad vai vātasya rūpam |
column2: that is the form of the wind;

column1: rūpeṇaiva vātam ava runddhe |
column2: verily by the form he wins the wind.

column1: añjalinā juhoti na hy eteṣām anyathāhutir avakalpate |
column2: He offers with his clasped hands, for not other wise can the oblation of these be accomplished.

column1: suvargāya vai lokāya devaratho yujyate yatrākūtāya manuṣyaratha eṣa khalu vai devaratho yad agnir agniṃ yunajmi śavasā ghṛtenety āha yunakty evainaṃ sa enaṃ yuktaḥ suvargaṃ lokam abhi vahati yat sarvābhiḥ pañcabhir yuñjyād yukto 'syāgniḥ pracyutaḥ syād apratiṣṭhitā āhutayaḥ syur apratiṣṭhitā stomā apratiṣṭhitāny ukthāni tisṛbhiḥ prātaḥsavane 'bhi mṛśati trivṛt |
column2: he, yoked, carries him to the world of heaven. If he were to yoke with all five together, his fire yoked would fall away, the libations would be without support, the Stomas without support, the hymns without support. He strokes (the fire) with three (verses) at the morning pressing; the fire is threefold [1]; verily he yokes the full extent of the fire;

column1: vā agnir yāvān evāgnis taṃ yunakti yathānasi yukta ādhīyata evam eva tat praty āhutayas tiṣṭhanti prati stomāḥ praty ukthāni yajñāyajñiyasya stotre dvābhyām abhi mṛśaty etāvān vai yajño yāvān agniṣṭomo bhūmā tvā asyāta ūrdhvaḥ kriyate yāvān eva yajñas tam antato 'nvārohati dvābhyām pratiṣṭhityā ekayāprastutam bhavaty atha |
column2: He strokes with two (verses) in the Stotra of the Yajñayajñiya; the sacrifice is as great as is the Agnistoma; a further extension is performed over and above it; verily he mounts at the end the whole extent of the sacrifice. (He strokes) with two (verses), for support;

column1: abhi mṛśaty upainam uttaro yajño namaty atho saṃtatyai pra vā eṣo 'smāl lokāc cyavate yo 'gniṃ cinute na vā etasyāniṣṭaka āhutir ava kalpate yāṃ vā eṣo 'niṣṭaka āhutiṃ juhoti sravati vai sā tāṃ sravantīṃ yajño 'nu parā bhavati yajñaṃ yajamāno yat punaścitiṃ cinuta āhutīnām pratiṣṭhityai praty āhutayas tiṣṭhanti |
column2: the rest of the sacrifice resorts to him; (verily it serves) for continuity. He who piles up the fire falls away from this world; his libation cannot be performed in a place without bricks; whatever libation he offers in a place without bricks, it runs away, and with its running away the sacrifice is ruined, with the sacrifice the sacrificer;

column1: na yajñaḥ parābhavati na yajamānas |
column2: the libations find support [3], the sacrifice is not ruined, nor the sacrificer.

column1: aṣṭāv upa dadhāty aṣṭākṣarā gāyatrī gāyatreṇaivainaṃ chandasā cinute yad ekādaśa traiṣṭubhena yad dvādaśa jāgatena chandobhir evainaṃ cinute napātko vai nāmaiṣo 'gnir yat punaścitir ya evaṃ vidvān punaścitiṃ cinuta ā tṛtīyāt puruṣād annam atti yathā vai punarādheya evam punaścitir yo 'gnyādheyena na |
column2: the Gayatri has eight syllables; verily he piles it with the Gayatri metre; if eleven, with the Tristubh, if twelve with the Jagati verily he piles it with the metres. The fire that is re-piled is called the descendant; he who knowing thus re-piles the fire eats food up to the third generation.

column1: ṛdhnoti sa punarādheyam ā dhatte yo 'gniṃ citvā nardhnoti sa punaścitiṃ cinute yat punaścitiṃ cinuta ṛddhyai |
column2: he who does not succeed through the establishment of the fire [4] re-establishes it; he who does not succeed by the piling up of the fire re-piles it.

column1: atho khalv āhur na cetavyeti rudro vā eṣa yad agnir yathā vyāghraṃ suptam bodhayati tādṛg eva tat |
column2: Or rather they say, 'one should not pile it up.' The fire is Rudra, and it is as if one stirs up a sleeping lion.

column1: atho khalv āhuś cetavyeti yathā vasīyāṃsam bhāgadheyena bodhayati tādṛg eva tat |
column2: But again they say, 'One should pile it up.' It is as if one awakens a richer man with his due portion.

column1: manur agnim acinuta tena nārdhnot sa etām punaścitim apaśyat tām acinuta tayā vai sa ārdhnod yat punaścitiṃ cinuta ṛddhyai |
column2: Manu piled the fire; with it he did not prosper; he saw this re-piling, he piled it, with it he prospered; in that he piles the re-piling, (it is) for prosperity.
