column1: chandaścitaṃ cinvīta paśukāmaḥ paśavo vai chandāṃsi paśumān eva bhavati śyenacitaṃ cinvīta suvargakāmaḥ śyeno vai vayasām patiṣṭhaḥ śyena eva bhūtvā suvargaṃ lokam patati kaṅkacitaṃ cinvīta yaḥ kāmayeta śīrṣaṇvān amuṣmiM loke syām iti śīrṣaṇvān evāmuṣmiM loke bhavati |
column2: He should pile in hawk shape who desires the sky; the hawk is the best flier among birds; verily becoming a hawk he flies to the world of heaven. He should pile in heron form who desires, 'May I be possessed of a head in yonder world'; verily he becomes possessed of a head in yonder world.

column1: alajacitaṃ cinvīta catuḥsītam pratiṣṭhākāmaś catasro diśo dikṣv eva prati tiṣṭhati praugacitaṃ cinvīta bhrātṛvyavān pra |
column2: He should pile in the form of an Alaja bird, with four furrows, who desires support; there are four quarters; verily he finds support in the quarters. He should pile in the form of a triangle, who has foes [1];

column1: eva bhrātṛvyān nudate |
column2: verily he repels his foes.

column1: ubhayataḥpraugaṃ cinvīta yaḥ kāmayeta pra jātān bhrātṛvyān nudeya pratijaniṣyamāṇān iti praiva jātān bhrātṛvyān nudate prati janiṣyamāṇān rathacakracitaṃ cinvīta bhrātṛvyavān vajro vai ratho vajram eva bhrātṛvyebhyaḥ pra harati droṇacitaṃ cinvītānnakāmo droṇe vā annam bhriyate sayony evānnam ava runddhe samūhyaṃ cinvīta paśukāmaḥ paśumān eva bhavati |

column2: your arrows are the waters; the sea, &c.

column1: adhipatayo nāma stha teṣāṃ va upari gṛhās |
column2: Ye are overlords by name; your houses are above;

column1: varṣaṃ va iṣavo 'vasvān kravyā nāma stha pārthivās teṣāṃ va iha gṛhāḥ |
column2: Ye are the raw-flesh eaters by name, of the earth; your houses are bore [4]; your arrows are food;

column1: annaṃ va iṣavo nimiṣo vātanāmam |
column2: winking is the name of the wind; to you homage;

column1: tebhyo vo namas te no mṛḍayata te yaṃ dviṣmo yaś ca no dveṣṭi taṃ vo jambhe dadhāmi hutādo vā anye devā ahutādo 'nye tān agnicid evobhayān prīṇāti dadhnā madhumiśreṇaitā āhutīr juhoti bhāgadheyenaivainān prīṇāti |
column2: him whom we hate and who hateth us I put in your jaws. Some gods eat the offerings, others do not; verily the piler of the fire delights both sets. He offers these libations with curds mixed with honey; verily he delights them with their proper portion.

column1: atho khalv āhus | iṣṭakā vai devā ahutāda iti |
column2: Or rather they say, 'The gods who eat not the oblations are the bricks' [5].

column1: anuparikrāmaṃ juhoti |
column2: He offers going round in order;

column1: aparivargam evainān prīṇāti |
column2: verily he delights them completely.

column1: imaṃ stanam ūrjasvantaṃ dhayāpām prapyātam agne sarirasya madhye |
column2: Suck this mighty breast of the waters, Filled in the midst of the flood, O Agni;

column1: utsaṃ juṣasva madhumantam ūrva samudriyaṃ sadanam ā viśasva |
column2: Rejoice in the spring of sweetness, O ocean, Enter thy seat of the sea.

column1: yo vā agnim prayujya na vimuñcati yathāśvo yukto 'vimucyamānaḥ kṣudhyan parābhavaty evam asyāgniḥ parā bhavati tam parābhavantaṃ yajamāno 'nu parā bhavati so 'gniṃ citvā lūkṣaḥ |
column2: If one having yoked the fire does not set it free, then just as a horse yoked and not set free in hunger is overcome, so his fire is overcome, and with it being overcome the sacrificer is overcome; he having piled the fire becomes aheat [6];

column1: imaṃ stanam ūrjasvantaṃ dhayāpām ity ājyasya pūrṇāṃ srucaṃ juhoti |
column2: 'Suck this mighty breast of the waters', (with these words) he offers a ladle full of butter;

column1: eṣa vā agner vimokas |
column2: this is the freeing of the fire;

column1: vimucyaivāsmā annam api dadhāti tasmād āhur yaś caivaṃ veda yaś ca na sudhāyaṃ ha vai vājī suhito dadhātīti |
column2: verily setting it free he gives it food. Therefore they say, both he who knows and he who knows not. 'A horse well loaded carries well';

column1: agnir vāva vājī tam eva tat prīṇāti sa enam prītaḥ prīṇāti vasīyān bhavati |
column2: the horse is Agni; verily he delights him, he delighted delights him; he becomes richer.

column1: indrāya rājñe sūkaras |
column2: The Horse Sacrifce (continued) To Indra, the king, a boar;

column1: varuṇāya rājñe kṛṣṇas |
column2: to Varuna, the king, a black (antelope);

column1: yamāya rājña ṛśyas |
column2: to Yama, the king, a deer;

column1: ṛṣabhāya rājñe gavayaḥ śārdūlāya rājñe gauraḥ puruṣarājāya markaṭaḥ kṣipraśyenasya vartikā nīlaṃgoḥ krimiḥ somasya rājñaḥ kuluṃgaḥ sindhoḥ śiṃśumāras |
column2: to the tiger, the king, a Bos Gavaeus; to the king of men a monkey; for the swift falcon a quail; for the Nilangu (snake) a worm; for Soma, the king, a gazelle;

column1: himavato hastī |
column2: for the ocean a crocodile;

column1: mayuḥ prājāpatyas |
column2: The ape is for Prajapati;

column1: ūlo halīkṣṇo vṛṣadaṃśas te dhātuḥ sarasvatyai śāriḥ śyetā puruṣavāc |
column2: the owl, the Haliksna the cat, are for Dhatr; to Sarasvati the white starling, of human speech;

column1: āraṇyo 'jo nakulaḥ śakā te pauṣṇās |
column2: the wild goat, the ichneumon, the Çaka, these are for Pusan;

column1: vāce krauñcaḥ |
column2: the curlew to speech.

column1: apāṃ naptre jaṣas |
column2: To the offspring of waters a fish;

column1: nākro makaraḥ kulikayas te 'kūpārasya vāce paiṅgarājas |
column2: the crocodile, the dolphin, the Kulikaya are for the ocean; to speech the Paingaraja;

column1: bhagāya kuṣītakas |
column2: to Bhaga the sea-crow;

column1: ātī vāhaso darvidā te vāyavyās |
column2: the swan, the Vahasa, the woodpecker, these are for Vayu;

column1: digbhyaś cakravākaḥ |
column2: to the quarters the Cakravaka.

column1: balāyājagaras | ākhuḥ sṛjayā śayaṇḍakas te maitrās |
column2: To might, a boa-constrictor; the mole, the Srjaya, the lizard, these are for Mitra;

column1: mṛtyave 'sitas |
column2: to death the dark (serpent);

column1: manyave svajaḥ kumbhīnasaḥ puṣkarasādo lohitāhis te tvāṣṭrāḥ pratiśrutkāyai vāhasaḥ |
column2: to wrath the viper; the pot-nosed, the lotus-sitter, the copper snake, these are for Tvastr; to the echo the Vahasa.

column1: puruṣamṛgaś candramase godhā kālakā dārvāghāṭas te vanaspatīnām eṇy ahne kṛṣṇo rātriyai pikaḥ kṣviṅkā nīlaśīrṣṇī te 'ryamṇe dhātuḥ katkaṭaḥ |
column2: The human beast to the moon; the lizard, the Kalaka, the woodpecker, these are for the trees; the dappled (deer) to day; the black (antelope) to night; the cuckoo, the Ksvinka, the black-headed, these are (to be offered) to Aryaman;

column1: saurī balākā |
column2: For the sun the crane;

column1: ṛśyo mayūraḥ śyenas te gandharvāṇām | vasūnāṃ kapiñjalas |
column2: the deer, the peacock, the hawk, these are for the Gandharvas; for the Vasus the francolin partridge;

column1: rudrāṇāṃ tittiris |
column2: for the Rudras the partridge;

column1: rohit kuṇḍṛṇācī golattikā tā apsarasām araṇyāya sṛmaraḥ |
column2: the red doe, the Kundrnaci, the Golattika, these are for the Apsarases; to the wood the Srmara.

column1: pṛṣato vaiśvadevaḥ pitvo nyaṅkuḥ kaśas te 'numatyai |
column2: the Pitva, Nyanku, the Kaça, these are (to be offered) to Anumati;

column1: anyavāpo 'rdhamāsānām māsāṃ kaśyapaḥ kvayiḥ kuṭarur dātyauhas te sinīvālyai bṛhaspataye śitpuṭaḥ |
column2: the tortoise for the months; the Kvayi, the Kutaru, the gallinule, these are (to be offered) to Sinivali; to Brhaspati the cat.

column1: śakā bhaumī pāṅktraḥ kaśo mānthīlavas te pitṝṇām ṛtūnāṃ jahakā saṃvatsarāya lopā kapota ulūkaḥ śaśas te nairṛtāḥ kṛkavākuḥ sāvitraḥ |
column2: The Çaka, is for earth; the field-rat, the Kaça, the flying fox, these are for the fathers; the pole-cat for the seasons; the quail to the year; the pigeon, the owl, the hare, these are for Nirrti;

column1: rurū raudraḥ kṛkalāsaḥ śakuniḥ pippakā te śaravyāyai hariṇo mārutas |
column2: The deer for Rudra; the chameleon, the bird, the Pippaka, these are (to be offered) to the arrow shot;

column1: brahmaṇe śārgas tarakṣuḥ kṛṣṇaḥ śvā caturakṣo gardabhas ta itarajanānām agnaye dhūṅkṣṇā |
column2: the Çarga to the Brahman; the hyena, the black (deer), the dog of four eyes, the ass, these are for other men; to Agni the crow.

column1: alaja āntarikṣas |
column2: The Alaja is for the atmosphere;

column1: udro madguḥ plavas te 'pām adityai haṃsasācis |
column2: the otter, the diver, the swimmer, these for the waters; to Aditi the Hansasaci;

column1: indrāṇyai kīrśā gṛdhraḥ śitikakṣī vārdhrāṇasas te divyās |
column2: to Indrani the Kirça; the vulture, the white-breasted, the Vardhranasa, these are for the sky;

column1: dyāvāpṛthivyā śvāvit |
column2: the hedgehog is for sky and earth.

column1: suparṇaḥ pārjanyas |
column2: The eagle for Parjanya;

column1: haṃso vṛko vṛṣadaṃśas ta aindrās |
column2: the swan, the wolf, the cat, these are for Indra;

column1: apām udras |
column2: the otter for the waters;

column1: aryamṇe lopāśaḥ siṃho nakulo vyāghras te mahendrāya kāmāya parasvān |
column2: the lion, the ichneumon, the tiger, these are (to be offered) to great Indra; the rhinoceros to desire.

column1: āgneyaḥ kṛṣṇagrīvaḥ sārasvatī meṣī babhruḥ saumyaḥ pauṣṇaḥ śyāmaḥ śitipṛṣṭho bārhaspatyaḥ śilpo vaiśvadevas |
column2: For Agni the black-necked; for Sarasvati the ewe; the brown one for Soma; the dark for Pusan; the white-backed for Brhaspati;

column1: aindro 'ruṇas |
column2: the ruddy one for Indra;

column1: mārutaḥ kalmāṣas |
column2: the speckled one for the Maruts;

column1: aindrāgnaḥ saṃhitas |
column2: the mixed one for Indra and Agni;

column1: adhorāmaḥ sāvitras |
column2: the one spotted below for Savitr;

column1: vāruṇaḥ petvaḥ |
column2: the ram for Varuna.

column1: aśvas tūparo gomṛgas te prājāpatyās |
column2: The horse, the hornless one, the Gayal, these are for Prajapati;

column1: āgneyau kṛṣṇagrīvau tvāṣṭrau lomaśasakthau śitipṛṣṭhau bārhaspatyau dhātre pṛṣodaraḥ sauryo balakṣaḥ petvaḥ |
column2: for Agni the two with black necks; for Tvastr the two with hairy thighs; the two white-backed for Brhaspati; to Dhatr the speckled bellied one; for the sun the white ram.

column1: agnaye 'nīkavate rohitāñjir anaḍvān adhorāmau sāvitrau pauṣṇau rajatanābhī vaiśvadevau piśaṃgau dūparau mārutaḥ kalmāṣas |
column2: To Agni of the front the red-limbed ox; the two spotted below for Savitr; the two red-navelled for Pusan; the two hornless tawny ones for the All-gods; the speckled for the Maruts;

column1: āgneyaḥ kṛṣṇo 'jaḥ sārasvatī meṣī vāruṇaḥ kṛṣṇa ekaśitipāt petvaḥ |
column2: the black goat for Agni the ewe for Sarasvati; the black ram with one white foot for Varuna.

column1: hiraṇyavarṇāḥ śucayaḥ pāvakā yāsu jātaḥ kaśyapo yāsv indraḥ | agniṃ garbhaṃ dadhire virūpās tā na āpaḥ śaṃ syonā bhavantu |
column2: The Piling of the Fire Altar (continued) Golden of colour, pure, purifying, In which was born Kaçyapa, in which Indra, They have conceived Agni as a germ, of varied forms;

column1: yāsāṃ rājā varuṇo yāti madhye satyānṛte avapaśyañ janānām |
column2: Those in whose midst Varuna doth go, Gazing on the truth and falsehood of men, Dripping honey, pure, purifying;

column1: madhuścutaḥ śucayo yāḥ pāvakās tā na āpaḥ śaṃ syonā bhavantu |
column2: May these waters be gentle and kindly to us.

column1: yāsāṃ devā divi kṛṇvanti bhakṣaṃ yā antarikṣe bahudhā bhavanti | yāḥ pṛthivīm payaso 'ndanti | śukrās tā na āpaḥ śaṃ syonā bhavantu |
column2: Those of which in the sky the gods make their food, Those that are in many places in the sky, Those that inundate the earth with their sap [1], the pure ones May these waters be gentle and kindly to us.

column1: śivena mā cakṣuṣā paśyatāpaḥ śivayā tanuvo 'pa spṛśata tvacam me |
column2: With auspicious eye gaze on me, O waters; With auspicious body, do ye touch my skin;

column1: sarvāṃ agnīṃr apsuṣado huve vo mayi varco balam ojo ni dhatta |
column2: invoke all you Agnis that sit in the waters; Do ye confer upon me radiance and might and force.

column1: yad adaḥ samprayatīr ahāv anadatā hate | tasmād ā nadyo nāma stha tā vo nāmāni sindhavaḥ |
column2: When as ye went below Ye cried (ánadata) on the slaying of the serpent, Therefore are yo criers (nadyáh) by name; These are your names, O streams.

column1: yat preṣitā varuṇena tāḥ śībhaṃ samavalgata | tad āpnod indro vo yatīs tasmād āpo anu sthana |
column2: When instigated by Varuna Ye wallowed speedily [2], Then Indra obtained (apnot) you as ye went Therefore ye are waters (ápah).

column1: indro vaḥ śaktibhir devīs tasmād vār ṇāma vo hitam | eko devo apy atiṣṭhat syandamānā yathāvaśam |
column2: As ye glided against his will, He stayed (ávivarata) your courses, Indra with his might, O goddesses;

column1: ud āniṣur mahīr iti tasmād udakam ucyate |
column2: Therefore your name is water (váh).

column1: āpo bhadrā ghṛtam id āpa āsur agnīṣomau bibhraty āpa it tāḥ |
column2: One god stepped upon them, As they glided, according to his will, (Saying) 'The great ones have breathed forth (úd) Therefore they are called water.

column1: tīvro raso madhupṛcām |
column2: The waters are kindly, the waters were ghee;

column1: araṃgama ā mā prāṇena saha varcasā gan |
column2: These waters bear Agni and Soma;

column1: ād it paśyāmy uta vā śṛṇomy ā mā ghoṣo gachati vāṅ na āsām |
column2: I behold, or I hear; The cry cometh to me, the voice of them to us;

column1: manye bhejāno amṛtasya tarhi hiraṇyavarṇā atṛpaṃ yad vaḥ |
column2: consider that I have enjoyed the ambrosia then, When I delighted you, O ye of golden hue.

column1: āpo hi ṣṭhā mayobhuvas tā na ūrje dadhātana |
column2: Ye, waters, are healing;

column1: mahe raṇāya cakṣase |
column2: Further us to strength, To see great joy.

column1: yo vaḥ śivatamo rasas tasya bhājayateha naḥ | uśatīr iva mātaraḥ |
column2: The most auspicious flavour that is yours, Accord to us here, Like eager mothers.

column1: tasmā araṃ gamāma vo yasya kṣayāya jinvatha | āpo janayathā ca naḥ |
column2: To him may we come with satisfaction, To whose dwelling ye quicken us, waters, and propagate us.

column1: divi śrayasvāntarikṣe yatasva pṛthivyā sam bhava brahmavarcasam asi brahmavarcasāya tvā |
column2: Arise to the sky, aim at the atmosphere, be united with the earth; thou art splendour; for splendour thee!

column1: apāṃ grahān gṛhṇāti |
column2: He draws cups of water;

column1: etad vāva rājasūyaṃ yad ete grahāḥ savo 'gnis |
column2: the cups are the royal consecration;

column1: varuṇasavo rājasūyam agnisavaś cityas tābhyām eva sūyate |
column2: the royal consecration is the consecration of Varuna; (the fire) to be piled is Agni's consecration;

column1: atho ubhāv eva lokāv abhi jayati yaś ca rājasūyenejānasya yaś cāgnicite |
column2: verily also he conquers both the worlds, that of him who has offered the royal consecration and that of the piler of the fire.

column1: āpo bhavanti |
column2: There are waters;

column1: āpo vā agner bhrātṛvyās |
column2: the waters are foes of Agni;

column1: yad apo 'gner adhastād upadadhāti bhrātṛvyābhibhūtyai bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyo bhavati |
column2: in that he puts the waters down below the fire, (they serve) to overcome his foe; he prospers himself, his foe is defeated.

column1: amṛtam |
column2: The waters are ambrosia [1];

column1: vā āpas tasmād adbhir avatāntam abhi ṣiñcanti nārtim ārchati sarvam āyur eti yasyaitā upadhīyante ya u cainā evaṃ veda |
column2: therefore they sprinkle with water him who is faint; he does not go to ruin, he lives all his life, for whom these are put down, and who knows them thus.

column1: annaṃ vā āpaḥ paśava āpas | annam paśavas |
column2: The waters are food, the waters are cattle, cattle are food;

column1: annādaḥ paśumān bhavati yasyaitā upadīyante ya u cainā evaṃ veda dvādaśa bhavanti dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsarenaivāsmai |
column2: an eater of food and rich in cattle he becomes, for whom these are put down, and who knows them thus. They are twelve; the year has twelve months; verily by the year he wins food for him [2];

column1: annam ava runddhe pātrāṇi bhavanti pātre vā annam adyate sayony evānnam ava runddhe |
column2: there are vessels used; in a vessel is food eaten; verily he wins food with its birthplace;

column1: ā dvādaśāt puruṣād annam atty atho pātrān na chidyate yasyaitā upadhīyante ya u cainā evaṃ veda kumbhāś ca kumbhīś ca mithunāni bhavanti mithunasya prajātyai pra prajayā paśubhir mithunair jāyate yasyaitā upadhīyante ya u |
column2: up to the twelfth generation he eats food; moreover, he is not cut off from his vessel for whom these are put down, nor he who knows them thus. The pots and the pans make pairs, for the propagation of pairing; with offspring, with cattle, with pairings is he propagated for whom these are put down and he who [3] knows them thus.

column1: cainā evaṃ veda śug vā agniḥ so 'dhvaryuṃ yajamānam prajāḥ śucārpayati yad apa upadadhāti śucam evāsya śamayati nārtim ārchaty adhvaryur na yajamānaḥ śāmyanti prajā yatraitā upadhīyante |
column2: Agni is pain; he afflicts the Adhvaryu, the sacrificer, and offspring with pain; in that he puts down water, he soothes his pain; neither Adhvaryu nor sacrificer goes to ruin;

column1: apāṃ vā etāni hṛdayāni yad etā āpas |
column2: offspring are soothed where these are put down.

column1: yad etā apa upadadhāti divyābhir evaināḥ saṃ sṛjati varṣukaḥ parjanyaḥ |
column2: in that he puts these down, he unites these with (the waters) of the sky; Parjanya becomes likely to rain [4].

column1: bhavati yo vā etāsām āyatanaṃ klptiṃ vedāyatanavān bhavati kalpate 'smai |
column2: He who knows their home and their arrangement becomes possessed of a home, things go in order for him.

column1: anusītam upa dadhāti |
column2: Along the furrows he puts (them) down;

column1: etad vā āsām āyatanam eṣā klptis |
column2: this is their home, their arrangements;

column1: ya evaṃ vedāyatanavān bhavati kalpate 'smai dvaṃdvam anyā upa dadhāti catasro madhye dhṛtyai |
column2: he who knows thus becomes possessed of home, and things go in order for him. The others he puts down in pairs, but four in the middle, for support.

column1: annaṃ vā iṣṭakās |
column2: in the middle he puts (them) down;

column1: evāsmā annam ava runddhe madhyata upa dadhāti madhyata evāsmā annaṃ dadhāti tasmān madhyato 'nnam adyate bārhaspatyo bhavati brahma vai devānām bṛhaspatis |
column2: verily he bestows food on him in the middle; therefore in the middle is food eaten. It is offered to Brhaspati; Brhaspati is the holy power of the gods: verily by holy power he wins food for him.

column1: brahmaṇaivāsmā annam ava runddhe brahmavarcasam asi brahmavarcasāya tvety āha tejasvī brahmavarcasī bhavati yasyaiṣa upadhīyate ya u cainam evaṃ veda |
column2: 'Thou art splendour; for splendour thee!' he says; brilliant and resplendent does he become, for whom these are put down, and he who knows it thus.

column1: bhūteṣṭakā upa dadhāti |
column2: He puts down the bricks of being;

column1: atrātra vai mṛtyur jāyate yatrayatraiva mṛtyur jāyate tata evainam ava yajate tasmād agnicit sarvam āyu eti sarve hy asya mṛtyavo 'veṣṭās tasmād agnicin nābhicaritavai pratyag enam abhicāra stṛṇute sūyate vā eṣa yo 'gniṃ cinute devasuvām etāni havīṃṣi bhavanti |
column2: in every place is death born; wherever death is born, thence he removes it by sacrifice; therefore the piler of the fire lives all his life, for all deaths are removed by him; therefore the piler of the fire is not to be practised against; his witchcraft turns upon him (who does so) and lays him low.

column1: etāvanto vai devānāṃ savās ta eva |
column2: these are the offerings of the divine consecrators;

column1: asmai savān pra yachanti ta enaṃ suvante savo 'gnir varuṇasavo rājasūyam brahmasavaś cityas |
column2: they consecrate him, the fire is consecration; the royal consecration is the consecration of Varuna;

column1: devasya tvā savituḥ prasava ity āha savitṛprasūta evainam brahmaṇā devatābhir abhi ṣiñcati |
column2: 'On the instigation of the god Savitr, thee', he says; verily instigated by Savitr he consecrates him with holy power, with the deities.

column1: annasyānnasyābhi ṣiñcati | annasyānnasyāvaruddhyai purastāt pratyañcam abhi ṣiñcati purastād dhi pratīcīnam annam adyate śīrṣato 'bhi ṣiñcati śīrṣato hy annam adyate |
column2: He pours down every sort of food, to win every sort of food. He pours down over him from the front face to face; for from the front face to face is food eaten. He pours down from the head, for from the head is food eaten;

column1: ā mukhād anvavasrāvayati |
column2: he causes (the water) to flow over up to the mouth [2];

column1: mukhata evāsmā annādyaṃ dadhāti |
column2: verily on the mouth he bestows food-eating upon him.

column1: agnes tvā sāmrājyenābhi ṣiñcāmīty āha |
column2: 'With the lordship of Agni I consecrate thee', he says;

column1: eṣa vā agneḥ savas tenaivainam abhi ṣiñcati bṛhaspates tvā sāmrājyenābhi ṣiñcāmīty āha brahma vai devānām bṛhaspatis |
column2: this is the consecration of Agni; verily he consecrates him with it. 'With the lordship of Brhaspati I consecrate thee', he says; Brhaspati is the holy power of the gods;

column1: brahmaṇaivainam abhi ṣiñcati |
column2: verily with holy power he consecrates him.

column1: indrasya tvā sāmrājyenābhi ṣiñcāmīty āha |
column2: 'With the lordship of Indra I consecrate thee', he says;

column1: indriyam evāsminn upariṣṭād dadhāti |
column2: verily he confers power from above upon him.

column1: etat | vai rājasūyasya rūpam |
column2: That [3] is the form of the royal consecration.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān agniṃ cinuta ubhāv eva lokāv abhi jayati yaś ca rājasūyenejānasya yaś cāgnicitas |
column2: He who knowing thus piles the fire conquers both the worlds, that of him who has offered the royal consecration and that of the piler of the fire.

column1: indrasya suṣuvāṇasya daśadhendriyaṃ vīryam parāpatat tad devāḥ sautrāmaṇyā sam abharan |
column2: When Indra had been consecrated, his power and strength fell away in ten places; the gods brought it together with the Sautramani;

column1: sūyate vā eṣa yo 'gniṃ cinute |
column2: he who piles the fire is consecrated;

column1: agniṃ citvā sautrāmaṇyā yajetendriyam eva vīryaṃ sambhṛtyātman dhatte |
column2: having piled the fire he should sacrifice with the Sautramani; verily collecting power and strength he places them in himself.

column1: sajūr abdo 'yāvabhiḥ sajūr uṣā aruṇībhiḥ sajūḥ sūrya etaścena sajoṣāv aśvinā daṃsobhiḥ sajūr agnir vaiśvānara iḍābhis |
column2: The year in unison with the Ayavans the dawn in unison with the ruddy (cows); Surya in unison with the steed; the Açvins in unison with the wondrous works. Agni Vaiçvanara in unison with the food offerings;

column1: māsā ayāvās |
column2: with ghee; hail!

column1: uṣā aruṇī sūrya etaśas | ime aśvinā saṃvatsaro 'gnir vaiśvānaraḥ paśava iḍā paśavo ghṛtam |
column2: The year is the year, the Ayavas are the months, the red one the dawn, the steed Surya, the Açvins these two (worlds), Agni Vaiçvanara the year, the food offerings cattle, ghee cattle.

column1: saṃvatsaram paśavo 'nu pra jāyante saṃvatsareṇaivāsmai paśūn pra janayati darbhastambe juhoti yat |
column2: With the year cattle are born; verily with the year he produces cattle for him. He offers on a blade of Darbha grass [1];

column1: vā asyā amṛtaṃ yad vīryaṃ tad darbhās tasmiñ juhoti praiva jāyate 'nnādo bhavati yasyaivaṃ juhvati |
column2: the Darbhas are the ambrosia, the strength of the (earth); he offers on it; verily he is propagated. An eater of food he becomes for whom they offer thus.

column1: etā vai devatā agneḥ purastādbhāgās tā eva prīṇāti |
column2: These deities are the foremost portions of Agni; verily he delights them;

column1: atho cakṣur evāgneḥ purastāt prati dadhāti |
column2: verily too he places the eye of Agni in front;

column1: anandho bhavati ya evaṃ veda |
column2: he becomes not blind who knows thus.

column1: āpo vā idam agre salilam āsīt sa prajāpatiḥ puṣkaraparṇe vāto bhūto 'lelāyat saḥ |
column2: Waters were the world at first, the Moving ocean; Prajapati, becoming wind, rocked about on a lotus leaf;

column1: pratiṣṭhāṃ nāvindata sa etad apāṃ kulāyam apaśyat tasminn agnim acinuta tad iyam abhavat tato vai sa praty atiṣṭhat |
column2: he [2] could find no support; he saw that nest of the waters, on it he piled the fire, that became this (earth), then indeed did he find support.

column1: yām purastād upādadhāt tac chiro 'bhavat sā prācī {dig < diś} yāṃ dakṣiṇata upādadhāt sa dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣo 'bhavat sā dakṣiṇā {dig < diś} yām paścād upādadhāt tat pucham abhavat sā pratīcī {dig < diś} yām uttarata upādadhāt |
column2: (The brick) which he put down in front became the head, that is the eastern quarter; (the brick) which he put down on the right became the right side, that is the southern quarter; (the brick) which he put down behind became the tail, that is the western quarter;

column1: sa uttaraḥ pakṣo 'bhavat sodīcī {dig < diś} yām upariṣṭād upādadhāt tat pṛṣṭham abhavat sordhvā {dig < diś} iyam vā agniḥ pañceṣṭakas tasmād yad asyāṃ khananty abhīṣṭakāṃ tṛndanty abhi śarkarām |
column2: (the brick) which he put down on the left [3] became the left side, that is the northern quarter; (the brick) which he put down above became the back, that is the zenith. Agni of the five bricks is this (earth); therefore when they dig in it they knock up against the brick, against gravel.

column1: sarvā vā iyaṃ vayobhyo naktaṃ dṛśe dīpyate tasmād imāṃ vayāṃsi naktaṃ nādhy āsate ya evaṃ vidvān agniṃ cinute praty eva | tiṣṭhaty abhi diśo jayati |
column2: Now all this (earth) in the eyes of the birds shines at night, therefore birds do not at night rest upon it. He who knowing this piles a fire finds support, and conquers all the quarters.

column1: āgneyo vai brāhmaṇas tasmād brāhmaṇāya sarvāsu dikṣv ardhukam |
column2: The Brahman is connected with Agni, therefore the Brahman finds prosperity in all the quarters;

column1: svām eva tad diśam anv eti |
column2: verily every quarter he goes to is his own.

column1: apāṃ vā agniḥ kulāyam |
column2: The fire is the nest of the waters;

column1: tasmād āpo 'gniṃ hārukāḥ svām eva tad yonim pra viśanti |
column2: therefore waters draw the fire; verily they enter their own birthplace.

column1: saṃvatsaram ukhyam bhṛtvā dvitīye saṃvatsara āgneyam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vaped aindram ekādaśakapālaṃ vaiśvadevaṃ dvādaśakapālam bārhaspatyaṃ caruṃ vaiṣṇavaṃ trikapālam |
column2: Having kept the fire in the pan for a year in the second year he should offer on eight potsherds to Agni, to Indra on eleven potsherds, to the All-gods on twelve potsherds, to Brhaspati an oblation, to Visnu on three potsherds;

column1: tritīye saṃvatsare 'bhijitā yajeta yad aṣṭākapālo bhavaty aṣṭākṣarā gāyatry āgneyaṃ gāyatram prātaḥsavanam prātaḥsavanam eva tena dādhāra gāyatrīṃ chandas |
column2: in the third year he should sacrifice with the Abhijit (offering). In that there is (an offering) on eight potsherds, the Gayatri has eight syllables, and the morning pressing is connected with Agni and the Gayatri, verily he supports by it the morning pressing and the Gayatri metre.

column1: yad ekādaśakapālo bhavaty ekādaśākṣarā triṣṭug aindraṃ traiṣṭubham mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanam mādhyaṃdinam eva savanaṃ tena dādhāra triṣṭubham |
column2: In that there is (an offering) on eleven potsherds, the Tristubh has eleven syllables, and the midday pressing is connected with Indra and the Tristubh, verily he supports by it the midday pressing and the Tristubh [1] metre.

column1: yad dvādaśakapālo bhavati dvādaśākṣarā jagatī vaiśvadevaṃ jāgataṃ tṛtīyasavanam | tṛtīyasavanam eva tena dādhāra jagatīṃ chandas |
column2: In that there is (an offering) on twelve potsherds, the Jagati has twelve syllables, and the third pressing is connected with the All-gods and the Jagati, verily he supports by it the third pressing and the Jagati metre.

column1: yad bārhaspatyaś carur bhavati brahma vai devānām bṛhaspatis |
column2: In that there is an oblation to Brhaspati, and Brhaspati is the holy power of the gods, verily he supports by it holy power.

column1: brahmaiva tena dādhāra yad vaiṣṇavas trikapālo bhavati yajño vai viṣṇus | yajñam eva tena dādhāra yat tṛtīye saṃvatsare 'bhijitā yajate 'bhijityai yat saṃvatsaram ukhyam bibhartīmam eva |
column2: In that there is (an offering) to Visnu on three potsherds, and Visnu is the sacrifice, verily he supports by it the sacrifice. In that he sacrifices with the Abhijit in the third year, (it serves) for conquest.

column1: tena lokaṃ spṛṇoti yad dvitīye saṃvatsare 'gniṃ cinute 'ntarikṣam eva tena spṛṇoti yat tṛtīye saṃvatsare yajate 'mum eva tena lokaṃ spṛṇoti |
column2: in that he piles the fire in the second year, he saves the atmosphere by it; in that he sacrifices in the third year, he saves yonder world by it.

column1: etaṃ vai para {F āṭṇāraḥ}{W ātṇāraḥ}{GLOS āṭṇāraḥ} kakṣīvāṃ auśijo vītahavyaḥ śrāyasas trasadasyuḥ{FN corrected in IS Ed: trasadasyuḥ} paurukutsyaḥ prajākāmā acinvata tato vai te sahasraṃsahasram putrān avindanta prathate prajayā paśubhis tām mātrām āpnoti yāṃ te 'gachan ya evaṃ vidvān agniṃ cinute |
column2: This (fire) Para Atnara, Kaksivant Auçija, Vitahavya Çrayasa, and Trasadasyu Paurukutsya piled, being desirous of offspring; then indeed did they win thousands each of children; he is extended with offspring, with cattle, that measure he attains which they attained, who knowing thus piles the fire. Prajapati piled the fire; it kept being razor-edged;

column1: prajāpatir agnim acinuta sa kṣurapavir bhūtvātiṣṭhat taṃ devā bibhyato nopāyan te chandobhir ātmānaṃ chādayitvopāyan tac chandasāṃ chandastvam brahma vai chandāṃsi brahmaṇa etad rūpaṃ yat kṛṣṇājinam |
column2: the gods in terror did not approach it; they, clothing themselves in the metres, approached it, and that is why the metres have their name. The metres are holy power; the black antelope skin is the form of holy power;

column1: kārṣṇī upānahāv upa muñcate chandobhir evātmānaṃ chādayitvāgnim upa caraty ātmano 'hiṃsāyai devanidhir vā eṣa ni dhīyate yad agniḥ |
column2: he puts on a pair of black antelope skin shoes; verily clothing himself with the metres he approaches the fire, to prevent injury to himself. The fire is put down as a treasure of the gods [1].

column1: anye vā vai nidhim aguptaṃ vindanti na vā prati pra jānāti |
column2: Now a treasure unguarded others find, or he cannot recollect where it is;

column1: ukhām ā krāmaty ātmānam evādhipāṃ kurute guptyai |
column2: he steps on the fire-pan; verily he makes himself its overlord, for guardianship.

column1: atho khalv āhus |
column2: the pan is connected with Nirrti;

column1: nākramyeti nairṛty ukhā yad ākrāmen nirṛtyā ātmānam api dadhyāt tasmān nākramyā puruṣaśīrṣam upa dadhāti guptyai |
column2: if he were to step on it, he would hand himself over to Nirrti; therefore it should not be stepped on. He puts down the human head, for guardianship;

column1: atho yathā brūyāt | etan me gopāyeti tādṛg eva tat |
column2: and moreover this is just as if one should say, 'Guard that for me' [2].

column1: prajāpatir vā atharvā |
column2: Atharvan is Prajapati;

column1: agnir eva dadhyaṅṅ ātharvaṇas tasyeṣṭakā asthāni |
column2: Dadhyañc Atharvana is the fire, his bones are the bricks;

column1: indro dadhīco asthabhir iti yad iṣṭakābhir agniṃ cinoti sātmānam evāgniṃ cinute sātmāmuṣmiM loke bhavati ya evaṃ veda śarīraṃ vā etad agner yac citya ātmā vaiśvānaras |
column2: as to that the seer says, 'Indra with the bones of Dadhyañc'. In that he piles the fire with the bricks, he piles up the fire with itself; he has his own self in yonder world who knows thus. (The fire) to be piled is the body of Agni, Vaiçvanara is the self;

column1: yac cite vaiśvānaraṃ juhoti śarīram eva saṃskṛtya |
column2: in that he offers to Vaiçvanara after the piling, he prepares its [3] body and mounts it;

column1: abhyārohati śarīraṃ vā etad yajamānaḥ saṃs kurute yad agniṃ cinute yac cite vaiśvānaraṃ juhoti śasīram eva saṃskṛtyātmanābhyārohati tasmāt tasya nāva dyanti jīvann eva devān apy eti vaiśvānaryarcā purīṣam upa dadhāti |
column2: the sacrificer thus prepares his body, in that he piles the fire; in that he offers to Vaiçvanara after the piling, verily having pre pared his body he mounts it with the self; therefore they do not cut off from it; verily living he goes to the gods. He puts on dust with a verse addressed to Vaiçvanara;

column1: iyaṃ vā agnir vaiśvānaras tasyaiṣā citir yat purīṣam agnim eva vaiśvānaraṃ cinute |
column2: Agni Vaiçvanara is this (earth), the dust is its piling; verily he piles Agni Vaiçvanara;

column1: eṣā vā agneḥ priyā tanūr yad vaiśvānaraḥ priyām evāsya tanuvam ava runddhe |
column2: Vaiçvanara is the form dear to Agni; verily he wins the form dear to him.

column1: agner vai dīkṣayā devā virājam āpnuvan tisro rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt tripadā {virāṭ < virāj} virājam āpnoti ṣaḍ rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti daśa rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: The gods obtained the brilliance (virájam) of Agni by means of the consecration; for three nights should he be consecrated; the Viraj has three feet, he obtains the Viraj. For six nights should he b consecrated; the year consists of six seasons;

column1: daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti dvādaśa rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: the Viraj is the year, he obtains the Viraj. For ten nights should he be consecrated; the Viraj has ten syllables;

column1: dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti trayodaśa rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt trayodaśa |
column2: he obtains the Viraj. He should be consecrated for thirteen nights; the year has thirteen months [1]; the Viraj is the year; he obtains the Viraj.

column1: māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro {virāḍ < virāj} pañcadaśa rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt pañcadaśa vā ardhamāsasya rātrayas |
column2: For fifteen nights should he be consecrated; the nights of the half-month are fifteen; the year is made up by the half-months; the Viraj is the year;

column1: ardhamāsaśaḥ saṃvatsara āpyate saṃvatsaro {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti saptadaśa rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: he obtains the Viraj. For seventeen nights should he be consecrated; the year has twelve months and seven seasons; the Viraj is the year; he obtains the Viraj.

column1: caturviṃśatir ardhamāsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti triṃśataṃ rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: For twenty-four nights should he be consecrated; the year has twenty-four half-months; the Viraj is the year; he obtains the Viraj. For thirty nights should he be consecrated [2];

column1: triṃśadakṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti māsaṃ dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: the Viraj has thirty syllables; he obtains the Viraj. For a month should he be consecrated;

column1: yo māsaḥ sa saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro {virāḍ < virāj} virājam āpnoti caturo māso dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: the year is the month; the Viraj is the year; he obtains the Viraj. For four months should he be consecrated;

column1: caturo vā etam māso vasavo 'bibharus te pṛthivīm ājayan gāyatrīṃ chandas |
column2: for four months the Vasus bore him, they conquered the earth, the Gayatri metre;

column1: aṣṭau rudrās te 'ntarikṣam ājayan triṣṭubhaṃ chandas |
column2: for eight the Rudras, they conquered the atmosphere, the Tristubh metre;

column1: devādaśādityās te divam ājayañ jagatīṃ chandas tato vai te vyāvṛtam agachañ charaiṣṭhyaṃ devānām |
column2: for twelve the Adityas, they conquered the sky, the Jagati metre; then they attained distinction, supremacy over the gods.

column1: tasmād dvādaśa māso bhṛtvāgniṃ cinvīta dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaro 'gniś cityas tasyāhorātrāṇīṣṭakās |
column2: Therefore after keeping the fire for twelve months, should one pile it up; the year has twelve months, the fire to be piled is the year, the bricks are days and nights;

column1: āpteṣṭakam enaṃ cinute 'tho vyāvṛtam eva gachati śraiṣṭhyaṃ samānānām |
column2: he piles him with the bricks obtained; verily also he attains distinction, supremacy over his equals.

column1: suvargāya vā eṣa lokāya cīyate yad agnis taṃ yan nānvārohet suvargāl lokād yajamāno hīyeta pṛthivīm ākramiṣam prāṇo mā mā hāsīt |
column2: Agni is piled for the world of heaven; if he were not to mount after him the sacrificer would be excluded from the world of heaven. 'I have mounted on the earth; let not breath forsake me';

column1: antarikṣam ākramiṣam prajā mā mā hāsīt |
column2: 'I have mounted on the atmosphere; let not offspring forsake me';

column1: divam ākramiṣaṃ suvar aganma | ity āha |
column2: 'I have mounted on the sky, we have attained the light', he says;

column1: eṣa vā agner anvārohas tenaivainam anvārohati suvargasya lokasya samaṣṭyai yat pakṣasammitām minuyāt |
column2: this is the mounting after Agni verily by it he mounts after him, to attain the world of heaven.

column1: kanīyāṃsaṃ yajñakratum upeyāt pāpīyasy asyātmanaḥ prajā syāt |
column2: If he were to set up (the eleven posts) commensurate with the wings [1], he would make the sacrificial rite too small, his offspring would be worse off than himself.

column1: vedisammitām minoti jyāyāṃsam eva yajñakratum upaiti nāsyātmanaḥ pāpīyasī prajā bhavati sāhasraṃ cinvīta prathamaṃ cinvānaḥ sahasrasammito vā ayaṃ lokas |
column2: verily he makes the sacrificial rite larger, his offspring does not become worse than himself. He should pile (the fire) of a thousand (bricks) when first piling (it); this world is commensurate with a thousand;

column1: imam eva lokam abhi jayati dviṣāhasraṃ cinvīta dvitīyaṃ cinvānas |
column2: verily he conquers this world. He should pile (it) of two thousand when piling a second time;

column1: dviṣāhasraṃ vā antarikṣam antarikṣam evābhi jayati triṣāhasraṃ cinvīta tṛtīyaṃ cinvānaḥ |
column2: He should pile (it) of three thousand when piling for the third time [2]; yonder world is commensurate with three thousand; verily he conquers yonder world.

column1: triṣāhasro vā asau loko 'mum eva lokam abhi jayati jānudaghnaṃ cinvīta prathamaṃ civānas |
column2: Knee deep should he pile (it), when piling for the first time; verily with the Gayatri he mounts this world;

column1: gāyatriyaivemaṃ lokam abhyārohati nābhidaghnaṃ cinvīta dvitīyaṃ cinvānas triṣṭubhaivāntarikṣam abhyārohati grīvadaghnaṃ cinvīta tṛtīyaṃ cinvānas |
column2: navel deep should he pile (it) when piling for the second time; verily with the Tristubh he mounts the atmosphere; neck deep should he pile (it) when piling for the third time; verily with the Jagati he mounts yonder world.

column1: jagatyaivāmuṃ lokam abhyārohati nāgniṃ citvā rāmām upeyād ayonau reto dhāsyāmīti na dvitīyaṃ citvānyasya striyam | upeyāt | na tṛtīyaṃ citvā kāṃ canopeyāt |
column2: After piling the fire he should not have intercourse with a woman of pleasure, thinking, 'I shall deposit seed in that which is no womb'; nor after piling for the second time should he have intercourse with the wife of another [3], nor after piling for a third time should he have intercourse with any woman whatever.

column1: reto vā etan ni dhatte yad agniṃ cinute yad upeyād retasā vy ṛdhyeta |
column2: In that he piles the fire, he deposits seed; if he were to have intercourse.

column1: atho khalv āhus |
column2: he would be deprived of seed.

column1: aprajasyaṃ tad yan nopeyād iti yad retaḥsicāv upadadhāti te eva yajamānasya reto bibhṛtas tasmād upeyād retaso 'skandāya trīṇi vāva retāṃsi pitā putraḥ pautraḥ |
column2: Or rather they say, 'If he were not to have intercourse, there would be no offspring.' In that he puts down the two Retahsic (bricks), they support the seed of the sacrificer; therefore he should have intercourse, for the non-spilling of seed.' Three seeds are there, father, son, grandson [4];

column1: yad dve retaḥsicāv upadadhyād reto 'sy vi chindyāt tisra upa dadhāti retasaḥ saṃtatyai |
column2: if he were to put down two Retahsic (bricks), he would cleave his seed; three he puts down, for the continuity of seed;

column1: iyaṃ vāva prathamā retaḥsig vāg vā iyaṃ tasmāt paśyantīmām paśyanti vācaṃ vadantīm antarikṣaṃ dvitīyā prāṇo vā antarikṣaṃ tasmān nāntarikṣam paśyanti na prāṇam asau tṛtīyā cakṣur vā asau tasmāt paśyanty amūm paśyanti cakṣus |
column2: the first Retahsic is this (earth), this (earth) is speech, therefore they see this (earth), they see speech speaking; the second is the atmosphere, the atmosphere is breath, therefore they see not the atmosphere, nor breath; the third is yonder (sky), yonder (sky) is the eye, therefore they see yonder (sky), they see the eye.

column1: yajuṣemāṃ ca | amūṃcopa dadhāti manasā madhyamām eṣāṃ lokānāṃ klptyai |
column2: With Yajus he sets down this one [5] and yonder one, but with mind only the middle, to arrange these worlds, and also the breaths.

column1: atho prāṇānām iṣṭo yajño bhṛgubhir āśīrdā vasubhis tasya ta iṣṭasya vītasya draviṇeha bhakṣīyety āha stutaśastre evaitena duhe pitā mātariśvāchidrā padā dhā achidrā uśijaḥ padānu takṣuḥ somo viśvavin netā neṣad bṛhaspatir ukthāmadāni śaṃsiṣad ity āha |
column2: 'The sacrifice offered by the Bhrgus, the Vasus, accord our desires; of thee thus offered, enjoyed, may I here enjoy wealth,' he says; verily he milks thereby the song and the recitation. 'Father Matariçvan, bestow flawless abodes; the flawless abodes the Uçijs have made;

column1: etad vā agner uktham | tenaivainam anu śaṃsati |
column2: that is Agni's hymn, and with it he recites after him.

column1: sūyate vā eṣo 'gnīnāṃ ya ukhāyām bhriyate yad adhaḥ sādayed garbhāḥ prapādukāḥ syus | atho yathā savāt pratyavarohati tādṛg eva tat |

column2: man is sixfold [1], the body, the head, four limbs;

column1: horātrāṇy evāsya prājāpatyās |
column2: the Prajapati (bricks) are the days and nights;

column2: in that he piles the fire with bricks, and Viçvakarman is this (earth), verily he puts down the Viçvakarman (bricks). Therefore they say, 'Threefold is Agni.' column1: agnim eva tat spṛṇoti |
column2: verily thus he preserves his fire.

column1: prajāpatir agnim acinutartubhiḥ saṃvatsaram |
column2: Prajapati piled the fire as the year by the seasons;

column2: by the spring he piled its front half, by the summer its right wing, by the rains its tail, by the autumn its left wing, by the winter its middle. By the Brahman class he piled its front half, by the lordly class its right wing, by cattle its tail, by the people its left wing, by hope its middle.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān agniṃ cinuta ṛtubhir evainaṃ cinute |
column2: He who knowing thus piles the fire piles it with the seasons;

column1: atho etad eva sarvam ava |
column2: verily he wins all [1];

column1: runddhe śṛṇvanty enam agniṃ cikyānam atty annam | rocate |
column2: they hearken to him who has piled the fire, he eats food, he is resplendent.

column2: The first layer is this (earth), the mortar the plants and trees; the second is the atmosphere, the mortar the birds; the third is yonder (sky), the mortar the Naksatras;

column2: verily he preserves all. In that there [2] are three layers, (it is) since Agni is threefold;

column1: yad dve dvipād yajamānaḥ pratiṣṭhityai pañca citayo bhavanti pāṅktaḥ puruṣas |
column2: in that there are two (more), the sacrificer has two feet, (it is) for support; there are five layers, man is five fold;

column2: verily he preserves himself. There are five layers, he covers (them) with five (sets of) mortar, these make up ten, man has ten elements;

column1: yāvān eva puruṣas taṃ spṛṇoti |
column2: he preserves man in his full extent.

column1: atho daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājy evānnādye prati tiṣṭhati saṃvatsaro vai ṣaṣṭhī citis |

column1: ṣaṭ citayo bhavanti ṣaṭ purīṣāṇi dvādaśa sam padyante dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsara eva prati tiṣṭhati |

column2: the brown, the reddish-brown, the parrot brown, these are for Rudra. The white, the white-eyed, the white-necked, these have the fathers as their deities. Three black barren cows are for Varuna, three white barren cows for the Sun;

column2: the red-spotted hornless ones are for Indra and Brhaspati.

column1: somaindrā babhrulalāmās tūparāḥ |
column2: the brown-spotted hornless ones are for Soma and Indra.

column2: verily he piles the fire according to the deity. He falls not a victim to the deities;

column1: etad ahnaḥ |

column1: aśvam ava ghrāpayati |
column2: he causes the horse to sniff it;

column1: tvām agne vṛṣabhaṃ cekitānam punar yuvānam janayann upāgām |

column1: paśavo vā ete yad iṣṭakāś cityāṃcityām ṛṣabham upa dadhāti mithunam evāsya tad yajñe karoti prajananāya tasmād yūthe-yūtha ṛṣabhaḥ saṃvatsarasya pratimāṃ yāṃ tvā rātry upāsate | prajāṃ suvīrāṃ kṛtvā viśvam āyur vy aśnavat |
column2: The bricks are cattle, in each layer he puts down a bull (brick); verily in his sacrifice he makes a pairing for propagation; therefore in every herd there is a bull. The image of the year Which men revere in thee, O night, Making his offspring rich in heroes, May he obtain all life.

column1: prājāpatyām |
column2: He puts down this Prajapati (brick) [1];

column1: etām upa dadhātīyaṃ vāvaiṣaikāṣṭakā yad evaikāṣṭakāyām annaṃ kriyate tad evaitayāva runddhe |
column2: the sole eighth day is this (earth); in that food is made on the sole eighth day, he wins it thereby;

column1: eṣā vai prajāpateḥ kāmadughā tayaiva yajamāno 'muṣmiM loke 'gniṃ duhe yena devā jyotiṣordhvā udāyan yenādityā vasavo yena rudrāḥ | yenāṅgiraso mahimānam ānaśus tenaitu yajamānaḥ svasti |
column2: this is the wish cow of Prajapati; verily by it the sacrificer in yonder world milks the fire. With the light wherewith the gods went upward, Wherewith the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, Wherewith the Angirases attained greatness, With that let the sacrificer go in prosperity.

column1: suvargāya vā eṣa lokāya |

column2: (with the words) With the light wherewith the gods went upwards', he lights the fire in the pan; verily he puts down the bricks connected with the trees, to win the world of heaven. (Homage) to the hundred-weaponed, him of a hundred powers, Him of a hundred aids, the overcomer of hostility, To Indra who shall lead us over all obstacles Through autumns without fail.

column1: ye catvāraḥ pathayo devayānā antarā dyāvāpṛthivī viyanti | teṣāṃ yo ajyānim ajītim āvahāt tasmai no devāḥ | pari datteha sarve |
column2: The four paths going to the gods Which stretch between sky and earth, To him, O gods, do ye all accord us Who brought to them unfailing power and untirelessness [3].

column1: grīṣmo hemanta uta no vasantaḥ śarad varṣāḥ suvitaṃ no astu |
column2: Summer, winter, and spring for us, Autumn, the rains be favourable for us;

column1: teṣām ṛtūnāṃ śataśāradānāṃ nivāta eṣāṃ abhaye syāma |
column2: May we enjoy the favour and protection Of these seasons through a hundred autumns.

column1: iduvatsarāya parivatsarāya saṃvatsarāya kṛṇutā bṛhan namaḥ | teṣāṃ vayaṃ sumatau yajñiyānāṃ jyog ajītā ahatāḥ syāma |
column2: To the Idu year, the complete year, the year Pay ye honour great; In their lovingkindness that are worthy of sacrifice May we long be unfailing, unsmitten.
