The theologians say, 'Neither by Rc nor by Saman is the five made up; what then is the fivefold character of the sacrifice?' Fried grains, mush, rice grains, the cake, clotted milk, thereby the five is made up;

column1: suvargāya vā etāni lokāya hūyante yad dākṣiṇāni dvābhyāṃ gārhapatye juhoti dvipād yajamānaḥ pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: The Exposition of the Daksina and other Offerings The sacrifices with the gifts are offered for the world of heaven. He offers with two (verses) on the Garhapatya; the sacrificer has two feet;

column1: āgnīdhre juhoti |
column2: He offers in the Agnidh's altar;

column2: the learned man is a Brahman, a seer and sprung from seers; therefore he says thus. 'Gaze on the heaven, gaze on the atmosphere', he says; verily he makes him go to the world of' heaven. 'Join those in the seat', he says, for friendship.

column1: asmaddātrā devatrā gachata madhumatīḥ pra dātāram ā viśatety āha vayam iha pradātāraḥ smo 'smān amutra madhumatīr ā viśateti |
column2: 'Given by us, go to the gods, full of sweetness; enter the giver', he says; 'we here are givers; do ye there enter us, full of sweetness' [4], he says in effect.

column1: vāvaitad āha hiraṇyaṃ dadāti otir vai hiraṇyam |
column2: He gives gold; gold is light;

column1: jyotir eva purastād dhatte suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai |
column2: verily he places light before, to light up the world of heaven.

column1: agnīdhe dadāti |
column2: He gives to the Agnidh;

column1: agnimukhān evartūn prīṇāti brahmaṇe dadāti prasūtyai hotre dadāti |
column2: he gives to the Brahman priest, for instigation; he gives to the Hotr;

column1: ātmā vā eṣa yajñasya yad dhotā |
column2: the Hotr is the self of the sacrifice;

column1: ātmānam eva yajñasya dakṣiṇābhiḥ sam ardhayati |
column2: verily he unites the self of the sacrifice with the gifts.

column1: samiṣṭayajūṃṣi juhoti yajñasya samiṣṭyai yad vai yajñasya krūraṃ yad viliṣṭaṃ yad atyeti yan nātyeti yad atikaroti yan nāpi karoti tad eva taiḥ prīṇāti nava juhoti nava vai puruṣe prāṇāḥ puruṣeṇa yajñaḥ sammitas |
column2: He offers the Samistayajuses, for the completion of the sacrifice. Whatever is harsh or injured in the sacrifice, what he passes over, what he does not pass over, what he does redundantly, what he does not do, all that he propitiates with them. He offers nine; nine are the breaths in man, the sacrifice is commensurate with man;

column1: yāvān eva yajñas tam prīṇāti ṣaḍ ṛgmiyāṇi juhoti ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: all the sacrifice he delights thus. He offers six with Rcs; the seasons are six;

column1: ṛtūn eva prīṇāti trīṇi yajūṃṣi |
column2: verily he delights the seasons; he offers three with Yajuses [1];

column1: traya ime lokās |
column2: these worlds are three;

column1: imān eva lokān prīṇāti yajña yajñaṃ gacha yajñapatiṃ gachety āha yajñapatim evainaṃ gamayati svām yoniṃ gachety āha svām evainaṃ yoniṃ gamayati |
column2: verily he delights these worlds. 'O sacrifice, go to the sacrifice; go to the lord of the sacrifice', he says; verily he makes it go to the lord of the sacrifice. 'Go to thine own birthplace', he says;

column1: ṣa te yajño yajñapate sahasūktavākaḥ suvīra ity āha yajamāma eva vīryaṃ dadhāti vāsiṣṭho ha sātyahavyo devabhāgam papracha yat sṛñjayān bahuyājino 'yīyajo yajñe | yajñam praty atiṣṭhipā yajñapatāv iti sa hovāca yajñapatāv iti satyād vai sṛñjayāḥ parā babhūvur iti hovāca yajñe vāva yajñaḥ pratiṣṭhāpya āsīd yajamānasyāparābhāvāyeti devā gātuvido gātuṃ vittvā gātum itety āha yajña eva yajñam prati ṣṭhāpayati yajamānasyāparābhāvāya |
column2: 'This is thy sacrifice, O lord of the sacrifice, with its, utterance of hymns and producing noble heroes', he says; verily he confers strength upon the sacrificer. Vasistha Satyahavya asked Devabhaga, 'When thou didst cause to sacrifice the Srñjayas, with many sacrificers, didst thou cause the sacrifice to rest upon the sacrifice [2] or on the lord of the sacrifice? He replied, 'On the lord of the sacrifice.' 'But in truth Srñjayas have been defeated', he said, 'the sacrifice should have been made to rest on the sacrifice, to prevent the defeat of the sacrificer.' 'Ye gods, that find the way, finding the way, go on the way', he says;

column1: avabhṛthayajūṃṣi juhoti yad evārvācīnam ekahāyanād enaḥ karoti tad eva tair ava yajate |
column2: He offers the Avabhrthayajuses; whatever sin he has committed in the year before, verily that thereby he propitiates.

column1: apo 'vabhṛtham avaiti |
column2: Varuna is in the waters;

column1: apsu vai varuṇaḥ sākṣād eva varuṇam ava yajate vartmanā vā anvitya yajñaṃ rakṣāṃsi jighāṃsanti sāmnā prastotānvavaiti sāma vai rakṣohā rakṣasām apahatyai trir nidhanam upaiti traya ime lokās |
column2: verily straightway he propitiates Varuna. The Raksases, following along by the path, seek to injure the sacrifice; the Prastotr follows along with the Saman, the slayer of Raksases, is the Saman; (verily it serves) for the smiting away of the Raksases. Thrice he performs the finale;

column1: ebhya eva lokebhyo rakṣāṃsi |
column2: verily from these worlds [1] he smites away the Raksases.

column1: apa hanti puruṣaḥpuruṣo nidhanam upaiti puruṣaḥpuruṣo hi rakṣasvī rakṣasām apahatyai |
column2: Each one performs the finale; for each one is infested by the Raksases, for the smiting away of the Raksases.

column1: uruṃ hi rājā varuṇaś cakārety āha pratiṣṭhityai śataṃ te rājan bhiṣajaḥ sahasram ity āha bheṣajam evāsmai karoti |
column2: 'King Varuna hath made a broad (path)', he says, for support. 'A hundred remedies are thine, O king, a thousand', he says; verily he makes medicine for him.

column1: abhiṣṭhito varuṇasya pāśa ity āha varuṇapāśam evābhi tiṣṭhati barhir abhi juhoti | āhutīnām pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: 'The noose of Varuna is overcome', he says verily he overcomes the noose of Varuna. He makes offering over the strew, for the support of the oblations;

column1: atho agnivaty eva juhoti |
column2: verily also he offers in what has fire.

column1: apabarhiṣaḥ prayājān |
column2: the strew is offspring;

column1: yajati prajā vai barhiḥ prajā eva varuṇapāśān muñcati |
column2: verily he frees offspring from Varuna's noose. He offers the two portions of butter;

column1: ājyabhāgau yajati yajñasyaiva cakṣuṣī nāntar eti varuṇaṃ yajati varuṇapāśād evainam muñcati |
column2: verily he does not obstruct the two eyes of the sacrifice. He sacrifices to Varuna; verily he frees him from Varuna's noose.

column1: agnīvaruṇau yajati sākṣād evainaṃ varuṇapāśān muñcati |
column2: He sacrifices to Agni and Varuna; verily straightway he frees him from Varuna's noose.

column1: apabarhiṣāv anūyajau yajati prajā vai barhiḥ prajā eva varuṇapāśān muñcati caturaḥ prayājān yajati dvāv anūyājau ṣaṭ sam padyante ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ |
column2: He offers two after-offerings, omitting that to the strew; the strew is offspring; verily he frees offspring from Varuna's noose. He offers four fore-offerings and two after-offerings; they make up six, the seasons are six [3];

column1: ṛtuṣv eva prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: verily he finds support in the seasons.

column1: avabhṛtha nicaṅkuṇety āha yathoditam eva varuṇam ava yajate samudre te hṛdayam apsv antar ity āha samudrehy antar varuṇaḥ saṃ tvā viśantv oṣadhīr utāpa ity āha |
column2: 'O bath, O flood', he says; verily he propitiates by this utterance Varuna. In the sea is thy heart, within the waters', he says, for Varuna is in the sea. 'Let the plants and the waters enter thee" he says;

column1: adbhir evainam oṣadhībhiḥ samyañcaṃ dadhāti devīr āpa eṣa vo garbha ity āha yathāyajur evaitat paśavo vai |
column2: verily he unites him with the waters and the plants. 'Ye divine waters, this is thy foetus', he says; that is according to the text.

column1: somas |
column2: The Soma is cattle [4];

column1: yad bhindūnām bhakṣayet paśumānt syād varuṇas tv enaṃ gṛhṇīyāt |
column2: if he were to partake of the drops, he would be possessed of cattle, but Varuna would seize him;

column1: yan na bhakṣayed apaśuḥ syān nainaṃ varuṇo gṛhṇīyāt |
column2: if he were not to partake, he would have no cattle, but Varuna would not seize him;

column1: upaspṛśyam eva paśumān bhavati nainaṃ varuṇo gṛhṇāti pratiyuto varuṇasya pāśa ity āha varuṇapāśād eva nir mucyate |
column2: he should touch them only, he becomes possessed of cattle, Varuna seizes him not. 'The noose of Varuna is loosed', he says; verily is he freed from Varuna's noose.

column1: apratīkṣam ā yanti varuṇasyāntarhityai |
column2: They advance without looking round, for concealment from Varuna.

column1: edho 'sy edhiṣīmahīty āha samidhaivāgniṃ namasyanta upāyanti tejo 'si tejo mayi dhehīty āha teja evātman dhatte |
column2: verily with the kindling-stick they approach the fire in reverence. 'Thou art brilliance; grant me brilliance', he says; verily he bestows brilliance upon himself.

column1: sphyena vedim ud dhanti rathākṣeṇa vi mimīte yūpam minoti trivṛtam eva vajraṃ sambhṛtya bhrātṛvyāya pra harati stṛtyai yad antarvedi minuyād devalokam abhi jayed yad bahirvedi manuṣyalokaṃ vedyantasya saṃdhau minoty ubhayor lokayor abhijityai |
column2: With the wooden sword he digs up the altar, with the axle of a chariot he measures. He sets up the sacrificial post; verily gathering together a threefold bolt he hurls it at his foe, to lay him low. If he were to set it up within the altar, he would win the world of the gods; if outside the altar, the world of men;

column1: uparasammitām minuyāt pitṛlokakāmasya raśanasammitām manuṣyalokakāmasya caṣālasammitām indriyakāmasya sarvānt samān pratiṣṭhākāmasya ye trayo madhyamās tānt samān paśukāmasyaitān vai |
column2: He should set (the set) up with the lower parts alike for one who desires the world of the Pitrs, with the girdle part alike for one who desires the world of men, with the top pieces alike for one who desires power, and all alike for one who desires support; the three in the middle alike for one who desires cattle;

column1: anu paśava upa tiṣṭhante paśumān eva bhavati vyatiṣajed itarān prajayaivainam paśubhir vyatiṣajati yaṃ kāmayeta pramāyukaḥ syād iti gartamitaṃ tasya minuyād uttarārdhyaṃ varṣiṣṭham atha hrasīyāṃsam eṣā vai gartamid yasyaivam minoti tājak pra mīyate dakṣiṇārdhyaṃ varṣiṣṭham minuyāt suvargakāmasyātha hrasīyāṃsam ākramaṇam eva tat setuṃ yajamānaḥ kurute suvargasya lokasya samaṣṭyai |
column2: If he desire of a man, 'May he be liable to die', he should set it up for him in grave fashion, the northern half the higher, then (the southern) the lower; this is the grave fashion; he for whom he sets it up thus swiftly dies. For him who desires the heaven he should set it up with the southern half the higher, then the (northern) half the lower; verily the sacrificer makes it a ladder and a bridge to attain the world of heaven [2].

column1: yad ekasmin yūpe dve raśane parivyayati tasmād eko dve jāye vindate yan naikāṃ raśanāṃ dvayor yūpayoḥ parivyayati tasmān naikā dvau patī vindate yaṃ kāmayeta stry asya jāyetety upānte tasya vyatiṣajet stry evāsya jāyate yaṃ kāmayeta pumān asya jāyetety āntaṃ tasya pra veṣṭayet pumān evāsya |
column2: In that on one post he twines round two girdles, therefore one man wins two wives; in that he does not wind one girdle round two posts, therefore one wife does not find two husbands. If he desire of a man, 'Be a girl born to him', he should intertwine (the girdles) near the ends; verily a girl is born to him; if he desire of a man, 'Be a son born to him', he should cover it round right up to the end;

column1: jāyate |
column2: verily a son is born to him [3].

column1: asurā vai devān dakṣiṇata upānayan tān devā upaśayenaivāpānudanta tad upaśayasyopaśayatvaṃ yad dakṣiṇata upaśaya upaśaye bhrātṛvyāpanuttyai sarve vā anye yūpāḥ paśumanto 'thopaśaya evāpaśus tasya yajamānaḥ paśur yan na nirdiśed ārtim ārched yajamāno 'sau te paśur iti nir diśed yaṃ dviṣyād yam eva |
column2: The Asuras drove the gods to the south, the gods repelled them by the Upaçaya (post); that is why the Upaçaya has its name. In that the Upaçaya lies near (upaçáye) on the south, (it serves) to drive away the foe. All the other posts have victims (attached), the Upaçaya has none, its victim is the sacrificer; if he were not to indicate (a victim), the sacrificer would be ruined.

column1: dveṣṭi tam asmai paśuṃ nir diśati yadi na dviṣyād ākhus te paśur iti brūyān na grāmyān paśūn hinasti nāraṇyān prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata so 'nnādyena vy ārdhyata sa etām ekādaśinīm apaśyat tayā vai so 'nnādyam avārunddha yad daśa yūpā bhavanti daśākṣarā virāḍ annaṃ virāḍ virājaivānnādyam ava runddhe |
column2: If he hates not, 'The mole is thy victim', he should say; he harms not domestic nor wild animals. Prajapati created offspring; he was destitute of proper food, he saw this set of eleven, and therewith he won proper food. In that there are ten posts, the Viraj has ten syllables, and the Viraj is food, he wins proper food by the Viraj [5];

column1: ya ekādaśa stana evāsyai sa duha evaināṃ tena vajro vā eṣā sam mīyate yad ekādaśinī seśvarā purastāt pratyañcaṃ yajñaṃ sammarditor yat pātnīvatam minoti yajñasya praty uttabdhyai sayatvāya |
column2: In that the set of eleven (is set up), thunderbolt is set up; it is liable to crush the sacrifice face to face; in that he sets up (the stake) (for Tvastr) with the wives, (it serves) to establish the sacrifice and to bind.

column1: prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata sa riricāno 'manyata sa etām ekādaśinīm apaśyat tayā vai sa āyur indriyaṃ vīryam ātmann adhatta prajā iva khalu vā eṣa sṛjate yo yajate sa etarhi riricāna iva yad eṣaikādaśinī bhavaty āyur eva tayendriyaṃ vīryaṃ yajamāna atman dhatte praivāgneyena vāpayati mithunaṃ sārasvatyā karoti retaḥ |
column2: Prajapati created offspring; he thought himself emptied, he saw this set of eleven (victims), with it he bestowed life, power, and strength upon himself; he who sacrifices creates as it were offspring; then he is as it were emptied; in that this set of eleven is (offered), with it the sacrificer bestows life, power, and strength upon himself.

column1: saumyena dadhāti pra janayati pauṣṇena bārhaspatyo bhavati brahma vai devānām bṛhaspatir brahmaṇaivāsmai prajāḥ pra janayati vaiśvadevo bhavati vaiśvadevyo vai prajāḥ prajā evāsmai pra janayatīndriyam evaindreṇāvarunddhe viśam mārutenaujo balam aindrāgnena prasavāya sāvitro nirvaruṇatvāya vāruṇas |
column2: With (the victim) for Agni he scatters, with that for Sarasvati he makes a pairing, with that for Soma he impregnates seed [1], with that for Pusan he propagates. There is one for Brhaspati; Brhaspati is the holy power (Brahman) of the gods; verily with the holy power (Brahman) he produces offspring for him. There is one for the All-gods;

column1: madhyata aindram ā labhate madhyata evendriyaṃ yajamāne dadhāti |
column2: In the middle he offers that for Indra; verily in the middle he bestows power on the sacrificer [2].

column1: purastād aindrasya vaiśvadevam ālabhate vaiśvadevaṃ vā annam annam eva purastād dhatte tasmāt purastād annam adyata aindram ālabhya mārutam ā labhate viḍ vai maruto viśam evāsmā anu badhnāti yadi kāmayeta yo 'vagataḥ so 'pa rudhyatāṃ yo 'paruddhaḥ so 'va gachatv ity aindrasya loke vāruṇam ā labheta vāruṇasya loka aindram |
column2: If he desire, 'May he who has attained (power) be banished; may he who is banished return (to power)', in the place of that for Indra he should offer that for Varuna, in the place of that for Varuna that for Indra [3]. He who has attained (power) is banished, he who is banished returns (to power). If he desire, 'May the people fall into confusion', he should interchange the animals;

column1: ya evāvagataḥ so 'pa rudhyate yo 'paruddhaḥ so 'va gachati yadi kāmayeta prajā muhyeyur iti paśūn vyatiṣajet prajā eva mohayati yad abhivāhato 'pāṃ vāruṇam ālabheta prajā varuṇo gṛhṇīyād dakṣiṇata udañcam ā labhate 'pavāhato 'pām prajānām avaruṇagrāhāya |
column2: verily he causes the people to fall into confusion. If he should offer that to Varuna along the stream of the waters, Varuna would seize his offspring; he offers (the victim) facing north on the south side against the stream of the waters, to prevent Varuna seizing his offspring. Indra caused Manu to sacrifice with his wife; after she had been encircled with fire he let her go;

column1: indraḥ patniyā manum ayājayat tām paryagnikṛtām ud asṛjat tayā manur ārdhnod yat paryagnikṛtam pātnīvatam utsṛjati yām eva manur ṛddhim ārdhnot tām eva yajamāna ṛdhnoti yajñasya vā apratiṣṭhitād yajñaḥ parā bhavati yajñam parābhavantaṃ yajamāno 'nu parā bhavati yad ājyeṇa pātnīvataṃ saṃsthāpayati yajñasya pratiṣṭhityai yajñam pratitiṣṭhantaṃ yajamāno 'nu prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: From what is unsupported in the sacrifice the sacrifice comes to ruin; as the sacrifice comes to ruin the sacrificer comes to ruin along with it; in that he completes (the offering) (for Tvastr) with the wives with butter, (it serves) to support the sacrifice, and as the sacrifice finds support, the sacrificer finds support along with it. The offering of the caul [1] has been performed, the offering of the cow is not yet over, then he performs (the offering) (for Tvastr) with the wives; verily he performs it at the right moment;

column1: iṣṭaṃ vapayā |
column2: It is for Tvastr;

column1: bhavati aniṣṭaṃ vaśayātha pātnīvatena pra carati tīrtha eva pra caraty atho etarhy evāsya yāmas tvāṣṭro bhavati tvaṣṭā vai retasaḥ siktasya rūpāṇi vi karoti tam eva vṛṣāṇam patnīṣv api sṛjati so 'smai rūpāṇi vi karoti |
column2: Tvastr of the seed that is spilt moulds forms, him he sets loose as a male among wives; he for him moulds forms.

column1: ghnanati vā etat somaṃ yad abhiṣuṇvanti yat saumyo bhavati yathā mṛtāyānustaraṇīṃ ghnanti tādṛg eva tat |
column2: They kill the Soma in that they press it; in that there is (an oblation) of Soma, that is as when they slay for the dead a barren cow.

column1: yad uttarārdhe vā madhye vā juhuyāt devatābhyaḥ samadaṃ dadhyād dakṣiṇārdhe juhoty eṣā vai pitṝṇāṃ dik svāyām eva diśi pit ṝn niravadayate |
column2: If he were to offer in the northern half or the middle, he would cause conflict with the gods; he offers on the southern half; this is the quarter of the Pitrs; verily in their own quarter he propitiates the Pitrs.

column1: udgātṛbhyo haranti sāmadavatyo vai saumyo yad eva sāmnaś chambaṭkurvanti tasyaiva sa śāntis |
column2: whatever of the Saman they do amiss, that is the atonement for it. They look at [1] (the victim) for Soma is a purifier;

column1: ava |
column2: verily they purify themselves.

column1: īkṣante pavitraṃ vai saumya ātmānam eva pavayante ya ātmānaṃ na paripaśyed itāsuḥ syād abhidadiṃ kṛtvāvekṣeta tasmin hy ātmānam paripaśyaty atho ātmānam eva pavayate yo gatamanāḥ syāt so 'vekṣeta yan me manaḥ parāgataṃ yad vā me aparāgatam | rājñā somena tad vayam asmāsu dhārayāmasīti mana evātman dādhāra |
column2: He who cannot see himself would be dead. Having made it full all round, he should look at (it), for in it he sees himself; verily also he purifies himself. He whose mind is gone should look at (it), (saying), 'That mind of mine which hath gone away, or which hath gone elsewhere, by means of King Soma, we keep within us';

column1: na gatamanā bhavati |
column2: verily he keeps his mind in himself [2], his mind is not gone.

column1: apa vai tṛtīyasavane yajñaḥ krāmatījānād anījānam abhy āgnāvaiṣṇavyarcā ghṛtasya yajaty agniḥ sarvā devatā viṣṇur yajño devatāś caiva yajñaṃ ca dādhāra |
column2: At the third pressing the sacrifice departs from him who has sacrificed to him who has not sacrificed; he offers ghee with a verse to Agni and Visnu; all the deities are Agni, the sacrifice is Visnu; verily he supports the deities and the sacrifice.

column1: upāṃśu yajati mithunatvāya brahmavādino vadanti mitro yajñasya sviṣṭaṃ yuvate varuṇo duriṣṭaṃ kva tarhi yajñaḥ kva yajamāno bhavatīti yan maitrāvaruṇīṃ vaśām ālabhate mitreṇaiva |
column2: He sacrifices muttering, for pairing. The theologians say, 'Mitra appropriates the well-performed part of the sacrifice, Varuna the ill-performed; where then is the sacrifice, and where the sacrificer?;

column1: yajñasya sviṣṭaṃ śamayati varuṇena duriṣṭaṃ nārtim ārchati yajamānas |
column2: In that he offers a cow to Mitra and Varuna, by Mitra [3] he propitiates the well-performed part of the sacrifice, by Varuna the ill-performed; the sacrificer is not ruined.

column1: yathā vai lāṅgaleno 'rvarām prabhindanty evam ṛksāme yajñam pra bhintto yan maitrāvaruṇīṃ vaśām ālabhate yajñāyaiva prabhinnāya matyam anvavāsyati śāntyai yātayāmāni vā etasya chandāṃsi ya ījānaś chandasām eṣa raso yad vaśā yan maitrāvaruṇīṃ vaśām ālabhate chandāṃsy eva punar ā prīṇāty ayātayāmatvāyātho chandaḥsv eva rasaṃ dadhāti |
column2: Even as men plough the field with the plough, so do the Rc and the Saman plough the sacrifice; in that he offers a cow to Mitra and Varuna, verily he rolls a roller over the ploughed-up sacrifice, for atonement. The metres of him who has sacrificed are worn out, the cow is the sap of the metres; in that he offers the cow to Mitra and Varuna, he again delights the metres, to drive away weariness; verily also he bestows sap upon the metres.

column1: devā vā indriyaṃ vīryaṃ vy abhajanta tato yad atyaśiṣyata tad atigrāhyā abhavan tad atigrāhyāṇām atigrāhyatvam |
column2: The gods divided up power and strength; what there was left over became the Atigrahya cups, and that is why the Atigrahyas have their name.

column1: yad atigrāhyā gṛhyanta indriyam eva tad vīryaṃ yajamāna ātman dhatte teja āgneyenendriyam aindreṇa brahmavarcasaṃ sauryeṇa |
column2: In that the Atigrahyas are drawn, verily thus the sacrificer bestows. upon himself power and strength, brilliance by that for Agni, power by that for Indra, splendour by that for Surya.

column1: upastambhanaṃ vā etad yajñasya yad atigrāhyāś cakre pṛṣṭhāni yat pṛṣṭhye na gṛhṇīyāt prāñcaṃ yajñam pṛṣṭhāni saṃ śṛṇīyus |
column2: The Atigrahyas are the support of the sacrifice, the Prsthas are the two wheels, if he were not to. draw them in the Prsthya (rite), the Prsthas would destroy the sacrifice in front;

column1: gṛhṇīyāt pratyañcaṃ yajñam atigrāhyāḥ saṃ śṛṇīyus |
column2: if he were to draw them in the Ukthya [1], the Atigrahyas would destroy the sacrifice behind;

column1: viśvajiti sarvapṛṣṭhe grahītavyā yajñasya savīryatvāya prajāpatir devebhyo yajñān vyādiśat sa priyās tanūr apa ny adhatta tad atigrāhyā abhavan vitanus tasya yajña ity āhur yasyātigrāhyā na gṛhyanta iti | apy agniṣṭome grāhītavyā yajñasya satanutvāya devatā vai sarvāḥ sadṛśīr āsan tā na vyāvṛtam agachan te devāḥ |
column2: but they should be drawn in the Viçvajit with all the Prsthas, so that the sacrifice may have all its strength. Prajapati indicated the sacrifices to the gods, he put away their dear forms, they became the Atigrahya; 'Bodiless is his sacrifice', they say, 'for whom the Atigrahyas are not drawn.' They should be drawn also in the Agnistoma, so that the sacrifice may have its body. All the deities were alike, and were not discriminated;

column1: eta etān grahān apaśyan tān agṛhṇata | āgneyam agnir aindram indraḥ sauryaṃ sūryas tato vai te 'nyābhir devatābhir vyāvṛtam agachan yasyaivaṃ viduṣa ete grahā gṛhyante vyāvṛtam eva pāpmanā bhrātṛvyeṇa gachati |
column2: these gods [2] saw these cups and drew them, Agni that for Agni, Indra that for Indra, Surya that for Surya; then indeed were they discriminated from the other gods; he, for whom knowing thus these cups are drawn, is discriminated from his evil foe.

column1: ime lokā jyotiṣmantaḥ samāvadvīryāḥ kāryā ity āhus |
column2: 'These worlds must be made full of light, with like strength', they say;

column1: āgneyenāsmiM loke jyotir dhatta aindreṇāntarikṣe | indravāyū hi sayujau sauryeṇāmuṣmiM loke |
column2: verily with that for Agni he bestows light on this world, with that for Indra on the atmosphere, for Indra and Vayu are yokefellows;

column1: jyotir dhatte jyotiṣmanto 'smā ime lokā bhavanti samāvadvīryān enān kurute |
column2: with that for Surya on yonder world [3] he bestows light; full of light these worlds become for him;

column1: etān vai grahān bambāviśvavayasāv avittām | tābhyām ime lokāḥ parāñcaś cārvāñcaś ca prābhus |
column2: Bamba and Viçvavayasa found these cups, and to them these worlds, the distant and the near, became revealed;

column1: yasyaivaṃ viduṣa ete grahā gṛhyante prāsmā ime lokāḥ parāñcaś cārvāñcaś ca bhānti |
column2: to him, for whom knowing thus these cups are drawn, these worlds, the distant and the near, become revealed.

column1: devā vai yad yajñe 'kurvata tad asurā akurvata te devā adābhye chandāṃsi savanāni sam asthāpayan tato devā abhavan parāsurās |
column2: Whatever the gods did at the sacrifice the Asuras did. The gods caused the metres and the pressings to find support in the Adabhya; then the gods prospered, the Asuras were defeated;

column1: yasyaivaṃ viduṣo 'dābhyo gṛhyate bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyo bhavati yad vai devā asurān adābhyenādabhnuvan tad adābhyasyādābhyatvam |
column2: he, for whom knowing thus the Adabhya is drawn, prospers himself, his foe is defeated. Because the gods deceived the Asuras with the Adabhya (undeceivable), that is why the Adabhya has its name.

column1: ya evaṃ veda dabhnoty eva bhrātṛvyaṃ nainam bhrātṛvyo dabhnoti |
column2: He who knows thus deceives his foe; his foe deceives him not [1].

column1: eṣā vai prajāpater atimokṣiṇī nāma tanūr yad adābhyas |
column2: The Adabhya is the form of Prajapati, called the freer;

column1: upanaddhasya gṛhṇāty atimuktyai |
column2: he draws from (the Soma) which is tied up, for freedom;

column1: ati pāpmānam bhrātṛvyam mucyate ya evaṃ veda ghnanti vā etat somaṃ yad abhiṣuṇvanti some hanyamāne yajño hanyate yajñe yajamānas |
column2: he who knows thus is set free from his evil foe. They kill the Soma in that they press it; in the slaying of the Soma the sacrifice is slain, with the sacrifice the sacrificer.

column1: brahmavādino vadanti kiṃ tad yajñe yajamānaḥ kurute yena jīvant suvargaṃ lokam etīti jīvagaho vā eṣa yad adābhyas |
column2: The theologians say, 'What is it that the sacrificer does in the sacrifice whereby he goes alive to the world of heaven?' The Adabhya is the taking alive;

column1: anabhiṣutasya gṛhṇāti jīvantam evainaṃ suvargaṃ lokaṃ gamayati vi vā etad yajñaṃ chindanti yad adābhye saṃsthāpayanti |
column2: verily he makes him go alive to the world of heaven. Now they break the sacrifice asunder when they make it find support in the Adabhya;

column1: aṃśūn api sṛjati yajñasya saṃtatyai |
column2: he lets go the shoots, for the continuance of the sacrifice.

column1: devā vai prabāhug grahān agṛhṇata sa etam prajāpatir aṃśum apaśyat tam agṛhṇīta tena vai sa ārdhnot |
column2: The gods drew the cups in a line; Prajapati saw this Ançu, drew it, and therewith prospered.

column1: yasyaivaṃ viduṣo 'ṃśur gṛhyata ṛdhnoty eva sakṛdabhiṣutasya gṛhṇāti sakṛd dhi sa tenārdhnot |
column2: Verily he, for whom knowing thus the Ançu is drawn, prospers. He draws from (the Soma) when it has been once pressed, for once he prospered thereby.

column1: manasā gṛhṇāti mana iva hi prajāpatiḥ prajāpater āptyai |
column2: He draws with the mind, for Prajapati is mind as it were; (verily it serves) to obtain Prajapati.

column1: audumbareṇa gṛhṇāti |
column2: He draws with (a vessel) of Udumbara;

column1: ūrg vā udumbaras |
column2: the Udumbara is strength;

column1: ūrjam evāva runddhe catuḥsrakti bhavati dikṣu |
column2: it has four corners; verily he finds support in the quarters [1].

column1: eva prati tiṣṭhati yo vā aṃśor āyatanaṃ vedāyatanavān bhavati vāmadevyam iti sāma tad vā asyāyatanam manasā gāyamāno gṛhṇāti |
column2: He who knows the foundation of the Ançu becomes possessed of a foundation. The Saman is that called the Vamadevya; singing in his mind that foundation he draws; verily he becomes possessed of a foundation.

column1: āyatanavān eva bhavati yad adhvaryur aṃśuṃ gṛhṇan nārdhayed ubhābhyāṃ nardhyetādhvaryave ca yajamānāya ca yad ardhayed ubhābhyām ṛdhyeta |
column2: If the Adhvaryu were not to make a success of drawing the Ançu, for both the Adhvaryu and the sacrificer would it go ill; if he were to make a success, for both would it go well;

column1: anavānaṃ gṛhṇāti saivāsyarddhis |
column2: he draws without breathing; this is its success.

column1: hiraṇyam abhi vy aniti |
column2: gold is immortality, breath is life;

column1: amṛtaṃ vai hiraṇyam āyuḥ prāṇa āyuṣaivāmṛtam abhi dhinoti śatamānam bhavati śatāyuḥ puruṣaḥ śatendriyas |
column2: verily with life he quickens immortality; it is of a hundred (Krsnalas) in weight, man has a hundred (years of) life, a hundred powers;

column1: āyuṣy evendriye prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: verily in life, in power he finds support.

column1: prajāpatir devebhyo yajñān vyādiśat sa riricāno 'manyata sa yajñānāṃ ṣoḍaśadhendriyaṃ vīryam ātmānam abhi sam akkhidat tat ṣoḍaśy abhavat na vai ṣoḍaśī nāma yajño 'sti yad vāva ṣoḍaśaṃ stotraṃ ṣoḍaśaṃ śastraṃ tena ṣoḍaśī tat ṣoḍaśinaḥ ṣoḍaśitvam |
column2: he pressed over himself the power and strength of the sacrifice in sixteen ways; that became the Sodaçin; there is no sacrifice called Sodaçin; in that there is a sixteenth Stotra and a sixteenth Çastra, therefore is it the Sodaçin, and that is why the Sodaçin has its name.

column1: yat ṣoḍaśī gṛhyata indriyam eva tad vīryaṃ yajamāna ātman dhatte devebhyo vai suvargo lokaḥ |
column2: In that the Sodaçin is drawn, so the sacrificer bestows power and strength upon himself.

column1: na prābhavat ta etaṃ ṣoḍaśinam apaśyan tam agṛhṇata tato vai tebhyaḥ suvargo lokaḥ prābhavat |
column2: To the gods the world of heaven [1] did not become manifest; they saw this Sodaçin, and drew it; then did the world of heaven become manifest to them;

column1: yat ṣoḍaśī gṛhyate suvargasya lokasyābhijityai |
column2: in that the Sodaçin is drawn, (it serves) for the conquest of the world of heaven.

column1: indro vai devānām ānujāvara āsīt sa prajāpatim upādhāvat tasmā etaṃ ṣoḍaśinam prāyachat tam agṛhṇīta tato vai so 'graṃ devatānām pary ait |
column2: Indra was the youngest of the gods, he had recourse to Prajapati, he bestowed on him the Sodaçin, he drew it; then indeed did he attain the summit of the gods;

column1: yasyaivaṃ viduṣaḥ ṣoḍaśī gṛhyate | agram eva samānānām pary eti prātaḥsavane gṛhṇāti vajro vai ṣoḍaśī vajraḥ prātaḥsavanam |
column2: he for whom knowing thus the Sodaçin [2] is drawn attains the summit of his equals. He draws at the morning pressing; the Sodaçin is the thunderbolt, the morning pressing is the thunderbolt;

column1: svād evainaṃ yoner ni gṛhṇāti savanesavane 'bhi gṛhṇāti savanātsavanād evainam pra janayati tṛtīyasavane paśukāmasya gṛhṇīyāt |
column2: verily he draws it from its own birthplace. At each pressing he draws; verily from each pressing he produces it. At the third pressing he should draw (it) for one who desires cattle;

column1: vajro vai ṣoḍaśī paśavas tṛtīyasavanam |
column2: the Sodaçin is the thunderbolt, the third pressing is cattle;

column1: vajreṇaivāsmai tṛtīyasavanāt paśūn ava runddhe nokthye gṛhṇīyāt prajā vai paśava ukthāni yad ukthye |
column2: verily by means of the thunderbolt he wins for him cattle from the third pressing. He should not draw (it) in the Ukthya; the Ukthas are offspring and cattle;

column1: gṛhṇīyāt prajām paśūn asya nir dahet | atirātre paśukāmasya gṛhṇīyāt |
column2: if he were to draw (it) in the Ukthya [3], he would consume his offspring and cattle. He should draw (it) for one who desires cattle in the Atiratra;

column1: vajro vai ṣoḍaśī vajreṇaivāsmai paśūn avarudhya rātriyopariṣṭāc chamayati |
column2: the Sodaçin is the thunderbolt; verily having won cattle for him by the thunderbolt, he calms them later with (the Çastras of) the night.

column1: apy agniṣṭome rājanyasya gṛhṇīyat | vyāvṛtkāmo hi rājanyo yajate sāhna evāsmai vajraṃ gṛhṇāti sa enaṃ vajro bhūtyā inddhe nir vā dahati |
column2: He should also draw (it) in the Agnistoma for a Rajanya, for a Rajanya sacrifices desiring distinction; verily in the day rite he grasps a bolt for him, and the bolt kindles him to prosperity, or it burns him;

column1: ekaviṃśaṃ stotram bhavati pratiṣṭhityai harivac chasyate |
column2: the twenty-onefold is the Stotra used, for support; what is recited has the word 'bay' in it;

column1: indrasya priyaṃ dhāma |
column2: he obtains the dear abode of Indra [4].

column1: upāpnoti kanīyāṃsi vai deveṣu chandāṃsy āsañ jyāyāṃsy asureṣu te devāḥ kanīyasā chandasā jyāyaś chando 'bhi vy aśaṃsan tato vai te 'surāṇāṃ lokam avṛñjata yat kanīyasā chandasā jyāyaś chando 'bhi viśaṃsati bhrātṛvyasyaiva tal lokaṃ vṛṅkte ṣaḍ akṣarāṇy ati recayanti ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: The smaller metres were among the gods, the larger among the Asuras; the gods recited the larger metre with the smaller on either side; then indeed did they appropriate the world of the Asuras. In that he recites the larger metre with a smaller metre on either side, verily thus he appropriates the world of his foe. They make six syllables redundant;

column1: ṛtūn eva prīṇāti catvāri pūrvāṇy ava kalpayanti |
column2: verily he delights the seasons. They place four in front [5];

column1: catuṣpada eva paśūn ava runddhe dve uttare dvipada evāva runddhe |
column2: verily he wins four-footed cattle; two last; verily he wins two-footed (cattle);

column1: anuṣṭubham abhi sam pādayanti vāg vā {anuṣṭup < anuṣṭubh} tasmāt prāṇānāṃ vāg uttamā samayāviṣite sūrye ṣoḍaśina stotram upākaroti |
column2: they make up an Anustubh; the Anustubh is speech, therefore speech is the highest of the breaths. When the sun is half-set, he sets about the Stotra of the Sodaçin;

column1: etasmin vai loka indro vṛtram ahan |
column2: in this world Indra slew Vrtra;

column1: sākṣād eva vajram bhrātṛvyāya pra harati |
column2: verily straightway be hurls the bolt against his foe.

column1: aruṇapiśaṃgo 'śvo dakṣiṇā |
column2: The sacrificial fee is a reddish-brown horse;

column1: tad vai vajrasya rūpam |
column2: that is the form of the bolt;

column1: samṛddhyai |
column2: (verily it serves) for success.

column1: prajananaṃ jyotir agnir devatānāṃ jyotir virāṭ chandasāṃ jhotis |
column2: Agni is the light of the gods; the Viraj is the light of the metres. The Viraj of speech ends in Agni;

column1: virāḍ vāco 'gnau saṃ tiṣṭhate virājam abhi sam padyate tasmāt taj jyotir ucyate dvau stomau prātaḥsavanaṃ vahato yathā prāṇaś cāpānaś ca dvau mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanaṃ yathā cakṣuś ca śrotraṃ ca dvau tṛtīyasavanaṃ yathā vāk ca pratiṣṭhā ca puruṣasammito vā eṣa yajño 'sthūriḥ |
column2: Therefore it is called light. Two Stomas bear the morning pressing, like expiration and inspiration; two the midday pressing, like eye and ear; two the third pressing, like speech and support. This sacrifice is commensurate with man, and is perfect [1].

column1: yaṃ kāmaṃ kāmayate tam etenābhy aśnute sarvaṃ hy asthuriṇābhyaśnute |
column2: Whatever desire a man has, he wins by it, for one wins all by that which is perfect.

column1: agniṣṭomena vai prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata tā agniṣṭomenaiva pary agṛhṇāt tāsām parigṛhītānām aśvataro 'ty apravata tasyānuhāya reta ādatta tad gardabhe ny {amārṭ < amārj} tāsām parigṛhītānām aśvataro 'ty apravata tasyānuhāya reta ādatta tad gardabhe ny {amārṭ < amārj} tasmād gardabho dviretās | atho āhus |
column2: By means of the Agnistoma Prajapati created off spring; by means of the Agnistoma he grasped them. When he grasped them the mule escaped. Following it he took its seed, and placed it in the ass.

column1: vaḍabāyāṃ ny amārḍ iti tasmād vaḍabā dviretās | atho āhus |
column2: Therefore the ass has double seed. They also say, 'He placed it in the mare.' Therefore the mare has double seed.

column1: oṣadhīṣu |
column2: They also say, 'In the plants [2] he placed it.' Therefore plants, though not anointed, glisten.' They also say, 'He placed it in offspring.' Therefore twins are born.

column1: ny amārḍ iti tasmād oṣadhayo 'nabhyaktā rebhanti |
column2: Therefore the mule has no offspring, for his seed has been taken from him.

column1: atho āhuḥ prajāsu ny amārḍ iti tasmād yamau jāyete tasmād aśvataro na pra jāyata āttaretā hi tasmād barhiṣy anavaklptaḥ sarvavedase vā sahasre vāvaklptas |
column2: Therefore he is not suitable for the sacrifice, but is suitable if there is a sacrifice when one gives (to the priests) all one's goods or a thousand, for he escaped.

column1: ati hy apravata ya evaṃ vidvān agniṣṭomena yajate prājātāḥ prajā janayati pari prajātā gṛhṇāti tasmād āhus | jyeṣṭhayajña iti |
column2: He who knowing thus sacrifices with the Agnistoma begets unborn offspring and grasps those that are born. Therefore they say, 'It is the best of sacrifices [3].' Prajapati indeed is the best, for he sacrificed with it first.

column1: prajāpatir vāva jyeṣṭhaḥ sa hy etenāgre 'yajata prajāpatir akāmayata pra jāyeyeti sa mukhatas trivṛtaṃ nir amimīta tam agnir devatānv asṛjyata gāyatrī chando rathaṃtaraṃ sāma brāhmaṇo manuṣyāṇām ajaḥ paśūnām |
column2: Prajapati desired, 'May I have offspring.' He meted out the Trivrt from his mouth. After it the god Agni was created, the Gayatri metre, the Rathantara Saman, of men the Brahman, of cattle the goat;

column1: tasmāt te mukhyās | mukhato hy asṛjyanta |
column2: therefore are they the chief, for they were produced from the mouth.

column1: uraso bāhubhyām pañcadaśaṃ nir amimīta tam indro devatānv asṛjyata triṣṭup chando bṛhat | sāma rājanyo manuṣyāṇām aviḥ paśūnām |
column2: From the breast and arms he meted out the Pañcadaça Stoma. After it the god Indra was created, the Tristubh metre, the Brhat [4] Saman, of men the Rajanya, of cattle the sheep.

column1: tasmāt te vīryāvantas |
column2: There fore they are strong, for they were created from strength.

column1: vīryād dhy asṛjyanta madhyataḥ saptadaśaṃ nir amimīta taṃ viśve devā devatā anv asṛjyanta jagatī chando vairūpaṃ sāma vaiśyo manuṣyāṇāṃ gāvaḥ paśūnām |
column2: From the middle he meted out the Saptadaça Stoma. After it the All-gods as deities were created, the Jagati metre, the Vairupa Saman, of men the Vaiçya, of cattle cows.

column1: tasmāt ta ādyās | annadhānād dhy asṛjyanta tasmād bhūyāṃso 'nyebhyas |
column2: Therefore are they to be eaten, for they were created from the receptacle of food.

column1: bhūyiṣṭhā hi devatā anv asṛjyanta patta ekaviṃśaṃ nir amimīta tam anuṣṭup chandaḥ |
column2: Therefore are they more numerous than others, for they were created after the most numerous of the gods. From his feet he meted out the Ekavinça Stoma.

column1: anv asṛjyata vairājaṃ sāma śūdro manuṣyāṇām aśvaḥ paśūnām |
column2: After it the Anustubh metre [5] was created, the Vairaja Saman, of men the Çudra, of cattle the horse.

column1: tasmāt tau bhūtasaṃkrāmiṇāv aśvaś ca śūdraś ca tasmāc chūdro yajñe 'navaklptas | na hi devatā anv asṛjyata tasmāt pādāv upa jīvataḥ patto hy asṛjyetām prāṇā vai trivṛt |
column2: Therefore the two, the horse and the Çudra, are dependent on others. Therefore the Çudra is not fit for the sacrifice, for he was not created after any gods. Therefore they depend on their feet, for they were created from the feet. The Trivrt is the breaths;

column1: ardhamāsāḥ pañcadaśaḥ prajāpatiḥ saptadaśas traya ime lokās |
column2: the Pañcadaça the half-months; the Saptadaça Prajapati; these worlds are three;

column1: asāv āditya ekaviṃśas |
column2: the Ekavinça is the sun yonder.

column1: etasmin vā ete śritā etasmin pratiṣṭhitās |
column2: In this they rest, in this they find support.

column1: ya evaṃ vedaitasminn eva śrayata etasmin prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: He who knows thus rests on this, finds, support in this.

column1: prātaḥsavane vai gāyatreṇa chandasā tṛvṛte stomāya jyotir dadhad eti trivṛtā brahmavarcasena pañcadaśāya jyotir dadhad eti pañcadaśenaujasā vīryeṇa saptadaśāya jyotir dadhad eti saptadaśena prājāpatyena prajananenaikaviṃśāya jyotir dadhad eti stoma eva tat stomāya jyotir dadhad eti |
column2: At the morning pressing he keeps glorifying the Trivrt Stoma by the Gayatri metre; the Pañcadaça Stoma by the Trivrt, which is splendour; the Saptadaça by the Pañcadaça which is force and strength; the Ekavinça by the Saptadaça which is connected with Prajapati and causes begetting.

column1: atho stoma eva stomam abhi pra ṇayati yāvanto vai stomās tāvantaḥ kāmās tāvanto lokās tāvanti jyotīṃṣi | etāvata eva stomān etāvataḥ kāmān etāvato lokān etāvanti jyotīṃṣy ava runddhe |
column2: Verily thus Stoma glorifies Stoma; verily also Stoma leads Stoma forth. As many as are the Stomas, so many are desires, so many the worlds, so many the lights; verily so many Stomas, so many desires, so many worlds, so many lights does he win.

column1: brahmavādino vadanti sa tvai yajeta yo 'gniṣṭomena yajamāno 'tha sarvastomena yajeteti yasya trivṛtam antaryanti prāṇāṃs tasyāntaryanti prāṇeṣu me 'py asad iti khalu vai yajñena yajamāno yajate yasya pañcadaśam antaryanti vīryaṃ tasyāntar yanti vīrye me 'py asad iti khalu vai yajñena yajamāno yajate yasya saptadaśam antaryanti | prajāṃ tasyāntar yanti prajāyām me 'py asad iti khalu vai yajñena yajamāno yajate yasyaikaviṃśam antaryanti pratiṣṭhāṃ tasyāntar yanti pratiṣṭhāyām me 'py asad iti khalu vai yajñena yajamāno yajate yasya triṇavam antaryanty ṛtūṃś ca tasya nakṣatriyāṃ ca virājam antar yanti |
column2: The theologians say, 'He indeed would really sacrifice, who having sacrificed with the Agnistoma should also sacrifice with the Sarvastoma.' If they omit the Trivrt Stoma, then his vital airs are omitted, but he who offers the sacrifice does so with the wish, 'May it be in my vital airs. If they omit the Pañcadaça Stoma, his strength is omitted, but he who offers the sacrifice does so with the wish, 'May it be in my strength.' If they omit the Saptadaça Stoma [1], his offspring is omitted, but he who offers the sacrifice does so with the wish, 'May it be in my offspring.' If they omit the Ekavinça Stoma, his support is omitted, but he who offers the sacrifice does so with the wish, 'May it be in my support.' If they omit the Trinava Stoma, his seasons and the strength of the Naksatras are omitted, but he who offers the sacrifice does so with the wish, 'May it be in my seasons and the strength of the Naksatras' [2].

column1: khalu vai yajñena yajamāno yajate yasya trayastriṃśam antaryanti devatās tasyāntar yanti devatāsu me 'py asad iti khalu vai yajñena yajamāno yajate yo vai stomānām avamam paramatāṃ gachantaṃ veda paramatām eva gachati trivṛd vai stomānām avamas trivṛt paramas a evaṃ veda paramatām eva gachati |
column2: If they omit the Trayastrinça Stoma, his deities are omitted, and he who offers the sacrifice does so with the wish, 'May it be in my deities.' He who knows the lowest of the Stomas attaining the first place, obtains him self the first place. The Trivrt is the lowest of Stomas, the Trivrt occupies the first place. He who know thus obtains the first place.

With the success which Atri had, the sacrificer prospers.
