column1: eṣa vai devayānaḥ panthās tam evānvārohanti |
column2: This is the path that goes to the gods; verily they mount upon it.

column1: ākrośanto yānti |
column2: They go calling aloud;

column1: avartim evānyasmin pratiṣajya pratiṣṭhāṃ gachanti yadā daśa śataṃ kurvanty athaikam utthānam |
column2: verily fastening misfortune on another they attain support. When ten (cows) make a hundred, then is one time to stop.

column1: śatāyuḥ puruṣaḥ śatendriyas |
column2: Man is of a hundred (years of) life and of a hundred powers;

column1: āyuṣy evendriye prati tiṣṭhanti yadā śataṃ sahasraṃ kurvanty athaikam utthānam |
column2: verily in life and power do they find support. When a hundred make a thousand, then is one time to stop.

column1: sahasrasammito vā asau lokas |
column2: Yonder world is measured by a thousand;

column1: amum eva lokam abhi jayanti yadaiṣām pramīyeta yadā vā jīyerann athaikam utthānam | tad dhi tīrtham |
column2: verily they conquer yonder world. If one of them perish or they be oppressed, then is one time to stop, for that is a suitable opportunity.

column1: kusurubinda auddālakir akāmayata paśumānt syām iti sa etaṃ saptarātram āharat tenāyajata tena vai sa yāvanto grāmyāḥ paśavas tān avārunddha ya evaṃ vidvānt saptarātreṇa yajate yāvanta eva grāmyāḥ paśavas tān evāva runddhe saptarātro bhavati sapta grāmyāḥ paśavaḥ saptāraṇyāḥ sapta chandāṃsi |
column2: Kusurubinda Auddalaki desired, 'May I be rich in cattle.' He grasped this (rite) of seven nights, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed did be win all the domestic animals. He, who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of seven nights, wins all domestic animals. (The rite) is of seven nights; the domesticated animals are seven, the wild seven, the metres seven, for winning both.

column1: ubhayasyāvaruddhyai trivṛd agniṣṭomo bhavati tejaḥ |
column2: There is an Agnistoma with the Trivrt (Stoma); verily he wins brilliance [1].

column1: evāva runddhe pañcadaśo bhavati |
column2: There is a Pañcadaça (Stoma);

column1: indriyam evāva runddhe saptadaśo bhavati | annādyasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: verily he wins power. There is a Saptadaça (Stoma), for the winning of food;

column1: atho praiva tena jāyate |
column2: verily also by it he is propagated.

column1: ekaviṃśo bhavati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: There is an Ekavinça (Stoma), for support;

column1: atho rucam evātman dhatte triṇavo bhavati vijityai pañcaviṃśo 'gniṣṭomo bhavati prajāpater āptyai mahāvratavān annādyasyāvaruddhyai viśvajit sarvapṛṣṭho 'tirātro bhavati sarvasyābhijityai yat pratyakṣam pūrveṣv ahaḥsu pṛṣṭhāny upeyuḥ pratyakṣam |
column2: verily he places radiance in himself. There is a Trinava (Stoma), for conquest. There is an Agnistoma with the Pañcadaça (Stoma) to obtain Prajapati; it has (the characteristics of) the Mahavrata, to win food. There is a Viçvajit Atiratra with all the Prsthas, to conquer all.

column1: viśvajiti yathā dugdhām upasīdaty evam uttamam ahaḥ syāt |
column2: If they were in the preceding days to perform the Prsthas in the obvious way, and similarly in the Viçvajit [2], the last day would be as when one sits down to a cow which has already been milked;

column1: naikarātraś cana syāt |
column2: it would not be good enough for even a single night (rite).

column1: bṛhadrathantare pūrveṣv ahaḥsūpa yanti |
column2: In the preceding days they perform the Brhat and the Rathantara.

column1: iyaṃ vāva rathaṃtaram asau bṛhat |
column2: The Rathantara is this (earth), the Brhat yonder (sky);

column1: ābhyām eva na yanty atho anayor eva prati tiṣṭhanti yat pratyakṣaṃ viśvajiti pṛṣṭhāny upayanti yathā prattāṃ duhe tādṛg eva tat |
column2: verily they depart not from them; verily also in them do they find support. In that they perform the Prsthas in the Viçvajit in the obvious manner, it is as when one milks a cow which is ready to give.

column1: bṛhaspatir akāmayata brahmavarcasī syām iti sa etam aṣṭarātram apaśyat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai sa brahmavarcasy abhavat |
column2: Brhaspati desired, 'May I be resplendent.' He saw this rite of eight nights, he grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed did he become resplendent.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān aṣṭarātreṇa yajate brahmavarcasy eva bhavati |
column2: He, who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of eight nights, becomes resplendent.

column1: aṣṭarātro bhavati |
column2: (The rite) is of eight nights;

column1: aṣṭarātro bhavati catarso vai diśas | catarso 'vāntaradiśās |
column2: the quarters are four, the intermediate quarters four;

column1: digbhya eva brahmavarcasam ava runddhe |
column2: verily from the quarters he wins splendour [1].

column1: trivṛd agniṣṭomo bhavati teja evāva runddhe pañcadaśo bhavati |
column2: There is an Agnistoma with the Trivrt (Stoma); verily he wins brilliance. There is a Pañcadaça (Stoma);

column1: indriyam evāva runddhe saptadaśo bhavaty annādyasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: verily he wins power. There is a Saptadaça (Stoma), for the winning of food;

column1: atho praiva tena jāyate |
column2: verily also by it he is propagated.

column1: ekaviṃśo bhavati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: There is an Ekavinça (Stoma), for support verily he places radiance in himself.

column1: atho rucam evātman dhatte triṇavo bhavati vijityai trayastriṃśo bhavati pratiṣṭhityai pañcaviṃśo 'gniṣṭomo bhavati prajāpater āptyai mahāvratavān annādyasyāvaruddhyai viśvajit sarvapṛṣṭho 'tirātro bhavati sarvasyābhijityai |
column2: There is a Trinava (Stoma), for conquest. There is a Trayastrinça (Stoma), for support. There is an Agnistoma with the Pañcadaça (Stoma), to obtain Prajapati; it has (the characteristics of) the Mahavrata, to win food. There is a Viçvajit Atiratra with all the Prsthas, to conquer all.

column1: prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata tāḥ sṛṣṭāḥ kṣudhaṃ ny āyan |
column2: Prajapati created offspring. They being created were ahungered.

column1: sa etaṃ navarātram apaśyat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai prajābhyo 'kalpata yarhi prajāḥ kṣudhaṃ nigacheyus tarhi navarātreṇa yajeta | ime hi vā etāsāṃ lokā aklptā athaitāḥ kṣudhaṃ ni gachanti |
column2: He saw this (rite) of nine nights, he grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed was he able to help offspring, When offspring are ahungered, one should sacrifice with (the rite) of nine nights, for these worlds are not fitted for them, and thus they are ahungered;

column1: imān evābhyo lokān kalpayati tān kalpamānān prajābhyo 'nu kalpate kalpante |
column2: verily he makes these worlds fitted for them, and as they become fitted he becomes fit for offspring along with them;

column1: asmā ime lokā ūrjam prajāsu dadhāti trirātreṇaivemaṃ lokaṃ kalpayati trirāttreṇāntarikṣaṃ trirātreṇāmuṃ lokam |
column2: By means of three nights he makes fit this world, by means of three nights the atmosphere, by means of three nights yonder world.

column1: yathā guṇe guṇam anvasyaty evam eva tal loke lokam anv asyati dhṛtyā aśithilambhāvāya jyotir gaur āyur iti jñātā stomā bhavanti |
column2: As a man casts thread on thread, so he casts world on world, for firmness, and to avoid looseness. The Stomas are known as Jyotis, Go, and Ayus.

column1: iyaṃ vāva jyotir antarikṣaṃ gaur asāv āyus |
column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere, the Ayus yonder (sky);

column1: eṣv eva lokeṣu prati tiṣṭhanti jñātraṃ prajānāṃ |
column2: verily they find support in these worlds, and he becomes famous among people [2].

column1: gachati navarātro bhavati |
column2: (The rite) is of nine nights;

column1: abhipūrvam evāsmin tejo dadhāti yo jyogāmayāvī syāt sa navarātreṇa yajeta prāṇā hi vā etasyādhṛtās |
column2: If a man be a long time ill, he should sacrifice with (the rite) of nine nights; for his breaths are loosened, and thus is he ill long;

column1: athaitasya jyog āmayati prāṇān evāsmin dādhāras | ata yadītāsur bhavati jīvaty eva |
column2: verily he supports his breaths in him, and even if his life be gone, yet he lives.

column1: prajāpatir akāmayata pra jāyeyeti sa etaṃ daśahotāram apaśyat tam ajuhot tena daśarātram asṛjata tena daśarātreṇa prājāyata daśarātrāya dīkṣiṣyamāṇo daśahotāraṃ juhuyāt |
column2: Prajapati desired, 'May I be propagated.' He saw this Daçahotr, and offered it. By this he created (the rite) of ten nights, and by this (rite) often nights he was propagated. If one is about to consecrate oneself for (the rite) of ten nights one should offer the Daçahotr;

column1: daśahotraiva daśarātraṃ sṛjata tena daśarātreṇa pra jāyate vairājo vā eṣa yajño yad daśarātras |
column2: verily he creates by the Daçahotr (the rite) of ten nights, and by (the rite) of ten nights he is propagated.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān daśarātreṇa yajate virājam eva gachati prājāpatyo vā eṣa yajño yad daśarātraḥ |
column2: The sacrifice of ten nights is connected with the Viraj. He, who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of ten nights, attains the Viraj.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān daśarātreṇa yajate praiva jāyate |
column2: He, who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of ten nights, is propagated.

column1: indro vai sadṛṅ devatābhir āsīt sa na vyāvṛtam agachat sa prajāpatim upādhāvat tasmā etaṃ daśarātram prāyachat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai so 'nyābhir devatābhir vyāvṛtam agachat |
column2: Indra was on a level with the gods, he was not separated from them. He ran up to Prajapati; he gave him this (rite) of ten nights. He grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed he became separated from the other gods.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān daśarātreṇa yajate vyāvṛtam eva pāpmanā bhrātṛvyeṇa gachati trikakud vai |
column2: He, who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of ten nights, attains separation from the evil enemy. The sacrifice of ten nights has three eminences [2];

column1: eṣa yajño yad daśarātraḥ kakut pañcadaśaḥ kakud ekaviṃśaḥ kakut trayastriṃśas |
column2: the Pañcadaça (Stoma) is one eminence; the Ekavinça one eminence, the Trayastrinça one eminence.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvān daśarātreṇa yajate trikakud eva samānānām bhavati yajāmanaḥ pañcadaśo yajamāna ekaviṃśo yajamānas trayastriṃśaḥ pura itarās |
column2: He, who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of ten nights, becomes thrice eminent among his peers. The sacrificer is the Pañcadaça; the sacrificer the Ekavimça, the sacrificer the Trayastrinça, and the others are the citadels.

column1: abhicaryamāṇo daśarātreṇa yajeta devapurā eva pary ūhate tasya na kutaś canopāvyādho bhavati nainam abhicarant stṛṇute devāsurāḥ saṃyattā āsan te devā etāḥ |
column2: If a man have witchcraft practised against him, he should sacrifice with (the rite) of ten nights; verily he surrounds himself with the divine citadels; no harm whatever can befall him, the practiser of witchcraft overcomes him not.

column1: devapurā apaśyan yad daśarātras tāḥ pary auhanta teṣāṃ na kutaś canopāvyādho 'bhavat tato devā abhavan parāsurās |
column2: The gods and the Asuras were in conflict. The gods [3] saw in (the rite) of ten nights the divine citadels. They surrounded themselves with them;

column1: yo bhrātṛvyavānt syāt sa daśarātreṇa yajeta devapurā eva pary ūhate tasya na kutaś canopāvyādho bhavati bhavaty ātmanā parāsya bhrātṛvyo bhavati stoma stomasyopastir bhavati bhrātṛvyam evopastiṃ kurute jāmi vai |
column2: He who has enemies should sacrifice with (the rite) of ten nights; verily he surrounds himself with the divine citadels; no harm whatever befalls him; he prospers and his enemy is defeated. Stoma serves Stoma;

column1: etat kurvanti yaj jyāyāṃsaṃ stomam upetya kanīyāṃsam upayanti yad agniṣṭomasāmāny avastāc ca parastāc ca bhavanty ajāmitvāya trivṛd agniṣṭomo 'gniṣṭud āgneyīṣu bhavati teja evāva runddhe pañcadaśa ukthya aindrīṣu |
column2: to break the uniformity the Agnistoma Samans are before and after (the greater Stoma). There is an Agnistoma, with the Trivrt (Stoma), in praise of Agni, with verses addressed to Agni; verily he wins brilliance. There is an Ukthya, with the Pañcadaça (Stoma), and verses addressed to Indra;

column1: indriyam evāva runddhe trivṛd agniṣṭomo vaiśvadevīṣu puṣṭim evāva runddhe saptadaśo 'gniṣṭomaḥ prājāpatyāsu tīvrasomas | annādyasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: There is an Agnistoma, with the Trivrt (Stoma), and verses addressed to the All-gods; verily he wins prosperity. There is an Agni stoma, with the Saptadaça (Stoma), and verses addressed to Prajapati, in which the Soma offering is bitter, to win food;

column1: atho praiva teha jāyate |
column2: verily also by it he is propagated [5].

column1: ekaviṃśa ukthyaḥ saurīṣu pratiṣṭhiyai |
column2: There is an Ukthya with the Ekavinça (Stoma), and verses addressed to the sun, for support;

column1: atho rucam evātman dhatte saptadaśo 'gniṣṭomaḥ prājāpatyāsūpahavyas |
column2: There is an Agnistoma, with the Saptadaça (Stoma), and verses addressed to Prajapati, (called) the added oblation;

column1: upahavam eva gachati triṇavāv agniṣṭomāv abhita aindrīṣu vijityai trayastriṃśa ukthyo vaiśvadevīṣu pratiṣṭhityai viśvajit sarvapṛṣṭho 'tirātro bhavati sarvasyābhijityai |
column2: verily he is invited by all. There are two Agnistomas, with the Trinava (Stoma) on either side (of the Ukthya), with verses addressed to Indra, for conquest. There is an Ukthya, with the Trayastrinça (Stoma) with verses addressed to the All-gods, for rest. There is an Atiratra Viçvajit with all the Prsthas, for supremacy.

column1: ṛtavo vai prajākāmāḥ prajāṃ nāvindanta te 'kāmayanta prajāṃ sṛjemahi prajām ava rundhīmahi prajāṃ vindemahi prajāvantaḥ syāmeti ta etam ekādaśarātram apaśyan tam āharan tenāyajanta tato vai te prajām asṛjanta prajām avārundhata prajām avindanta prajāvanto 'bhavan ta ṛtavo 'bhavan tad ārtavānām ārtavatvam ṛtūnāṃ vā ete putrās tasmāt |
column2: The seasons, desirous of offspring, could not procure offspring. They desired, 'May we create offspring, may we win offspring, may we procure offspring, may we possess offspring.' They saw this (rite) of eleven nights; they grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed did they create offspring, win offspring, procure offspring, and possess offspring. They became the seasons, and that is why the seasonal periods are seasonal periods.

column1: ārtavā ucyante ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa ekādaśarātram āsate prajām eva sṛjante prajām ava rundhate prajāṃ vindante prajāvanto bhavanti jyotir atirātro bhavati jyotir eva purastād dadhate suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai pṛṣṭhyaḥ ṣaḍaho bhavati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ ṣaṭ pṛṣṭhāni pṛṣṭhair evartūn anvārohanty ṛtubhiḥ saṃvatsaram |
column2: Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of eleven nights, create offspring, win offspring, procure offspring, and possess offspring. There is an Atiratra with the form of light; verily they place light before them, to reveal the world of heaven. There is a Prsthva Sadaha; the seasons are six, the Prsthas are six;

column1: te saṃvatsara eva prati tiṣṭhanti caturviṃśo bhavati caturviṃśatyakṣarā gāyatrī |
column2: verily by the Prsthas they mount upon the seasons, by the seasons upon the year; verily in the year they find support. There is Caturvinça;

column1: gāyatriyām eva brahmavarcase prati tiṣṭhanti catuścatvāriṃśo bhavati catuścatvāriṃśadakṣarā {triṣṭug < triṣṭubh} indriyaṃ {triṣṭup < triṣṭubh} triṣṭubhy evendriye prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily in the Gayatri and in splendour they find support. There is a Catucçatvarinça; the Tristubh has forty-four syllables, the Tristubh is power; verily in the Tristubh and in power they find support.

column1: aṣṭācatvāriṃśo bhavati |
column2: There is an Astacatvarinça;

column1: aṣṭācatvāriṃśadakṣarā jagatī jāgatāḥ paśavas |
column2: the Jagati has forty-eight syllables, cattle are connected with the Jagati;

column1: jagatyām eva paśuṣu prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily in the Jagati and in cattle they find support.

column1: ekādaśarātro bhavati pañca vā ṛtava ārtavāḥ pañca |
column2: (The rite) is of eleven nights, the seasons are five, the seasonal periods are five;

column1: ṛtuṣv evārtaveṣu saṃvatsare pratiṣṭhāya prajām ava rundhate |
column2: verily in the seasons, in the seasonal periods, and in the year they find support and win offspring.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavataḥ prajāyati parigṛhītyai |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, to secure offspring.

column1: aindravāyavāgrān gṛhṇīyād yaḥ kāmayeta yathāpūrvam prajāḥ kalperann iti yajñasya vai klptim anu prajāḥ kalpante yajñasyāklptim anu na kalpante yathāpūrvam eva prajāḥ kalpayati na jyāyāṃsaṃ kanīyān ati krāmati |
column2: He should draw the cup for Indra and Vayu first if he desire, 'May my offspring accord in order of seniority.' Offspring are in accord according to the arrangement of the sacrifice, and if the sacrifice is disarranged, they are at discord. Verily he makes his offspring in accord in order of seniority; the younger does not overstep the older.

column1: aindravāyavāgrān gṛhṇīyād āmayāvinaḥ prāṇena vā eṣa vy ṛdhyate yasyāmayati prāṇa aindravāyavaḥ prāṇenaivainaṃ sam ardhayati maitrāvaruṇāgrān gṛhṇīran yeṣāṃ dīkṣitānām pramīyeta |
column2: He should draw the cup for Indra and Vayu first for one who is ill. For he who is ill is separated from breath, the cup for Indra and Vayu is breath; verily he unites him with breath. They should draw the cup for Mitra and Varuna first if when they are consecrated one die [1].

column1: prāṇāpānābhyāṃ vā ete vy ṛdhyante yeṣāṃ dīkṣitānām pramīyate prāṇāpānau mitrāvaruṇau prāṇāpānāv eva mukhataḥ pari harante |
column2: From expiration and inspiration are they separated of whom when consecrated one dies, Mitra and Varuna are expiration and inspiration; verily at the commencement they grasp expiration and inspiration.

column1: āśvināgrān gṛhṇītānujāvaras |
column2: He should draw the Açvina cup first who is infirm.

column1: aśvinau vai devānām ānujāvarau paścevāgram pary aitām aśvināv etasyā devatā ya ānujāvaras tāv evainam agram pari ṇayataḥ śukrāgrān gṛhṇīta gataśrīḥ pratiṣṭhākāmas |
column2: The Açvins are of the gods those who are infirm, late as it were came they to the front. The Açvins are the gods of him who is infirm; they lead him to the front. He who desires support having attained prosperity should draw the Çukra Cup first.

column1: asau vā ādityaḥ śukra eṣo 'ntas |
column2: The Çukra is yonder sun, this is the end;

column1: antam manuṣyaḥ | śriyai gattvā ni vartate |
column2: a man when he has reached the end [2] of prosperity stops;

column1: antād evāntam ā rabhate na tataḥ pāpīyān bhavati manthyagrān gṛhṇītābhicaran |
column2: verily from the end he grasps the end, and becomes not worse. He who practises witchcraft should draw the Manthin cup first.

column1: ārtapātraṃ vā etad yan manthipātram mṛtyunaivainaṃ grāhayati tājag ārtim ārchati |
column2: The Manthin vessel is a vessel of misfortune; verily he causes death to seize on him; swiftly does he reach misfortune.

column1: āgrayaṇāgrān gṛhṇīta yasya pitā pitāmahaḥ puṇyaḥ syād atha tan na prāpnuyāt |
column2: He should draw the Agrayana cup first whose father and grandfather are holy, and who yet does not possess holiness.

column1: vācā vā eṣa indriyeṇa vy ṛdhyate yasya pitā pitāmahaḥ puṇyaḥ | bhavaty atha tan na prāpnoti |
column2: From speech and power is he separated whose father and grandfather are holy [3], and who yet does not possess holiness.

column1: ura ivaitad yajñasya vāg iva yad āgrayaṇas |
column2: The Agrayana (cup) is the breast as it were and the speech as it were of the sacrifice;

column1: vācaivainam indriyeṇa sam ardhayati na tataḥ pāpīyān bhavati |
column2: verily with speech and with power he unites him, then he becomes not worse.

column1: ukthyāgrān gṛhṇītābhicaryamāṇaḥ sarveṣāṃ vā etat pātrāṇām indriyaṃ yad ukthyapātram |
column2: He against whom witchcraft is practised should draw the Ukthya cup first. The Ukthya vessel is the power of all vessels;

column1: sarveṇaivainam indriyeṇāti pra yuṅkte sarasvaty abhi no neṣi vasya iti purorucaṃ kuryāt |
column2: verily he yokes him with all power. He should take as Puroruc (the verse) 'O Sarasvati, lead us to prosperity.' Sarasvati is speech [4];

column1: vāg vai |
column2: verily with speech he yokes him.

column1: sarasvatī vācaivainam ati pra yuṅkte mā tvat kṣetrāṇy araṇāni ganmety āha mṛtyor vai kṣetrāṇy araṇāni tenaiva mṛtyoḥ kṣetrāṇi na gachati pūrṇān grahān gṛhṇīyād āmayāvinaḥ prāṇān vā etasya śug ṛchati yasyāmayati prāṇā grahāḥ prāṇān evāsya śuco muñcati |
column2: 'May we go not through thee to joyless fields', he says. The joyless fields are those of death; verily he goes not to the fields of death. He should draw full cups for one who is ill. Pain afflicts the breaths of him who is ill, the cups are breaths;

column1: uta yadītāsur bhavati jīvaty eva pūrṇān grahān gṛhṇīyād yarhi parjanyo na varṣet prāṇān vā etarhi prajānāṃ śug ṛchati yarhi parjanyo na varṣat prāṇā grahāḥ prāṇān eva prajānāṃ śuco muñcati tājak pra varṣati | gāyatro vā aindravāyavas |
column2: Pain afflicts the breaths of the people if rain does not fall, the cups are breaths; verily he frees the breaths of the people from pain, and rain soon falls. (The cup) for Indra and Vayu is connected with the Gayatri, the opening day is connected with the Gayatri, and therefore on the opening day (the cup) for Indra and Vayu is drawn;

column1: gāyatram prāyaṇīyam ahar |
column2: verily he draws it in its own abode.

column1: tasmāt prāyaṇīye 'hann aindravāyavo gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti traiṣṭubho vai śukras traiṣṭubham dvitīyam ahar |
column2: The Çukra is connected with the Tristubh, the second day is connected with the Tristubh, and therefore on the second day the Çukra is drawn; verily he draws it in its own abode.

column1: jāgataṃ tṛtīyam ahar | tasmāt tṛtīye 'hann āgrayaṇo gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti |
column2: The Agrayana is connected with the Jagati, the third day is connected with the Jagati, and therefore on the third day the Agrayana is drawn; verily he draws it in its own abode.

column1: yajñam āpad yac chandāṃsy āpnoti yad āgrayaṇaḥ śvo gṛhyate yatraiva yajñam adṛśan tata evainam punaḥ pra yuṅkte jaganmukho vai dvitīyas trirātras | jāgata āgrayaṇas |
column2: In that it completes the metres, it completes the sacrifice [1]; in that the Agrayana is drawn on the next day, where they have seen the sacrifice, thence does he again employ it. The second three nights begin with the Jagati, the Agrayana is connected with the Jagati;

column1: yac caturthe 'hann āgrayaṇo gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti |
column2: in that the Agrayana is drawn on the fourth day, he draws it in its own abode;

column1: atho svam eva chando 'nu paryāvartante rāthaṃtaro vā aindravāyavas | rāthaṃtaram pañcamam ahar | tasmāt pañcame 'han |
column2: (The cup) for Indra and Vayu is connected with the Rathantara (Saman), the fifth day is connected with the Rathantara, and therefore on the fifth day [2] (the cup) for Indra and Vayu is drawn;

column1: aindravāyavo gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti bārhato vai śukras | bārhataṃ ṣaṣṭham ahar | tasmāt ṣaṣṭhe 'hañ chukro gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti |
column2: verily he draws it in its own abode. The Çukra is connected with the Brhati, the sixth day is connected with the Brhati, and therefore on the sixth day the Çukra is drawn; verily he draws it in its own abode.

column1: etad vai dvitīyaṃ yajñam āpad yac chandāṃsy āpnoti yac chukraḥ śvo gṛhyate yatraiva yajñam adṛśan tata evainam punaḥ pra yuṅkte triṣṭuṅmukho vai tṛtīyas trirātras traiṣṭubhaḥ |
column2: In that it completes the metres, it completes for the second time the sacrifice; in that the Çukra is drawn on the next day, where they have seen the sacrifice, thence does he again employ it. The third three nights begin with the Tristubh, the Çukra is connected with the Tristubh [3];

column1: śukras | yat saptame 'hañ chukro gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti |
column2: in that the Çukra is drawn on its seventh day, he draws it in its own abode, and they revolve round their own metre.

column1: vāg aṣṭamam ahar | tasmād aṣṭame 'hann āgrayaṇo gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti prāṇo vā aindravāyavaḥ prāṇo navamam ahar | tasmān navame 'hann aindravāyavo gṛhyate sva evainam āyatane gṛhṇāti |
column2: The Agrayana, is speech, the eighth day is speech, and therefore on the eighth day the Agrayana is drawn; verily he draws it in its own abode. (The cup) for Indra and Vayu is breath, the ninth day is breath, and therefore on the ninth day (the cup) for Indra and Vayu.

column1: etat |
column2: is drawn;

column1: vai tritīyaṃ yajñam āpad yac chandāṃsy āpnoti yad aindravāyavaḥ śvo gṛhyate yatraiva yajñam adṛśan tata evainam punaḥ pra yuṅkte |
column2: In that [4] it completes the metres, it completes for the third time the sacrifice; in that (the cup) for Indra and Vayu is drawn on the next day, where they have seen the sacrifice, thence does he again employ it, and they revolve round their own metre.

column1: atho svam eva chando 'nu paryāvartante patho vā ete 'dhy apathena yanti ye 'nyenaindravāyavāt pratipadyante |
column2: They go by a trackless way leaving the path who start with anything except (the cup) for Indra and Vayu.

column1: antaḥ khalu vā eṣa yajñasya yad daśamam ahar daśame 'hann aindravāyavo gṛhyate yajñasya |
column2: The tenth day is the end of the sacrifice, (the cup) for Indra and Vayu is drawn on the tenth day;

column1: evāntaṃ gatvāpathāt panthām api yanti | atho yathā vahīyasā pratisāraṃ vahanti tādṛg eva tat |
column2: verily having reached the end of the sacrifice [5], they proceed from the trackless way to the path, and it is as when men go pushing on with a strong (team).

column1: chandāṃsy anyo'nyasya lokam abhya adhyāyan tāny etenaiva devā vy avāhayan |
column2: The metres set their wishes on one another's world, and the gods then interchanged them.

column1: aindravāyavasya vā etad āyatanaṃ yac caturtham ahar |
column2: The fourth day is the abode of (the cup) for Indra and Vayu, the Agrayana is drawn on this (day);

column1: tasminn āgrayaṇo gṛhyate tasmād āgrayaṇasyāyatane navame 'hann aindravāyavo gṛhyate śukrasya vā etad āyatanaṃ yat pañcamam |
column2: therefore (the cup) for Indra and Vayu is drawn on the ninth day, the abode of the Agrayana. The fifth day is the abode of the Çukra [6], (the cup) for Indra and Vayu is drawn on this (day);

column1: tasminn aindravāyavo gṛhyate tasmād aindravāyavasyāyatane saptame 'hañ chukro gṛhyate |
column2: therefore the Çukra is drawn on the seventh day, the abode of (the cup) for Indra and Vayu.

column1: āgrayaṇasya vā etad āyatanaṃ yat ṣaṣṭham ahar |
column2: The sixth day is the abode of the Agrayana, the Çukra is drawn on this (day);

column1: tasmaiñ chukro gṛhyate tasmāc chukrasyāyatane 'ṣṭame 'hann āgrayaṇo gṛhyate chandāṃsy eva tad vi vāhayati pra vasyaso vivāham āpnoti ya evaṃ veda |
column2: therefore the Agrayana is drawn on the eighth day, the abode of the Çukra. Verily thus does he exchange the metres, and he who knows thus obtains interchange with the richer;

column1: atho devatābhya eva yajñe saṃvidaṃ dadhāti tasmād idam anyo'nyasmai dadhāti |
column2: verily also he causes concord in the sacrifice for the gods. Therefore one gives this to another.

column1: prajāpatir akāmayata pra jāyeyeti sa etaṃ dvādaśarātram apaśyat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai sa prājāyata yaḥ kāmayeta pra jāyeyeti sa dvādaśarātreṇa yajeta praiva jāyate brahmavādino vadanti |
column2: Prajapati desired, 'May I be propagated.' He saw this (rite) of twelve nights; he grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed was he propagated. He who desires, 'May I be propagated', should sacrifice with (the rite) of twelve nights; verily he is propagated.

column1: agniṣṭomaprāyaṇā yajñā atha kasmād atirātraḥ pūrvaḥ pra yujyata iti cakṣuṣī vā ete yajñasya yad atirātrau kanīnike agniṣṭomau yat |
column2: The theologians say, 'The sacrifices have Agnistomas at the beginning; why then is Atiratra first employed?' The two Atiratras are the eyes of the sacrifice, the two Agnistomas the pupils;

column1: agniṣṭomaṃ pūrvam prayuñjīran bahirdhā kanīnike dadhyus tasmād atirātraḥ pūrvaḥ pra yujyate cakṣuṣī eva yajñe dhitvā madhyataḥ kanīnike prati dadhati yo vai gāyatrīṃ jyotiḥpakṣāṃ veda jyotiṣā bhāsā suvargaṃ lokam eti yāv agniṣṭomau tau pakṣau ye 'ntare 'ṣṭāv ukthyāḥ sa ātmā |
column2: if [1] they were to employ the Agnistoma first, they would put the pupils outside; therefore the Atiratra is employed first; verily having inserted the eyes of the sacrifice they put the pupils in them. He, who knows the Gayatri to have sides of light, goes to the world of heaven with light and radiance. The sides are the Agnistomas, the eight Ukthyas in between are the body;

column1: eṣā vai gāyatrī jyotiḥpakṣā ya evaṃ veda jyotiṣā bhāsā suvargaṃ lokam |
column2: verily the Gayatri has sides of light. He who knows thus goes to the world of heaven with light and radiance [2].

column1: eti prajāpatir vā eṣa dvādaśadhā vihito yad dvādaśarātras |
column2: The twelve nights' (rite) is Prajapati in twelve divisions.

column1: yāv atirātrau tau pakṣau ye 'ntare 'ṣṭāv ukthyāḥ sa ātmā prajāpatir vāvaiṣa sant sad dha vai sattreṇa spṛṇoti prāṇā vai sat prāṇān eva spṛṇoti sarvāsāṃ vā ete prajānām prāṇair āsate ye sattram āsate tasmāt pṛchanti kim ete sattriṇa iti priyaḥ prajānām utthito bhavati ya evaṃ veda |
column2: The two sides are the Atiratras, the eight Ukthyas within are the body; Prajapati in such guise touches truth with the Sattra, truth is the breaths; verily he touches the breaths. Those who perform the Sattra perform it with the breath of all people, and therefore they ask, 'Are these performers of a Sattra?' Dear to people and noble is he who knows thus.

column1: na vā eṣo 'nyatovaiśvānaraḥ suvargāya lokāya prābhavat |
column2: This (rite) with a Vaiçvanara on one side (only) was not able to win the world of heaven;

column1: ūrdhvo ha vā eṣa ātata āsīt te devā etaṃ vaiśvānaram pary auhant suvargasya lokasya prabhūtyai |
column2: it was stretched upwards and the gods piled round this Vaiçvanara, to overcome the world of heaven.

column1: ṛtavo vā etena prajāpatim ayājayan teṣv ārdhnod adhi tat |
column2: The seasons made Prajapati sacrifice with it, and in them because of it he prospered.

column1: ṛdhnoti ha vā ṛtvikṣu ya evaṃ vidvān dvādaśāhena yajate te 'sminn aichanta sa rasam aha vasantāya prāyachat |
column2: He prospers among the priests who knowing thus sacrifices with (the rite) of twelve days. They were desirous of obtaining (their desires) from him.

column1: yavaṃ grīṣmāyauṣadhīr varṣābhyo vrīhīñ charade māṣatilau hemantaśiśirābhyām |
column2: He gave to the spring the sap [1], to the hot season barley, to the rains plants, to autumn rice, beans and sesamum to winter and the cool season.

column1: tenendram prajāpatir ayājayat tato vā indra indro 'bhavat tasmād āhus |
column2: Prajapati made Indra sacrifice with it. Then indeed did Indra become Indra;

column1: ānujāvarasya yajña iti sa hy etenāgre 'yajata |
column2: therefore they say, 'It is the sacrifice of the inferior', for he by it first sacrificed.

column1: eṣa ha vai kuṇapam atti yaḥ sattre pratigṛhṇāti puruṣakuṇapam aśvakuṇapam |
column2: He eats a corpse who accepts a present at a Sattra; a human corpse or the corpse of a horse.

column1: gaur vā annam |
column2: Food is the cow;

column1: yena pātreṇānnam bibhrati yat tan na nirṇenijati tato 'dhi | malaṃ jāyate |
column2: in that he does not purify the vessel in which they carry food, filth is produced from it [2].

column1: eka eva yajeta | eko hi prajāpatir ārdhnot |
column2: One should sacrifice by oneself, for Prajapati prospered by himself.

column1: dvādaśa rātrīr dīkṣitaḥ syāt |
column2: One should be consecrated for twelve nights;

column1: dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpatir {vāvaiṣa < vāvaiṣas} eṣa ha tvai jāyate yas tapaso 'dhi jāyate caturdhā vā etās tisrastisro rātrayo yad dvādaśo 'pasadas |
column2: the year consists of twelve months, Prajapati is the year, he is Prajapati, he is born indeed who is born from fervour. The twelve Upasads are these four sets of three nights;

column1: yāḥ prathamā yajñaṃ tābhiḥ sam bharati yā dvitīyā yajñaṃ tābhir ā rabhate | yās tṛtīyāḥ pātrāṇi tābhir nir ṇenikte yāś caturthīr api tābhir ātmānam antarataḥ śundhate yo vā asya paśum atti māṃsaṃ so 'tti yaḥ puroḍāśam matiṣkaṃ {sa < sas} yaḥ parivāpam purīṣaṃ {sa < sas} ya ājyam majjānaṃ {sa < sas} yaḥ somaṃ svedaṃ sas |
column2: with the first three he prepares the sacrifice, with the second three he grasps the sacrifice [3], with the third three he cleanses the vessels, and with the fourth three he purifies himself within. He who eats his victim, eats his flesh, who eats his sacrificial cake, eats his brains, who eats his fried grain, eats his excrement, who eats his ghee, eats his marrow, who eats his Soma, eats his sweat, and also he eats the excrements from his head, who accepts (a present) at the twelve-day (rite).

column1: api ha vā asya śīrṣaṇyā niṣpadaḥ prati gṛhṇāti yo dvādaśāhe pratigṛhṇāti tasmād dvādaśāhena na yājyam pāpmano vyāvṛttyai |
column2: Therefore one should not cause one to sacrifice with the twelve-day (rite), to avert evil. The Horse Sacrifice (continued) To one hail! To two hail!

column1: ekasmai svāhā dvābhyāṃ svāhā tribhyaḥ svāhā caturbhyaḥ svāhā pañcabhyaḥ svāhā ṣaḍbhyaḥ svāhā saptabhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To three hail! To four hail! To five hail! To six hail! To seven hail!

column1: aṣṭābhyaḥ svāhā navabhyaḥ svāhā daśabhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To eight hail! To nine hail! To ten hail! To eleven hail! To twelve hail!

column1: ekādaśabhyaḥ svāhā dvādaśabhyaḥ svāhā trayodaśabhyaḥ svāhā caturdaśabhyaḥ svāhā pañcadaśabhyaḥ svāhā ṣoḍaśabhyaḥ svāhā saptadaśabhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To two hundred hail! To all hail! To one hail! To three hail! To five hail!

column1: aṣṭādaśabhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To six hail! To eight hail!

column1: ekān na viṃśatyai svāhā navaviṃśatyai svāhā |
column2: To twenty hail! To ninety-five hail! To a hundred hail! To all hail!

column1: ekādaśabhyaḥ svāhā trayodāsabhyaḥ svāhā pañcadaśabhyaḥ svāhā saptadaśabhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To ten hail! To twenty hail! To thirty hail!

column1: ekān na catvāriṃśate svāhā navacatvāriṃśate svāhā |
column2: To forty hail! To fifty hail!

column1: ekān na ṣaṣṭyai svāhā navaṣaṣṭyai svāhā |
column2: To sixty hail! To seventy hail!

column1: ekān nāśītyai svāhā navāśītyai svāhā |
column2: To eighty hail! To ninety hail!

column1: ekān na śatāya svāhā śatāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To a hundred hail! To all hail!

column1: dvābhyāṃ svāhā caturbhyaḥ svāhā ṣaḍbhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To twenty hail! To forty hail! To sixty hail!

column1: aṣṭānavatyai svāhā śatāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To eighty hail! To a hundred hail! To all hail!

column1: ekādaśabhyaḥ svāhā trayodāsabhyaḥ svāhā pañcadaśabhyaḥ svāhā saptadaśabhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To fifty hail! To a hundred hail! To two hundred hail! To three hundred hail!

column1: ekān na catvāriṃśate svāhā navacatvāriṃśate svāhā |
column2: To four hundred hail! To five hundred hail!

column1: ekān na ṣaṣṭyai svāhā navaṣaṣṭyai svāhā |
column2: To six hundred hail! To seven hundred hail! To eight hundred hail!

column1: ekān nāśītyai svāhā navāśītyai svāhā |
column2: To nine hundred hail! To a thousand hail!

column1: ekān na śatāya svāhā śatāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To all hail! To a hundred hail! To a thousand hail! To ten thousand hail!

column1: aśītyai svāhā navatyai svāhā śatāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To a hundred thousand hail! To ten hundred thousand hail! To ten million hail!

column1: aśītyai svāhā śatāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To a hundred million hail! To a thousand million hail!

column1: aṣṭābhyaḥ śatebhyaḥ svāhā navabhyaḥ śatebhyaḥ svāhā sahasrāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To ten thousand million hail! To a hundred thousand million hail!

column1: śatāya svāhā sahasrāya svāhā |
column2: To ten hundred thousand million hail!

column1: uṣase svāhā vyuṣṭyai svāhā | udeṣyate svāhā |
column2: To dawn hail! To the dawning hail! To him that will rise hail!

column1: uditāya svāhā suvargāya svāhā lokāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To the rising hail! To the risen hail! To heaven hail! To the world hail! To all hail!

column1: prajavaṃ vā etena yanti yad daśamam ahar |
column2: In that it is the tenth day they loosen their sins.

column1: pāpāvahīyaṃ vā etena bhavanti yad daśamam ahar yo vai prajavaṃ yatām apathena pratipadyate ya sthāṇuṃ hanti yo bhreṣaṃ nyeti sa hīyate sa yo vai daśame 'hann avivākya upahanyate sa hīyate tasmai ya upahatāya vyāha tam evānvārabhya sam aśnute |
column2: He who among men going swiftly falls in with a trackless way, he who strikes a post, and he who stumbles, are left out. So he, who on this tenth day, the Avivakya, comes to grief, is left out. If one points out (an error) to one who comes to grief, he seizes hold of him and comes out successfully, and then the one who pointed out (his error) is left out [1].

column1: hīyate tasmād daśame 'hann avivākya upahatāya na vyucyam atho khalv āhur yajñasya vai samṛddhena devāḥ suvargaṃ lokam āyan yajñasya vyṛddhenāsurān parābhāvayann iti yat khalu vai yajñasya samṛddhaṃ tad yajamānasya yad vyṛddhaṃ tad bhrātṛvyasya sa yo vai daśame 'hann avivākya upahanyate sa evāti recayati te ye bāhyā dṛśīkavaḥ |
column2: Therefore on the tenth day, the Avivakya, one should not point out (errors) to one who comes to grief. Or rather they say, 'By that which was successful in the sacrifice the gods went to the world of heaven, and overcame the Asuras by what was unsuccessful.' What is successful in the sacrifice belongs to the sacrificer, what is unsuccessful to his enemy. Now he, who comes to grief on the tenth day, the Avivakya, produces overmuch.

column1: syus te vi brūyus |
column2: Those who are outside as spectators [2] should point out (his error).

column1: yadi tatra na vindeyur antaḥsadasād vyucyam |
column2: If there be none there, then (the error) should be pointed out from within the Sadas.

column1: tad vyucyam eva |
column2: At any rate it should be pointed out.

column1: atha vā etat sarparājñiyā ṛgbhi stuvanti |
column2: They sing the verses of the serpent queen on that day.

column1: iyaṃ vai sarpato rājñī yad vā asyāṃ kiṃ cārcanti yad ānṛcus teneyaṃ sarparājñī te yad eva kiṃ ca vācānṛcur yad ato 'dhy arcitāraḥ |
column2: The queen of what creeps is this (earth). Whatever on this (earth) they praise, whatever they have praised, through that is this (earth) the serpent queen.

column1: tad ubhayam āptvāvarudhyot tiṣṭhāmeti tābhir manasā stuvate na vā imām aśvaratho nāśvatarīrathaḥ sadyaḥ paryāptum arhati mano vā imāṃ sadyaḥ paryāptum arhati manaḥ paribhavitum atha brahma vadanti parimitā vā ṛcaḥ parimitāni sāmāni parimitāni yajūṃṣy athaitasyaivānto nāsti yad brahma tat pratigṛṇata ā cakṣīta sa pratigaraḥ |
column2: Now whatever they have praised with speech and what they will praise thereafter, (it is done thinking), 'Having won both and obtained them, let us stop.' They sing these (verses) with the mind. Neither a horse chariot nor a mule chariot can in one moment encompass this (earth), but mind can in one moment encompass it, mind can overcome it. Then they repeat the Brahman. The Rc verses are limited, the Samans are limited, and the Yajuses are limited, but of the Brahman there is no end, and that he should declare to the one who responds.

column1: brahmavādino vadanti kiṃ dvādaśāhasya prathamenāhnartvijāṃ yajamāno vṛṅkta iti teja indriyam iti kiṃ dvitīyeneti prāṇān annādyam iti kiṃ tṛtīyeneti trīn imāM lokān iti kiṃ caturtheneti catuṣpadaḥ paśūn iti kim pañcameneti pañcākṣarām paṅktim iti kiṃ ṣaṣṭheneti ṣaḍ ṛtūn iti kiṃ saptameneti saptapadāṃ śakvarīm iti | kim aṣṭameneti | aṣṭākṣarāṃ gāyatrīm iti kiṃ navameneti trivṛtaṃ stomam iti kiṃ daśameneti daśākṣarāṃ virājam iti kim ekādaśeneti | ekādaśākṣarāṃ tṛṣṭubham iti kiṃ dvādaśeneti dvādaśākṣarāṃ jagatīm iti |
column2: The theologians say, 'By the first day of the twelve-day rite what is it that the sacrificer takes from the priests?' 'Brilliance and power' is (the answer). 'What by the second?' 'The breaths and food.' 'What by the third?' 'These three worlds.' 'What by the fourth?' 'Four-footed cattle.' 'What by the fifth?' 'The Pankti with its elements.' 'What by the sixth?' 'The six seasons.' 'What by the seventh?' 'The Çakvari with its seven feet.' 'What by the eighth?' 'The Gayatri with its eight syllables.' 'What by the ninth?' 'The Trivrt Stoma.' 'What by the tenth?' 'The Viraj with its ten syllables.' 'What by the eleventh?' 'The Tristubh with its eleven syllables.' 'What by the twelfth?' 'The Jagati with its twelve syllables.' So much is there as that.

column1: yāvad evāsti tad eṣāṃ vṛṅkte |
column2: So much as that he takes from them.

column1: eṣa vā āpto dvādaśāho yat trayodaśarātraḥ samānaṃ hy etad ahar yat prāyaṇīyaś codayanīyaś ca tryatirātro bhavati traya ime lokās |
column2: (The rite) of thirteen nights is a complete (rite of) twelve days, for the opening and concluding days are the same. There are three Atiratras, three are these worlds, for the obtaining of these worlds.

column1: eṣāṃ lokānām āptyai prāṇo vai prathamo 'tirātro vyāno dvitīyo 'pānas tṛtīyaḥ prāṇāpānodāneṣv evānnādye prati tiṣṭhanti sarvam āyur yanti ya evaṃ vidvāṃsas trayodaśarātram āsate tad āhus |
column2: The first Atiratra is the expiration, the second cross-breathing, the third inspiration; verily they find support in expiration, inspiration, out-breathing, and food, and reach their full life, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of thirteen nights.

column1: yad dvādaśāhas tāṃ vi chindyur yan madhye 'tirātraṃ kuryur upadāsukā gṛhapater vāk syāt | upariṣṭāc chandomānām mahāvrataṃ kurvanti saṃtatām eva vācam ava runddhe 'nupadāsukā gṛhapater vāg bhavati paśavo vai chandomā annam mahāvratam |
column2: They say, '(The rite) of twelve days is the sequence of speech. They would cleave it if they put an Atiratra in the middle, and the speech of the householder would be liable to fail.' They perform the Mahavrata after the Chandomas; verily they maintain the sequence of speech, and the speech of the householder is not likely to fail.

column1: yad upariṣṭāc chandomānām mahāvrataṃ kurvanti paśuṣu caivānnādye ca prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: in that they perform the Mahavrata after the Chandomas, they find support in cattle and in food.

column1: ubhayor lokayor ṛdhnuyāmeti ta etaṃ caturdaśarātram apaśyan tam āharan tenāyajanta tato vai ta ubhayor lokayor ārdhnuvann asmiṃś cāmuṣmiṃś ca ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaś caturdaśarātram āsata ubhayor eva lokayor ṛdhnuvanty asmiṃś cāmuṣmiṃś ca caturdaśarātro bhavati sapta grāmyā oṣadhayaḥ saptāraṇyā ubhayīṣām avaruddhyai yat parācīnāni prāṣṭhāni |
column2: The Adityas desired, 'May we be prosperous in both worlds.' They saw this (rite) of fourteen nights; they grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed they prospered in both worlds, this and yonder. Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of fourteen nights, prosper in both worlds, this and yonder. (The rite) is of fourteen nights, there are seven domesticated plants and seven wild;

column1: bhavanty amum eva tair lokam abhi jayanti yat pratīcīnāni pṛṣṭhāni bhavantīmam eva tair lokam abhi jayanti trayastriṃśau madhyata stomau bhavataḥ sāmrājyam eva gachanti |
column2: In that the Prsthas are performed in succession [1], they conquer by them yonder world. In that the Prsthas are reversed, they conquer by them this world. There are two Trayastrinça Stomas in the middle; verily they attain sovereignty.

column1: adhirājau bhavato 'dhirājā eva samānānām bhavanti | atirātrā vabhito bhavataḥ parigṛhītyai |
column2: (These two) are overlords; verily they become overlords of their peers. There are Atiratras on either side, for security.

column1: prajāpatiḥ suvargaṃ lokam ait taṃ devā anv āyan tān ādityāś ca paśavaś cānv āyan te devā abruvan yān paśūn upājīviṣma ta ime 'nvāgmann iti tebhya etaṃ caturdaśarātram praty auhan ta ādityāḥ pṛṣṭhaiḥ suvargaṃ lokam ārohan tryahābhyām asmiM loke paśūn praty auhan pṛṣṭhair ādityā amuṣmiM loka ārdhnuvan tryahābhyām asmin |
column2: The gods followed him, and the Adityas and the cattle followed them. The gods said, 'The cattle on which we have lived have followed us.' They arranged this (rite) of fourteen nights away for them. The Adityas mounted the world of heaven with the Prsthas; they arranged the cattle in this world with the two Tryahas. By means of the Prsthas the Adityas prospered in yonder world, the cattle in this world by the Tryahas [1].

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaś caturdaśarātram āsata ubhayor eva lokayor ṛdhnuvanty asmiṃś cāmuṣmiṃś ca pṛṣṭhair evāmuṣmiM loka ṛdhnuvanti tryahābhyām asmiM loke jyotir gaur āyur iti tryaho bhavati |
column2: Those who, knowing thus, perform (the rite of) fourteen nights, prosper in both worlds, in this and in yonder; by the Prsthas they prosper in yonder world and by the Tryahas in this world. The three days are the Jyotis, Go, and Ayus.

column1: iyaṃ vāva jyotir antarikṣaṃ gaur asāv āyus |
column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere, the Ayus yonder (sky);

column1: imān eva lokān abhyārohanti yad anyataḥ pṛṣṭhāni syur vivivadhaṃ syāt |
column2: verily they mount upon these worlds. If the Prsthas were on one side, there would be a lack of balance;

column1: madhye pṛṣṭhāni bhavanti savivadhatvāya |
column2: the Prsthas are in the middle, for balance [2].

column1: ojo vai vīryam pṛṣṭhāni |
column2: The Prsthas are force and strength;

column1: oja eva vīryam madhyato dadhate bṛhadrathaṃtarābhyāṃ yanti |
column2: verily they place force and strength in the middle. They proceed with the Brhat and the Rathantara (Samans).

column1: iyaṃ vāva rathaṃtaram asau bṛhat |
column2: The Rathantara is this (earth), the Brhat yonder (sky);

column1: ābhyām eva yanti |
column2: verily with them do they proceed;

column1: atho anayor eva prati tiṣṭhani |
column2: verily also in them they find support.

column1: ete vai yajñasyāñjasāyanī srutī tābhyām eva suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti parāñco vā ete suvargaṃ lokam abhyārohanti ye parācīnāni pṛṣṭhāny upayanti pratyañ tryaho bhavati pratyavarūḍhyā atho pratiṣṭhiyai |
column2: These indeed are the quick paths of the sacrifice; verily by them do they proceed to the world of heaven. They mount the world of heaven turning away (from earth), who perform the Prsthas in succession. The Tryaha is reversed, for the return (from heaven), and for support.

column1: ubhayor lokayor ṛddhvot tiṣṭhanti caturdaśaitās |
column2: Having prospered in either world they cease (the rite). The (nights) are fourteen.

column1: tāsāṃ yā daśa daśākṣarā virāḍ annaṃ virāḍ virājaivānnādyam ava rundhate yāś catasraś catasro diśo dikṣv eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: As for ten of them, the Viraj is ten-syllabled, the Viraj is food; verily by the Viraj they win food. As for four, the quarters are four; verily they find support in the quarters.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavataḥ parigṛhītyai |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, for security.

column1: indro vai sadṛṅ devatābhir āsīt sa na vyāvṛtam agachat sa prajāpatim upādhāvat tasmā etam pañcadaśarātram pāyachat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai so 'nyābhir devatābhir vyāvṛtam agachat |
column2: Indra was on a level with the gods, he was not distinguished from them. He ran up to Prajapati; he gave him this (rite) of fifteen nights. He grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed he became distinguished from the other gods.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ pañcadaśarātram āsate vyāvṛtam eva pāpmanā bhrātṛvyeṇa gachanti jyotir gaur āyur iti tryaho bhavati |
column2: Those who knowing thus perform (the rite) of fifteen nights attain distinction from the evil enemy. The three days are Jyotis, Go, and Ayus.

column1: iyaṃ vāva jyotir antarikṣam | gaur asāv āyus |
column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere [1], the Ayus yonder (sky);

column1: eṣv eva lokeṣu prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they find support in these worlds.

column1: asattraṃ vā etad yad achandomam |
column2: There can be no Sattra where there is no Chandoma;

column1: yac chandomā bhavanti tena sattram | devatā eva pṛṣṭhair ava rundhate paśūñ chandomais |
column2: in that there axe Chandomas, there is the Sattra. The gods they win by the Prsthas, the cattle by the Chandomas.

column1: ojasy eva vīrye paśuṣu prati tiṣṭhanti pañcadaśarātro bhavati pañcadaśo vajras |
column2: The Prsthas are force and strength, the strength, and in cattle, they Chandomas cattle; verily in force and find support. (The rite) is of fifteen nights; the bolt is fifteenfold;

column1: vajram eva bhrātṛvyebhyaḥ pra haranti |
column2: verily they hurl the bolt at their enemies.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavatas |
column2: He was afraid of the Asuras.

column1: indriyasya parigṛhītyai | indro vai śithila ivāpratiṣṭhita āsīt so 'surebhyo 'bibhet sa prajāpatim upādhāvat tasmā etam pañcadaśarātraṃ vajram prāyachat tenāsurān parābhāvya vijitya śriyam agachat |
column2: He ran up to Prajapati; he gave him this (rite) of fifteen nights as a bolt. With it he overcame and conquered the Asuras and attained prosperity. By the Agnistut he burned away the evil, by (the rite) of fifteen nights he placed force, might, power, and strength in himself.

column1: agniṣṭutā pāpmānaṃ nir adahata pañcadaśarātreṇaujo balam indriyaṃ vīryam ātmann adhatta ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ pañcadaśarātram āsate bhrātṛvyān eva parābhāvya vijitya śriyaṃ gachanti |
column2: Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of fifteen nights overcome and conquer their enemies and attain prosperity. By the Agnistut they burn away the evil [1], by (the rite) of fifteen nights they place force, might, power, and strength in themselves.

column1: agniṣṭutā pāpmānaṃ niḥ |
column2: These (nights) are full of cattle.

column1: dahante pañcadaśarātreṇaujo balam indriyaṃ vīryam ātman dadhate | etā eva paśavyāḥ pañcadaśa vā ardhamāsasya rātrayas |
column2: Fifteen indeed are the nights of the half-month, the year is made up of half-months, cattle are born throughout the year; therefore (these nights) are full of cattle.

column1: etā eva suvargyāḥ pañcadaśa vā ardhamāsasya rātrayas | ardhamāsaśaḥ saṃvatsara āpyate saṃvatsaraḥ suvargo lokas tasmād suvargyās |
column2: These (nights) are heavenly. Fifteen indeed are the nights of the half-month, the year is made up of halfmonths, the world of heaven is the year; verily (these nights) are heavenly.

column1: jyotir gaur āyur iti tryaho bhavati |
column2: There are the three days, Jyotis, Ayus, and Go.

column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere [2], the Ayus yonder (sky);

column2: verily they place force and strength in the middle. They proceed with the Brhat and the Rathantara (Samans).

column2: verily also in them they find support.

column2: These indeed are the quick paths of the sacrifice; verily by them do they proceed to the world of heaven [3].

column1: yanti parāñco vā ete suvargaṃ lokam abhyārohanti ye parācīnāni pṛṣṭhāny upayanti pratyañ tryaho bhavati pratyavarūḍhyā atho pratiṣṭhiyai |
column2: They mount the world of heaven turning away (from earth), who perform the Prsthas in succession. The Tryaha is reversed, for the return (from heaven), and for support.

column2: Having prospered in either world they cease (the rite). These (nights) are fifteen. As for ten of them, the Viraj is ten-syllabled, the Viraj is food; verily by the Viraj they win food. As for five, the quarters are five;

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavatas |
column2: verily they find support in the quarters.

column1: indriyasya vīryasya prajāyati paśūnām parigṛhītyai |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, for securing power, strength, offspring, and cattle.

column1: prajāpatir akāmayata | annādaḥ syām iti sa etaṃ saptadaśarātram apaśyat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai so 'nnādo 'bhavat |
column2: Prajapati desired, 'May I be an eater of food.' He saw this (rite of) seventeen nights; he grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed he became an eater of food.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ saptadaśarātram āsate 'nnādā eva bhavanti pañcāho bhavati pañca vā ṛtavaḥ saṃvatsaras |
column2: Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of seventeen nights, become eaters of food. There is a period of five days; the seasons are five in the year;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva saṃvatsare prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily in the seasons and the year they find sup port.

column1: atho pañcākṣarā paṅktiḥ pāṅkto yajñas |
column2: Again the Pankti is of five elements, the sacrifice is fivefold;

column1: yajñam evāva rundhate |
column2: verily they win the sacrifice.

column1: asattraṃ vā etat | yad achandomam |
column2: There can be no Sattra where there is no Chandoma;

column1: yac chandomā bhavanti tena sattram |
column2: in that there are Chandomas, there is the sacrifice.

column1: devatā eva pṛṣṭhair ava rundhate paśūñ chandomais |
column2: The gods they win by the Prsthas, the cattle by the Chandomas.

column1: ojasy eva vīrye paśuṣu prati tiṣṭhanti saptadaśarātro bhavati saptadaśaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpater āptyai | atirātrāv abhito bhavatas |
column2: The Prsthas are force and strength, the Chandomas cattle; verily in force and strength, and in cattle, they find support. (The rite is) of seventeen nights; Prajapati is seventeenfold;

column1: annādyasya parigṛhītyai |
column2: (verily it serves) to obtain Prajapati.

column1: sā virāḍ vikramyātiṣṭhad brahmaṇā deveṣv annenāsureṣu te devā akāmayanta |
column2: The Viraj dividing itself stayed among the gods with the holy power (Brahman), among the Asuras with food.

column1: ubhayaṃ saṃ vṛñjīmahi brahma cānnaṃ ceti ta etā viṃśatiṃ rātrīr apaśyan tato vai ta ubhayaṃ sam avṛñjata brahma cānnaṃ ca brahmavarcasino 'nnādā abhavan ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa etā āsata ubhayam eva saṃ vṛñjate brahma cānnaṃ ca |
column2: They saw (the rite of) these twenty nights. Then indeed they acquired both the holy power (Brahman) and food, and became resplendent and eaters of food. Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite of) these nights, acquire both the holy power (Brahman) and food [1], and become resplendent and eaters of food.

column1: brahmavarcasino 'nnādā bhavanti dve vā ete virājau tayor eva nānā prati tiṣṭhanti viṃśo vai puruṣo daśa hastyā aṅgulayo daśa padyās |
column2: They (make up) two Virajs; verily separately in them they find support. Man is twentyfold, ten fingers and ten toes;

column1: yāvān eva puruṣas tam āptvot tiṣṭhanti jyotir gaur āyur iti tryahā bhavanti |
column2: verily obtaining the greatness of man they cease (the rite). There are Tryahas consisting of Jyotis, Go, and Ayus.

column1: iyaṃ vāva jyotir antarikṣaṃ gaur asāv āyus |
column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere, the Ayus yonder (sky);

column1: imān eva lokān abhyārohanti |
column2: verily they mount upon these worlds.

column1: abhipūrvaṃ tryahā bhavanti |
column2: The Tryahas go in order;

column1: abhipūrvam eva suvargam | lokam abhyārohanti yad anyataḥ pṛṣṭhāni madhye pṛṣṭhāni bhavanti savivadhatvāya |
column2: verily in order they mount the world of heaven [2]. If the Prsthas were on one side there would be a lack of balance; the Prsthas are in the middle, for balance.

column1: ojo vai vīryam pṛṣṭhāni |
column2: The Prsthas are force and strength;

column1: oja eva vīryam madhyato dadhate bṛhadrathaṃtarābhyāṃ yanti |
column2: verily they place force and strength in the middle. They proceed with the Brhat and the Rathantara (Samans).

column1: iyaṃ vāva rathaṃtaram asau bṛhat |
column2: The Rathantara is this (earth), the Brhat yonder (sky);

column1: ābhyām eva yanti | atho anayor eva prati tiṣṭhani |
column2: verily with them do they proceed, verily also in them they find support.

column1: ete vai yajñasyāñjasāyanī srutī tābhyām eva suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti parāñco vā ete suvargaṃ lokam abhyārohanti ye parācīnāni pṛṣṭhāny upayanti pratyañ tryaho bhavati pratyavarūḍhyā atho pratiṣṭhiyai |
column2: These indeed are the quick paths of the sacrifice; verily by them do they proceed to the world of heaven. They mount the world of heaven turning away (from earth), who perform the Prsthas in succession. The Tryaha is re versed, for the return (from heaven), and for support.

column1: ubhayor lokayor ṛddhvot tiṣṭhanti | atirātrāv abhito bhavatas | brahmavarcasasyānnādyasya pari gṛhītyai |
column2: Having prospered in either world they cease (the rite). There are Atiratras on either side, for securing splendour and food.

column1: asāva ādityo 'smiM loka āsīt taṃ devāḥ pṛṣṭhaiḥ parigṛhya suvargaṃ lokam agamayan parair avastāt pary agṛhṇan divākīrtyena suvarge loke praty asthāpayan paraiḥ parastāt pary agṛhṇan pṛṣṭhair upāvārohan |
column2: The gods surrounded it with the Prsthas and removed it to the world of heaven. They surrounded it from below with the Para (Samans), and placed it with the Divakirtya (Saman) in the world of heaven. They surrounded it from above with the Para (Samans), and with the Prsthas they descended (from heaven).

column1: sa vā asāv ādityo 'muṣmiM loke parair ubhayataḥ parigṛhītas |
column2: Yonder sun indeed in yonder world is surrounded by the Para (Samans) on both sides.

column1: yat pṛṣṭhāni bhavanti suvargam eva tair lokaṃ yajamānā yanti parair avastāt pari gṛhṇanti divākīrtyena |
column2: In that there are Prsthas the sacrificers go by them to the world of heaven; they surround it from below with the Para (Samans), and by the Divakirtya (Saman) find support [1] in the world of heaven.

column1: suvarge loke prati tiṣṭhanti paraiḥ parastāt pari gṛhṇanti pṛṣṭhair upāvarohanti yat pare parastān na syuḥ parāsuvargāl lokān niṣ padyeranñcaḥ yad avastān na syuḥ prajā nir daheyus |
column2: They surround it from above with the Para (Samans), and descend with the Prsthas. If there were not Paras above, they would depart away from the world of heaven; if there were none below, they would. burn creatures.

column1: abhito divākīrtyam paraḥsāmāno bhavanti suvarga evaināM loka ubhayataḥ pari gṛhṇanti yajamānā vai divākīrtyam |
column2: There are Parahsamans on both sides of the Divakirtya; verily they surround them on both sides in the world of heaven. The Divakirtya is the sacrificers, the Parahsamans the year;

column1: saṃvatsaraḥ paraḥsāmānas |
column2: the Parahsamans are on both sides of the Divakirtya;

column1: abhito divākīrtyam paraḥsāmāno bhavanti saṃvatsara evobhayataḥ | prati tiṣṭhanti pṛṣṭhaṃ vai divākīrtyam pārśve paraḥsāmānas |
column2: The Divakirtya is the back, the Parahsamans the two sides; the Parahsamans are on both sides of the Divakirtya; therefore the sides are on both sides of the back.

column2: They desired, 'Let us strike off the misfortune, the evil of death, and reach the conclave of the gods.' They saw this twenty-four night (rite); they grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then they struck off the misfortune, the evil of death, and reached the conclave of the gods. Those who knowing thus perform the twenty-four night (rite) strike off the misfortune, the evil, and win prosperity, for the conclave of the gods is in the case of man [1] prosperity.

column2: The year consists of six seasons, and, entering it, the months, the half-months and the seasons reached the conclave of the gods. Those who knowing thus perform the twenty-four night rite, entering the year, reach a better station. There are three Trayastrinças before, and three Trayastrinças behind; verily with Trayastrinças on either hand they strike off the evil of misfortune and in the middle reach the conclave of the gods [2], for the conclave of the gods is the Prsthas.

column1: jāmi vā etat kurvanti yat trayas trayastriṃśā anvañcas | madhye 'nirukto bhavati tenājāmi |
column2: There is uniformity in that there are three Trayastrinças in succession, and a break in the uniformity in that there is in the middle one which is not defined.

column1: ūrdhvāni pṛṣṭhāni bhavanty ūrdhvāś chandomās |
column2: The Prsthas go onwards, the Chandomas go onwards;

column1: ubhābhyāṃ rūpābhyāṃ suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti |
column2: with both forms they go to the world of heaven.

column1: asattraṃ vā etad yad achandomam |
column2: There can be no Sattra where there is no Chandoma;

column1: yac chandomā bhavanti tena sattram |
column2: in that there are Chandomas, there is the Sattra.

column1: devatā eva pṛṣṭhair ava rundhate paśūñ chandomais | ojo vai vīryam pṛṣṭhāni paśavaḥ |
column2: The gods they win by the Prsthas, the cattle by the Chandomas. The Prsthas are force and strength, the Chandomas cattle [3];

column1: ojasy eva vīrye paśuṣu prati tiṣṭhanti trayas trayastriṃśā avastād bhavanti trayas trayastriṃśāḥ parastān madhye pṛṣṭhāni |
column2: verily in force and strength and in cattle they find support. There are three Trayastrinças before, and three Trayastrinças behind; in the middle there are the Prsthas.

column1: uro vai trayastriṃśā ātmā pṛṣṭhāni |
column2: The Trayastrinças are the breast, the Prsthas the breath;

column1: ātmana eva tad yajamānāḥ śarma nahyante 'nārtyai bṛhadrathaṃtarābhyāṃ yanti |
column2: verily thus the sacrificers don a protection for the breath, to avoid injury. They proceed with the Brhat and the Rathantara.

column1: iyaṃ vāva rathaṃtaram asau bṛhat |
column2: The Rathantara is this (world), the Brhat yonder (world);

column1: ābhyām eva yanti |
column2: verily they proceed with them;

column1: atho anayor eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily also in them they find support.

column1: ete vai yajñasyāñjasāyanī srutī tābhyām eva |
column2: These indeed are the quick paths of the sacrifice;

column1: suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti parāñco vā ete suvargaṃ lokam abhyārohanti ye parācīnāni pṛṣṭhāny upayanti pratyaṅ ṣaḍaho bhavati pratyavarūḍhyā atho pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: verily by them do they [4] proceed to the world of heaven. They mount the world of heaven turning away (from earth) who perform the Prsthas in succession. The six-day (rite) is reversed for the return (from the heaven), and for support.

column1: ubhayor lokayor ṛddhvot tiṣṭhanti trivṛto 'dhi trivṛtam upa yanti stomānāṃ sampattyai prabhavāya jyotir agniṣṭomo bhavati |
column2: Having prospered in either world they cease (the rite). They go from a Trivrt to a Trivrt, for the attainment of the Stomas, for pre eminence. There is an Agnistoma in the Jyotis form.

column1: ayaṃ vāva sa kṣayas |
column2: This dwelling is this (world);

column1: asmād eva tena kṣayān na yanti caturviṃśatirātro bhavati caturviṃśatir ardhamāsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ suvargo lokaḥ saṃvatsara eva suvarge loke prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily by reason thereof they depart not from this dwelling. (The rite is one) of twenty-four nights. Twenty-four halfmonths make up the year, the year is the world of heaven; verily they find support in the year, the world of heaven.

column1: atho caturviṃśatyakṣarā gāyatrī gāyatrī brahmavarcasam |
column2: Now the Gayatri is of twenty-four syllables;

column1: gāyatriyaiva brahmavarcasam ava rundhate | atirātrāv abhito bhavatas | brahmavarcasasya parigṛhītyai |
column2: the Gayatri is splendour; verily by the Gayatri they win splendour. There are Atiratras on either side, to secure splendour.

column1: ṛkṣā vā iyam alomakāsīt sākāmayata |
column2: This (earth) was bare and hairless.

column1: oṣadhībhir vanaspatibhiḥ pra jāyeyeti saitās triṃśataṃ rātrīr apaśyat tato vā iyam oṣadhībhir vanaspatibhiḥ prājāyata ye prajākāmāḥ paśukāmāḥ syus ta etā āsīran praiva jāyante prajayā paśubhis |
column2: It desired, 'Let me be propagated with plants and trees.' It saw these thirty nights. Then indeed it was propagated with plants and trees. Those who desire offspring and cattle should perform (the rite of) these (nights); they are propagated with offspring and cattle.

column1: iyaṃ vā akṣudhyat saitāṃ virājam apaśyat tām ātman dhitvānnādyam avārunddhauṣadhīḥ |
column2: This (earth) was hungry. It saw this Viraj, and placing it within itself it won food, plants [1], trees, offspring, cattle.

column1: vanaspatīn prajām paśūn tenāvardhata sā jemānam amhimānam agachat |
column2: Thereby it grew, it attained victoriousness and greatness.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa etā āsate virājam evātman dhitvānnādyam ava rundhate vardhante prajayā paśubhis |
column2: Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite of) these (nights), placing the Viraj in themselves, win food, grow great with offspring and cattle, and attain victoriousness and might.

column1: jemānam mahimānaṃ gachanti jyotir atirātro bhavati suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai pṛṣṭhyaḥ ṣaḍaho bhavati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ ṣaṭ pṛṣṭhāni pṛṣṭhair evartūn anvārohanty ṛtubhiḥ saṃvatsaram |
column2: There is a Jyotistoma Atiratra, for the revealing of the world of heaven. There is a Prsthya Sadaha. The seasons are six, the Prsthas are six; verily by the Prsthas they reach the seasons, with the seasons the year;

column1: te saṃvatsara eva |
column2: the year [2] they find support.

column1: prati tiṣṭhanti trayastriṃśāt trayastriṃśam upa yanti yajñasya saṃtatyai |
column2: From the Trayastrinças they go to the Trayastrinça, for the continuity of the sacrifice.

column1: atho prajāpatir vai trayastriṃśaḥ prajāpatim evā rabhante pratiṣṭhityai triṇavo bhavati vijityai |
column2: Now the Trayastrinça is Prajapati; verily they seize hold of Prajapati, for support. There is a Trinava, for victory.

column1: ekaviṃśo bhavati pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: There is an Ekavinça, for support;

column1: atho rucam evātman dadhate trivṛd agniṣṭud bhavati pāpmānam eva tena nir dahante 'tho tejo vai trivṛt teja evātman dadhate pañcadaśa indrastomo bhavati |
column2: There is a praise of Agni with the Trivrt; verily they bum away evil with it. Now the Trivrt is brilliance; verily they place brilliance in themselves. There is a praise of Indra with the Pañcadaça;

column1: indriyam evāva |
column2: verily they win power (indriyá) [3].

column1: rundhate saptadaśo bhavati |
column2: There is a Saptadaça, for the winning of food;

column1: atho praiva tena jāyante |
column2: verily by it they are propagated.

column1: ekaviṃśo bhavati rpatiṣṭhityai |
column2: There is an Ekavinça, for support;

column1: atho rucam evātman dadhate caturviṃśo bhavati caturviṃśatir ardhamāsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ suvargo lokaḥ saṃvatsara eva suvarge loke prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they place radiance in themselves. There is a Caturvinça. Twenty-four half-months make up the year, the year is the world of heaven; verily they find support in the year, the world of heaven.

column1: atho eṣa vai viṣūvān viṣūvanto bhavanti ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa etā āsate caturviṃśāt pṛṣṭhāny upa yanti saṃvatsara eva pratiṣṭhāya |
column2: Now there is the chief (day), and those who knowing thus perform (the rite of) these (nights) become the chief. From the Caturvinça they go to the Prsthas.

column1: devatā abhyārohanti trayastriṃśāt trayastriṃśam upa yanti trayastriṃśad vai devatās |
column2: Verily having found support in the year [4] they attain the gods. From the Trayastrinça they go to the Trayastrinça. The gods are three and thirty;

column1: devatāsv eva prati tiṣṭhanti triṇavo bhavati |
column2: verily in the gods they find support. There is a Trinava.

column1: ime vai lokās triṇavas |
column2: The Trinava is these worlds;

column1: eṣv eva lokeṣu prati tiṣṭhanti dvāv ekaviṃśau bhavataḥ pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: verily in these worlds they find support. There are two Ekavinças, for support;

column1: atho rucam evātman dadhate bahavaḥ ṣoḍaśino bhavanti tasmād bahavaḥ prajāsu vṛṣāṇas |
column2: verily they place radiance in themselves. There are many Sodaçins, and therefore there are many males among offspring.

column1: yad ete stomā vyatiṣaktā bhavanti tasmād iyam oṣadhībhir vanaspatibhir vyatiṣaktā |
column2: In that these Stomas are intermingled, therefore this (earth) is covered with mingled plants and trees [5].

column1: vyatiṣajyante prajayā paśubhir ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa etā āsate |
column2: Those who knowing thus perform (the rite of) these (nights) have both offspring and cattle.

column1: aklptā vā ete suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti |
column2: These go imperfect to the world of heaven, for they resort to various Stomas;

column1: uccāvacān hi stomān upayanti yad eta ūrdhvāḥ klptā stomā bhavanti klptā eva suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanty ubhayor ebhyo lokayoḥ kalpate triṃśad etās triṃśadakṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājaivānnādyam ava rundhate |
column2: in that the Stomas are arranged in order, they go in order to the world of heaven, and there is order in both these worlds. These (nights) are thirty in number, the Viraj has thirty syllables;

column1: annādyasya parigṛhītyai |
column2: verily by the Viraj they win food.

column1: {dvātriṃśadakṣarānuṣṭug < dvātriṃśadakṣarānuṣṭubh} ānuṣṭubhaḥ prajāpatiḥ svenaiva chandasā prajāpatim āptvā śriyaṃ gachanti |
column2: There are Atiratras on either hand, to secure food.

column1: śrīr hi manuṣyasya suvargo lokas |
column2: Prajapati went to the world of heaven.

column1: dvātriṃśad etās |
column2: They saw (the rite of) these thirty-two nights.

column1: {dvātriṃśadakṣarānuṣṭug < dvātriṃśadakṣarānuṣṭubh} vāg {anuṣṭup < anuṣṭubh} sarvām eva vācam āpnuvanti sarve vāco vaditāro bhavanti sarve hi śriyaṃ gachanti jyotir gaur āyur iti tryahā bhavanti |
column2: These (nights) are thirty-two, the Anustubh has thirty-two syllables, the Anustubh is speech; verily they gain all speech; all become speakers of speech, for all attain prosperity. There are the three days, Jyotis, Go, and Ayus.

column1: iyaṃ vāva jyotir antarikṣaṃ gaur asāv āyur imān eva lokān abhyārohanti |
column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere, and the Ayus yonder (sky); verily they mount upon these worlds.

column1: abhipūrvaṃ tryahā bhavanti |
column2: The three days occur in order;

column1: abhipūrvam eva suvargaṃ lokam abhyārohanti bṛhadrathaṃtarābhyāṃ yanti |
column2: verily in order do they mount upon the world of heaven. They proceed with the Brhat and Rathantara (Samans) [2].

column1: iyaṃ vāva rathaṃtaram asau bṛhat |
column2: The Rathantara is this (earth), the Brhat yonder (sky);

column1: ābhyām eva yanti |
column2: verily with them do they proceed;

column1: atho anayor eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily also in them they find support.

column1: ete vai yajñasyāñjasāyanī srutī tābhyām eva suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti parāñco vā ete suvargaṃ lokam abhyārohanti ye parācas tryahān upayanti pratyaṅ tryaho bhavati pratyavarūḍhyā{FN corrected in IS Ed: pratyavarūḍhyā} atho pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: These indeed are the quick paths of the sacrifice; verily by them do they proceed to the world of heaven. Those who perform the three days in succession mount upon the world of heaven turning away (from earth). There is a three day period reversed, for returning (from heaven), and also for support.

column1: ubhayor lokayor ṛddhvot tiṣṭhanti dvātriṃśad etās tāsāṃ yās triṃśat triṃśadakṣarā virāḍ annaṃ virāḍ virājaivānnādyam ava rundhate ye dve ahorātre eva te ubhābhyāṃ rūpābhyāṃ suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti |
column2: Having prospered in both worlds they cease (the rite). These (nights) are thirty-two. As for thirty of them, the Viraj has thirty syllables, the Viraj is food; verily by the Viraj they win food. As for the (remaining) two, they are days and nights, and by both forms they go to the world of heaven.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavataḥ parigṛhītyai |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, for security.

column1: dve vāva devasattre dvādaśāhaś ca trayastriṃśadahaś ca ya evaṃ vidvāṃsas trayastriṃśadaham āsate sākṣād eva devatā abhyārohanti yathā khalu vai śreyān abhyārūḍhaḥ kāmayate tathā karoti yady avavidhyati pāpīyān bhavati yadi nāvavidhyati sadṛṅ ya evaṃ vidvāṃsas trayastriṃśadaham āsate vi pāpmanā bhrātṛvyeṇā vartante 'harbhājo vā etā devā agra āharan |
column2: There are two Sattras of the gods, that of twelve days and that of thirty-three days. Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite of) thirty-three days, mount openly upon the deities. As a great man who has reached (the goal) seeks (more), so he does. If he fail he becomes worse;

column1: ahar eko 'bhajatāhar ekas tābhir vai te prabāhug ārdhnuvan ya evaṃ vidvāṃsas trayastriṃśadaham āsate sarva eva prabāhug ṛdhnuvanti sarve grāmaṇīyam prāpnuvanti pañcāhā bhavanti pañca vā ṛtavaḥ saṃvatsaras |
column2: One took one day, one another, and with them all equally prospered. Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of thirty-three days, all equally prosper, all gain the rank of village chief. There are five day periods; the year has five seasons;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva saṃvatsare prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they rest on the seasons, the year.

column1: atho pañcākṣarā paṅktiḥ pāṅkto yajñas |
column2: Again the Pankti has five syllables, the sacrifice is fivefold;

column1: yajñam evāva rundhate trīṇy āśvināni bhavanti traya ime lokās | eṣu |
column2: verily they win the sacrifice. There are three (days with the) Açvina (Çastra); three are these worlds;

column1: eva lokeṣu prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily in these [2] worlds they find support.

column1: atho trīṇi vai yajñasyendriyāṇi tāny evāva rundhate viśvajid bhavaty annādyasyāvaruddhyai sarvapṛṣṭho bhavati sarvasyābhijityai vāg vai dvādaśāhas |
column2: Again three are the powers of the sacrifice; verily they win them. There is a Viçvajit (day), for the winning of food. It has all the Prsthas, for the conquest of all. The twelve-day (rite) is speech.

column1: yat purastād dvādaśāham upeyur anāptāṃ vācam upeyur upadāsukaiṣāṃ vāk syāt |
column2: If they were to perform the twelve-day (rite) before (what has already gone), they would perform speech imperfectly, and their speech would be likely to fail.

column1: upariṣṭād dvādaśāham upa yanty āptām eva vācam upa yanti tasmād upariṣṭād vācā vadāmas |
column2: They perform the twelve-day (rite) afterwards; verily they perform speech perfectly, and therefore we utter speech from above.

column1: vai daśarātreṇa prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata yad daśarātro bhavati prajā eva tad yajamānāḥ sṛjante |
column2: Intermediately indeed [3] by means of a ten-nights' (rite) did Prajapati create offspring. In that there is a ten-nights' (rite), the sacrificers create offspring.

column1: etāṃ ha vā udaṅkaḥ śaulbāyanaḥ sattrasyarddhim uvāca yad daśarātras |
column2: Udanka Çaulbayana has declared the ten-night rite to be the prosperity of the Sattra.

column1: yad daśarātro bhavati sattrasyarddhyai |
column2: In that there is a ten-nights' rite, (it serves) for the prosperity of the Sattra.

column1: atho yad eva pūrveṣv ahaḥsu viloma kriyate tasyaivaiṣā śāntis |
column2: Verily also whatever is wrongly done in the former days, it serves to atone.

column1: dvyanīkā vā etā rātrayo yajamānā viśvajit sahātirātreṇa pūrvāḥ ṣoḍaśa sahātirātreṇottarāḥ ṣoḍaśa ya evaṃ vidvāṃsas trayastriṃśadaham āsata aiṣāṃ dvyanīkā prajā jāyate |
column2: These nights form two rows, the sacrificers are the Viçvajit, the first are sixteen with the Atiratra, the second are sixteen with the Atiratra. To those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of thirty-three days, are born children in two rows.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavataḥ parigṛhītyai |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, for security.

column1: ādityā akāmayanta suvargaṃ lokam iyāmeti te suvargaṃ lokaṃ na prājānan na suvargaṃ lokam āyan ta etaṃ ṣaṭtriṃśadrātram apaśyan tam āharan tenāyajanta tato vai te suvargaṃ lokam prājānant suvargaṃ lokam āyan ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ ṣaṭtriṃśadrātram āsate suvargam eva lokam pra jānanti suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti jyotir atirātraḥ |
column2: The Adityas desired, 'Let us go to the world of heaven.' They discerned not the world of heaven, they went not to the world of heaven. They saw this (rite) of thirty-six nights; they grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed did they discern the world of heaven, and went to the world of heaven. Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of thirty six nights, discern the world of heaven, and go to the world of heaven.

column1: bhavati jyotir eva purastād dadhate suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai ṣaḍahā bhavanti ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: verily they put light before them, to reveal the world of heaven. There are Sadahas; six are the seasons;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva prati tiṣṭhanti catvāro bhavanti catasro diśas |
column2: verily in the seasons they find support. There are four (Sadahas); four are the quarters;

column1: dikṣv eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily in the quarters they find support.

column1: asattraṃ vā etad yad achandomam |
column2: There can be no Sattra where there is no Chandoma;

column1: yac chandomā bhavanti tena sattram |
column2: in that there are Chandomas, there is the Sattra.

column1: devatā eva pṛṣṭhair ava rundhate paśūñ chandomais | ojo vai rīvyam pṛṣṭhāni paśavaś chandomās |
column2: The gods they win by the Prsthas, the cattle by the Chandomas. The Prsthas are force and strength, the Chandomas cattle;

column1: ojasy eva | vīrye prati tiṣṭhanti ṣaṭtriṃśadrātro bhavati ṣaṭtriṃśadakṣarā bṛhatī bārhatāḥ paśavas |
column2: verily in force [2] and strength they find support. (The rite has) thirty-six nights; the Brhati has thirty-six syllables, cattle are connected with the Brhati;

column1: bṛhatyaiva paśūn ava rundhate bṛhatī chandasāṃ svārājyam āśnuta |
column2: The Brhati obtained the sovereignty over the metres.

column1: aśnuvate svārājyaṃ ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ ṣaṭtriṃśadrātram āsate suvargam eva lokaṃ yanti |
column2: They obtain sovereignty who knowing thus perform (the rite) of thirty-six nights; verily they go to the world of heaven.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavataḥ suvargasya lokasya parigṛhītyai |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, for the securing of the world of heaven.

column1: vasiṣṭho hataputro 'kāmayata vindeya prajām abhi saudāsān bhaveyam iti sa etam ekasmānnapañcāśam apaśyat tam āharat tenāyajata tato vai so 'vindata prajām abhi saudāsān abhavat |
column2: Vasistha, his sons slain, desired, 'May I win offspring, and defeat the Sauddsas.' He saw this (rite) of forty-nine nights; he grasped it, and sacrificed with it. Then indeed did he win offspring and defeated the Sauddsas.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa ekasmānnapañcāśam āsate vindante prajām abhi bhrātṛvyān bhavanti trayas trivṛto 'gniṣṭomā bhavanti vajrasyaiva mukahṃ saṃ śyanti daśa pañcadaśā bhavanti pañcadaśo vajraḥ |
column2: Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of forty-nine nights, win offspring and defeat their enemies. There are three Agnistomas with the Trivrt; verily they sharpen the point of the bolt. There are ten Pañcadaças; the bolt is fifteenfold [1];

column1: vajram eva bhrātṛvyebhyaḥ pra haranti ṣoḍaśimad daśamam ahar bhavati vajra eva vīryaṃ dadhati dvādaśa saptadaśā bhavanti |
column2: verily they take away the bolt from their rivals. The tenth day has a Sodaçin; verily they place strength in the bolt. There axe twelve Saptadaças, to win food;

column1: annādyasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: verily also they are propagated by them.

column1: atho praiva tair jāyante pṛṣṭhyaḥ ṣaḍaho bhavati ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ ṣaṭ pṛṣṭhāni pṛṣṭhair evartūn anvārohanty ṛtubhiḥ saṃvatsaram |
column2: There is a Prsthya Sadaha. Six are the seasons, six the Prsthas; verily by the Prsthas they mount upon the seasons, by the seasons upon the year;

column1: te saṃvatsara eva prati tiṣṭhanti dvādaśaikaviṃśā bhavanti pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: verily in the year they find support. There are twelve Ekavinças, for support;

column1: atho rucam evātman |
column2: verily they place radiance in themselves [2].

column1: dadhate bahavaḥ ṣoḍaśino bhavanti vijityai ṣaḍ āśvināni bhavanti ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: There are many Sodaçins, for conquest. There are six (days) with the Açvina (Çastra), six are the seasons;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they rest on the seasons.

column1: ūnātiriktā vā etā rātrayas |
column2: These nights are deficient and redundant.
