column1: ūnās tad yad ekasyai na pañcāśad atiriktās tad yad bhūyasīr aṣṭācatvāriṃśatas |
column2: They are deficient in that they are fifty less one, redundant in that they are (one) more than forty-eight.

column1: ūnāc ca khalu vā atiriktāc ca prajāpatiḥ prājāyata |
column2: Both from the deficient, indeed, and from the redundant Prajapati was propagated.

column1: ye prajākāmāḥ paśukāmāḥ syus ta etā āsīran praiva jāyante prajayā paśubhis |
column2: Those who desire offspring and cattle should perform (the rite of) these nights; verily are they propagated with offspring and cattle.

column1: vairājo vā eṣa yajño yad ekasmānnapañcāśas |
column2: This sacrifice is connected with the Viraj because it is one of forty-nine (nights).

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsa ekasmānnapañcāśam āsate virājam eva gachanty annādā bhavanti |
column2: Those, who knowing thus perform (the rite) of forty-nine nights, attain the Viraj, and become eaters of food.

column1: atirātrāv abhito bhavatas |
column2: There are Atiratras on either side, for the securing of food.

column1: saṃvatsarāya dīkṣiṣyamāṇā ekāṣṭakāyāṃ dīkṣeran | eṣā vai saṃvatsarasya patnī yad ekāṣṭakā |
column2: Those who are about to consecrate themselves for the year (rite) should consecrate themselves on the Ekastaka. The Ekastaka is the wife of the year;

column1: etasyāṃ vā eṣa etāṃ rātriṃ vasati sākṣād eva saṃvatsaram ārabhya dīkṣante |
column2: on that night he dwells with her; verily they consecrate themselves grasping openly the year.

column1: ārtaṃ vā ete saṃvatsarasyābhi dīkṣante ya ekāṣṭakāyāṃ dīkṣante 'ntanāmānāv ṛtū bhavatas | vyastaṃ vā ete saṃvatsarasyābhi dīkṣante ya ekāṣṭakāyāṃ dīkṣante 'ntanāmānāv ṛtū bhavataḥ phalgunīpūrṇamāse dīkṣeran mukhaṃ vā etat |
column2: Those who consecrate themselves on the Ekastaka consecrate themselves in the troubled part of the year, for then are the two months called the end. Those who consecrate themselves on the Ekastaka consecrate themselves on the torn part of the year, for them are the two seasons called the end. They should consecrate themselves on the full moon in Phalguni.

column1: saṃvatsarasya yat phalgunīpūrṇamāsas |
column2: The full moon in Phalguni is the beginning of the year [1];

column1: mukhata eva saṃvatsaram ārabhya dīkṣante tasyaikaiva niryā yat sāmmeghye viṣūvānt sampadyate citrāpūrṇamāse dīkṣeran mukhaṃ vā etat saṃvatsarasya yac citrāpūrṇamāsas |
column2: verily they consecrate them selves grasping the year at its beginning. To that there is this one objection that the Visuvant day falls in the cloudy season. They should consecrate themselves on the full moon in Citra. The full moon in Citra, is the beginning of the year;

column1: mukhata eva saṃvatsaram ārabhya dīkṣante tasya na kā cana niryā bhavati caturahe purastāt paurṇamāsyai dīkṣeran teṣām ekāṣṭakāyāṃ krayaḥ sam padyate tenaikāṣṭakāṃ na chambaṭ kurvanti teṣām |
column2: verily they consecrate themselves grasping the year at the beginning. In that there is no objection at all. They should consecrate themselves on the fourth day before the full moon. Then the buying (of the Soma) falls for them on the Ekastaka; verily they do not waste the Ekastaka.

column1: pūrvapakṣe sutyā sam padyate pūrvapakṣam māsā abhi sam padyante te pūrvapakṣa ut tiṣṭhanti tān uttiṣṭhata oṣadhayo vanaspatayo 'nūt tiṣṭhanti tān kalyāṇī kīrtir anūt tiṣṭhati |
column2: In their case [2] the pressing-(day) falls on the first half (of the month), the months end in the first half, they complete (the rite) in the first half, and when they complete the rite the plants and trees come out after them.

column1: arātsur ime yajamānā iti tad anu sarve rādhnuvanti |
column2: And after them follows the fair report, 'These sacrificers have succeeded', and therefore all succeed.

column1: suvargaṃ vā ete lokaṃ yanti ye sattram upayanti |
column2: They go to the world of heaven who perform the Sattra.

column1: abhīndhata eva dīkṣābhir ātmānaṃ śrapayanta upasadbhis |
column2: They kindle themselves with the Diksas, and cook themselves with the Upasads.

column1: dvābhyāṃ lomāva dyanti dvābhyāṃ tvacam | dvābhyām asṛt | dvābhyām māṃsam |
column2: With two they cut off their hair, with two their skin, with two their blood, with two their flesh, with two their bones, with two their marrow.

column1: dvābhyām asthi dvābhyām majjānam ātmadakṣiṇaṃ vai sattram ātmānam eva dakṣiṇāṃ nītvā suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti śikhām anu pra vapante | ṛddhyai | atho raghīyāṃsaḥ suvargaṃ lokam ayāmeti |
column2: In the Sattra the self is the sacrificial gift; verily taking the self as the gift they go to the world of heaven. They cut off the top-knot, for prosperity, (thinking), 'More swiftly may we attain the world of heaven.' The theologians say, 'The Atiratra is the highest of the forms of sacrifice.

column1: atirātraḥ paramo yajñakratūnāṃ kasmāt tam prathamam upa yantīti | etad vā agniṣṭomam prathamam upa yanty athokthyam atha ṣoḍaśinam athātirātram anupūrvam evaitad yajñakratūn upetya tān ālabhya parigṛhya somam evaitat pibanta āsate jyotiṣṭomam prathamam upa yanti jyotiṣṭomo vai stomānām mukham mukhata eva stomān pra yuñjate te |
column2: Why do they perform it first?' Now in doing so they really perform in order first the Agnistoma, then the Ukthya, then the Sodaçin, then the Atiratra, all the forms of sacrifice, and seizing and holding them, they keep drinking the Soma. They perform the Jyotistoma first; the Jyotistoma is the beginning of the Stomas; verily they commence the Stomas from the beginning [1].

column1: saṃstutā virājam abhi sam padyante dve carcāv ati ricyete ekayā gaur atirikta ekayāyur ūnaḥ suvargo vai loko jyotir ūrg virāṭ suvargam eva tena lokaṃ yanti rathaṃtaraṃ divā bhavati rathaṃtaraṃ naktam ity āhur brahmavādinaḥ kena tad ajāmīti saubharaṃ tṛtīyasavane brahmasāmam bṛhat tan madhyato dadhati vidhṛtyai tenājāmi |
column2: The Stomas being sung together make up the Viraj, and two verses are redundant; the Gostoma has one too many, and the Ayustoma one too few. The Jyotistoma is the world of heaven, the Viraj is strength; verily by it they go to the world of heaven. 'The Rathantara is used in the day, the Rathantara at night', say the theologians, 'what is used to avoid repetition?' The great Saman of Sobhari is used as the Brahmasaman at the third pressing;

column1: jyotiṣṭomam prathamam upa yanti |
column2: They first perform the Jyotistoma;

column1: asminn eva tena loke prati tiṣṭhanti goṣṭomaṃ dvitīyam upa yanti |
column2: verily by it they find support in this world. They perform secondly the Gostoma;

column1: antarikṣa eva tena prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily by it they find support in the atmosphere.

column1: āyuṣṭomaṃ tṛtīyam upa yanti |
column2: They perform thirdly the Ayustoma;

column1: amuṣminn eva tena loke prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily by it they find support in yonder world.

column1: iyaṃ vāva jyotir antarikṣaṃ gaus | asāv āyus |
column2: The Jyotis is this (earth), the Go the atmosphere, and the Ayus yonder (sky).

column1: yad etānt stomān upayanty eṣv eva tal lokeṣu sattriṇaḥ pratitiṣṭhanto yanti te saṃstutā virājam |
column2: In that they perform these Stomas, the performers of the Sattra keep finding support in these worlds.

column1: abhi sam padyante dve carcāv ati ricyete ekayā gaur atirikta ekayāyur ūnaḥ suvargo vai loko jyotir ūrg virāḍ ūrjam evāva rundhate te na kṣudhārtim ārchanti |
column2: These, (Stomas) being sung together make up the Viraj [1], and two verses are redundant; the Gostoma has one too many, and the Ayustoma one too few. The Jyotistoma is the world of heaven, the Viraj is strength; verily they win strength.

column1: akṣodhukā bhavanti kṣutsambādhā iva hi sattriṇas |
column2: They experience not misery through hunger, and are not hungry, for the performers of Sattras are as it were afflicted with hunger.

column1: agniṣṭomāv abhitaḥ pradhī tau | ukthyā madhye nabhyaṃ tat tad etat pariyad devacakram |
column2: The two Agnistomas on either side are the rims, the Ukthyas in the middle the nave, and that is the circling wheel of the gods.

column1: ṣaḍahena yanti devacakram eva samārohanty ariṣṭyai te svasti sam aśnuvate sāḍahena yanti ṣaḍ vā ṛtavas |
column2: In that they go [2] by that Sadaha, they mount the wheel of the gods, for safety. They obtain prosperity. They go with the Sadaha; there are six seasons;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily in the seasons they find support.

column1: ubhayatojyotiṣā yanti |
column2: The go with a Jyotistoma on either hand;

column1: ubhayata eva suvarge loke pratitiṣṭhanto yanti dvau ṣaḍahau bhavatas tāni dvādaśāhāni sam padyante dvādaśo vai puruṣo dve sakthyau dvau bāhū ātmā ca śiraś ca catvāry aṅgāni stanau dvādaśau |
column2: verily on either hand they find support in the world of heaven. There are two Sadahas, they make up twelve days. Man is of twelve parts, two thighs, two arms, the trunk and the head, four members, and the breasts as the eleventh and twelfth [3].

column1: tat puruṣam anu paryāvartante trayaḥ ṣaḍahā bhavanti tāny aṣṭādaśāhāni sam padyante navānyāni navānyāni nava vai puruṣe prāṇās tat prāṇān anu paryāvartante catvāraḥ ṣaḍahā bhavanti tāni caturviṃśatir ahāni sam padyante caturviṃśatir ardhamāsāḥ saṃvatsaras tat saṃvatsaram anu paryāvartante |
column2: Therefore (the days) follow man. There are three Sadahas, they make up eighteen days, nine and nine. Nine are the breaths in man; verily they follow the breaths. There are four Sadahas, they make up twenty-four days.

column1: apratiṣṭhitaḥ saṃvatsara iti khalu vā āhur varṣīyān pratiṣṭhāyā iti |
column2: The year consists of twentyfour half-months; verily they follow the year. 'The year is not fixed', they say.

column1: etāvad vai saṃvatsarasya brāhmaṇaṃ yāvan māsas | māsimāsy eva pratitiṣṭhanto yanti |
column2: 'It is greater than a support.' The Brahmana of the month is that of the year also verily they go finding support in each month.

column1: meṣas tvā pacatair avatu lohitagrīvaś chāgaiḥ śalmalir vṛddhyā parṇo brahmaṇā plakṣo medhena nyagrodhaś camasair udumbara ūrjā gāyatrī chandobhis trivṛt stomais |
column2: The Horse Sacrifice (continued) Let the ram aid thee with cooked food, the dark-necked with goats, the cotton-tree with increase, the Parna-tree with the holy power (Brahman), the fig-tree with the sacrifice, the banyan with the beakers, the Udumbara with strength, the Gayatri with the metres, the Trivrt with the Stomas.

column1: avantī sthāvantīs tvāvantu priyaṃ tvā priyāṇāṃ varṣiṣṭham āpyānāṃ nidhīnāṃ tvā nidhipatiṃ havāmahe vaso mama |
column2: b Ye are helpers; let the helpers help thee. Deal among dear things, best among things to be sought, treasure lord of treasures, thee we hail, O my radiant one.

column1: kūpyābhyaḥ svāhā kūlyābhyaḥ svāhā vikaryābhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To those of the clefts hail! To those of holes hail! To those which are dug for hail!

column1: avaṭyābhyaḥ svāhā khanyābhyaḥ svāhā hradyābhyaḥ svāhā sūdyābhyaḥ svāhā sarasyābhyaḥ svāhā vaiśantībhyaḥ svāhā palvalyābhyaḥ svāhā varṣyābhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To those of rain hail! To those without rain hail! To those of hail hail! To those of rime hail! To those which glide hail!

column1: avarṣyābhyaḥ svāhā hrādunībhyaḥ svāhā pṛṣvābhyaḥ svāhā syandamānābhyaḥ svāhā sthāvarābhyaḥ svāhā nādeyībhyaḥ svāhā saindhavībhyaḥ svāhā samudriyābhyaḥ svāhā sarvābhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To those which are stagnant hail! To those of the streams hail! To those of the rivers hail! To those of the ocean hail! To all hail!

column1: adbhyaḥ svāhā vahantībhyaḥ svāhā parivahantībhyaḥ svāhā samantaṃ vahantībhyaḥ svāhā śīghraṃ vahantībhyaḥ svāhā śībhaṃ vahantībhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To waters hail! To those that flow hail! To those that flow around hail To those that flow all about hail! To those that flow swiftly hail! To those that flow quickly hail!

column1: ugraṃ vahantībhyaḥ svāhā bhīmaṃ vahantībhyaḥ svāhā |
column2: To those that flow wildly hail! To those that flow terribly hail!

column1: ambhobhyaḥ svāhā nabhobhyaḥ svāhā mahobhyaḥ svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To the waters of earth hail! To those of the atmosphere hail! To those of the sky hail! To all hail!

column1: yo arvantaṃ jighāṃsati tam abhy amīti varuṇaḥ |
column2: Him who is fain to injure the steed Varuna punisheth.

column1: paro martaḥ paraḥ śvā |
column2: Away the man, away the dog!

column1: ahaṃ ca tvaṃ ca vṛtrahant sam babhūva sanibhya ā |
column2: I and thou, Vrtra-slayer, Have been united to win spoils;

column1: arātīvā cid adrivo 'nu nau śūra maṃsatai bhadrā indrasya rātayaḥ | abhi kratvendra bhūr adha jman na te vivyaṅ mahimānaṃ rajāṃsi |
column2: Even the foe, O hero with the bolt, Must think of us; Good are Indra's gifts. Thou hast surpassed in might, O Indra, on the earth The regions comprehend not thy greatness;

column1: svenā hi vṛtraṃ śavasā jaghantha na śatrur antaṃ vividad yudhā te |
column2: For with thine own strength thou didst slay Vrtra; No foe hath found the end of thee in fight.

column1: namo rājñe namo varuṇāya namo 'śvāya namaḥ prajāpataye namo 'dhipataye |
column2: Homage to the king! Homage to Varuna! Homage to the horse! Homage to Prajapati! Homage to the overlord!

column1: adhipatir asy adhipatim mā kurv adhipatir aham prajānām bhūyāsam māṃ dhehi mayi dhehi |
column2: make me an overlord; may I be overlord of creatures. Place me, place in me. To him that is driven near hail!

column1: upākṛtāya svāhā | ālabdhāya svāhā hutāya svāhā |
column2: To him that is taken hold of hail! To him that is sacrificed hail!

column1: mayobhūr vāto abhi vātūsrā ūrjasvatīr oṣadhīr ā riśantām |
column2: Let the healing wind blow upon our cows, Let them feed on strengthening herbs;

column1: pīvasvatīr jīvadhanyāḥ pibantv avasāya padvate rudra mṛḍa |
column2: Let them drink waters full of life and fatness; Rudra, be gracious to the food that hath feet.

column1: yāḥ sarūpā virūpā ekarūpā yāsām agnir iṣṭyā nāmāni veda |
column2: Those which are of one, of various hues, or of like hue Those whose names Agni knoweth by sacrifice;

column1: yā aṅgirasas tapaseha cakrus tābhyaḥ parjanya mahi śarma yacha |
column2: Those which the Angirases made here by devotion, To those, O Parjanya, grant abundant protection.

column1: yā deveṣu tanuvam airayanta yāsāṃ somo viśvā rūpāṇi veda |
column2: Those who offered to the gods their bodies; Those whose every form Soma knoweth;

column1: tā asmabhyam payasā pinvamānāḥ prajāvatīr indra | goṣṭhe rirīhi |
column2: Indra [1], place them in our pastures, Swelling with milk and rich in offspring.

column1: prajāpatir mahyam etā rarāṇo viśvair devaiḥ pitṛbhiḥ saṃvidānaḥ | śivāḥ satīr upa no goṣṭham ākas tāsāṃ vayam prajayā saṃ sadema |
column2: Prajapati, bestowing these on me, In harmony with all the gods and Pitrs, Hath brought them, auspicious, to our pastures. May we possess their offspring.

column1: iha dhṛtiḥ svāhā | iha vidhṛtiḥ svāhā |
column2: Here is support, hail! Here is keeping apart, hail!

column1: iha rantiḥ svāhā |
column2: Here is joy, hail!

column1: iha ramatiḥ svāhā mahīm ū ṣu sutrāmāṇam |
column2: Here is delight, hail!' The great. The protecting.

column1: kiṃ svid āsīt pūrvacittiḥ kiṃ svid āsīd bṛhad vayaḥ | kiṃ svid āsīt piśaṃgilā kiṃ svid āsīt pilippilā |
column2: What was the first conception? What was the great age? What was the tawny one? What was the smooth one? The sky was the first conception. The horse was the great age.

column1: rātrir āsīt piśaṃgilāvir āsīt pilippilā |
column2: The night was the tawny one. The sheep was the smooth one.

column1: kaḥ svid ekākī carati ka u svij jāyate punaḥ | kiṃ svid dhimasya bheṣajaṃ kiṃ svid āvapanam mahat |
column2: Who moveth alone? Who too is born again? What is a remedy for the cold? What is the great enveloper? The sun moveth alone [1].

column1: candramā jāyate punaḥ |
column2: The moon is born again.

column1: agnir himasya bheṣajam bhūmir āvapanam mahat |
column2: Fire is the remedy for the cold. Earth is the great enveloper.

column1: pṛchāmi tvā param antam pṛthivyāḥ pṛchāmi tvā bhuvanasya nābhim |
column2: I ask thee of the furthest end of the earth. ask thee of the navel of the world.

column1: pṛchāmi tvā vṛṣṇo aśvasya retaḥ pṛchāmi vācaḥ paramaṃ vyoma |
column2: ask thee of the seed of the strong horse. ask thee of speech's highest realm.

column1: vedim āhuḥ param antam pṛthivyā yajñam āhur bhuvanasya nābhim |
column2: They call the altar-ground the furthest end of the earth. They call the sacrifice the navel of the world.

column1: somam āhur vṛṣṇo aśvasya reto brahmaiva vācaḥ paramaṃ vyoma |
column2: They call Soma the seed of the strong horse. (They call) the Brahman the highest realm of speech.

column1: ambe ambāly ambike na mā nayati kaś cana |
column2: O Amba! O Ambali! O Ambika! No one leadest me.

column1: sasasty aśvakaḥ |
column2: The wicked horse is sleeping.

column1: subhage kāmpīlavāsini suvarge loke sam prorṇvāthām |
column2: O fair one, clad in fair raiment in the world of heaven be ye two covered....

column1: priya strīṇām apīcyaḥ | ya āsāṃ kṛṣṇe lakṣmaṇi sardigṛdim parāvadhīt | ambe ambāly ambike na mā yabhati kaś cana | sasasty aśvakaḥ |
column2: {...several verses omitted from original translation...} 1 When the deer eateth grain, He deemeth not his flock fat. When the Çadra woman is the loved of the Aryan, She seeketh not wealth for prosperity....

column1: ūrdhvām enām uc chrayatād veṇubhāraṃ girāv iva |
column2: {...several verses omitted from original translation...} Dadhikravan have I sung, The swift strong horse.

column1: puṣṭam paśu manyate |
column2: May he make our mouths fragrant;

column1: sasasty aśvakaḥ |
column2: May he lengthen our days.

column1: sasasty aśvakaḥ |
column2: Ye waters are healing;

column1: mahe raṇāya cakṣase |
column2: Further us to strength, To see great joy.

column1: yo vaḥ śivatamo rasas tasya bhājayateha naḥ | uśatīr iva mātaraḥ |
column2: The most auspicious flavour that is yours Accord to us here Like eager mothers.

column1: tasmā araṃ gamāma vo yasya kṣayāya jinvatha | āpo janayathā ca naḥ |
column2: To him may we come with satisfaction, To whose dwelling ye quicken us, waters, and propagate us.

column1: bhūr bhuvaḥ suvar vasavas tvāñjantu gāyatreṇa chandasā rudrās tvāñjantu traiṣṭubhena chandasādityās tvāñjantu jāgatena chandasā yad vāto apo agamad indrasya tanuvam priyām | etaṃ stotar etena pathā punar aśvam ā vartayāsi naḥ |
column2: Let the Vasus anoint thee with the Gayatri metre. Let the Rudras anoint thee with the Tristubh metre. Let the Adityas anoint thee with the Jagati metre. As the wind hath gone to the waters, Indra's dear body, By that path, O praiser, Bring back to us the horse.

column1: lājīñ chācīn yaśo mamām |
column2: O thou that hast barley, that hast grain, (bring) renown for me;

column1: yavyāyai gavyāyā etad devā annam attaitad annam addhi prajāpate yuñjanti bradhnam aruṣaṃ carantam pari tasthuṣaḥ |
column2: For barley, for milk, this food eat, O ye gods; this food eat, O Prajapati. They yoke the tawny ruddy one, Which goeth round them that stand;

column1: rocante rocanā divi |
column2: The lights shine in the sky.

column1: yuñjanty asya kāmyā harī vipakṣasā rathe | śoṇā dhṛṣṇū nṛvāhasā |
column2: They yoke his dear steeds On either side of the chariot, Dark, strong, bearing heroes.

column1: ketuṃ kṛṇvann aketave peśo maryā apeśase | sam uṣadbhir ajāyathāḥ |
column2: Making a banner for that which hath none, Form for the formless, O ye men, Thou wert born with the dawns.

column1: prāṇāya svāhā vyānāya svāhā |
column2: To cross-breathing hail! To inspiration hail!

column1: apānāya svāhā snāvabhyaḥ svāhā saṃtānebhyaḥ svāhā parisaṃtānebhyaḥ svāhā parvabhyaḥ svāhā saṃdhānebhyaḥ svāhā śarīrebhyaḥ svāhā yajñāya svāhā dakṣiṇābhyaḥ svāhā suvargāya svāhā lokāya svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To the sacrifice hail! To the sacrificial gifts hail! To heaven hail! To the world hail! To all hail!

column1: sitāya svāhā | asitāya svāhā |
column2: To the bound hail! To the unbound hail!

column1: abhihitāya svāhā | anabhihitāya svāhā yuktāya svāhā |
column2: To the fastened hail! To the unfastened hail! To the yoked hail! To the unyoked hail!

column1: ayuktāya svāhā suyuktāya svāhā |
column2: To the well-yoked hail! To the unyoked hail!

column1: udyuktāya svāhā vimuktāya svāhā pramuktāya svāhā vañcate svāhā parivañcate svāhā saṃvañcate svāhā |
column2: To the one set free hail! To the one lot go hail! To that which moveth crookedly hail! To that which moveth around hail! To that which moveth together hail!

column1: anuvañcate svāhā | udvañcate svāhā |
column2: To that which moveth along hail! To that which goeth hail!

column1: yate svāhā dhāvate svāhā tiṣṭhate svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To that which riseth hail! To that which standeth hail! To all hail!

column1: gāvo vā etat sattram āsatāśṛṅgāḥ satīḥ śṛṅgāṇi no jāyantā iti kāmena tāsāṃ daśa māsā niṣaṇṇā āsann atha śṛṅgāny ajāyanta tā ud atiṣṭhan | arātsmeti | atha yāsāṃ nājāyanta tāḥ saṃvatsaram āptvod atiṣṭhan | arātsmeti yāsāṃ cājāyanta yāsāṃ ca na tā ubhayīr ud atiṣṭhan | arātsmeti gosattraṃ vai |
column2: The Gavam Ayana The cows performed that Sattra, being hornless, with the desire, 'May horns be born to us.' For ten months they performed it, and then horns were born, and they ceased (the rite), (saying), 'We have obtained (our desire).' Then those whose horns were not born ceased (the rite) after making up the year, (saying), 'We have obtained (our desire).' Both those which obtained horns and those which did not ceased, (saying),'We have obtained (our desire).' The year is the cows' Sattra [1], and those who knowing thus perform the year (sacrifice) are prosperous.

column1: ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ saṃvatsaram upayanty ṛdhnuvanty eva tasmāt tūparā vārṣikau māsau partvā carati sattrābhijitaṃ hy asyai tasmāt saṃvatsarasado yat kiṃ ca grihe kriyate tad āptam avaruddham abhijitaṃ kriyate samudraṃ vā ete pra plavante ye saṃvatsaram upayanti yo vai samudrasya pāraṃ na paśyati na vai sa tata ud eti saṃvatsaraḥ |
column2: Therefore a hornless cow has pleasure during the two months of the rainy season, for that is won for it by the Sattra. Therefore whatever is done in the house of one who performs for a year (a Sattra), that is done completely, successfully, and adequately. Those who perform the year (Sattra) are swimming on the ocean. He who does not see the further bank of the ocean cannot get out from it.

column1: vai samudras tasyaitat pāraṃ yad atirātrau ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ saṃvatsaram upayanty anārtā evodṛcam gachanti |
column2: The ocean is the year [2]. Its further banks are the two Atiratras. Those who knowing thus perform the year (Sattra) reach the end without injury.

column1: iyaṃ vai pūrvo 'tirātro 'sāv uttaras |
column2: The former Atiratra is this (earth), the latter is yonder (sky);

column1: manaḥ pūrvo vāg uttaraḥ prāṇaḥ pūrvo 'pāna uttaraḥ prarodhanam pūrva udayanam uttaras |
column2: the former is mind, the latter speech; the former expiration, the latter inspiration; the former the commencement, the latter the end.

column1: jyotiṣṭomo vaiśvānaro 'tirātro bhavati jyotir eva purastād dadhate suvargasya lokasyānukhyātyai caturviṃśaḥ prāyaṇīyo bhavati caturviṃśatir ardhamāsāḥ |
column2: The Atiratra is a Jyotistoma, of Vaiçvanara; verily they put light before them, to reveal the world of heaven. There is a fore offering, accompanied by the Caturvinça Stoma. The year has twenty-four half-months [3];

column1: saṃvatsaraḥ prayanta eva saṃvatsare prati tiṣṭhanti tasya trīṇi ca śatāni ṣaṣṭiś ca stotrīyas tāvatīḥ saṃvatsarasya rātrayas |
column2: verily as they go on they find support in the year. There are three hundred and sixty Stotriyas; so many are the nights of the year;

column1: ubhe eva saṃvatsarasya rūpe āpnuvanti te saṃsthityā ariṣṭyā uttarair ahobhiś caranti ṣaḍahā bhavanti ṣaḍ vā ṛtavaḥ saṃvatsaras |
column2: verily they attain both forms of the year. They perform (the rites of) the next days for rest, for safety. There are six-day periods. The year has six seasons;

column1: ṛtuṣv eva saṃvatsare prati tiṣṭhanti gauś cāyuś ca madhyata stomau bhavataḥ saṃvatsarasyaiva tan mithunam madhyataḥ | dadhati rpajananāya jyotir abhito bhavati vimocanam eva tat |
column2: verily they find support in the seasons, the year. The Go and the Ayus (Stomas) are the Stomas in the middle; verily they place a pair in the middle of the year [4] for procreation. On either side there is the Jyotistoma.

column1: chandāṃsy eva tad vimokaṃ yanti |
column2: It is the releasing; verily the metres are released;

column1: atho ubhayatojyotiṣaiva ṣaḍahena suvargaṃ lokaṃ yanti brahmavadino vadanti |
column2: verily also they go to the world of heaven with the six-day (rite) which has a Jyotistoma on either side.

column1: āsate kena yantīti devayānena patheti brūyāt |
column2: by what path do they go?' One should reply,' By the path that leads to the gods.

column1: chandāṃsi vai devayānaḥ panthā gāyatrī triṣṭub jagatī jyotir vai gāyatrī gaus triṣṭug āyur jagatī yad ete stomā bhavanti devayānenaiva |
column2: The path that leads to the gods is the metres, the Gayatri, Tristubh, and Jagati. The Gayatri is the Jyotistoma, the Tristubh, the Gostoma, the Jagati the Ayustoma. In that there are these Stomas, so do they go by the path that leads to the gods [5].

column1: tat pathā yanti samānaṃ sāma bhavati devaloko vai sāma devalokād eva na yanti |
column2: There is used the same Saman. The Saman is the world of the gods; verily they leave not the world of the gods.

column1: anyāanyā ṛco bhavanti manuṣyaloko vā ṛcas |
column2: There are used various verses. The verses are the world of man;

column1: manuṣyalokād evānyamanyaṃ devalokam abhyārohanto yanti |
column2: verily they keep mounting one world of gods after another from the world of men.

column1: abhivarto brahmasāmam bhavati suvargasya lokasyābhivṛttyai |
column2: There is the Brahman's Saman as the Abhivarta to win the world of heaven.

column1: abhijid bhavati suvargasya lokasyābhijityai viśvajid bhavati viśvasya jityai māsimāsi pṛṣṭhāny upa yanti māsimāsy atigrāhyā gṛhyante māsimāsy eva vīryaṃ dadhati māsām pratiṣṭhityai |
column2: There is the Abhijit (day) for the gaining of the world of heaven. There is the Viçvajit (day) for the gaining of all. Month by month they perform the Prsthas, month by month the Atigrahyas are drawn; verily in each month they place strength, for the support of the months.

column1: upariṣṭān māsām pṛṣṭhāny upa yanti tasmād upariṣṭād oṣadhayaḥ phalaṃ gṛhṇanti |
column2: They perform the Prsthas in the latter part of the month. Therefore it is on the top that the plants bear fruit.

column1: gāvo vā etat sattram āsatāśṛṅgāḥ satīḥ śṛṅgāṇi siṣāsantīs tāsāṃ daśa māsā niṣaṇṇā āsan |
column2: The cows performed that Sattra, being hornless and desiring to obtain horns. For ten months they performed it, and then horns appeared.

column1: arātsmot tiṣṭhāmāva taṃ kāmam arutsmahi yena kāmena nyaṣadāmeti tāsām u tvā abruvann ardhā {F vā}{W vā}{GLOS vā} yāvatīr vā | āsamahā evemau dvādaśau māsau saṃvatsaraṃ sampādyot tiṣṭhāmeti tāsām |
column2: They said, 'We have gained (them), let us cease (the rite), for we have attained the desire for the sake of which we began (the rite).' But others said, either half of them or as many as might be the case, 'Let us perform (the rite) for these months, the eleventh and the twelfth, and when we have made up the year, let us cease' [1].

column1: dvādaśe māsi śṛṅgāṇi prāvartanta śraddhayā vāśraddhayā vā tā imā yās tūparās | ubhayyo vāva tā ārdhnuvan yāś ca śṛṅgāṇy asanvan yāś corjam avārundhata |
column2: In their case their horns grew in the twelfth month. Whether by faith, or by lack of faith-that is, those which have no horns-both indeed were prosperous, those which gained horns and those which won strength.

column1: ṛdhnoti daśasu māsūttiṣṭhann ṛdhnoti dvādaśasu ya evaṃ veda padena khalu vā ete yanti vindati khalu vai padena yan tad vā etad ṛdhham ayanam |
column2: He who ceases after ten months is prosperous, and he who ceases after twelve also, if he knows thus. They go by their feet, and he who goes by his foot attains (what he seeks).

column1: tasmād etad gosani |
column2: The Ayana is successful, and therefore is it productive of cows.

column1: prathame māsi pṛṣṭhāny upa yanti madhyama upa yanty uttama upa yanti tad āhus |
column2: They perform the Prahas in the first month, they perform them in the middle month, they perform them in the last month.

column1: yāṃ vai trir ekasyāhna upasīdanti dahraṃ vai sāparābhyāṃ dohābhyāṃ duhe 'tha kutaḥ sā dhokṣyate yāṃ dvādaśa kṛtva upasīdantīti saṃvatsaraṃ sampādyottame māsi sakṛt pṛṣṭhāny upeyus tad yajamānā yajñam paśūn ava rundhate samudraṃ vai |
column2: They say, 'In the case of a cow which they milk thrice a day, she yields sparingly at the latter two milkings; how then can she be milked who is twelve times milked?' Having made up the year, they should perform the Prsthas once in the last month; verily the sacrificers win the sacrifice and cattle.

column1: ete 'navāram apāram pra plavante ye saṃvatsaram upayanti yad bṛhadrathaṃtare anvarjeyur yathā madhye samudrasya plavam anvarjeyus tādṛk tat |
column2: It is an ocean [1] without a near or a further shore that they enter upon who perform the year (rite). If they employ the Brhat and the Rathantara Samans, it would be as if they were to provide a boat in the middle of the ocean.

column1: anutsargam bṛhadrathaṃtarābhyām itvā pratiṣṭhāṃ gachanti sarvebhyo vai kāmebhyaḥ saṃdhir duhe tad yajamānāḥ sarvān kāmān ava rundhate |
column2: Going continuously with the Brhat and the Rathantara they obtain support. The union is milked for all desires; thus the sacrificers obtain all desires.

column1: samānya ṛco bhavanti manuṣyaloko vā ṛcas |
column2: The Rcs are the same. The Rcs are the world of men;

column1: manuṣyalokād eva na yanti |
column2: verily they leave not the world of man.

column1: anyadanyat sāma bhavati devaloko vai sāma devalokād evānyamanyam manuṣyalokam pratyavarohanto yanti jagatīm agre upa yanti jagatīṃ vai chandāṃsi pratyavarohanty āgrayaṇaṃ grahā bṛhat pṛṣṭhāni trayastriṃśaṃ stomās tasmāj jyāyāṃsaṃ kanīyān pratyavarohati vaiśvakarmaṇo gṛhyate viśvāny eva tena karmāṇi yajamānā ava rundhate |
column2: verily they descend from the world of the gods to one world after another of men. They first use the Jagati, and the metres descend from the Jagati, the cups from the Agrayana, the Prsthas from the Brhat, the Stomas from the Trayastrinça. Therefore the younger descends before an elder. The Viçvakarman cup is drawn; verily by it the sacrificers win all rites.

column1: ādityaḥ | gṛhyate |
column2: The cup for Aditi [1] is drawn.

column1: iyaṃ vā aditis |
column2: Aditi is this (earth);

column1: asyām eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they rest on this (earth).

column1: anyo'nyo gṛhyete mithunatvāya prajātyai |
column2: The one and the other are drawn, for pairing, for propagation.

column1: avānataraṃ vai daśarātreṇa prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata yad daśarātro bhavati prajā eva tad yajamānāḥ sṛjante |
column2: Of old Prajapati created offspring by means of the ten-night (rite); in that the ten-night rite is performed, the sacrificers create offspring.

column1: etāṃ ha vā udaṅkaḥ śaulbāyanaḥ sattrasyarddhim uvāca yad daśarātaś | yad daśarātro bhavati sattrasyarddhyai |
column2: Udanka Çaulbayana has declared the ten-night rite to be the prosperity of the Sattra, and the ten-night rite serves for the prosperity of the Sattra.

column1: atho yad eva pūrveṣv ahaḥsu viloma kriyate tasyaivaiṣā śāntiḥ |
column2: Verily also whatever is done wrongly in the earlier days, this serves to atone for it.

column1: yadi somau saṃsutau syātām mahati rātriyai prātaranuvākam upākuryāt pūrvo vācam pūrvo devatāḥ pūrvaś chandāṃsi vṛṅkte vṛṣaṇvatīm pratipadaṃ kuryāt prātaḥsavanād evaiṣām indraṃ vṛṅkte |
column2: If two libations are offered simultaneously, then one should perform the early litany in the advanced part of the night. He who does it first wins the speech, the gods, and the metres (of the others). The strophe should contain the word 'strong (vrsan)'; verily he takes Indra away from their morning pressing.

column1: atho khalv āhuḥ savanamukhesavanamukhe kāryeti savanamukhātsavanamukhād evaiṣām indraṃ vṛṅkte saṃveśāyopaveśāya gāyatriyās triṣṭubho jagatyā anuṣṭubhaḥ paṅktyā abhibhūtyai svāhā chandāṃsi vai saṃveśa upaveśas |
column2: Or rather they say, 'The strophe at the beginning of each pressing should be of this kind'; verily he takes Indra away from each of their pressings. For entry, for rest, for the overcoming, of the Gayatri, of the Tristubh, of the Jagati, of the Anustubh, of the Pankti, hail!

column1: chandobhir evaiṣāṃ |
column2: Entry and rest are the metres;

column1: chandāṃsi vṛṅkte sajanīyaṃ śasyam |
column2: One should recite the Sajaniya hymn;

column1: vihavyaṃ śasyam agastyasya kayāśubhīyaṃ śasyam etāvad vā asti yāvad etat |
column2: one should recite the Kayaçubhiya hymn of Agastya. This indeed is so much as that, verily he takes away so much as is theirs.

column1: yāvad evāsti tad eṣāṃ vṛṅkte yadi prātaḥsavane kalaśo dīryeta vaiṣṇavīṣu śipiviṣṭavatīṣu stuvīran yad vai yajñasyātiricyate viṣṇuṃ tac chipiviṣṭam abhy ati ricyate tad viṣṇuḥ śivipiṣṭo 'tirikta evātiriktaṃ dadhāti |
column2: If at the early pressing the bowl is broken, they should sing verses addressed to Visnu and containing the epithet Çipivista. Whatever in the sacrifice is redundant, is redundant with regard to Visnu Çipivista; verily Visnu Çipivista places the redundant in the redundant. Verily having obtained the redundant by the redundant, they win it.

column1: atho atiriktenaivātiriktam āptvāva rundhate yadi madhyaṃdine dīryeta vaṣaṭkāranidhanaṃ sāma kuryus |
column2: If it is broken at the midday pressing, they should make the Saman have the Vasatkara as its finale.

column1: vaṣaṭkāro vai yajñasya pratiṣṭhā pratiṣṭhām evainad gamayanti yadi tṛtīyasavana etad eva |
column2: The support of the sacrifice is the Vasatkara; verily they make the Saman obtain support. If it breaks at the third pressing, the same thing (should be done).

column1: ṣaḍahair māsānt sampādyāhar ut sṛjanti ṣaḍahair hi māsānt sampaśyanti |
column2: Having made up the month with the six-day periods they leave out a day, for they behold the months by the six-day periods.

column1: ardhamāsair māsānt sampādyāhar ut sṛjanati | ardhamāsair hi māsānt sampaśyanti |
column2: Having made up the months with the half-months, they leave out a day, for they behold the months by the half-months.

column1: amāvāyayā māsānt sampādyāhar ut sṛjanti | amāvāsyayā hi māsānt sampaśyanti paurṇamāsyā māsānt sampādyāhar ut sṛjanti paurṇamāsyā hi māsānt sampaśyanti yo vai pūrṇa āsiñcati parā sa siñcati yaḥ pūrṇād udacati |
column2: Having made up the months by the new moon night, they leave out a day, for they behold the months by the new moon night. Having made up the months by the full moon night, they leave out a day, for they behold the month by the full moon night. He who pours (liquid) into a full (vessel) wastes the liquid;

column1: prāṇam asmint sa dadhāti yat paurṇamāsyā māsānt sampādyāhar utsṛjanti saṃvatsarāyaiva tat prāṇaṃ dadhati tad anu sattriṇaḥ prāṇanti yad ahar notsṛjeyur yathā dṛtir upanaddho vipataty evaṃ saṃvatsaro vi patet |
column2: he who pours out from a full (vessel) [1] places breath in it. In that, having made up the months with the full moon night, they leave out a day, they place breath in the year, and the performers of the Sattra breathe along it. If they did not leave out a day, then the year would fall asunder, as falls asunder a skin bag tied tight, and they would be ruined.

column1: yat paurṇamāsyā māsānt sampādyāhar utsṛjanti saṃvatsarāyaiva tad udānaṃ dadhati tad anu sattriṇa ut |
column2: In that, having made up the months with the full moon night, they leave out a day, they place out-breathing in the year, and the performers of the Sattra breathe out along it [2], and are not ruined.

column1: ananti nārtim ārchanti pūrṇamāse vai devānāṃ sutas |
column2: At the full moon (the Soma) of the gods is pressed.

column1: yat paurṇamāsyā māsānt sampādyāhar utsṛjanti devānām eva tad yajñena yajñam pratyavarohanti vi vā etad yajñaṃ chindanti yat ṣaḍahasaṃtataṃ santam athāhar utsṛjanti prājāpatyam paśum ālabhante prajāpatiḥ sarvā devatās |
column2: In that, having made up the months with the full moon night, they leave out a day, with the sacrifice to the gods they go to another sacrifice. They cleave asunder the sacrifice, in that (after performing it) as a series of sixday rites they leave out a day. They offer an animal for Prajapati.

column1: devatābhir eva yajñaṃ saṃ tanvanti yanti vā ete savanād ye 'haḥ |
column2: Prajapati is all the gods; verily with the gods do they offer the sacrifice.

column1: utsṛjanti turīyaṃ khalu vā etat savanaṃ yat sāṃnāyyam |
column2: They leave the pressing [3], who leave out the day. The Samnayya is the fourth pressing.

column1: yat sāṃnāyyam bhavati tenaiva savanān na yanti samupahūya bhakṣayanti |
column2: Because there is the Samnayya, they do not leave the pressing.

column1: etatsomapīthā hy etarhi yathāyatanaṃ vā eteṣāṃ savanabhājo devatā gachanti ye 'har utsṛjanti |
column2: They partake of it after uttering the invocation, for they have this then as their Soma drink. The deities who share in the pressings of those who leave out the day go to their places;

column1: anusavanam puroḍāśān nir vapanti yathāyatanād eva savanabhājo devatā ava rundhate |
column2: verily they win the deities who share in the pressing from their several places.

column1: 'ṣṭākapālān prātaḥsavana ekādaśakapālān mādhyaṃdine savane dvādaśakapālāṃs tṛtīyasavane chandāṃsy evāptvāva rundhate vaiśvadevaṃ caruṃ tṛtīyasavane nir vapanti vaiśvadevaṃ vai tṛtīyasavanam |
column2: (They offer the cakes) on eight potsherds at the early pressing, on eleven potsherds at the midday pressing, and on twelve potsherds at the third pressing; verily they obtain and win the metres. They offer an oblation to the All-gods at the third pressing. The third pressing belongs to the All-gods;

column1: tenaiva tṛtīyasavanān na yanti |
column2: verily they leave not the third pressing.

column1: utsṛjyāṃ notsṛjyām iti mīmāṃsante brahmavādinas tad v āhus | utsṛjyam eveti | amāvāsyāyāṃ ca paurṇamāsyāṃ cotsṛjyam ity āhus | ete hi yajñaṃ vahata iti te tvāva notsṛjye ity āhur ye avāntaraṃ yajñam bhejāte iti yā prathamā vyaṣṭakā tasyām utsṛjyam ity āhus | eṣa vai māso viśara iti nādiṣṭam |
column2: The theologians consider, 'Should (a day) be left out, or should it not be left out?' They say, 'It should be left out.' They say, 'It should be left out at the new moon and at the full moon, for these two guide the sacrifice.' 'These two must not be left out,' they say, 'for these two determine the dependent sacrifice.' '(The day) should be left out on the first Vyastaka,' they say, 'for this is what rends the month.' They should not leave out a day which is appointed [1].

column1: yad ādiṣṭam utsṛjeyur yādṛśe punaḥ paryāplāve madhye ṣaḍahasya sampadyeta ṣaḍahair māsānt sampādya yat saptamam ahas tasminn ut sṛjyeyus tad agnaye vasumate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nir vapeyur aindraṃ dadhīndrāya marutvate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ vaiśvadevaṃ dvādaśakapālam agner vai vasumataḥ prātaḥsavanam |
column2: If they should leave out one which is appointed, they should leave it out on the seventh day after making up the months with six-day periods, whatever be the recur rent position which it occupies in the course of the six-day period. They should then offer to Agni, with the Vasus, a cake on eight potsherds, to Indra curds, to Indra with the Maruts a cake on eleven potsherds, to the All-gods a cake on twelve potsherds.

column1: yad agnaye vasumate puroḍāśam aṣṭākapālaṃ nirvapati devatām eva tad bhāginīṃ kurvanti | savanam aṣṭābhir upa yanti yad aindraṃ dadhi bhavatīndram eva tad bhāgadheyān na cyāvayanti |
column2: in that they offer to Agni with the Vasus a cake on eight potsherds, they make the god share in it [2], and they approach the pressing with eight. In that the curds belong to Indra, they do not shut out Indra from a share.

column1: indrasya vai marutvato mādhyaṃdinaṃ savanam |
column2: The midday pressing belongs to Indra with the Maruts.

column1: yad indrāya marutvate puroḍāśam ekādaśakapālaṃ nirvapanti devatām eva tad bhāginīṃ kurvanti savanam ekādaśabhir upa yanti viśveṣāṃ vai devānām ṛbhumatāṃ tṛtīyasavanam |
column2: In that they offer to Indra with the Maruts a cake on eleven potsherds, they make the god share in it, and they approach the pressing with eleven [3]. The third pressing belongs to the All-gods with the Rbhus.

column1: yad vaiśvadevaṃ dvādaśakapālaṃ nirvapanti devatā eva tad bhāginīḥ kurvanti savanaṃ dvādaśabhiḥ |
column2: In that they offer to the All-gods a cake on twelve pot sherds, they make the gods share in it, and they approach the pressing with twelve.

column1: upa yanti prājāpatyam paśum ā labhante yajño vai prajāpatir yajñasyānanusargāya |
column2: They offer a beast to Prajapati-Prajapati is the sacrifice that the sacrifice may not be abandoned.

column1: abhivarta itaḥ ṣaṇ māso brahmasāmam bhavati brahma vā abhivartas |
column2: For six months (as they go) hence the Brahman's Saman should be the 'victorious'.

column1: brahmaṇaiva tat suvargaṃ lokam abhivartayanto yanti pratikūlam iva hītaḥ suvargo lokas |
column2: verily they go winning the world of heaven by the holy power (Brahman); for the world of heaven is as it were opposite from hence.

column1: indra kratuṃ na ā bhara pitā putrebhyo yathā | śikṣā no asmin puruhūta yāmani jīvā jyotir aśīmahīty amuta āyatāṃ ṣaṇ māso brahmasāmam bhavati |
column2: When they come thence the Brahman's Saman for six months should be 'O Indra, bear us strength, as a father to his sons. Guide us, O thou that art much invoked, on our path.

column1: ayaṃ vai loko jyotiḥ prajā jyotis |
column2: Living, may we attain the light.' The light is this world, the light is offspring;

column1: imam eva tal lokam paśyanto 'bhivadanta ā yanti |
column2: verily they come, gazing on this world by repeating the verse.

column1: devānāṃ vā antaṃ jagmuṣām indriyaṃ vīryam apākrāmat tat krośenāvā rundhata tat krośasya krośatvam |
column2: When the gods had come to the end, their power and strength departed. They won them again by the Kroça (Saman), and that is why the Kroça has the name.

column1: yat krośena cātvālasyānte stuvanti yajñasyaivāntaṃ gatvendriyaṃ vīryam ava rundhate sattrasyarddhyāhavanīyasyānte stuvanti |
column2: In that they sing the Kroça at the end of the pit, they win power and strength at the end of the sacrifice. They sing the Sattra syarddhi (Saman) at the end of the Ahavaniya;

column1: agnim evopadraṣṭāraṃ kṛtvarddhim upa yanti prajāpaterhṛdayena havirdhāne 'nta stuvanti premāṇam evāsya gachanti ślokena purastāt sadasaḥ |
column2: verily, making Agni a witness, they advance to prosperity. They sing the Prajapater Hrdaya within the shed;

column1: stuvanty anuślokena paścāt |
column2: verily they win his favour.

column1: yajñasyaivāntaṃ gatvā ślokabhājo bhavanti navabhir adhvaryur ud gāyati nava vai puruṣe prāṇāḥ prāṇān eva yajamāneṣu dadhāti sarvā aindriyo bhavanti prāṇeṣv evendriyaṃ dadhati |
column2: They sing the Çloka (Saman) in front of the Sadas [1], the Anuçloka (Saman) behind; verily fame is their portion at the end of the sacrifice. The Adhvaryu sings nine (verses). Nine are the breaths in man; verily he places breaths in the sacrificers.

column1: apratihṛtābhir ud gāyati tasmāt puruṣaḥ sarvāṇy anyāni śīrṣṇo 'ṅgāni praty acati śira eva na pañcadaśaṃ rathaṃtaram bhavatīndriyam evāva rundhate saptadaśam |
column2: verily he places power (indriya) in the breaths. He sings without the Pratihara. Therefore a man can contract all the other members (of the body) except the head, but the bead not. The Rathantara (Saman) has the Pañcadaça (Stoma);

column1: bṛhad annādyasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: verily they win power.

column1: atho praiva tena jāyante |
column2: verily also they are propagated by it.

column1: ekaviṃśam bhadraṃ dvipadāsu pratiṣṭhityai patnaya upa gāyanti mithunatvāya prajātyai prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata so 'kāmayata |
column2: The Bhadra (Saman) has the Ekavinça (Stoma) with Dvipada verses, for support. The wives (of the sacrificers) sing, for offspring, for propagation. Prajapati created offspring;

column1: āsām ahaṃ rājyam parīyām iti tāsāṃ rājanenaiva rājyam pary ait tad rājanasya rājanatvam |
column2: he desired, 'May I gain the kingship over them.' He obtained the kingship over them by the Rajana (Saman), and that is why the Rajana has the name.

column1: yad rājanam bhavati prajānām eva tad yajamānā rājyam pari yanti pañcaviṃśam bhavati prajāpateḥ |
column2: In that there is the Rajana, the sacrificers obtain the kingship over offspring. It has the Pañcavinça (Stoma), to win Prajapati [3]. They sing five (verses) standing;

column1: āptyai pañcabhis tiṣṭhanta stuvanti devalokam evābhi jayanti pañcabhir āsīnā manuṣyalokam evābhi jayanti daśa sam padyante daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājaivānnādyam ava rundhate pañcadhā viniṣadya stuvanti pañca diśas |
column2: verily they win the world of the gods; five sitting; verily they win the world of men. These come to ten; the Viraj is of ten syllables, the Viraj is food;

column1: dikṣav eva prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they rest on the quarters.

column1: ekaikayāstutayā samāyanti digbhya evānnādyaṃ sam bharanti tābhir udgātod gāyati digbhya evānnādyam |
column2: They come up each before one verse has been sung; verily they bear food from the quarters. The Udgatr sings these (verses);

column1: sambhṛtya teja ātman dadhate tasmād ekaḥ prāṇaḥ sarvāṇy aṅgāny avati |
column2: verily having borne food from the quarters [4] they place glory in themselves. Therefore one breath protects all the limbs.

column1: atho yathā suparṇa utpatiṣyañ chira uttamaṃ kuruta evam eva tad yajamānāḥ prajānām uttamā bhavanti |
column2: Therefore, just as a bird about to fly upwards raises its head aloft, so the sacrificers are highest among people. The Udgatr mounts a throne;

column1: āsandīm udgātā rohati sāmrājyam eva gachanti pleṅkhaṃ hotā nākasyaiva pṛṣṭhaṃ rohanti kūrcāv adhvaryur bradhnasyaiva viṣṭapaṃ gachanti |
column2: verily they attain rule. The Hotr (mounts) a swing; verily they mount the back of the firmament. The Adhvaryu (mounts) two mats; verily they reach the surface of the ruddy one.

column1: etāvanto vai devalokās teṣv eva yathāpūrvam prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: So many indeed are the worlds, and in them in order they find support.

column1: atho ākramaṇam eva tat setuṃ yajamānāḥ kurvate suvargasya lokasya samaṣṭyai |
column2: Then the sacrificers make thus a bridge to mount, for the gaining of the world of heaven.

column1: arkyeṇa vai sahasraśaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajā asṛjata tābhya ilāṃdenerāṃ lūtām avārunddha yad arkyam bhavati prajā eva tad yajamānāḥ sṛjante |
column2: By means of the Arkya (Saman) Prajapati created offspring in thousands. From them by means of the Ilamda (Saman) he took away the food they had gathered. In that there is the Arkya, the sacrificers create offspring;

column1: ilāṃdam bhavati prajābhya eva sṛṣṭābhya irāṃ lūtām ava rundhate tasmād yāṃ samāṃ sattraṃ samṛddhaṃ kṣodhukās tāṃ samām prajā iṣaṃ hy āsām ūrjam ādadate yāṃ samāṃ vyṛddham akṣodhukās tāṃ samām prajāḥ |
column2: in that there is the Ilamda, they take away from the offspring which has been created the food they have gathered. Therefore, in whatever year the Sattra is performed, the offspring are hungry in that year, for they take their food and strength; in whatever year the Sattra is imperfect, the offspring are not hungry in that year [1];

column1: na hy āsām iṣam ūrjam ādadate |
column2: for they take not their food and strength.

column1: utkrodaṃ kurvate yathā bandhān mumucānā utkrodaṃ kurvata evam eva tad yajamānā devabandhān mumucānā utkrodaṃ kurvata iṣam ūrjaṃ ātman dadhānās |
column2: They raise a loud noise. As men being freed from bonds cry aloud, so the sacrificers freed from the bonds of the gods cry aloud, placing food and strength in themselves.

column1: vāṇaḥ śatatantur bhavati śatāyuḥ puruṣaḥ śatendriyas |
column2: The lute has a hundred strings. Man is of a hundred (years) of age, and of a hundredfold strength;

column1: āyuṣy evendriye prati tiṣṭhanti |
column2: verily they find support in age and strength.

column1: ājiṃ dhāvanty anabhijitasyābhijityai dundubhīnt samāghnanti paramā vā eṣā vāg yā dundubhau paramām eva |
column2: They run a race, to win what has not yet been won. They beat drums; the voice of the drum is the highest (form of) speech; verily they win the highest (form of) speech.

column1: vācam ava rundhate bhūmidundubhim ā ghnanti yaivemāṃ vāk praviṣṭā tām evāva rundhate |
column2: They beat the earth-drum; verily they win that speech which has entered this (earth); verily also they conquer the earth.

column1: atho imām eva jayanti sarvā vāco vadanti sarvāsāṃ vācām avaruddhyai |
column2: All (forms of) speech they utter, to gain all (forms of speech).

column1: ārdre carman vyāyachete indriyasyāvaruddhyai |
column2: Two strive on a dry hide, to gain strength.

column1: ānyaḥ krośati prānyaḥ śaṃsati ya ākrośati punāty evainānt {sa < sas} yaḥ praśaṃsati pūteṣv evānnādyaṃ dadhāti |
column2: One reviles, another extols. He who reviles purifies them, he who extols places food in them after they are purified.

column1: vā ete devakṛtaṃ ca pūrvair māsair ava rundhate yad bhūtechadāṃ sāmāni bhavanty ubhayasyāvaruddhyai yanti vā ete mithunād ye saṃvatsaram upayanti |
column2: They win by the first months what is done by the Rsis and by the gods; in that the Bhutechad Samans are used, both are gained. Those who perform the year rite lose their virility.

column1: antarvedi mithunau sam bhavatas tenaiva mithunān na yanti |
column2: There are a pair united within the sacrificial ground; verily they lose not virility.

column1: carmāva bhindanti pāpmānam evaiṣām ava bhindanti māpa rātsīr māti vyātsīr ity āha sampraty evaiṣām pāpmānam ava bhindanti | udakumbhān adhinidhāya dāsyo mārjālīyam pari nṛtyanti pado nighnatīr idammadhuṃ gāyantyas |
column2: verily they now remove their sin. Slave girls dance round the Marjaliya fire with water-pots on their heads, beating the ground with their feet, and singing 'This is honey.' Honey indeed is the chiefest food of the gods; verily they win the chiefest food. They beat the ground with their feet;

column1: madhu vai devānām paramam annādyam paramam evānnādyam ava rundhate pado ni ghnanti mahīyām evaiṣu dadhati |
column2: verily they endow the (sacrificers) with might. The Horse Sacrifice (continued) To earth hail! To the atmosphere hail! To the sky hail!

column1: pṛthivyai svāhāntarikṣāya svāhā dive svāhā samploṣyate svāhā samplavamānāya svāhā samplutāya svāhā medhāyiṣyate svāhā meghāyate svāhā meghitāya svāhā meghāya svāhā nīhārāya svāhā nihākāyai svāhā prāsacāya svāhā pracalākāyai svāhā vidyotiṣyate svāhā vidyotamānāya svāhā saṃvidyotamānāya svāhā stanayiṣyate svāhā stanayate svāhograṃ stanayate svāhā varṣiṣyate svāhā varṣate svāhābhivarṣate svāhā parivarṣate svāhā saṃvarṣate |
column2: To freezing hail! To springing hail! To that which will lighten hail! To that which lighteneth hail! To that which lighteneth together hail!

column1: svāhānuvarṣate svāhā śīkāyiṣyate svāhā śīkāyate svāhā śīkitāya svāhā proṣiṣyate svāhā pruṣṇate svāhā paripruṣṇate svāhā |
column2: To that which will rain hail! To that which raineth hail! To that which raineth around hail! To that which raineth about hail! To that which raineth together hail!

column1: udgrahīṣyate svāhodgṛhṇate svāhodgṛhītāya svāhā viploṣyate svāhā viplavamānāya svāhā viplutāya svāhā |
column2: To that which is sprinkled hail! To that which will warm hail! To that which warmeth hail! To that which warmeth around hail! To that which will cease hail!

column1: ātapsyate svāhātapate svāhogram ātapate svāhā |
column2: To that which streameth away hail! To that which hath streamed away hail!

column1: ṛgbhyaḥ svāhā yajurbhyaḥ svāhā sāmabhyaḥ svāhāṅgirobhyaḥ svāhā vedebhyaḥ svāhā gāthābhyaḥ svāhā nārāśaṃsībhyaḥ svāhā raibhībhyaḥ svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To the Rc verses hail! To the Yajus verses hail! To the Samans hail! To the Angirases hail! To the Vedas hail!

column1: datvate svāhādantakāya svāhā prāṇine svāhāprāṇāya svāhā mukhavate svāhāmukhāya svāhā nāsikavate svāhānāsikāya svāhā |
column2: To the breathing hail! To that which hath not breath hail! To that which hath a face hail! To the faceless hail! To that which hath a nose hail!

column1: akṣaṇvate svāhānakṣikāya svāhā karṇine svāhākarṇakāya svāhā śīrṣaṇvate svāhāśīrṣakāya svāhā padvate svāhāpādakāya svāhā prāṇate svāhāprāṇate svāhā vadate svāhāvadate svāhā paśyate svāhāpaśyate svāhā śṛṇvate svāhāśṛṇvate svāhā manasvine svāhā |
column2: To that which hath ears hail! To the earless hail! To that which hath a head hail! To the headless hail! To that which hath feet hail!

column1: amanase svāhā retasvine svāhāretaskāya svāhā prajābhyaḥ svāhā prajananāya svāhā lomavate svāhālomakāya svāhā tvace svāhātvakkāya svāhā carmaṇvate svāhācarmakāya svāhā lohitavate svāhālohitāya svāhā māṃsanvate svāhāmāṃsakāya svāhā snāvabhyaḥ svāhāsnāvakāya svāhā |
column2: To that which breatheth not hail! To that which speaketh hail! To the speechless hail! To that which seeth hail! To that which seeth not hail!

column1: asthanvate svāhānasthikāya svāhā majjanvate svāhāmajjakāya svāhā |
column2: To offspring hail! To begetting hail! To that which hath hair hail! To the hairless hail!

column1: aṅgine svāhānaṅgāya svāhā |
column2: To that which hath a hide hail!

column1: ātmane svāhānātmane svāhā sarvasmai svāhā |
column2: To the bloodless hail! To that which hath flesh hail! To the fleshless hail!

column1: kas tvā yunakti sa tvā yunaktu viṣṇus tvā yunaktu |
column2: To the trunk hail! To the trunkless hail! Who yoketh thee? Let him yoke thee.

column1: asya yajñasyarddhyai mahyaṃ saṃnatyai | amuṣmai kāmāya |
column2: Let Visnu yoke thee, for the prosperity of this sacrifice, for my pre-eminence, for N.N.'s pleasure;

column1: āyuṣe tvā prāṇāya tvāpānāya tvā vyānāya tvā vyuṣṭyai tvā rayyai tvā rādhase tvā ghoṣāya tvā poṣāya tvārādghoṣāya tvā pracyutyai tvā |
column2: for life thee, for expiration thee, for inspiration thee, for cross-breathing thee, for dawning thee, for wealth thee, for prosperity thee, for sound thee, for nourishing thee, for calling from afar thee, for falling thee (I yoke).

column1: agnaye gāyatrāya trivṛte rāthaṃtarāya vāsantāyāṣṭākapālas |
column2: To Agni, of the Gayatri (metre), the Trivrt (Stoma), the Rathantara (Saman), the spring (season), (offering is made) on eight potsherds.

column1: indrāya traiṣṭubhāya pañcadaśāya bārhatāya graiṣmāyaikādaśakapālas |
column2: To Indra, of the Tristubh (metre), the Pañcadaça, (Stoma), the Brhat (Saman), the summer (season), (offering is made) on eleven potsherds.

column1: viśvebhyo devebhyo jāgatebhyaḥ saptadaśebhyo vairūpebhyo vārṣikebhyo dvādaśakapālas |
column2: To the All-gods of the Jagati (metre), the Saptadaça (Stoma), the Vairupa (Saman), the rainy (season), (offering is made) on twelve potsherds.

column1: mitrāvaruṇābhyām ānuṣṭubhābhyām ekaviṃśābhyāṃ vairājābhyāṃ śāradābhyām payasyā bṛhaspataye pāṅktāya triṇavāya śākvarāya haimantikāya caruḥ savitra ātichandasāya trayastriṃśāya raivatāya śaiśirāya dvādaśakapālas |
column2: To Mitra and Varuna, of the Anustubh (metre), the Ekavinça (Stoma), the Vairaja (Saman), the autumn (season), curds. To Brhaspati, of the Pankti (metre), the Trinava (Stoma), the Çakvara (Saman), the winter (season), an oblation (is made). To Savitr, of the Atichandas (metre), the Trayastrinça (Stoma), the Raivata (Saman), the cool (season), (offering is made) on twelve potsherds.

column1: adityai viṣṇupatnyai carus |
column2: To Aditi, as Visnu's consort, an oblation (is made).

column1: agnaye vaiśvānarāya dvādaśakapālas |
column2: To Agni Vaiçvanara (offering is made) on twelve potsherds.

column1: anumatyai caruḥ kāya ekakapālaḥ |
column2: To Ka (offering is made) on one potsherd.

column1: yo vā agnāv agniḥ prahriyate yaś ca somo rājā tayor eṣa ātithyaṃ yad agnīṣomīyas |
column2: Now for the fire which is produced on the fire-altar and for Soma, the king, the beast for Agni and Soma is the guest-offering.

column1: athaiṣa rudro yaś cīyate yat saṃcite 'gnāv etāni havīṃṣi na nirvapet | eṣa eva rudro 'śānta upotthāya prajām paśūn yajamānasyābhi manyeta yat saṃcite 'gnāv etāni havīṃṣi nirvapati bhāgadheyenaivainaṃ śamayati nāsya rudro 'śāntaḥ |
column2: Again the fire which is piled up is cruel, and if one were not to cast upon the fire which has been piled up these oblations, the cruel fire would spring up in wrath, and injure the offspring and cattle of the sacrificer. In that he casts the oblations on the fire which has been piled up, he appeases it with its own portion, and the cruel fire [1] does not spring up in wrath and injure his offspring and cattle.

column1: upotthāya prajām paśūn abhi manyate daśa havīṃṣi bhavanti nava vai puruṣe prāṇā nābhir daśamī prāṇān eva yajamāne dadhāti |
column2: There are ten oblations. Nine are the breaths in man, and the navel is the tenth; verily he places breaths in the sacrificer.

column1: atho daśākṣarā {virāḍ < virāj} annaṃ {virāḍ < virāj} virājy evānnādye prati tiṣṭhati |
column2: Again the Viraj is of ten syllables; the Viraj is food; verily he finds support in the Viraj as food.

column1: ṛtubhir vā eṣa chandobhi stomaiḥ pṛṣṭhaiś cetavya ity āhus |
column2: 'It must be piled with the seasons, the metres, the Stomas, and the Prsthas', they say.

column1: yad etāni havīṃṣi nirvapaty ṛtubhir evainaṃ chandobhi stomaiḥ pṛṣṭhaiś cinute diśaḥ suṣuvāṇena |
column2: In that he casts these oblations, he piles it with the seasons, the metres, the Stomas, and the Prsthas.

column1: abhijityā ity āhus |
column2: 'The quarters can be won by one who has pressed the Soma' they say [2].

column1: yad etāni havīṃṣi nirvapati diśām abhijityai |
column2: In that he casts these oblations, (it is) for the winning of the quarters.

column1: etayā vā indraṃ devā ayājayan tasmād indrasavas |
column2: The gods made Indra sacrifice with it, and therefore is it Indra's pressing;

column1: etayā manum manuṣyās tasmān manusavas |
column2: men made Manu sacrifice with it, and therefore is it Manu's pressing.

column1: yathendro devānāṃ yathā manur manuṣyāṇām evam bhavati ya evaṃ vidvān etayeṣṭyā yajate digvatīḥ puro'nuvākyā bhavanti sarvāsāṃ diśām abhijityai |
column2: As Indra among the gods, as Manu among men, becomes he who knowing thus sacrifices with this sacrifice. The Puronuvakyas contain the word 'quarter', for the conquest of the quarters.

column1: yaḥ prāṇato nimiṣato mahitvaika id rājā jagato babhūva | ya īśe asya dvipadaś catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema |
column2: Who is the sole lord of the world, Which breatheth and winketh, through his greatness, Who is the lord of biped and of quadruped here, Who is the god whom we are to worship with oblation? Thou art taken with a foundation.

column1: upayāmagṛhīto 'si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭaṃ gṛhṇāmi tasya te dyaur mahimā nakṣatrāṇi rūpam ādityas te tejas tasmai tvā mahimne prajāpataye svāhā |
column2: I take thee dear to Prajapati. Of thee the sky is the greatness, the Naksatras the form, the sun the splendour; to his greatness, to Prajapati, thee (I offer). Hail!

column1: ya ātmadā baladā yasya viśva upāsate praśiṣaṃ yasya devāḥ |
column2: He who is the giver of soul, the giver of strength, On whose instruction all, on whose (instruction) the gods depend.

column1: yasya chāyāmṛtaṃ yasya mṛtyuḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema |
column2: Whose shadow is immortality, whose shadow is death; Who is the god whom we are to worship with oblation? Thou art taken with a foundation.

column1: upayāmagṛhīto 'si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭaṃ gṛhṇāmi tasya te pṛthivī mahimauṣadhayo vanaspatayo rūpam agnis te tejas tasmai tvā mahimne prajāpataye svāhā |
column2: I take thee dear to Prajapati. Of thee the earth is the greatness, the plants and trees the form, the fire the splendour; to his greatness, to Prajapati, thee (I offer). Hail!

column1: ā brahman brāhmaṇo brahmavarcasī jāyatām āsmin rāṣṭre rājanya iṣavyaḥ śūro mahāratho jāyatām |
column2: In the priesthood may a Brahmana be born of spiritual glory. In this kingdom may a prince be born, an archer, a hero, and a great car fighter;

column1: dogdhrī dhenus |
column2: a milk cow; a draught ox;

column1: voḍhānaḍvān āśuḥ saptiḥ puraṃdhir yoṣā jiṣṇū ratheṣṭhāḥ sabheyo yuvā |
column2: a swift racer; a prolific woman; victorious warrior; a youth fit for the assembly.

column1: āsya yajamānasya vīro jāyatām |
column2: To this sacrificer be a hero born.

column1: nikāmenikāme naḥ parjanyo varṣatu phalinyo na oṣadhayaḥ pacyantām |
column2: May Parjanya rain for us whensoever we desire. May our plants ripen with fruit.

column1: yogakṣemo naḥ kalpatām |
column2: May union and peace be ours.

column1: ākrān vājī pṛthivīm agniṃ yujam akṛta vājy arvākrān vājy antarikṣaṃ vāyuṃ yujam akṛta vājy arvā dyāṃ vājy ākraṃsta sūryaṃ yujam akṛta vājy arvā |
column2: The steed hath come to the earth; the strong steed hath made Agni his yoke-fellow. The steed hath come to the atmosphere; the strong steed hath made Vayu his yoke-follow. The steed hath come to the sky;

column1: agnis te vājin yuṅṅ anu tvā rabhe svasti mā sam pāraya vāyus te vājin yuṅṅ anu tvā rabhe svasti mā sam |
column2: Agni is thy yoke-fellow, O steed; I grasp thee; bear me prosperously. Vayu is thy yoke-fellow, O steed; I grasp thee;

column1: jajñi bījam |
column2: bear me prosperously [1].

column1: varṣṭā parjanyaḥ paktā sasyam | supippalā oṣadhayaḥ svadhicaraṇeyam |
column2: The Aditya is thy yoke-fellow, O steed; I grasp thee; bear me prosperously. Thou art the supporter of expiration;

column1: sūpasadano 'gniḥ svadhyakṣam antarikṣam |
column2: Thou art the eye; place the eye in me. Thou art the ear;

column1: supāvaḥ pavamānaḥ sūpasthānā dyauḥ śivam asau tapan yathāpūrvam ahorātre pañcadaśino 'rdhamāsās triṃśino māsāḥ kṛptā ṛtavaḥ śāntaḥ saṃvatsaraḥ |
column2: May the seed be living, Parjanya rain, the corn be ripened, the plants rich in leaves, this (earth) easy to walk on, the fire easy of approach, the atmosphere easy to see through, the wind purifying, the sky easy of access, he that burns yonder kindly, the day and night as of old, the half months of fifteen days, the months of thirty days, the seasons in due order, and the year auspicious.

column1: āgneyo 'ṣṭākapālaḥ saumyaś caruḥ sāvitro 'ṣṭākapālaḥ pauṣṇaś carus |
column2: To) Agni (offering is made) on eight potsherds; to Soma an oblation; to Savitr (offering) on eight potsherds; to Pusan an oblation;

column1: raudraś carus |
column2: to Rudra an oblation;

column1: agnaye vaiśvānarāya dvādaśakapālo mṛgākhare yadi nāgachet |
column2: to Agni Vaiçvanara (offering) on eight potsherds; if he should not go to the wild beast's lair;

column1: agnaye 'ṃhomuce 'ṣṭākapālaḥ sauryam payas |
column2: to Agni, saviour from distress, (offering is made) on eight potsherds;

column1: vāyavya ājyabhāgaḥ |
column2: Vayu receives a share in the butter offering.

column1: agnaye 'ṃhomuce 'ṣṭākapālas |
column2: To Agni, saviour from distress, (offering is made) on eight potsherds;

column1: indrāyāṃhomuca ekādaśakapālas |
column2: to Indra, saviour from distress, on eleven potsherds;

column1: mitrāvaruṇābhyām āgomugbhyām payasyā vāyosāvitra āgomugbhyāṃ carus |
column2: to Mitra and Varuna, saviours from sin, a milk offering; to Vayu and Savitr saviours from sin, an oblation;

column1: aśvibhyām āgomugbhyāṃ dhānās |
column2: to the Açvins, saviours from sin, grain;

column1: marudbhya enomugbhyaḥ saptakapālas |
column2: to the Maruts, saviours from evil, on seven potsherds;

column1: viśvebhyo devebhya enomugbhyo dvādaśakapālas |
column2: to the All-gods, saviours from evil, on twelve potsherds;

column1: anumatyai carus |
column2: to Anumati an oblation;

column1: agnaye vaiśvānarāya dvādaśakapālas |
column2: to Agni, Vaiçvanara on twelve potsherds;

column1: dyāvāpṛthivībhyām aṃhomugbhyāṃ dvikapālaḥ |
column2: to heaven and earth, saviours from evil, on two potsherds.

column1: agnaye sam anamat pṛthivyai sam anamat |
column2: To Agni he made obeisance; to the earth he made obeisance;

column1: yathāgniḥ pṛthivyā samanamad evam mahyam bhadrāḥ saṃnatayaḥ saṃ namantu vāyave sam anamad antarikṣāya sam anamat |
column2: as Agni with the earth made harmony, so for me may favourable harmonies be made. To Vayu he made obeisance, to the atmosphere he made obeisance; as Vayu with the atmosphere (made harmony, so &c.).

column1: yathā vāyur antarikṣeṇa sūryāya sam anamad dive sam anamat | yathā sūryo divā candramase sam anaman nakṣatrebhyaḥ sam anamat |
column2: To Surya he made obeisance, to the sky he made obeisance; as Surya with the sky (made harmony, so &c.). To the moon he made obeisance, to the Naksatras he made obeisance;

column1: yathā candramā nakṣatrais |
column2: as the moon with the Naksatras (made harmony, so &c.).

column1: varuṇāya sam anamad adbhyaḥ sam anamat |
column2: To Varuna he made obeisance, to the waters he made obeisance [1];

column1: varuṇo 'dbhiḥ sāmne sam anamad ṛce sam anamat |
column2: as Varuna with the waters (made harmony, so &c.). To the Saman he made obeisance, to the Rc he made obeisance;

column1: yathā sāmarcā brahmaṇe sam anamat kṣatrāya sam anamat | yathā brahma kṣatreṇa rājñe sam anamad viśe sam anamat |
column2: as the Saman with the Rc (made harmony, so &c.). To the Brahman (caste) he made obeisance, to the Ksatriya (caste) he made obeisance; as the Brahman with the Ksatriya (made harmony, so &c.).

column1: yathā rājā viśā rathāya sam anamad aśvebhyaḥ sam anamat | yathā ratho 'śvaiḥ prajāpataye sam anamad bhūtebhyaḥ sam anamat |
column2: as the king with the people (made harmony, so &c.). To the chariot he made obeisance, to the horses he made obeisance; as the chariot with the horses (made harmony, so &c.).

column1: yathā prajāpatir bhūtaiḥ samanamad evam mahyam bhadrāḥ saṃnatayaḥ saṃ namantu |
column2: as Prajapati with creatures made harmony, so for me may favourable harmonies be made.

column1: ye te panthānaḥ savitaḥ pūrvyāso 'reṇavo vitatā antarikṣe | tebhir no adya pathibhiḥ sugebhī rakṣā ca no adhi ca deva brūhi |
column2: Thine ancient paths, O Savitr, That are extended dustless through the atmosphere, With these to-day, with thy paths easy to travel, Guard us, and, O God, speak for us.

column1: namo 'gnaye pṛthivikṣite lokaspṛte lokam asmai yajamānāya dehi namo vāyave 'ntarikṣakṣite lokaspṛte lokam asmai yajamānāya dehi namaḥ sūryāya divikṣite lokaspṛte lokam asmai yajamānāya dehi |
column2: grant room to this thy sacrificer. Reverence to Vayu, dweller in the atmosphere, maker of room; grant room to this thy sacrificer. Reverence to Surya, dweller in the sky, maker of room; grant room to this thy sacrificer.

column1: yo vā aśvasya medhyasya śiro veda śīrṣaṇvān medhyo bhavati |
column2: He who knows the head of the sacrificial horse becomes possessed of a head and fit for sacrifice.

column1: uṣā vā aśvasya medhyasya śiraḥ sūryaś cakṣus | vātaḥ prāṇas | candramāḥ śrotram | diśaḥ pādau | avāntaradiśāḥ parśavas |
column2: The head of the sacrificial horse is the dawn, the eye the sun, the breath the wind, the ear the moon, the feet the quarters, the ribs the intermediate quarters, the winking the day and night, the joints the half-months, the joinings the months, the limbs the seasons, the trunk the year, the hair the rays (of the gun), the form the Naksatras, the bones the stars, the flesh the mist, the hair the plants, the tail hairs the trees, the mouth Agni, the open (mouth) Vaiçvanara [1], the belly the sea, the anus the atmosphere, the testicles the sky and the earth, the membrum virile, the pressing-stone, the seed the Soma.

column1: ahorātre nimeṣas |
column2: When it chews, there is lightning;

column1: tārakā asthāni nabho māṃsāni |
column2: when it moves about, there is thundering;

column1: oṣadhayo lomāni vanaspatayo vālās |
column2: when it makes water, there is rain;

column1: vaiśvānaro vyāttam |
column2: its speech is speech.

column1: dyāvāpṛthivī āṇḍau grāvā śepaḥ somo retas |
column2: The Mahiman (cup) indeed is born before the birth of the horse as the day.

column1: yaj jañjabhyate tad vi dyotate yad vidhūnute tat stanayati yan mehati tad varṣati vāg evāsya {vāg < vāc} ahar vā aśvasya jāyamānasya mahimā purastāj jāyate rātrir enam mahimā paścād anu jāyate |
column2: The Mahiman (cup) is born after it as the night.

column1: etau vai mahimānāv aśvam abhitaḥ sam babhūvatus |
column2: These two Mahiman (cups) surround on either side the horse.

column1: hayo devān avahad arvāsurān vājī gandharvān aśvo manuṣyān |
column2: As Haya (steed) it carried the gods, as Arvan (courser) the Asuras, as Vajin (racer) the Gandharvas, as Açva (horse) men.

column1: samudro vā aśvasya yoniḥ samudro bandhuḥ |
column2: The birthplace of the horse, indeed, is the sea, its kindred is the sea.
